Postal 3... Well, it gets a lot of bad press, and honestly, there's a reason for that. But there's one feature that really got me. It's the ability to complete the game without killing anyone!

Imagine: you're the Dude from Postal, known for his cruelty and love of violence, and you... plant flowers. Seriously, you can do that! And not just flowers. You can help old ladies cross the street, do good deeds, and generally be a good guy.

It's a complete game changer! In Postal, where everyone's all about shooting and blowing things up, you can be a pacifist. It's a bit poorly implemented, of course, and sometimes the game itself encourages violence. But the idea itself is simply brilliant!

So if you want to see a different side of Postal, if you're interested in how the Dude would act if he were a good guy, then Postal 3 might surprise you. But remember: this is still Postal 3, so the bugs, quirky humor, and other delights are still there. But damn, the opportunity to become the kindest Dude in the Postal world is worth it! The ultimate: A unique opportunity to complete the game in "pacifist" mode: planting flowers, not bothering anyone, and helping old ladies cross the streets!
Posted 4 is better. I approve.

column8: its shitty for a reason
column9: its shitty for a reason

Overall, it's pretty good, although the plot is incredibly choppy because the budget cuts cut all the game's content, making it feel more like a beta. But if you look at it that way, if not for all the problems during development, this game could have been a very good one; it had real potential. Many people mistakenly think that Postal 3 was developed by no-names and that the game was doomed from the start, but Akella is the largest game publisher in Russia, and their pockets were bursting with cash, so RWS handed over the entire game's development to them. They, a small indie studio, handed over the development to a large company. Naturally, this offer was lucrative, because the original developers only created the plot and then waited for the money from sales.

So, Vince Dezi wasn't so high on catnip that he'd screw up his line by handing it over to the natives. Akella looked even more prestigious compared to Running with Scissors, and its budget was three times larger, as the creators of the universe were running out of money from the second game. And initially, development was going well; Akella sent professionals to its subsidiary, Trashmasters, to work on it. Even just looking at the few shots from the beta version, it's clear that development was in full swing. In fact, most of the game's good aspects were created early on, and then everything went down the drain.

The global economic crisis hit. Akella could have bought the rights to hundreds more games yesterday, but the money suddenly disappeared. A bunch of projects had to be shut down, and development of the third installment stalled. Gradually, out of desperation, they had to fire the most experienced developers and hire newcomers, who, of course, lacked the same experience. RWS had no communication with Akella at all, there was no feedback whatsoever. The Americans only knew that the game's development was progressing, meaning everything was fine. And they had no idea about the hell that was going on with the Russians. Most of the workers left voluntarily because they had nowhere to get paid. Many of the people who developed the game last never received their pay.

So, the game was released, it was vilified, and rws, wanting to save the game, asked Akella to at least provide the game code. Well, there was no response, which is why it got a 3rd place permanently and remained with a failure status.

But if you decide to buy this game now, you'll be able to play it from start to finish without any problems, and probably even without a bunch of crashes and bugs. There are some issues with achievements, and maybe there are bugs sometimes, but I've never encountered any. At times, the game, along with everything else, would simply freeze and become unresponsive, requiring me to shut it down through the second desktop and Task Manager and restart it. The game crashed when I tried to use the grappling hook with the rocket launcher, and the catnip didn't work at all most of the time, slowing everything down. Everything else worked fine, and it was quite enjoyable.

The jokes in the game are pretty hilarious, and they tried to add variety to the missions, but most of the time you're just clearing out the area. You often don't understand who's doing what and all that crap from the characters because they're so vaguely described. I still don't understand [spoiler] why Dave and the Mayor were planning to detonate the bomb. [/spoiler] The melee weapons are just hilarious; you have to aim a centimeter to the left of your crosshair to hit.

And the promises for Postal 3 were greatly exaggerated. RWS would never have been able to deliver what they led fans to expect from Postal 3, and Postal 4 confirms that. Postal 4 was released in 2022, and the developers promised to deliver what it contains in the 2000s.

Of all the postals, this one has the best graphics. It's the only postal game where choices affect the plot. It has the best character model, and many of the cutscenes look really cool (especially: what the fuck is this on my watch?). It's also fun to play. The main draw of this game is its clunkiness, which is often laughable. Oh! And the soundtrack, it's simply the best. And the weapons, too. The chainsaw badger is a masterpiece, the fart gun is the best weapon for a pacifist, and my favorite was the M-60 machine gun.

It's a shame the game isn't polished. But I liked everything I played.

Basically, RWS is artificially boosting its reputation with the help of Postal 3. Like, we don't make shit like this (Postal 2 used to crash more often than Postal 3 during a normal playthrough). Apparently, RWS has completely forgotten how they used to hype Postal 3 everywhere.

column8: I'm madly in love with this
column9: I'm madly in love with this

I don't understand what's so bad about this game that it has so many bad reviews. It's quite fun to play, looks nice, has decent jokes, and genuinely great music. I personally played through it without getting bored. Everyone criticizes the controls, but I found them to be relatively fine. I had no issues with aiming or controls. The shaking while running is also criticized, but I actually enjoyed it. The game looks stylish, especially for its time. The only downside I can think of is that it crashed a couple of times, but those were all resolved by simply saving, which I did just in time. It didn't evoke any negative emotions at all, which I expected in abundance after reading the reviews.

[h1]The game isn't bad, but here's what I recommend doing right away to get achievements:[/h1]

You need to go to the game's root folder. If you don't know how to do this, go to your Steam Library ‚ûî right-click the POSTAL III icon ‚ûî select Properties ‚ûî click Installed Files ‚ûî then click Browse.

Next, go to the P3 folder ‚ûî CFG ‚ûî and open the "autoexec.cfg" file in Notepad or another text editor.

You'll find a line there called "host_thread_mode," in which you need to replace the number 2 with 0. After that, the achievements will work as they did before the patch.

If this guide isn't mine, I apologize in advance.

This game is simply a masterpiece among Russian games.
I recommend it to everyone.
This is certainly not the legendary second part, but it is also a favorite

column8:
This game was an absolute waste of my time, 25 hours down the drain for 35 shitty broken achievements. Postal 3 tries soooo hard to copy the humor that Postal 2 just naturally brought to the table and that was its downfall, the terrible racist jokes to the terrible sex jokes sprinkled in were awful to sit through for 25 hours. The achievement system is broken, the game is so riddled with bugs and crashes. You'll come across a crash like 6-7 times per level. The cut scenes and the music for this game are also just not good. The cutscenes are just boring slop with a old grainy filter over it and then they'll smack on some random big ass text at the end saying random things like "GOOD JOB!'. There's a few songs that were pretty decent but nothing left me blown away.  And the cherry on top has to be the awfully implemented karma system, where in order to fight the final boss and the other main bosses you MUST play through the boring ass good path. The game itself even mocks you at the end of the insane path for not doing the good path as the conclusion for the insane path is very lackluster, no boss fight, just get from point A to point B that's it. The end. Postal Dude's character assassination in this game was horrendous to see, but thankfully it was all just a bad dream.

Only good thing to come out of Postal 3 was the introduction of the Alternate Dude; aka Corey Cruise, who does AMAZING in Postal 4, Brain Damaged and Paradise Lost.

column8: Ratchet and based
column9: Ratchet and based

In this review, I'll try to answer the main and pressing questions: is Postal 3 worth buying? Is it really that bad? I'll say right away that the game is average, neither good nor bad. I only recommended it because it's hard to choose between yes and no. Let's move on to the game itself.
Pros: graphics, updated interface, awesome soundtrack, cool models. The ability to choose your side, and the choice of storylines. I enjoyed giving headshots. You don't have to constantly run around the map; you're teleported to the right place every time. Overall, good visuals. Cons: crappy hitboxes, no real sense of heaviness when dealing blows (i.e. just a blow and nothing more, for example with the same sledgehammer in post-game 2 things were much better. Some weapons are completely pointless to use due to their buggy hitboxes and damage. One of these is the machete, in the second part it was one of my favorites, in this one, on the contrary, you can still throw it like a boomerang, but how it is done... ugh. Not only can it simply not deal significant damage, but it moves incredibly slowly, most of the enemy will have time to run to the other end of the map. The same applies to returning it to your hand, before flying back, it will ricochet half the map purely for fun. And also the return to hand is canceled for everyone. Another disadvantage I consider the lack of many sound effects, which is a real shame. Hitboxes (especially on melee weapons) The combat is just incredibly stupid, you can miss an NPC 3 times in a row with the same sledgehammer. Some weapons are poorly made: the sledgehammer, for example, there's almost no blood when hitting, and on the alt attack, the guy just spins around with the sledgehammer and knocks down anyone in his path, without any sounds. A huge waste of potential. I wouldn't say the missions are bad, it just seems like the second game handled the story more energetically, so almost no mission managed to please or surprise. The kick was also disappointing. The hitboxes are bad, you hit the Le right on target, and it stuns you in place after the kick itself, which is incredibly annoying. There's no point in using it except to kick down doors. It's harder to hit an enemy when he's on the floor or getting up, especially considering that the kick also adds a stun. The cutscenes are stable. Crap. Inappropriate pop-up text that starts to irritate you over time, and fortunately, they pile on more. It has an old-movie feel, which I find completely out of place. Besides that, the cutscenes themselves are laggy, and the graphics seem worse than the game itself. Sometimes, due to the NPCs' stupidity, you can't complete a mission right away (the homeless attack on the police station, the prison escape, the slave escort from the building).
Bottom line: The game isn't great, but it's not bad either. I recommend picking it up on sale (I bought it for 70 rubles) if you're interested in playing, despite the dubious reviews.

column9:
Is Postal 3 really a bad game? It's a somewhat controversial topic, but I'm going to give my opinion.

This game was a disaster in its creation, a disaster in its interface, the fact that the postal worker's voice isn't the same, practically the entire gameplay, etc. But, personally, as a huge Postal fan, I say that the game really ISN'T THAT BAD (Try to digest those words). I've beaten it and done practically everything, and the few times I've encountered bugs, they haven't bothered me since the game barely has any. The story is still just as silly and darkly humorous as the previous Postal games, and it even made me laugh.

The good or bad reputation mechanic isn't that bad if you think about it; it's a very interesting thing where you're offered two completely different stories if you prefer to be sadistic and kill or you prefer to be good and knock people out. "But, Postal is a sadistic game." Let me remind you that in Postal 2, I emphasized that you're the one who does the bad things and that you can play through the entire Postal game without killing anyone or doing bad things.

Aside from that, the linear nature of the game isn't that bad due to the large number of missions, although this could be a downside to the game depending on who you ask. However, one point I want to talk about seriously is its sound; it's VERY loud, and you should turn it down if you don't want unnecessary noise pollution.

Ultimately, it's not and won't be the best Postal game in the series (possibly the worst), but it's STILL a Postal game in my opinion. You'll get used to the interface, the Postal Dude's voice, and everything else over time. Give it a chance; it's not as bad as they say.

column8: shit
column9: shit

I'm a guy who just loves playing games. Sure, there are crashes and bugs in many places, but in my opinion, the game is neither crap nor a masterpiece. It's fine for fun.

Hello everyone!

This game is complete crap. Everything about it is terrible: the controls are clunky, the missions are repetitive, the third-person view (what's the point of making a game that can even be considered a third-person shooter?), there are no funny jokes in the time I played, some achievements don't count, and for some reason it's up to me, not the developers, to fix them. I barely made it through the first hour and a half of the game, and then just turned it off. I think I've never seen a game so bad, although I didn't really want to look for one. I regret spending money on this game, even though I got it at a good discount (I got it for +500 tenge, which is equivalent to 75 rubles today). The only thing I was positively impressed with was the voice acting by Courage Bombay. Sure, it's not as good as the voice acting in the second post, but it's still not bad. And the characters' voices are quieter than the ambient sound, but I guess that's down to the original source engine, as HL2 has the same problem. Now I can understand those people, and RWS themselves, why they're trashing Postal 3. Overall, I wouldn't recommend buying this game for playthrough purposes, unless it's for a collection or for a platinum run (unless you're completely out of nerve).

[h1] Looking for a Job [/h1]

Postal 3 is a common tactic here, often mired in negative reviews, but in reality, it's a simple slog that will take up three hours of your life. And if you want to explore different paths (good or evil), just double that.

Overall, yes, there are some bugs where the script doesn't work or crashes, but overall, if you save often, the game is easy to play from A to Z.

There's not much to say about the plot: A guy is looking for a job.

There's really nothing to add or subtract here; it's a trash game with different tasks: go there, do something, solve a problem with a weapon or a stun gun. Want to be a good guy? - OK. Suddenly want to be an evil guy? - Yes, please. The ending is essentially the same.

Some moments are a bit silly, which is a bit funny in the cutscenes. The swearing is also appropriate. I logged into the game, relaxed without delving into it, and am already deleting it.

Most often, the same comments when shooting or arresting NPCs will irritate me. Dude repeats six phrases over and over again, which is annoying.

It's a bit sad that some achievements are also bugged and impossible to obtain, but overall, it's really worth playing through the game once and forgetting about it.
Honestly, I expected more, but with Akela it was a fuck up.
The game is crap, full of bugs, doesn't count achievements. But it's definitely better than Post 4.

column8: words cannot describe how awful this game is
column9: words cannot describe how awful this game is

[h3]So, after seeing this fake on Steam, I decided to reminisce about the past, because I played this in the early 2010s and it was my mistake.[/h3]
[hr][/hr] 
[b]This game is a broken piece of crap that no fix will fix, because it's simply impossible to play coherently due to things like:
- Bad AI,
- The constant onslaught of hordes of enemies firing at you from kilometers away,
- Bad lighting, the shadows of which can completely obscure an enemy and you only detect them by their bullet traces,
- Horrible missions with partners that are constantly being pushed onto you, where you have an almost 100% chance of dying from your own bullet,
- Stupid half-jokes with satire and references to trends that even in the 2000s were already considered dusty old crap, like Mavrodi and Mmm or An 80s porn actor,
- Stupid civilian bots that run under fire from their allies, so even if you want to save karma, you'll definitely lose it,
- Clumsy character controls, where control is atrocious in every aspect,
- Voice acting by Courage, which is extremely poorly integrated here. As much as I appreciated this voice acting back in the day, like in "The Big Bang Theory," here it's more annoying than it adds any style,
- Lack of checkpoints where they're needed, forcing you to manually save with these clunky controls, for which I think we can be grateful, not to Trashmasters, but to Valve for their source engine with the save system,
- And many minor flaws that kill the desire to play, like sound bugs, the possibility of crashing out of nowhere, etc., which are extremely rare, but oh so accurate for exploding asses.
[hr][/hr] 
The game has some interesting aspects, such as:
- A karma system that depends on your playstyle,
- A stylish menu with a guy watching TV,
- The story concept itself, with a psychologist and the need to find money for gas,
- And maybe something else? Feel free to add. It's just not coming to mind at the moment I'm writing. [/b]
[hr][/hr] 
[b]In conclusion, I'd like to add that this review is the result of two attempts to complete the game. Initially, out of the box, then with a bunch of fixes and patches from the manuals, the game really became more enjoyable to play, like the addition of GTA controls, the ability to jump, etc. But the pleasure comes from the overall experience, not the comfort of the game. Even with all the fixes, the game is terrible in terms of responsiveness and usability, especially in the shooter segment, which is critically important because you're bombarded with hordes of enemies, and when you also have to keep your allies alive, you end up suffering from poor shooting, the possibility of dying from an ally's bullet, the inappropriate behavior of teammates who might simply jump in front of a bullet or run away from you who knows where, and hordes of enemies who can sometimes see you from kilometers away. How I beat it in the 2010s, I have no idea, and maybe I didn't, because I don't remember a thing about it except for crashes and bugs. Maybe the game broke completely, and I dropped it then, just like I did now.[/b]

The game certainly looks great, but there are a couple of downsides that make it hard to play:
1. Third-person view
2. Bugs [i](however, thanks to patches, they're practically unnoticeable)[/i]
3. Linear narrative - for example, in Postal 2, you could go on any mission you wanted and then complete the remaining ones. In Postal 3, however, you only get to complete the missions the developers gave you.

At first I didn't really believe other people's reviews, thinking "pff, but there are fans of this game. And besides, they probably managed to fix it... in 14 years!". But no way... I won't talk about the third-person view, or the linearity and other ideas, the game is just different. But the fact that it's not interesting is a different matter. The missions are just the most boring crap, I've never seen such boring tasks in my life (even running around and clearing outposts in cyberpunk is much more interesting); the game itself is flawed, on the second or third mission they literally unleash a horde of enemies on you, when all you have is a really shitty melee that hardly deals 1 damage, and the only weapon is a taser, which takes fucking 5 minutes to kill... Shooting is also not interesting, the guns are wooden, the models don't care about hitting, the blood and ragdolls are terrible even by the standards of the first source! The game is a stretch, but you should only get it on sale for 30 rubles, just to get the +1 to your badge...

column9: Not as bad as people say but it isn't really good either, just in the middle. 5/10

Let's start with the pros: technically, it's currently quite good; it didn't crash once in 3.5 hours, it's fairly optimized, and its graphics require 10 times less PC resources than Postal 4. The soundtrack and character models are also excellent.
CONS: The humor is unfunny, and the localization voice was inexplicably replaced from Postal 2 (which was truly legendary) with the inept MTV voiceover, which kills any charisma the protagonist might have had. The AI ‚Äã‚Äãis incredibly dumb; you can run through missions or literally arm yourself with an M4 and shoot people in the head like you're opening beer cans. Bosses are also easily beaten on the first try. You wouldn't expect a plot from a series like this, but here it's incredibly rushed, stupid, and done for show, not to get a laugh from the trashy and cartoonish narrative. I won't even mention the idiocy of some missions and the complete lack of direction in some places.

It's worth a try if you're a fan of the series, as 3-4 hours isn't that long for a linear shooter, but you won't find anything interesting here.

I haven't finished it yet, but I'll have to finish it. The game is decent; the humor is dumb, but I find it funny at times.

It's cool, better than 4, and it has fewer bugs. There was only one bug with achievements, but I fixed it. The plot was small, but that's why there are two plot lines. I only completed one.

This game is complete crap. You're either given 5 minutes to run around the map, or you sit for half an hour, clearing out dummies who can't do anything to you, while you're practically immortal and any damage is like a mosquito bite. And even then, your HP refills after a while. And after this "cool" and "interesting" gameplay and game design, you watch ugly cutscenes with a shitty filter and peculiar humor. Seriously, half the game is cutscenes =/ which, on top of that, are pre-recorded and just ridiculous video playbacks! The game also has a REALLY weak narrative; we're just wandering around, completing tasks for all sorts of strangers, and doing stupid shit to earn money. (Spoiler: we won't get paid for the entire game.) But the funniest thing is... this game is better than Postal 4, which those incompetent RWS are trying to sell us. They've had nothing but toilet humor for a long time now... at least Postal 3 has decent style, graphics, music, and interface, and there's a bit of creativity. Postal 4 is just a carbon copy trying to replicate the success of Postal 2. If you play this game, only buy it on sale and just to try it out. The game takes 3-4 hours on average anyway. And once you've finished it, never play it again and forget it like a bad dream.

column9:
Postal 3 is a game with a very complicated history. Instead of making a sequel themselves, RWS handed the game over to our own "Akella." As a result, the game's concept changed significantly, and the game came out extremely buggy, even though it sold. Years and third-party patches later, the game is still quite entertaining. However, there are still a ton of bugs, including with achievements. They're all obtainable, but they depend on luck. I can hardly recommend the game. It's ironic that the series' creators mock it, considering it non-canon. However, they also stuffed Postal 2 with a ton of references and made their own fourth installment even worse (thanks to other reviews).

For example, in Postal 2 when you press 1 you can select all melee weapons, in Postal 3 not, the shovel is in one slot and the baseball bat in another and this is a mess, the game is so poorly programmed that some antivirus detect Postal 3 as virus but don't worry this is a false positive since according to RWS, Postal 3 is so pre-Alpha that some antiviruses think the game is suspicious, I bought it more to collect and I don't recommend the game, well, if you like Sonic 2006, SuperMan 64 and Duke Nukem Forever then yes this game is for you.

Al√©m de ser 3¬™ pessoa (O que n√£o √© um problema pra mim), o jogo n√£o segue o mesmo padr√£o dos outros; √â linear, voc√™ n√£o se sente com liberdade pra fazer o que quiser, a historia √© at√© meio fraca, desbalanceado e gameplay bugadissima (Apesar do tempo que esse bixo foi lan√ßado).
Curto muito a franquia postal, pretendo ainda zerar ou platinar esse, mas s√≥ quando eu tiver paciencia para ignorar os bugs e sistema de mira ridiculo desse jogo. 
Sobre a Lore do jogo, √© muito qualquer coisa, parece um pastel√£o tirado do filme, s√≥ que da forma mais porca possivel. Sem falar que transformaram o Dude num idiota funcional e trapalh√£o inconsequente (N√£o sei se essa √© a proposta conceitual da franquia). 
Enfim, esse eu n√£o consigo recomendar, apesar que na minha adolesc√™ncia eu ter me empolgado com ele por conta dos graficos e da suposta inova√ß√£o nos motores. Mas √© um joguinho bem meia boca.
column9:
Unfortunately, the game is bad! And I have the critical sense of an 8-year-old.
Besides being third-person (which isn't a problem for me), the game doesn't follow the same standard as the others. It's linear, you don't feel free to do whatever you want, the story is even a bit weak, unbalanced, and the gameplay is incredibly buggy (despite the time it's been released).
I really enjoy the postal franchise. I still intend to finish or platinum this one, but only when I have the patience to ignore the bugs and ridiculous targeting system.
As for the game's lore, it's pretty much a mess; it feels like a slapstick comedy from the movie, only in the crappy way possible. Not to mention that they turned the Dude into a functional idiot and an inconsequential bumbler (I don't know if that's the franchise's conceptual purpose).
Anyway, I can't recommend this one, even though I was excited about it as a teenager because of the graphics and the supposed innovation in the engine. But it's a pretty half-assed game.

column8:
Postal 3, developed by Trashmasters and published by Akella, is a notoriously divisive entry in the cult classic Postal series. Released in 2011, it attempts to build on the franchise‚Äôs reputation for outrageous, over-the-top violence and dark humor, but unfortunately, it‚Äôs marred by numerous technical problems, awkward controls, and a lack of polish that severely undermines the experience. While the game tries to maintain the anarchic spirit and irreverent tone fans expect, the final product feels like a half-finished project that struggles to capture the chaotic fun of its predecessors.

The narrative centers around the series‚Äô iconic anti-hero, known simply as the Postal Dude, who returns to his hometown of Catharsis to find things have changed in unsettling ways. The game‚Äôs story is a satirical take on American culture, politics, and social issues, filled with crude jokes, offensive stereotypes, and intentionally provocative scenarios. However, the humor often misses the mark, coming across as more crass than clever. The writing and voice acting are uneven, with many lines feeling forced or recycled, lacking the sharp wit and satirical edge that made earlier Postal games memorable.

Gameplay in Postal 3 diverges from the isometric view of the first two games, shifting to a third-person perspective with open-world elements. This change had the potential to modernize the series and offer players more freedom, but the execution leaves much to be desired. The controls are clunky and unresponsive, making simple actions like aiming, shooting, and navigating the world frustrating. Combat is a mix of ranged and melee weapons, but the combat mechanics feel shallow and unsatisfying, lacking the visceral punch that fans might expect from a game centered around violent chaos.

The open-world design attempts to provide players with multiple mission options and side activities, but the environments themselves are bland and poorly detailed. Catharsis feels lifeless, with repetitive NPC behaviors and minimal interaction. Missions are often monotonous and rely heavily on fetch quests or straightforward ‚Äúgo here, kill that‚Äù objectives that don‚Äôt add much variety or depth. Additionally, technical issues such as frequent bugs, crashes, and long loading times plague the experience, disrupting immersion and leading to player frustration.

Graphically, Postal 3 is outdated even for its release period. The character models and textures lack detail, animations are stiff and unnatural, and the overall visual design feels uninspired. Sound design fares little better: ambient sounds are sparse, weapon effects are underwhelming, and the soundtrack is forgettable. While the voice work attempts to inject some personality, it often falls flat due to poor direction and mediocre performances.

Multiplayer modes were included but failed to generate a significant player base, largely because of the game‚Äôs many flaws and the niche appeal of the series. Consequently, the multiplayer experience is almost irrelevant today, with servers either empty or non-existent.

Despite its many shortcomings, Postal 3 is not without some redeeming qualities. For fans who appreciate the series‚Äô controversial humor and are willing to look past the technical and design flaws, the game still offers moments of dark comedy and bizarre scenarios that align with the franchise‚Äôs legacy. The variety of weapons and the ability to approach missions in different ways‚Äîwhether with stealth, brute force, or chaos‚Äîcan provide brief bursts of enjoyment. There‚Äôs also a cult charm to its raw, unpolished nature, which some players find oddly endearing.

Ultimately, Postal 3 is a flawed and frustrating game that fails to live up to the standard set by its predecessors. It struggles with poor controls, repetitive gameplay, uninspired world-building, and technical issues that often derail the experience. While it tries to maintain the irreverent spirit of the Postal series, it does so with less wit and much less finesse. For newcomers or those unfamiliar with the franchise, it‚Äôs not a recommended entry. But for die-hard fans willing to endure its many problems, it might offer a gritty, if infuriating, continuation of the saga.

Rating: 4/10

Post-traumatic Stress Disorder, or How to Ruin a Legend.

So, I bought and installed this third installment. I thought, what could possibly go wrong? The next installment in this cult series, powered by the Source engine, and developed by Russian developers‚Äîit's about to be a wild ride, with jokes about vodka, swearing, and that same POSTAL spirit, only three times bigger and more detailed. For the first 20 minutes, I even enjoyed it: the cherished Russian swearing, the familiar Postal, everything seemed just as we love it.

And then it started...

And you know, I didn't even find any crashes! But I found everything else. This isn't a game, it's a tester's nightmare on a broken engine. I'm leading this pathetic helmet-sucker into the basement, and the door is locked tight. You tell him, "Follow me," and he runs into the wall and goes crazy. A shootout between two lost characters begins, and they both stand there, shooting into the sky, with the accuracy of a drunken sheriff. Until you go and kill one, you won't be able to progress to the next location. These aren't bugs; they're a systemic feature, a kind of "break your psyche" performance.

But the biggest crime is that they've robbed the game of its SOUL. That very freedom of action that made us all love POSTAL 2. You just wanted to have fun, shoot pigeons, set people on fire? No way! The game literally drags you by the scruff of the neck through the story, yelling, "Go earn some dough, bum!" And suddenly you're no longer the Lord of Chaos, but an obedient courier, running through dreary, linear locations and completing the most stupid tasks: "take that thing over there." WHERE DO I TAKE IT? HOW DO I TAKE IT? The map is a useless picture, with zero clues. You're running around the entire neighborhood, trying to guess which of the identical passages you should poke your head into. And all this is interspersed with hellish missions escorting idiots who stubbornly run into bullets.

Bottom line: This isn't POSTAL. It's some kind of sad parody, made by people who've only heard about the original in retellings. It seems the developers spent all their efforts recording Russian voiceovers, but they had neither the money nor the will to spend on gameplay and testing.

In its current state, it's a monument to how a great franchise can be ruined by one bad game. Not worth a penny, not a second of your time. Recommended only to game industry archaeologists studying the most notorious failures.

A valuable lesson: even the most beloved series can sink so low that it takes ten years to deal with the consequences. And yes, I still haven't finished the game, but I can already write a review.

P.S. Helmetsucker, I forgive you. It's not your fault you were created with such clumsy hands.

God, after playing POSTAL 2, considering all the negative references to POSTAL 3, I genuinely thought it was a terrible game and a failure. BUT THAT'S ABSOLUTELY NOT TRUE. The people who are mostly criticizing this game are people who simply fell for RWS propaganda.

Personally, having truly experienced this game, I can say it's simply amazing. Of course, it's not without bugs, I agree, but that's mostly because they simply gave up on the game and haven't fixed anything, considering it a "failure."

I can say there aren't really any bugs, but there are mostly crashes and a bit of a glitchy plot. I personally had the same problem: I couldn't get through the stun gun mission at the police station without a hitch. I had to just shoot everyone there, because the game crashed when I fired the stun gun. It works at random times, and it might not crash, but if that happens, you have to restart from your last save.

Overall, I'll say it again: the game is fantastic. The main reasons I didn't like it were because of "poor and awkward controls" (I personally think they're playable and even convenient), "poor optimization" (I was honestly shocked at how good the optimization was), and because this game was made by a Russian studio, maybe the Americans just didn't get the Russian jokes.

In my opinion, POSTAL 3 is the most underrated game out there, but I still recommend it. The game has excellent graphics and everything looks beautiful, and of course, the jokes. I think you won't regret it.

column9: I had my doubts. The game is definitely poorly made. Some achievements don't appear unless you edit the game files, it crashes occasionally, the hand-to-hand combat is horrible, the cinematics are very poor, and the guest characters don't take full advantage of them. Still, the game can still be enjoyable today if you're a fan of the series. The effort made by ZOOM Platform is appreciated; the difference today compared to how it was when it came out is abysmal. It's not 100% fixed, but it's definitely getting closer with each update. I hope one day they'll even restore the removed achievements. I appreciate the work Corey Cruise did as Dude and I'm glad he's still providing his voice in other Postal games.

Postal 3 isn't as bad as people say, but it also has little that's good. While you're playing it, you'll develop a neurosis, especially during the mission where you escort the mayor, who keeps crashing into walls and standing still for minutes at a time. There are constant bugs, crashes, the story and humor suck, and, really, what were they thinking when they made this game in the Source engine?
It had potential, but it was wasted, but I don't regret spending my time on it. Overall, it's worth playing out of curiosity.

You can finish the game in a couple of evenings. Sure, there are some bugs, but it's not terrible, and overall, I even enjoyed it.
There are some optimization issues, of course, and occasional severe FPS drops on Steam Deck when the locations are large and there are a ton of NPCs, but there were almost no crashes.
The locations are cool, by Source engine standards, and there's even a semblance of an open world, albeit in free roam. There's a wide variety of weapons, from a pet monkey to a vacuum cleaner. The visual style is cool.
I've been wanting to play it since 2011, but I never got around to it. Now, 14 years later, I've finished it and I'm not disappointed.
Well, it's a good game, it seems, but there are a ton of bugs everywhere.

Post-3 is either good or nothing, but there are positives everywhere: the missions are quite interesting, there are two paths, yes... How come there's no plot and the ending is cool, but you can still do whatever you want here, the third-person view is...

column8: Postal 3 is more of a novelty for Postal fans and not much else. It's not as bad as everyone paints it as, but it also isn't 'good' or on par with Postal 2 or even 4. Even with a community made patch and updates made by the Zoom Platform the game is still prone to crashes, bugs, and design choices that are fundamentally unchangable without further modding the game. It's redeeming qualities are few and far between to be enough to justify buying it even if you're a Postal fan - at least the soundtrack is stellar.

I don't understand why RWS is trashing Troika, even though they themselves released an even bigger piece of crap, Postal 4. I don't argue, the graphics are decent, but the gameplay itself is terrible. Yes, Troika changed a lot, but the point is that Troika is a continuation of the dude's story; it's even stated in the prologue, if you can even call it a prologue. Also, special mention to RWS, who claimed Postal 3 doesn't exist. They could have at least released their own Troika, since they have such a high opinion of themselves. And anyway, why does the fourth part come straight after Part 2? (I repeat, RWS themselves said Postal 3 doesn't exist.)

column9:
The game is notorious for its collision bugs, which cause the player or non-playable characters to become stuck in objects or the environment.

The artificial intelligence (AI) is extremely weak, with enemies reacting unpredictably and allies unable to complete basic tasks.
The save system is problematic, often corrupting progress files and forcing players to restart their journeys. This lack of technical stability not only undermines immersion but also demonstrates a lack of polish and quality control on the part of the developers, turning the gameplay experience into a constant battle against the software itself.
The game is an example of how a lack of technical care and poor design direction can completely ruin a title.

The Dude left Paradise and achieved Catharsis, accepting the world as it is...
The scale is very satisfying, often crudely executed, but ultimately fun and wild. The game encourages replayability not only through Steam achievements, but also because only by choosing one path or another will we be able to explore a particular level. Periodically, we are given the opportunity to switch sides or make "story-related" choices. The game is friendly to the "pacifist" player and is replete with beautiful animations for a more intense playthrough. Depending on your style, the Dude will either be the last sane person, melancholically accepting the madness around him, or "normal" in the madness that has engulfed everyone.

The game is more comedic, in the style of slapstick comedy. If you didn't like "The Naked Gun" and "Scary Movie," you won't enjoy it.

The music in the game is absolutely fantastic.
Today, you can play comfortably on even the weakest hardware without crashes or horrific lag, but when it first went on sale, it was a broken piece of code.

It's not a masterpiece, but it's a lot of fun.

column8:
Ho giocato Postal III su PC, acquistando una chiave su AllKeyShop per 1 euro. Ero curioso di vedere con i miei occhi cosa fosse andato storto in questo capitolo tanto criticato. Dopo averlo finito, posso dire che s√¨, le critiche erano fondate, e in certi momenti forse persino generose.

La prima cosa che salta all‚Äôocchio fin dall‚Äôinizio √® la quantit√† impressionante di bug. Gi√† nel prologo, sul ponte, quando bisogna dare fuoco agli zombie usando la benzina, ho avuto problemi: non c‚Äôera verso di versarla nella buca. √à stato il primo segnale che qualcosa non funzionava come doveva. In generale il gioco √® pieno di problemi tecnici. Mi √® capitato pi√π volte che i comandi di movimento si bloccassero da soli, le porte non si aprissero, i personaggi da scortare si piantassero e l‚Äôintelligenza artificiale sembrava spesso completamente assente. In pi√π di un‚Äôoccasione il gioco si √® bloccato improvvisamente, soprattutto in prossimit√† delle cut-scene.

Un altro aspetto che mi ha colpito √® stato il comportamento del protagonista. Le sue scelte e i suoi commenti sembrano talmente assurdi da farmi chiedere continuamente ‚Äúperch√©?‚Äù. Nei capitoli precedenti l‚Äôumorismo grottesco era parte dell‚Äôidentit√† della saga, ma qui si ha la sensazione di impersonare un tizio semplicemente stupido, senza alcun carisma. Anche la scelta di rendere il gioco in terza persona, rispetto alla prima dei precedenti titoli, non mi ha dato particolari emozioni. Non l‚Äôho trovata n√© una miglioria n√© un difetto, semplicemente un cambiamento che non aggiunge n√© toglie molto.

Dal punto di vista grafico, l‚Äôuso del Source Engine mi √® piaciuto. Sul mio PC il gioco √® girato senza problemi, anche se ho letto che al lancio l‚Äôottimizzazione era disastrosa. Alcune animazioni sembrano effettivamente mal rifinite, e in generale c‚Äô√® quella sensazione costante di un gioco lasciato a met√†, come se fosse stato completato di fretta o senza una vera supervisione.

Quello che pi√π mi ha deluso, per√≤, √® la componente satirica. Postal √® sempre stato un gioco politicamente scorretto, irriverente, sopra le righe, ma con un minimo di coerenza e una sua logica interna. Qui invece la volgarit√† sembra fine a se stessa. Le battute, i dialoghi e le situazioni ‚Äúsconvolgenti‚Äù non fanno ridere, non colpiscono, non disturbano: semplicemente, non funzionano. Manca completamente la vena di assurdit√† coinvolgente che aveva caratterizzato il secondo capitolo.

Anche la struttura del gioco contribuisce al senso generale di delusione. La libert√† dell‚Äôopen world di Postal 2 √® stata sostituita da una progressione lineare e noiosa. Le missioni sono poco ispirate e l‚Äôarsenale, per quanto vario, presenta armi che risultano quasi del tutto inutili. Personalmente, ho trovato deludenti strumenti come le granate, lo ‚Äúspara-sperma‚Äù (la prima arma che si trova), o i gatti-assassini, che sembrano inseriti solo per ricordare che siamo in un gioco ‚Äúfuori di testa‚Äù, ma senza alcun vero effetto comico o ludico.

Dopo aver completato il gioco, la sensazione √® quella di aver assistito a un‚Äôoccasione completamente sprecata. Affidare lo sviluppo a uno studio esterno, Akella, si √® rivelato un errore clamoroso. Il risultato √® un prodotto mal progettato, tecnicamente instabile e narrativamente inconsistente. Postal III non √® semplicemente un brutto gioco: √® un titolo che sembra non sapere cosa vuole essere. Spero sinceramente che Postal 4 riesca a riportare la serie su binari migliori, pi√π vicini allo spirito originale.

In definitiva, non mi pento di averlo giocato, ma solo perch√© adesso posso parlarne con cognizione di causa. Per√≤ lo ammetto: anche a un euro, forse ho speso troppo.
column9:
I played Postal III on PC, purchasing a key from AllKeyShop for ‚Ç¨1. I was curious to see for myself what had gone wrong with this much-criticized installment. After finishing it, I can say that yes, the criticism was well-founded, and at times, perhaps even generous. 

The first thing that stands out from the start is the impressive number of bugs. Already in the prologue, on the bridge, when you have to set zombies on fire using gasoline, I ran into trouble: there was no way to pour it into the hole. It was the first sign that something wasn't working as it should. Overall, the game is riddled with technical issues. I've had several instances where movement controls would freeze on their own, doors wouldn't open, characters I was escorting would get stuck, and the AI ‚Äã‚Äãoften seemed completely absent. On more than one occasion, the game suddenly froze, especially near cut-scenes. 

Another aspect that struck me was the protagonist's behavior. His choices and comments seem so absurd that they make me constantly ask, "Why?" In previous installments, grotesque humor was part of the franchise's identity, but here you feel like you're playing someone who's simply stupid, devoid of any charisma. Even the decision to make the game third-person, compared to the first-person perspective of previous titles, didn't particularly resonate with me. I didn't find it an improvement or a flaw, simply a change that didn't add or take away much.

Graphically, I liked the use of the Source Engine. The game ran flawlessly on my PC, though I've read that the optimization at launch was disastrous. Some animations do indeed seem poorly polished, and overall, there's that constant feeling of a game left unfinished, as if it were rushed through or unsupervised. 

What disappointed me most, however, was the satirical element. Postal has always been a politically incorrect, irreverent, and over-the-top game, but with a modicum of coherence and internal logic. Here, however, the vulgarity seems an end in itself. The jokes, dialogue, and "shocking" situations aren't funny, they don't resonate, they don't disturb: they simply don't work. The vein of engaging absurdity that characterized the second installment is completely missing.

The game's structure also contributes to the overall sense of disappointment. The freedom of Postal 2's open world has been replaced by a linear and boring progression. The missions are uninspired, and the arsenal, while varied, features weapons that feel almost entirely useless. Personally, I found tools like the grenades, the "sperm shooter" (the first weapon you find), and the killer cats disappointing, as they seem to be inserted merely to remind you that this is a "crazy" game, but without any real comic or playful effect.

After completing the game, I feel like I've witnessed a completely wasted opportunity. Outsourcing development to an external studio, Akella, proved to be a resounding mistake. The result is a poorly designed, technically unstable, and narratively inconsistent product. Postal III isn't simply a bad game: it's a title that doesn't seem to know what it wants to be. I sincerely hope that Postal 4 manages to bring the series back on track, closer to the original spirit.

Ultimately, I don't regret playing it, but only because I can now speak with full knowledge of the facts. But I admit: even at one euro, I probably spent too much.

One of the worst games of all time. That clumsy Gena from 7b would have put together a better game. I've tried playing it five times, but it's just physically painful. I've installed all sorts of fixes and so on, but it doesn't help. Thanks for the crap that was on the market back in the distant 2010s. It couldn't have been worse.

I noticed that those who didn't like Postal 3 spent roughly 1-6 hours playing, meaning they barely played this masterpiece. Moreover, I didn't download any fixes, and the game rarely crashed. Even Paradise Lost crashed more often than Postal 3.
Conclusion: Those who didn't like Postal 3 are victims of RWS propaganda.
Overall, I really liked the game; it's somehow different from the other games, and that's what draws me to it.

column9: What a perfect game, man, the talkers who are complaining about the game clearly don't understand or understand what postal games are. The game has bugs, yes, but it's still a wonderful game. On the contrary, I don't think they're a problem, it's a perfect continuation of the previous ones. The game takes you seriously so you go out killing everyone, and that's it. This one goes through another vibe of postal 1, which was just about killing everyone without even thinking. True fans of the franchise will enjoy it a lot. Even though the game wasn't developed entirely by the developer of the first ones, they did have participation and full presence in the development of the game, you can clearly see that they participated a lot.
The only downside is the technical aspect. Otherwise, it's not the worst game.

But the gameplay with mods is suitable for five hours of throwing shit and squirting urine at everything that moves. If you're an achievement hunter, then skip this masterpiece. Even the first game is worth something, which can't be said about Akella's creation.

column8:
This game is totally broken. I've tried reinstalling it, tried community mods to fix the issue, tried playing it from the start (3 times now) and about 5 missions in, without fail, a particular door won't open to trigger a cut scene, and you can not progress.  

And due to Steam's rubbish refund policy as all of that took me more than 2 hours (played for 4 hours trying to fix the problems only 3 days after purchase) they completely refuse to refund it. Just remember, ANY steam game giving you problems for more than an hour refund immediately, they just don't care after the 2 hour mark.

UPDATE : after trying various mods, uninstalling/reinstalling multiple times, I finally got past that level. Best setup seemed to be vanilla install (after uninstalling, completely deleting install directory, reinstalling), and then saving after every single doorway that actually opens... Took a few goes but finally cleared it. Game is still an unstable stinking pile of crap, but since Steam refuse to refund it I'll perservere through (must be a masochist!)

column9: The best game in the world, I really liked it. Buy it, friends, you won't regret it.

Among all the postal games, I think this is the worst.
Pros‚úÖ
Third-person perspective: allows you to see without getting shot
Cover system: allows you to dodge bullets
Weapon aiming
Self-regeneration system: adds action to your character
Good and evil system: allows you to choose your own actions
Postal Dude outfit and better graphics
Cons‚ùå
The intermittent fps drops really disrupt the gameplay
The game feels unfinished and rushed to sell
The plethora of bugs I never thought I'd encounter. If they were funny bugs, I wouldn't complain much, but they impact gameplay.
I think it's better to have an open-world game that spans days than to have a mission like this. There might be some, but it's not enough.
The audio is sometimes missing and sometimes lacks some of the original content. The AI ‚Äã‚Äãwalks around like it's confused about everything, whether it's us or the enemy. Sometimes it'll walk towards our bullets, causing us to accidentally shoot and waste merit unnecessarily. Also, when we're taking cover, it tends to stand behind us, not behind us, but directly behind us. It'll then collide with us, causing us to glitches and unable to shoot, unable to exit, and have to reload the save.
‚ùó‚ùóOverall‚ùó‚ùó
I don't really recommend this installment, even though it has the advantages I mentioned. Honestly, it can't compare to the previous installments in terms of fun, freedom, or anything else. Except for the visuals, it's annoying with the occasional FPS drop and the other shortcomings I mentioned.

column8:
This game feels like the greatest example of missing the entire point of what made Postal 2 work. Postal 3 is shallow, buggy, and while it does have SOME good ideas they're bogged down by mediocre execution, Saints Row 4-tier writing, and a severe misunderstanding of what makes Postal....well, Postal.

This might stand alongside Bayonetta 3 or No More Heroes 3 as one of the worst sequels ever made for series I enjoy.

Can I say the game is good? - No, can I say the game is bad? - No, it's average, with a plot that continues the Dude's story. Yes, there's some unfunny humor, but there are some funny moments too. I like Post-3 and am glad that you have a choice of paths:

1. If you're evil, then go back to the bad ending.
2. If you were less cruel, but weren't evil, then you get the good ending.
3. If you're good, meaning you didn't kill anyone (story bosses at the end don't count), then you get the happy ending where you see the interviewer's face, not like in previous endings.

Overall, the game was disappointing, but also a little enjoyable. There were some questionable moments with the control settings and the awkward machete, but these are just minor flaws and bugs.

Overall, 6 piss-stained corners out of 10.
The game is 10/10, top notch for the money, I don't regret buying it, the humor is great, I love Postal Dude

After 2-3 weeks, I managed to get this miracle running. It turned out the problem was Windows, as I understood it. How did I figure that out? I just downloaded it onto my brother's old laptop. The game really works perfectly. I liked it. I didn't notice any bugs. Bottom line: Postal III is awesome, and Postal 4 is complete crap. But I'm left with a bad taste in my mouth after spending money on the disc and drive.

I bought it because I love Postal, but this part is really not that great. The entire playthrough took me 4.5 hours and only crashed twice. The NPC AI is very dumb, the physics are weak, there are micro freezes and some awkward animations. I can't recommend it, but if you're a die-hard Postal fan, you can give it a try, but I don't recommend it.

column8: I went in with terrible expectations and was barely surprised Postal 3 was a little better than I heard it was. There were a lot of display glitches and nowhere near smooth fps; not only that but a lot of the mechanics and the 3rd person point of view was a change I didn't quite like much. the mission to mission style with no free roam capabilities was also a change I was not to fond of. while free roam did become available after beating the game it was honestly uninteresting considering most of the map was already explored throughout the missions. My final problem with the game was the hobo attack on the police department the lieutenant was a little bitch and wouldn't follow me if the world depended on it. On the bright side The guns were fun to play around with the physics were hilarious and some of the glitched gave the game more character and made is a funnier game to play. After all of my complaints the game was way more enjoyable than RWS and most other fans of the series had claimed. I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to everyone  but I also think people need to stop hating as much as they do.

column9: better than many AAA

Look, if I approach writing a review objectively (using all my eloquence), Postal 3 plays like you're digging through crap, but (important note!) GOOD crap. No, I'm serious, I'm telling you this, okay, about the cons: 1. The game is buggy, EVERYWHERE (I have a feeling that I found bugs with the voice acting and many other things almost everywhere, but I hasten to please you! The game has been fixed a little, well, at least two updates have been released for it) 2. Jokes.. Sometimes flat, sometimes completely out of place (In short, this is not a minus and not a plus, but I didn‚Äôt like much) 3. Stupid AI, this is the thing that really burned me when I was going through the story.. (Let's imagine a situation using an example from the game - your mission is to get with your companion to the final door or something like that, let's say you cleared out all the enemies on the level, approach the final door and.. nothing happens. Nothing! And you come to this shit-eater who is standing and running into the wall! Well, or just crashed into the hitboxes of some object and is also standing and running) Pros: 1. Really good Russian voice acting and... Um... That's all. I really don't recommend it to people who just finished Postal 2 (Because I was the same way until I played this MASTERPIECE. By the way, I really thought the game was essentially made by our people, so of course I like it, but it doesn't add any positives to the game). In short, this isn't what fans of the previous part would want to see. (And yes, a note for anyone reading this: I recommend playing the expansion to Postal 2, it's truly better and I've tested it myself.) I think this project could have turned into a really good game, but... It turned out that way! I give it a 4/10 (PS: Thanks for reading!)

column8:
TOTAL DISASTER. The WORST sequel in Gaming History. What the Hell happened??? Postal 2 was a Cult Classic‚ÄîFunny, Offensive, Outrageous, FREEDOM to do what you want in a Crazy Sandbox world. You could go full rampage or play it NICE. Your choice. That‚Äôs what made it a MASTERPIECE. A little chaotic joy from the early 2000s!

But then came Postal III‚Ä¶ and it‚Äôs like they FLUSHED everything good straight down the toilet. Russian devs took over (big mistake), engine change (Source??? Should‚Äôve stayed with what worked), and suddenly it‚Äôs a broken-on-arrival, rail-shooter MESS. Bugs, crashes, horrible writing, UNFUNNY garbage that tries way too hard. And the Postal Dude? A WHINY SHELL of his former self. They neutered him‚Äîturning a chaotic legend into a sad, scripted joke. PATHETIC!!!

Forced Morality System‚Äîwhat is this, a CANCEL CULTURE simulator? Postal 2 gave you agency. Postal III shoves a cringe story down your throat like you're some NPC in a bad student film. Unskippable cutscenes, awful acting, gameplay stiffer than Joe Biden trying to ride a bicycle. UNPLAYABLE JUNK.

They took a Beautiful Sandbox of freedom and turned it into a corridor shooter with AI dumber than the people running California.

Postal 2 was a chaotic GEM. Postal III is a national EMBARRASSMENT. Should‚Äôve been BANNED for being this BAD. Total F minus. RWS disowned it‚ÄîEVEN THEY knew it was a crime against gaming. Sad!

---

Also, the game sucks at counting achievements. I just shot a corpse in the hand and the game crashed.

In short, the game is super over-the-top imbalance for fans. The only downside is that all the characters are voiced by one person, and the NPCs speak English. Also, killing people isn't fun. CONCLUSION: I regret everything.

column9:
POSTAL 3 was one of the only games in the series that was not developed by RUNNING WITH SCISSORS but by AKELLA games, which already had good experience with the franchise, as they developed CORKSCREW RULES, the Russian expansion of POSTAL 2, which was only released in Russia. Although this game was developed by AKELLA games, RUNNING WITH SCISSORS had full supervision of the project. Most of the people who speak badly of POSTAL 3 are people who don't even seem like true fans of the franchise, nor do they understand what POSTAL is, and these people from this current Nutella gamer society who are prejudiced against the fact that POSTAL is a low-budget game, prioritize a bunch of nonsense that doesn't matter much, like for the game to be good it has to have ultra-realistic graphics and an open map without even trying it. Because these people who speak badly of POSTAL 3 are people who haven't even played the game, as well as those people adapted to today's society who are bothered by the satires that the game involves, which refer to the reality of the world that they don't want to face, using their low-budget game points to speak badly without even having tried it. What most people don't understand is that POSTAL is a compilation of satires on the reality of the shitty world we live in that most people don't want to face because it bothers them and POSTAL 3 remains a POSTAL the way we like it as it maintains the main points that made the franchise controversial such as the satires that increased even more, the politically incorrect content, the naughtiness and the graphic violence. The real-life figures that serve to represent the satires of the POSTAL series increased even more with appearances by Ron Jeremy, the famous PORN KING or king of porn, who is a very famous porn actor from the past who has made a ton of special appearances in famous films, who in the game he founds PORNWORLD and also becomes a candidate for mayor of CATHARSIS, Jennifer Walcott, who is a Playboy model from the 2001 Playmate who here in POSTAL is the new POSTAL BABE from RUNNING WITH SCISSORS, Randy Jones, who is the gay cowboy from VILLAGE PEOPLE who leads a gang of gay bikers in CATHARSIS where he has a ranch only for gay cowboys, Sergey Mavrodi who was responsible for the biggest fraud in the history of Russia where he committed more than 10 thousand against his MMM investors who ended up that in POSTAL 3 he is an exile from Russia who came to CATHARSIS where he bought the slot machine room from Jack Thompson, who he turned into a computer center that processes data matrices so that he could continue the attempted fraud against his investors, even trying to bribe the POSTAL DUDE himself to invest in his bank, UWE BOLL, who is known as the worst director who directs adaptations of games of very dubious quality since he doesn't give a damn about the project so that in the end the film is a flop and so he isn't harmed by the failure of the film, he goes to the government of his country, which in this case is Germany, to resolve the mess of the film's failure so he isn't harmed and is well paid in the end, coming out unscathed, which is a strategy he practiced in all projects. He also challenged his critics to a boxing match where they got beaten up badly by BOLL, being invited to make a special appearance in POSTAL 3 as he directed the wonderful POSTAL film, which is very POSTAL. Here we have the return of uncle DAVI, who is the uncle of POSTAL DUDE, who in POSTAL was the leader of a complex of stoner hippies in Paradise. Here in CATHARSIS, he starts working with Ron Jeremy in the slave boy trafficking as well as with AL-QAEDA with the appearance of OSAMA BIN LADEN himself who is carrying out his terrorist attacks in CATHARSIS to impose the ideology of the TALIBAN as well as working together with uncle DAVI in a negotiation with KROTCHY in which AL-QAEDA will bring a shipment of KROTCHY dolls that are composed of plutonium to KROTCHY who in the end will provide half of the shipment to AL-QAEDA, AL Gore who is the former vice president of the USA as well as an environmentalist who here in POSTAL 3 leads a faction of nature ecologists who use badgers instead of chainsaws, Sarah Palin who is a feminist politician from the United States who in POSTAL is the leader of the Hockey Moms who are the feminists of CATHARSIS and the dictator of Venezuela Hugo Ch√°vez who at the end of the game decides to put his project in a block socialist together with Brazil and Cuba in action to impose socialism in the United States since this is the dream of these disgusting little reds who invested so much in this bloc that Venezuela ended up economically bankrupt and the country is also in the shit, in the case of Cuba after the death of Fidel Castro his brother will not even be able to invest in this bloc as Cuba has always been a poor country and in Brazil with the return of Lula in politics that is worsening the prices of the products we consume all that is missing is for Brazil to go bankrupt once and for all like Venezuela. POSTAL 3 remains the same as POSTAL 2 since you are free to do whatever you want without anyone ordering you around where we again follow the troubled life of POSTAL DUDE who is now 43 years old trying to be a person and act like a passive person as well as what he is doing in CARTHARSIS to earn a living, although he cannot be a passive person in terms of the messes he ends up getting into in his path forcing him to become an insane person again as he was in PARADISE as well as in POSTAL 3 as in POSTAL 2 you make choices that will influence your path as well as in the end if you want to act as a good citizen, a completely insane person or a pacifist. POSTAL 3 was developed using the SOURCE engine, a VALVE engine. I'm not one of those faggots who prioritizes graphics, but one thing I have to highlight about POSTAL 3 is that for a low-budget game, it has impressive graphics, even for a low-budget game, like the look of POSTAL DUDE, which is really cool, Uncle DAVE's look is awesome, Ron Jeremy himself resembles himself in real life, as well as Jennifer Walcott, Randy Jones, Uwe Boll and Bin Laden because of the absurd level of detail they put into the game's physics. One point I like to highlight about POSTAL 3 is that, unlike previous games, it adopted a seventies aesthetic heavily inspired by the GRINDHOUSE films by Quentin Tarantino and Robert Rodrigues, which were a tribute to the controversial and politically incorrect productions that premiered on GRINDHOUSE during the 60s and 70s. This aesthetic is greatly reflected in POSTAL DUDE's fashion, which went from his 2000s gothic fashion in POSTAL 2 to a fashion more inspired by the seventies aesthetic, as well as the soundtrack, which for me has the best selection of songs in the series, as they licensed the instrumentals of the songs by the Russian band PETER PAN THE BAND, which fit perfectly with the game's aesthetic, as they are metal songs mixed with 70s hard rock, right down to the harmonica, creating some very exciting songs for those moments when you're going to rock the hell out. One thing that makes me happy is that there is still a community of fans of the POSTAL series who defend POSTAL 3 and also recognize that it was a game that was very unfairly treated because of this society we live in that wants to hide us from reality. I also felt pleasure in having the total freedom to gut the disgusting socialists from POSTAL 3 who are flooding my country, as well as destroy Hugo Ch√°vez's tank with my AT-4, so that in the end I could piss on it and feel like the savior of North America and the savior of the Fatherland who freed the UNITED STATES OF AMERICA from the disgusting socialists, or as I would say, "I REGRET NOTHING."
GABRIEL ONURIS HAS TO SEE MY ANALYSIS, BECAUSE I'M A HUGE FAN OF HIS.

column9: It's not as bad as they say. It's entertaining, and it's good that it has different routes.

Let's start with the technical part: it's been worse, and I understand the game has become more stable with the latest patches. I only had two crashes throughout the entire game and one bug where the boss you need to kill fell through the textures.

Give it a try if you want complete trash; the toilet jokes are free.

The voice acting for the game was done by KurazhBobey, and I was pleasantly surprised to hear his voice.

The game deservedly has low ratings, but if you just want to kill everyone and piss on them, this series is the only game for you.

column9:
[b]A game that, despite the story and several bugs, is fun. [/b]

[u]Pros:[/u]
The game's music is free to download.
Postcard's humor is still intact.
Achievements are currently 100% obtainable.
DRM-free.
It has three endings (bad, neutral, and good, depending on karma).

[u]Cons:[/u]
Some bugs that prevent you from completing missions and require you to restart them.
The game engine is a source code that isn't designed for third-person games, making it difficult to shoot straight with your sights.
Melee is poor, and the karma system is poorly designed.
In some situations, enemies are bullet sponges.

Despite all that, the game is entertaining for Postcard fans.

column9: After playing through the game with the patch, I know why the second generation added an easter egg to complain about this generation. I am too lazy to list the points one by one. It's lame.

Postal III is a game that's difficult to evaluate. In terms of gameplay and overall execution, it's a project that teeters on the edge: it has both successful achievements and glaring missteps. The main character, known to us all as the Dude, spends the entire game trying unsuccessfully to find his way in life, trying a variety of jobs‚Äîfrom a janitor at a strip club and a Segway thief to a bodyguard and, quite literally, a target. But a twist of fate leaves the old man with a hole in his pocket.

The plot, as usual, unfolds day by day, and each day presents the player with the signature blend of absurdity, dark humor, and wicked social satire, accompanied by cruelty and violence‚Äîprecisely the atmosphere that made the Postal franchise so beloved. I was especially delighted by Denis Kolesnikov's voice acting: his voice and translation add a special charm and nostalgic warmth to the project...
I won't go into plot details‚Äîthat's up to the player to decide. However, one thing is certain: if you're a fan of the series, then despite all its flaws, this "forgotten" and largely controversial installment is still worth checking out. Special thanks to Akella.

A good game from the Postal series has many things I like, such as:
1. the ability to choose who to team up with during a level
2. the aiming in this game is similar to games like Resident Evil or GTA and others
but there are also things I don't like about this game:
1. if you do something accidentally, for example, shoot someone in your group, their entire group turns against you
2. sometimes it kicks me out of the game for no reason
In short, it's an interesting game but needs some minor improvements :)

column8:
"Gaming Peak. Nothing Will Ever Top This."
Wow. Just‚Ä¶ wow.

Postal III is a masterpiece of modern game design. Who needs functional controls or coherent storylines when you can crash to desktop because you sneezed near an NPC? Genius. The devs clearly asked, "What if we made a sequel that no one asked for, took everything people liked about Postal 2, and just... didn‚Äôt do any of it?"

The AI? Revolutionary. I‚Äôve never seen cops run face-first into walls for five minutes straight. Truly ahead of its time.

Voice acting? Oscar-worthy. Everyone sounds like they recorded their lines at gunpoint through a potato.

Gameplay? Oh, the gameplay! Nothing beats the thrill of trying to walk in a straight line while the camera does its best impression of a drunk uncle at a wedding. Also, the moral choice system? Beautiful. Be good or evil? Joke‚Äôs on you, both paths suck equally. Equality at last.

In conclusion: Postal III cured my insomnia, ended my relationships, and made me reflect deeply on every life choice that led me here.

11/10. Play it if you hate yourself.

column9: Postal 3 has a nice dark humor, cool music and beautiful graphics, but damn it crashes like a drunk grandma driving a Chevrolet spark

POSRAL III

I recommend it to fans of Posral, and to regular people as well‚Äîjust for a fun evening or two.

- There's not much to do in the open world‚ÄîPosral 2 plays better and more intensely in the open world.
- Firing guns is enjoyable, but close combat (except for the badger) is awkward and useless.
- The levels, which are the main focus, are well-executed. Occasionally, there are crashes or characters getting stuck, but thankfully, the game has quick saves.
- The HUD, as well as the start and pause menus, are nice.
- The jokes and jokes in the style of Postal 2 are nice; I even wrote some down for myself.

Don't expect any discounts on this game‚Äîthey simply don't exist. Get it if you don't mind, or if you're a fan.

column9: Congratulations, Postal 4 fans!

I'll try to summarize: the game isn't fully polished (if you study its history, this isn't surprising), but at the same time, it has a storyline of sorts, even technically local to the CIS. Kurazh-Bambey's voice acting is pretty good. While earning achievements, there were some difficulties with broken elements, but in the end, everything worked out. The humor is an acquired taste. If you get a little used to the controls, you might even rate it a 3/5. (P.S. I don't remember exactly about this version, but I once came across some developer notes in the code itself, where I wanted to commiserate with him about his work.)

column8: Got the game on sale for ¬£1, That's still too much for this game, I was always curious of why this was the worst in the series and after playing it I see why. The jokes never land or are stale, the gameplay feels more like call of duty, the open world story is gone, you're set through a linear 'on the rails' story mode, Healing items are gone and in its place is a standard generic wait until your health regens, which is super slow, There's no difficulty settings, it has the source engine jank and i got stuck behind a door 5 times before I was able to get through, very little information at all time on where anything is or what you're meant to do, no map, no easy way of seeing if your stats if you're going for pacifist, game is always in 3rd person, music is very unfitting most of the time, bosses have no alternative way of beating them, achievements require some code diving and editing to actually get them to work, story feels disconnected and the gameplay feels just overall floaty. Don't even get it on sale unless you're looking for a good game to torture yourself with
column9: Got the game on sale for ¬£1, That's still too much for this game, I was always curious of why this was the worst in the series and after playing it I see why. The jokes never land or are stale, the gameplay feels more like call of duty, the open world story is gone, you're set through a linear 'on the rails' story mode, Healing items are gone and in its place is a standard generic wait until your health regens, which is super slow, There's no difficulty settings, it has the source engine jank and i got stuck behind a door 5 times before I was able to get through, very little information at all time on where anything is or what you're meant to do, no map, no easy way of seeing if your stats if you're going for pacifist, game is always in 3rd person, music is very unfitting most of the time, bosses have no alternative way of beating them, achievements require some code diving and editing to actually get them to work, story feels disconnected and the gameplay feels just overall floaty. Don't even get it on sale unless you're looking for a good game to torture yourself with

column9:
Oh well... hated, cursed, rated 24 as one of the worst games ever made, and not even Running with Scissors wants it, and a whole host of other things. You can watch a video on YouTube about what happened with Postal III if you're interested. Here I am to share my experience of the game today.

And I'm not going to lie, I really liked it hahaha. It has a good and bad ending depending on your decisions, crazy weapons as usual and good variety, third-person gameplay that was also interesting. It made me laugh a lot with the random things and what you can do, despite its reputation in the series (it was banned).

Maybe you'll give it a try. Today they put in some patches, removed 3 achievements that were broken, there was no way to get them. They also fixed some bugs related to other achievements that were super complicated and tedious to complete. If for some reason you have problems, there are optimization guides that can fix your problem. And last but not least, it has been translated into Spanish by the community :)

I had about 4 crashes in total. It didn't affect my saved games or anything like that. You can now easily get the achievements if you want to complete them, lol.

P.S. The soundtrack is amazing ‚ô•

column8: i don't think people give this game enough credit. it's fun. i like the story and characters, and they're all very in depth. it's cool how champ has an active role now. the cinematics are amazing, i love the style. i like the constant cutscenes, keeps it entertaining. i really like how it has replay value, as your choices change the story so you can replay and try other things. clearly, a lot of effort went into development. the combat isn't so bad. as for bugs and crashing, i haven't experienced any of the sort. even if there are some issues, it's nothing that prevents playing, and nothing i wouldn't expect from an indie game. and it's only $5, so you can't complain.

column9:
This thing is complicated; playing for an hour was complete torture.

Besides the game actually being pretty mediocre, the technical issues make matters worse. The AI ‚Äã‚Äãis pathetic, the Dude's movement is completely clunky, the soundtrack, besides being weak, has a bug that plays during the cutscene, the achievements don't unlock initially, forcing you to go into the game folder and edit a configuration file to make them work (WTF?), and a bug that affects level progression (like the game gives you the objective of defeating a certain number of enemies, but some don't appear), which made me give up playing.

Even though it's the black sheep of the franchise, I tried to play it to see if it's really as bad as they say, and... I can say that after just an hour of play, you already see how weak it is. However, I didn't expect there to be a bug that affected level completion. If it hadn't, I would have insisted on playing... what a drag.

3 reais was too expensive.

Until the very end, I hoped that all the "bad" reviews were just exaggerated fanboyism from the second game. But unfortunately, that's not the case. The game is truly flawed: the camera is constantly twitching due to the third view, weapon switching is awkward, NPCs behave worse than in the second Postal, achievements are poorly announced, and so on and so forth. This game also became the graveyard of a company like Akella, the one that gave me the legendary Corsairs as a child. Sleep well, wolf on the orange square. But this game has its upsides, too; it's still the same anti-social project where absurdity goes hand in hand with a ton of swearing, trash, and used napkins. That made me smile.
