column8: There is a game here, i can see the potential. honestly tho if you aren't a hardcore postal fan and even if you are i don't think i could recommend it. the amount of times i had to reload a level because a door is broken. that was the biggest problem, the doors would break all the time and i think it was because their was enemy's behind it, but even if you manage to kill them the door stays broken. the prison escort mission was the worst, i was on it for like 2 hours for a 15 min mission, i didn't even die, not once. the level was just that broken, i ended up reloading the whole level more than 3 times. also the new big thing here is taking cover but 40% of the time Dude just wont shoot behind cover. theirs other stuff to complain about but its mostly nitpicks. is there anything good? sure. the soundtrack for the most part is great. there's not much challenge so i had time to jam out to the music, except for the tutorial level, its got some weird lullaby. i also don't mid the shooting, there is flaws but the guns feel pretty well to shoot, melee not so much but guns are okay. honestly overall, if your a postal fan and you wanna play this part of postal history then i would recommend it. if your pretty new to postal, just go play postal 2.

√öltima cosa, si no hubiera ocurrido la crisis mundial de 2008/2009 Akella pudo haber hecho un mejor trabajo y no teniendo que despedir a mitad de la plantilla dejando a gente con menos experiencia. Dicho esto acabo.
column9:
Let's see... the game itself isn't bad, but some missions are bugged. Like the mission with the dog with the laser pointer (it works terribly), plus there's a high chance the dog will get stuck, or the mission with that degenerate [i]sadomasochist[/i] who gets stuck in doors and you have to kick him to make him walk, lol.

As for crashes, it only crashed once... and Postal 2 is more prone to that, and I don't see people online crying like bitches like they do with Postal 3.

I think people exaggerate a lot online. I don't care if it's linear or in third-person, as much as it is open world. I had a good time playing it. Don't be fooled by what people say out there. I took a risk buying it, and it's not what they say.

Last thing, if the global crisis of 2008/2009 hadn't happened, Akella could have done a better job and wouldn't have had to lay off half the staff, leaving less experienced people in the fold. With that, I'll conclude.
it goes well with beer

column8: My father smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, "If you ever want to see your children graduate, you have to stop immediately.". Tears welled up in his eyes when he realised exactly what was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your father put us through.". I agreed. At 13, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it because your game gave me cancer anyway.

column9: could you please sign my petition?

At first, you buy this game hoping for a continuation of the beloved second part, then after launching the game, you realize that something is wrong here, at least because of the voice acting - courage-bombay, then you see that it was made by the not very beloved Russian studio "Akella", because of the laziness of the developers to make the game themselves and entrusting the development to a second-rate studio from Russia, we got an unreal crap with crashes and bugs, a vaguely written plot where there is no plot at all, just random events just to give the player the opportunity to finally shoot over and over again, a looped bullshit where the dude tries to make money over and over again. I am a fan of the second part and I am very upset by this pathetic parody of it, I do not recommend buying it.

[h1] I don't regret anything [/h1]

The game could have been quite acceptable, but we have what we have.
I launched the game with great optimism, thinking that all the hate, while deserved, was likely exaggerated, and that the game itself could at least offer an interesting experience. Unfortunately, my expectations were completely disappointed, and I can't recommend this game, even for a beer in the evening.
The game is frustrating with its broken mechanics (hello, catnip), flaws in every aspect of gameplay, crashes, a dull, repetitive storyline with corridor-like locations (we try to earn money in every mission, but the Dude can't), scripts that don't work (for example, an NPC you absolutely must kill disappears or doesn't respawn at all; a script at a certain point in the story doesn't work for some reason). There's no humor or satire in the game, even though they tried. And the bombay swagger is like a bad cherry on a bad cake. Getting achievements requires a fair amount of tinkering, even with the story ones. Sometimes I had to replay missions five times, dancing with a tambourine.
In short, it's a broken piece of code, not a game. At least it's short, so thankfully.

I'd still like to point out the positives that it does have. Firstly, the music leaves a pleasant impression; the main menu music makes you want to listen to it even when you're not playing the game. Secondly, the spirit of the second post-apocalypse can truly be felt in the game's first missions, but even that quickly evaporates under all the game's flaws.
Buying and playing this is purely for the experience.

column9:
As a fan of the series, my review will be heavily biased.

Good Points
The main menu screen and in-game music are absolutely awesome.

Bad Points
There's no doubt that the most well-known entry in the series is the previous game, Part 2.

- If you try to leave a store without paying, the shutters suddenly close and the owner chases you with a rifle.
- The backroom of a local store turns out to be a terrorist hideout.
- If you cut in line at the register, you'll be verbally abused from behind.
- If you kick a ball, a dog will happily bring it back to you with its mouth.
- If you "trick" a donut and feed it to the police...
- The meaningless option to "commit suicide" is also available.

These kinds of playful elements are all part of the game. Despite its old game system and cheap graphics, it gained a cult following because of this unique "Postal" feel.

So what about this game? It changed from an FPS to a TPS. This was a decision made by the production team and is not something we should comment on. But what did they gain from the changes from 2 to 3 in exchange for destroying the Postal feel described above? The maps lack flexibility, the boring inside jokes, the hopeless AI, and the action lacking any sense of exhilaration...it's just too awful. The only thing worth playing is the post-game stroll mode (where you can freely roam the map, just like in 2), but being told to rampage in such a world that lacks exhilaration and playability is not enough to motivate me for more than five minutes. This game boasts the ability to choose between a good guy and a bad guy, but this was the default in the previous game, and the developers of the previous game didn't force a "choice" on the player, just let them "do as they please." In the Postal experience we expect, "choices" are nothing but an impurity.

As a fan of the series, I've experienced all the endings and played the game even after the recent update (bug fixes). As I mentioned at the beginning, this review is written with a fairly positive bias.

Look, I'm somewhat of a Postal fan and an insane fanatic Source [Engine] fan. I thought when people said this was a bad game, it was either a joke or they weren't Postal fans like me (and probably you). Little did I know, this game was (and still is) absolutely terrible. It's playable, but it's an awful experience. Seriously, few games in my life have made me feel dizzy.

Buy this game if you just want to collect video games and let it rot in your library. If you actually want to play, please don't.

column8:
i bought this at like a 3/4 discount so i could play straight through the whole postal series in sequence. the result was a chore of a detour between the entertaining Apocalypse Weekend and the excellent Paradise Lost. dull, finicky, feels poorly-playtested and i get the impression that the writers didn't really get postal 2 on more than a superficial level. if you've heard of postal, you know the deal with this game.

that said, as a stickler for The Experience‚Ñ¢Ô∏è, enduring postal 3 really hammers in the point that the postal 2 dude makes about how badly he was scarred by his years-long coma dream. in the context of postal 2, you're supposed to want postal 3 to be over as soon as possible, and postal 3 certainly delivers. how immersive!

next time you play Two Weeks in Paradise, stop after sunday, play through postal 3, and then resume from second monday. when you finally step onto that dusty railroad, you'll really feel like you're waking up from a nightmare with brain damage from years of atrophy and untreated cranial trauma.

column9: I think I'm a jerk

One cool summer evening, while my peers were developing, I was sitting at my computer and did not know what to do with myself and I decided to watch cute porn art with anime girls, but they did not give me much pleasure as before, and so I decided to plunge into the depths of the lower Internet and suddenly I found a game. I got tired when I had already played it and even completed it, well, and decided to replay it, after all, it is better than nothing. I immediately went to buy all the parts on Steam and when I was already ready to pay for the purchase, I noticed the absence of part 3. At first, I thought that I did not notice it, since this often happens to me due to insomnia, but when I went to the RWS page on Steam, I did not find part 3. This was still strange. Maybe they deleted it or it was so violent that it was banned. I decided to search for information on the Internet and lo and behold, it exists. I immediately went to look for it on Steam and found it. But for some reason, the game had mixed reviews and the metacritic rating was generally 24, although according to the trailer, it looks pretty good. Out of curiosity, I decided to start with part 3. After downloading, I went into the game, completed the tutorial, and began to play the main story. I was very amused by the first mission: collecting napkins in sperm and then shooting them at fat fems, but when I almost finished the quest, the game crashed. It was very strange. My computer is quite powerful and it can‚Äôt be that it couldn‚Äôt handle some stupid game. I went into it again and it crashed again. Bitch, maybe it‚Äôs just some kind of buggy mission or I caught a virus while downloading cute porn art with Miku. I went into it again and the game crashed again. I couldn‚Äôt stand it and hit the monitor. Luckily, I‚Äôm a very weakling, so I didn‚Äôt even break it. But my hand began to hurt as if I had hit a brick wall. And while I was moaning pitifully in pain, someone rang the doorbell. It‚Äôs strange who needs me, although maybe my wet dreams have come true and cute Neko-chan came to me. I went to the door and looked through the peephole, but there was no one there. Apparently, stupid children can‚Äôt be entertained by their parents, and they decided to pester me by standing there. 5 minutes on the stairwell I didn't see anyone and with a calm soul I entered the apartment eh but if it was cute Neko and not stupid children I would now pour her some tea and start telling stories about my worthless life sitting down at the computer I decided to play Postal Redux it seems like a remake of Postal maybe I'll play the original but then I don't want to injure my hand again because of crashes when I almost completed the first level someone rang the bell again I went to the door looked through the peephole and saw that the postman was standing on the other side I was glad because I recently ordered a dakimakura with cute Neko but it's strange that she arrived so quickly but still, in my joy I decided to open the door for him and take my beloved home opened the door this idiot started poking a shotgun at me and threatening but I didn't listen to him my thoughts were occupied with where he put my beloved I hope that everything is okay with her and this scumbag messenger didn't touch her with his greasy hands and somewhere in a minute he apparently He noticed that I wasn't listening to him, he hit me with the butt of his gun to bring me to my senses, I fell to the floor and cried in pain, and then this asshole did something terrible: he pulled a shotgun on me like the cat from Postal 2 and told me to never play Postal 3 or I'd be screwed.

column9:
This game is... strange. It's visually quite beautiful, and the protagonist's voice acting is really cool. Now, the rest...
The game has a LOT of weird and repetitive ideas, it's full of bugs, it's not very fun, and it ends up being a bit limited. The story is horrendously bad, and despite having more than one ending, none of them are interesting. Once you get one, you don't care about the others and just press Alt + F4 and delete the game. I only recommend it to those who want to feel sad or who really liked the previous game.
I don't get it. Shooting isn't as fun as in Postal 2, but it's just funny. It's a shame the game is linear.

column9: Full of bugs, game freezes every now and then to the point that it's unplayable. I'm very frustrated with this. A disappointment in otherwise a good franchise. Shame...

Honestly, having completed this game completely and achieved 100% of the achievements, it had potential. The third Postal could have been much better if not for RWS's cessation of control over Akella and Akella's negligent attitude toward the developers. Why Akella's bosses fired so many developers from Trashmasters and forced them to work on the game almost from the very beginning, we'll probably never know. However, with Steam patches, Postal 3 became playable and, overall, a very good game. Pros: the soundtrack, the style, and a decent storyline. Cons: Bugs and crashes. Yes, even with Steam patches, there are still crashes, but they were even fewer than in Postal 2. The patches also slightly disrupted the story achievements, so if you want to get all the achievements, check out the Steam guides for this game. Overall, I give it a 6.9/10. Enjoy the game, and let's sign the petition to remove the disgraceful Postal 4!

This game is a bittersweet memory for RWS.

Because the outsourcer didn't utilize the Source engine to the same level as Valve, and because it used problematic DRM for a while, the game received very poor reviews.

Although the outsourcer finally removed the stifling DRM in 2023, could they re-optimize it and even release it in Chinese?

Actually, compared to the other installments, I'm a Postal (not counting 4).
The game sucks, but I also think it's underrated. It has a great soundtrack, multiple endings are unique in this installment, and one of the best menus in any Postal game. Otherwise, I enjoyed the game. Call me crazy.

Oh, I don't even know where to begin. This game might be controversial at first glance; after playing the second part, this is definitely not what I expected. But it doesn't take much to figure out what's going on. The gameplay is well done, and the concept is good. The humor is excellent. I'm glad that the game's storyline depends on your choices, etc. I also really enjoyed the last two missions and the boss fights in them, namely Diveland and the Apocalypse.

But it's not for everyone and it's full of bugs; you'll have to put up with it for a while to fully enjoy it.
Overall rating: 7.8 out of 10. And that's only because the game costs only 240 rubles.

Overall, I recommend it.

column9:
The game is very bad, the worst in the POSTAL franchise, but I'm still giving it a positive rating, unlike my review of POSTAL 4, where I gave it a negative rating. POSTAL 4 was in early access for a long time, and the company had a more sinister budget than Postal 3, and to this day the game is poorly optimized and unregulated. Postal 3 runs well; after all, it uses the source engine (Half-Life 2, Left 4 Dead, etc.), and it launched like the crap it is without early access. This is the work of Trashmasters, really bad, but honestly, lol.
The game has strange gameplay, many repetitive NPCs, questionable animations and ragdolls, a lousy plot that's not very entertaining and crashes a few times. The positives are that the weapon variety is quite extensive, Postal Dude's voice, while not Rick Hunter's, is still well done, Uwe Boll's appearance is funny, the art is good, the soundtrack is cool and has subtitles and a Brazilian Portuguese interface. I don't think it's worth the full price, but on a 2 or 3 reais promotion, it might be worth it to play, have a few laughs, or for younger people who enjoy chasing achievements and getting involved. I received it as a gift from a subscriber and finished it live on the channel. Playing while exchanging ideas with the people in the chat makes the experience much better, lol. The game is so bad that it's fun.

If I hadn't received it as a gift and hadn't finished it live, the rating would be negative. Overall, about 3.5 out of 10. Under the aforementioned conditions, 5.5 out of 10.

[h1] You can call me an outcast from all humanity, but I like this part! [/h1]

In a threequel that almost no one likes, there are things I like.

[h3] Protagonist [/h3]
At least the dude himself, I like him the most. He's cool, has glasses, and doesn't regret anything.
And he's looking for a part-time job to buy gas so he can continue on his champ-fueled errands.

[h3] Music [/h3]
How could it be without it? It's so invigorating, you just want to run around and take down all the bad guys while listening to this ear-pumping music. My favorite tracks are "Helen" and "Nothing Is Scared," along with a couple of others.

[h3] Plot [/h3]
Even though it's simple, it could go on and on, which I like.

[h3] Voiceover [/h3]
It's done really well here, in the style of old films, as are the scenes themselves, where you can hear Russian voiceover and a bit of the original, which adds a bit of vibe and atmosphere to the old days, for which I salute the developers.

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
Basically, you have to collect something before the enemies arrive and then shoot back. Well, I like simplicity.

[h3] Graphics [/h3]
What can I say about it? I've seen better, of course, but let's forgive 2011 and the Source engine, and especially since the game was made by our own people.

These were the things I liked about the third installment.

[h3] Rating: [/h3]10/10

[h3] Is it worth buying? [/h3] I'll say it's an acquired taste.

Don't listen to the public that's trashing this part; play it yourself and you'll understand. Do you like her? Or are you just becoming a typical normie in a post-society that trashes the third installment, and there are reasons for that.

[h3] Bonus [/h3] 
Here's my sticker pack on Telegram featuring the guy from the third installment: https://t.me/addstickers/P3Dude_by_fStikBot
I don't regret anything

Yeah, it might not be better than P2, but it's definitely not as shitty as I expected reading the comments and reviews. I love the Postal series, and I can say the game is worth checking out, especially if it's on sale or free.

Postal III is a game that unfortunately disappointed many fans of the series. After the success of the previous installments, this release proved to be quite controversial and unsuccessful.

Firstly, the game's technical execution leaves much to be desired. Bugs, crashes, and problematic optimization make gameplay extremely frustrating. Many players encountered lag and low-quality textures, which significantly detracted from the experience and could distract from the main gameplay.

Secondly, the story and gameplay in Postal III were not as engaging as expected. The game lost the unique concept and dark humor for which it was loved. Instead, many scenes feel flat and unoriginal, creating a feeling that the developers didn't put enough effort into the game.

Furthermore, many players note that the game has become too limited in terms of freedom of action compared to its predecessors. This contradicts the spirit of the original games, where players could hint at how they wanted to handle situations.

Overall, Postal III is a disappointment for many fans. It doesn't live up to expectations and feels like a step backwards in the series, which unfortunately leaves a negative impression on players. If you're looking for a high-quality action game with a sharp sense of humor, it's better to consider the earlier games in the series.

Honestly, one of the best games in the Postal series. This is the first and only Postal where you can choose who to be. This is the only Postal where the game is played from a third-person perspective. This is the only Postal where the entire gameplay depends on your every action, which is unusual for this series of games. Of course, there are flaws, such as crashes, you can get stuck in a texture, NPCs with 0 intelligence, but still, don't forget that the game was released in 2011 and has a good storyline. I recommend buying it and I hope it was useful.

column8:
I have no idea what the hell even happened here... The first two Postal games are regarded as masterpieces but this game is quite literally the opposite of what Postal should even be. First of all I hate the fact that it's mission based which isn't what Postal games usually do. There are an unbearable amount of cutscenes it's unbelieveable, Postal 3 is very poorly optimisied and the gameplay is also terrible and buggy as hell. A Postal game made in source. It isn't as funny as Postal 2 at all. However I think Corey Cruise isn't a bad Postal Dude tbh he's probably the highlight of the game. Graphics are somewhat alright and I like the main menu.

If you want to play an actual good or somewhat decent sequel to Postal 2 get either the Paradise Lost DLC or Postal 4: No Regerts, NOT this. 

2/10

column8: Okay, guys, hear me out. It's nothing like Postal, and we can all agree on that. STILL, after playing it for over 2 hours, I had a laugh or two and somehow enjoyed it a little bit on my Steam Deck. Many years later, it feels like just another decent game from the era, BUT! BUT if every mission didn't give that wibe of very closed arena + if the game didn't crash ocassionally, I would definitely enjoy it a little bit more. The game only costs around a single dollar during the sale, and if you have never played the game but only heard how bad it is, then give it a try. With some polish it could be an average game, seriously.

Now I'll try to explain why Postal 3 isn't such a bad game. I'll tell you from my own experience.
I love the Postal series, and I've heard plenty of problems with this game. I played through the middle story ending, and you know what? I didn't experience a single crash or other issue. Some missions were boring and tedious, of course, but that's the foundation of all games. Every game has its flaws. Postal 3 really struck me with the Dude's voice acting. Sure, it's not the same as in Postal 2, but still, the Dude's voice in Postal 3 is fantastic and perfectly suits him, especially the Russian voice acting. The only bad thing I can say is the back view. DAMN IT. It's genuinely awkward at times, and this is the only game in the series with that (aside from the first and redux versions). In the end, what I can say, people, is that I understand that the developers didn't give a shit about the game, and even so, it turned out to be a decent product that's worth playing at least once.

column8:
I'm going to sound like a drama queen, but this is the truth. I underestimated this game's rancid energy. This is the first video game in history where the content made me want to physically throw up. Not the motion, the first level of the game alone. And I can stomach a lot, I listen to GWAR for pete's sake! It does get janky and I often get stuck in the same spot over and over again. 

The only positives was a great soundtrack, a few funny cutscenes that do make me laugh, and the introduction to the talented Corey Cruise, who did an amazing job voice acting both here and Postal: Brain Damaged (I credit him for that game more). Postal is still a great franchise btw. There is much better games to explore than this one. 

Final Verdict: 1.3 Krotchy Dolls out of 5. I need a tall glass of crisp ice water while I atone for my poor decision.

column9:
[h1]I played for 100 minutes and I don't even know where to begin...[/h1]
Maybe because it wasn't developed by Running With Scissors, but by a Russian company called Trashmasters (also known as TM Studios), a subsidiary of Akella, which also distributed this infamous game. But I don't think it's fair to judge just because it wasn't developed by RWS, since Postal Brain Damaged wasn't developed by RWS either, but rather distributed by them, and it's still a very good game. Anyway, getting back to Postal 3, we can start with the fact that the game is poorly optimized. I had three crashes in one day.

The game also has weird gameplay, unrelated to Postal, and not just because it's in third-person. Besides being difficult to control, Postal Dude has a weird weapon switch. Normally, in games, you switch weapons using the mouse scroll wheel (which doesn't work well for me) or the 1, 2, 3, 4 keys... But here, in this game, it's also by numbers, but also by letters. So it's 1, 2, 3, 4, G, N, T, 5... This makes everything more confusing. Plus, the graphics are a bit weird. Even though Postal 2's graphics are outdated, they're still much better done than this game. This game even has some really weird facial expressions. I think even Garry's Mod has better facial expressions.

The humor in this game is really questionable. It's kind of scatological, basically about farts, butts, penises, and piss. It feels like the jokes in this game were made by a 15-year-old trying to be funny.

The game has some pretty silly missions. Like the second mission, where you have to vacuum a sex shop of towels covered in "p0rr4" from men who are amused by adult content. And right after, some feminists enter the store and start protesting, and you have to literally throw towels covered in "p0rr4" at them with the vacuum cleaner... I still think not only the jokes were developed by a 15-year-old boy, but the entire game.

Anyway, right after this mission, you have another mission to capture rabid cats with HIV (???) and you have to use catnip spray to keep them from biting you. But when you catch three, some Chinese guys get pissed off and want to kill you. But you have to catch the rest of the cats while the Chinese attack you, and that's quite difficult, because the enemies have M16s, machetes, pistols, and you have nothing. Just a vacuum cleaner and a fart gun that can knock people out (???). This makes everything very unfair, as it's just one person against a bunch of Chinese guys with real guns, while you have a fart gun...

But, with sacrifice, I got through this level and moved on to the next one, given by Vince, where we have to help one of the Postal Babes at the mall as security, since some feminists were trying to destroy her event. The mission was to shock her with a taser, and that's when the game crashed. That was the moment I gave up playing and asked for a refund. I was even considering keeping the game to have the complete collection, but I preferred to ask for a refund and buy cards to level up on Steam or a better game.

I think the only good part of this game is a meme I didn't know came from here: that "Here kitty, you can have cheeseburger" meme. I didn't know it came from this game, lol.

Anyway, my final thoughts are: if you want to play this game out of curiosity, get the pirated version. It's good that it doesn't cost anything. Or buy it, test it and then ask for a refund, just like me.

The game is buggy, the tutorial is bad, and the annoying controls don't help the outcome much.
I played 88 minutes and I wouldn't play it again even for free.
If someone wants a quality sequel, I can recommend POSTAL 2: Apocalypse weekend and also Paradise lost.

column9:
I should get a refund for pirating this game.
If every video game ever created in history disappeared except this one, it would still be the worst.

I shit on 3, wrote 3, but I couldn't get 3. It felt like I got a huge slap in the face. The jokes are so shamefully cringeworthy that it becomes painful to play, the voice acting is even worse than the game itself, everything that happens in the game makes you wonder, "Why did I even buy this piece of crap 3?" and "Who the hell came up with the idea to make this?" The second part is still tolerable and livable, but the third part is a complete disgrace. I've never seen a worse game and I hope I never will.

This could have been an AWESOME game. I think the missions are pretty interesting, like shooting angry moms with sperm in a sex club or fighting the Chinese over AIDS-infected kitties‚Äîthose are cool ideas. But the game freezes, lags, and crashes VERY often, after which you can only minimize it. RWS could have fixed this part, and I think a HUGE number of fans would have been happy, but they're acting like selfish, resentful little children who don't want to do this out of self-esteem, because this part was made by a different studio. It's a shame, because if not for the technical problems, this part could have been a masterpiece... But I'll still give it a like, even if just to spite RWS!

column8: I like it in a special needs sort of way
column9: I like it in a special needs sort of way

I thoroughly enjoyed the game. I liked it. It's an interesting situation: there are issues with the game design and mechanics, but nevertheless, there are some very good ideas that bring novelty and fun. It felt like some of the game was made by people who simply had no idea what they were doing, what they were doing, or how to do it. As a result, some things turned out well, while others were downright awful. The game's saving grace is its short length, which prevents it from becoming boring. I think the game could have been saved and its ideas developed in future games in the series. Using Courage Bombay's voice acting was a mistake; it's terrible. The game crashed constantly during release. The Steam version runs smoothly on Manjaro Linux.
6 napkins out of 10

column8: yarrak gibi mk!!!!!

My friend gifted me this game for free, I feel like I still spent too much on this game.

The game only has like 2.5-3 hours of gameplay to it, though it's probably only about 2 hours of gameplay because Akilla just decided to give you the bare minimum when it comes to navigating the map. They will RARELY tell you about KEY MECHANICS in the game, they'll just let you figure if out for yourself after countless rounds of trial and error. Enemies also are just ridiculously beefy, and getting ammo for anything that isn't the pistol or assault rifle is almost impossible.  In the final section of the good ending, I literally had to fight through Venezuelan solders with barely any ammo because it's sparse. And I even had to fight a fucking TANK and I BARELY had any rocket ammo because it gave me the launcher at the END OF THE GAME. Speaking of the rocket launcher, I don't know what was wrong with its M1, but it would blow up in my face anytime I'd press or hold M1, but it would heatseek whenever I M2. 

Catnip is the only consumable, and the "Niptrip"(my shortened term) isn't even worth it. Instead of getting what feels like 30 seconds of slowed time, you get about 10 seconds of slowed time, you move a little slower too, AND the color palette is migraine inducing- NOT TO MENTION the fact that you get STUCK HALF THE TIME you use it.

The AI pathfinding is the most agitating thing to exist, it's like they intentionally made the companions find every way to slow you down so you have to play the game longer. When a character has to live and you have to get to a certain location, the NPC HAS TO GET TO THE LOCATION TOO. You can't just run through and get to the location to start the cutscene, you HAVE to get the NPC to the location too. Sometimes the NPC's will get stuck in place, run directly into hazards, or they'll decide to go on a side-quest to slay a magic dragon until you reset their pathfinding by tasing them or running into them to knock them down. 

The keybinds are stupid and disorienting, you can't jump, you can't crouch, but you can take cover... which is the only semi-redeemable thing about movement. The running is BAD, you have to sling your mouse to the side like it owes you money if you wanna turn, otherwise you run into a wall like my grandma when she gets belligerent. The movement itself is also shit it's not limited to running. You can only crouch if you're next to cover, but enemies can still shoot you if their gun is even a quark above your cover. You can climb over cover if it's short enough, but you have to button mash until Dude invents the ability to use hands and feet at the same time. Moving across cover is slower than a turtle with a deep vein thrombosis, so you're better off getting off of cover and moving to where you want to get. 

Doors are a whole other monster, good fucking luck getting through one when you're close to failing a mission. In the good ending, there's a section where you have to arrest the ecologists leader... In my run, the front door was glitched and would NOT let me walk through it. I almost died to a swarm of bees because there was some dude in a corner throwing beehives, and I couldn't shoot back at him because he was thundercunting hives at the door. So I had to go through the back door, which the game did a great job of telling me about. 

There's 2 paths to the game... the good path... and the insane path. I only did the insane path because it was faster and I had no idea what I was doing, but I'd rather eat glass than play the game again and do the good path. 

Allies will just randomly decide to shoot you when in combat, and you literally have to evade them until they find an enemy to shoot, or lose aggro. Because if you shoot them, then you'll have to deal with fighting both factions involved in the fight- or- they might just all aggro onto you for no reason, but you won't be forced to kill them all until you kill one of them.

The game straight up gives you the least helpful descriptions, so you're just left with a vague idea of where you're meant to go. Which ends up making you spend more time on the game than you should(playing the game alone still takes too much time, it's not worth it, don't buy it.).

There's "Optional Fun" objectives that just feel impossible, like... there's literally a mission where you defend playboy bunny Jennifer Walcott from a bunch of angry hockey moms, and you're SUPPOSED to use a taser to taze the 15-20 soccer moms, and wait for Jennifer to oh so SLOWLY kill them with a shovel, all while you have to protect her so she doesn't die. 
The game was VERY motion sickness inducing, though that might just be a neurological and optical skill issue on my part.

There's more I'd like to rant about, but I feel that even hating on the game is giving too much praise.

Edit: I did the good ending because a friend didn't believe me when I told them how bad this game was... jesus fucking christ... I would have had a more enjoyable time eating sandpaper with a side of neutron star. The good ending makes me wish the primordial soup wasn't an option on gods menu, because I refuse to believe that we evolved as a species and made THIS "game". This game should be against the Geneva Convention, it is a genuine hazard to the population and was something even Satan would deem "too harsh". I wouldn't wish this game upon my worst enemies. I would rather experience EVERY death(possible and not) over and over again for eternity, than play whatever the FUCK this shit is. RWS, we thank you for shitting on this disaster.



TL:DR... If you want a game with nonsensical chaos and humor fit for something on Adult Swim... go play the other Postal games, or play Saints Row 3(1 and 2 are the goats, but they're not as chaotic as 3)

column8: very fun after the patchs, not as bad as it was.
column9: very fun after the patchs, not as bad as it was.

A game deservedly drowned in its own crap due to its sheer unplayability at launch.

The same thing that plagued Fallout: New Vegas. But while Vegas was fixed, it seems they only recently managed to polish this game to a playable state (completely breaking the achievement system).

I've heard that this game isn't worth buying, even for the measly 40 rubles it's being sold for. And that even a Uwe Boll film would be better than this game.
And yes, the film is indeed better, but I disagree with the first statement.

The game is engaging. It's enjoyable to shoot, has great music, and a very cool visual style. Both the graphics and the interface are excellent. Even the third-person perspective is well-executed, in my opinion.

The plot, while disjointed and unfinished, is divided into three endings, one of which is crap, and the others are simply boring to get, but there is a plot, and it's... well, okay. There are jokes, and they're funny. And the game takes 3-4 hours to complete, just like the first two games. But unlike those, there are some questionable moments, like the incredibly boring tutorial.

I encountered exactly zero bugs. Perhaps I was lucky, but there wasn't a single problem.

But the game still deviates greatly from the original. Obviously, Postal's film is a much bigger inspiration than the first two games. But the developers know the plot, as they accurately recounted it at the beginning.
I don't know why they did this, because the film itself, while very much in the spirit of Postal, strayed too far from it. It's the same story here. But at least the guy is similar to the original.

Postal 3 is worth buying for 40 rubles if you like Postal, and especially if you liked the film. As of today, you can play it from start to finish. It's possible, but not necessarily necessary.

I played the game right after its release in 2011. It was a pirated copy. Oddly enough, I really liked it back then, although even then it was considered trash, to put it mildly. There were minimal bugs. I completed it about six times, getting both endings (Bad and Good). And now, 13 years later, I'm already 30. I decided to play the licensed version on Steam. The game was dirt cheap. Why not? What can I say about it in 2024? I completed the game once, getting the good ending, in 3 hours. During that time, there were 3 critical errors and 4 crashes. Dozens of bugs. And most importantly, about 10 achievements didn't count. They simply don't work. The game is completely empty, uninteresting, stupid, boring, and dull. Completely different emotions after 13 years. If anyone reads this comment about this game). In 2024, the game is trash in every form. In 2011, I would have given it a 9 out of 10. Now it's a 1 for nostalgia. How things change.
It's not as bad as I thought, but it would be nice to install some mods and fixes.

AVISO, essa review de merda sobre esse jogo de merda vai ter spoiler pra caralho, principalmente do Postal 3, e uns pouqu√≠ssimos sobre os outros, voc√™ foi avisado.

Eu iria jogar o jogo completo antes de fazer a review, mas eu acabei desistindo dessa ideia de t√£o ruim e pat√©tico que esse jogo √©. Eu t√¥ pouco me fudendo sobre o resto da hist√≥ria, o √∫nico motivo que eu comprei esse jogo foi pra ter todos os jogos da franquia Postal, EU ME ARREPENDO AMARGAMENTE.

Coisas que eu gostei do jogo:
Apesar desse jogo ser a pior coisa que eu joguei desde que eu nasci, tem algumas (poucas) coisas que eu gostei desse jogo.

* O sistema de karma - Pelo o que eu saiba (n√£o vi gameplay do Postal 4 e nem do Brain Damaged pra saber direito) esse √© o √∫nico jogo dessa franquia que genuinamente tem um sistema que suas escolhas importam (eu n√£o t√¥ contando o Paradise Lost porque literalmente a √∫nica coisa que muda se voc√™ jogar o jogo INTEIRO sem matar UMA pessoa √© uns dialogo diferenciado na boss fight contra a Bitch), mesmo que fa√ßa literalmente nenhum sentido o DUDE ser um POLICIAL no jogo (eu vejo o Dude como um cara neutro, mas ai vai pra vis√£o de cada pessoa e que se foda).

* Aba pra ver os objetivos das miss√µes - No Postal 2 e Paradise Lost (se o Mike J, vulgo copropriet√°rio da RWS considera o Paradise Lost trata o Paradise Lost como outro jogo, eu tamb√©m vou) pra voc√™ ver os objetivos das miss√µes voc√™ tem que apertar o mapa pra ver os objetivos, √© algo demorado? Nem tanto, mas s√≥ o fato de voc√™ poder continuar jogando o jogo sem ter que "pausar" pra ver os objetivos √© libertante... ou melhor, seria se o jogo em quest√£o n√£o fosse o Postal 3.

* O modelo do Postal Dude - Tem alguma coisa nesse modelo que eu acho melhor doq o do Postal 2 e do Postal 4 (s√≥ perde pro Dude do Postal Brain Damaged).

Coisas que odiei do jogo:
Depois de dar 3 min√∫sculas colheres de ch√° pra essa merda de jogo do caralho, bora pro que interessa.

* A IA pat√©tica e estupida desse jogo - Se voc√™ pegasse uma crian√ßa de 3 anos pra fazer a IA desse jogo, ela iria fazer algo melhor. Eu perdi a conta de quantas vezes eu vi NPC inimigo ignorando o Dude, NPC inimigo atirando no ch√£o, NPC amigo sendo uns retardados do caralho, NPC inimigo estando com uma fucking PISTOLA e fazendo quest√£o de chegar perto pra caralho do Dude pra atirar, √© cada p√©rola de merda que a IA desse jogo traz que eu quis me matar.

* As miss√µes repetitivas, sem sal e claramente feitas pra voc√™ n√£o poder reembolsar esse jogo - Puta que pariu, as miss√µes desse jogo, eu originalmente comprei esse jogo tanto porque queria ter todos os jogos da franquia Postal e tanto porque eu achei que seria aquele jogo ruim engra√ßado, mas eu tava errado, puta que pariu, como eu tava MUITO errado. Todas as miss√µes s√£o praticamente as mesmas, o Dude vai l√°, acontece alguma merda no lugar que ele foi e ele tem que matar (ou usar o taser se voc√™ for delirado o suficiente pra querer fazer o final pacifista) um monte de npc aleat√≥rio e acaba a miss√£o, toda, santa, miss√£o. Provavelmente tem alguma boss fight pra frente, mas agora eu n√£o t√¥ com saco pra verificar essa merda. Aproveitando que eu t√¥ falando de miss√£o, quem foi o filho da puta do caralho que decidiu colocar uma miss√£o que tu tem que matar 20 animais? Aquelas merda tem nem hitbox direito.

* As miss√µes claramente n√£o balanceadas - Isso pode ser s√≥ porque eu sou ruim mesmo, mas caralho, eu quero saber quem foi o filho da puta que decidiu que seria uma boa ideia colocar na SEGUNDA miss√£o do jogo pro Dude resgatar 15 gatos enquanto uns chin√™s arrombados querem matar o Dude. Brother, o Dude sequer tem arma direito nesse ponto do jogo. √â um spam de inimigo t√£o fudido em toda miss√£o que tem mod feito pra balancear os objetivos. E sabe qual o pior? Esse jogo sequer tem uma sele√ß√£o de dificuldade. Ou tu joga essa porra desbalanceada, ou instala mod, ou simplesmente n√£o joga (recomendo a ultima), simplesmente rid√≠culo. 

* O humor sem sal pra caralho - Nem parece que eu t√¥ jogando um jogo do Postal. Eu genuinamente n√£o consigo lembrar de nenhuma cena engra√ßada nesse jogo, e olha que no Paradise Lost teve piada de merda.

* O spam de cutscene - A cada 2 minutos de gamplay √© 5 cutscenes, quem foi o retardado que achou que seria uma boa ideia colocar tanta cutscene no jogo?

* TU N√ÉO CONSEGUE PULAR - A Trashmasters (depois de jogar o jogo eu entendi o porque do nome) achou que seria uma ideia tirar uma mec√¢nica B√ÅSICA de um jogo e inv√©s disso colocar uma mec√¢nica de que voc√™ precisa chegar perto de um objeto, apertar o bot√£o de agachar (que por sinal s√≥ funciona se voc√™ estiver perto de um objeto) e SE o objeto for alto o suficiente, aperta denovo que o Dude vai passar por cima. E ainda por cima, tem a mec√¢nica de correr, que quando voc√™ corre por cima de um inimigo, ele vai cair, que seria uma mec√¢nica at√© que legal SE A TELA N√ÉO FICASSE BALAN√áANDO QUE NEM MEU PAU √ÅS 3 DA MANH√É QUANDO TU CORRE.

* Os mapas vazios - Inv√©s de seguir com UM estilo de jogo (linear ou mundo aberto) esse imbecis decidiram juntar os dois, dai em algumas miss√µes o jogo √© linear, e no outro √© LINEAR E MUNDO ABERTO AO MESMO TEMPO. Essas porra desses mapas s√£o t√£o vazios que eu tenho certeza que eu no Microsoft Paint faria um design melhor, resumindo, as cidades s√£o pr√©dio, asfalto, lojinha, e mais nada. Sem casa pra voc√™ ir dentro e roubar, sem banco pra tamb√©m roubar, NADA.

* Conquistas n√£o funcionam - Voc√™ quer fazer o 100% nesse jogo? Que pena, voc√™ vai ter que usar aplicativo pra desbloquear conquista na Steam pra isso.

* Crashes constantes - Era pra eles terem arrumado isso em um patch recente (junto com as conquistas), arrumou? N√£o. Eu n√£o joguei o jogo antigamente, provavelmente tava pior, mas puta que pariu, ainda sim, ta crashando MUITO.

* Por que esse jogo √© em terceira pessoa? - Como se n√£o bastasse o sistema de "luta" rid√≠culo, eles ainda v√£o l√° e decidem fazer um jogo em TERCEIRA PESSOA em uma engine feita para jogos de PRIMEIRA PESSOA, eu nem teria tanto problema com isso, se ao menos fosse bom feito, √© de fuder,

Tem muito mais coisas que eu poderia ter falado nessa review, mas honestamente, eu j√° gastei mais tempo do que eu deveria, tanto jogando o jogo quanto escrevendo essa review. 

Se eu consegui convencer ao menos UMA pessoa a n√£o comprar esse jogo, eu j√° vou ficar feliz. Se voc√™ quer jogar uma continua√ß√£o BOA do Postal 2, compra o Paradise Lost. √â o mesmo pre√ßo mas √© muito melhor (se o seu PC for meio antigo talvez o Paradise Lost crashe quando vc iniciar, mas tem alguns tutorias na internet de como resolver isso).
column9:
WARNING: This shitty review of this shitty game will contain a ton of spoilers, especially for Postal 3, and a few for the others. You've been warned.

I was going to play the full game before writing this review, but I ended up giving up on that idea because it's so bad and pathetic. I don't give a damn about the rest of the story; the only reason I bought this game was to have all the games in the Postal franchise. I BITTERLY REGRET IT.

Things I liked about the game:
Although this game is the worst thing I've played since I was born, there are a few (few) things I liked about it.

* The karma system - As far as I know (I haven't seen gameplay from Postal 4 or Brain Damaged to know for sure), this is the only game in this franchise that genuinely has a system where your choices matter (I'm not counting Paradise Lost because literally the only thing that changes if you play the ENTIRE game without killing ONE person is some different dialogue in the boss fight against Bitch), even though it makes literally no sense for DUDE to be a COP in the game (I see Dude as a neutral guy, but that depends on each person's perspective and who cares).

* Tab to view mission objectives - In Postal 2 and Paradise Lost (if Mike J, aka co-owner of RWS, considers Paradise Lost to be another game, I do too), to see the mission objectives you have to tap the map to see the objectives. Is it time-consuming? Not really, but just the fact that you can continue playing the game without having to "pause" to see the objectives is liberating... or rather, it would be if the game in question weren't Postal 3.

* The Postal Dude model - There's something about this model that I think is better than the ones in Postal 2 and Postal 4 (second only to the Dude from Postal Brain Damaged).

Things I hated about the game:
After giving this shitty game three tiny teaspoons of criticism, let's get down to business.

* The pathetic and stupid AI in this game - If you got a 3-year-old to design this game's AI, they'd do better. I've lost count of how many times I've seen enemy NPCs ignoring the Dude, enemy NPCs shooting at the ground, friendly NPCs being fucking retarded, enemy NPCs wielding a fucking GUN and insisting on getting so close to the Dude to shoot. The AI ‚Äã‚Äãin this game is so damn shitty that I wanted to kill myself.

* The repetitive, tasteless missions, clearly designed to make you unable to refund this game - Holy shit, the missions in this game. I originally bought this game so much because I wanted to own every game in the Postal franchise and so much because I thought it would be that funny, bad game, but I was wrong, holy shit, I was SO wrong. All the missions are practically the same: the Dude goes there, something bad happens where he went, and he has to kill (or taser if you're delusional enough to want the pacifist ending) a bunch of random NPCs, and then the mission, the whole damn mission, ends. There's probably a boss fight coming up, but I don't feel like checking that shit out right now. While I'm on the subject of missions, who the fuck decided to put a mission where you have to kill 20 animals? That shit doesn't even have a proper hitbox.

* The clearly unbalanced missions - This might just be because I'm bad, but damn, I want to know who the fuck decided it would be a good idea to put the game's SECOND mission for Dude to rescue 15 cats while some Chinese jerks want to kill Dude. Bro, Dude doesn't even have a proper weapon at this point in the game. He's such a fucked-up enemy spam in every mission that there's a mod made to balance the objectives. And you know what's worse? This game doesn't even have a difficulty setting. You either play this unbalanced shit, install a mod, or just don't play (I recommend the latter), it's simply ridiculous.

* The completely unbalanced humor - It doesn't even feel like I'm playing a Postal game. I genuinely can't think of a single funny scene in this game, and Paradise Lost had some really shitty jokes.

* Cutscene spam - Every 2 minutes of gameplay, there are 5 cutscenes. Who was the retard who thought it would be a good idea to put so many cutscenes in the game?

* YOU CAN'T JUMP - Trashmasters (after playing the game, I understood the name) thought it would be a good idea to remove a BASIC mechanic from a game and instead put in a mechanic where you need to get close to an object, press the crouch button (which, by the way, only works if you're close to an object), and IF the object is high enough, press it again and the Dude will walk over it. And on top of that, there's the running mechanic, which means when you run over an enemy, they'll fall, which would be a pretty cool mechanic IF THE SCREEN DIDN'T JOLLY SHAKE LIKE MY DICK AT 3 AM WHEN YOU RUN.

* The empty maps - Instead of sticking with ONE game style (linear or open world), these idiots decided to combine the two. So, in some missions, the game is linear, and in others, it's LINEAR AND OPEN WORLD AT THE SAME TIME. These damn maps are so empty that I'm sure I could design them better in Microsoft Paint. In short, the cities are just buildings, asphalt, little shops, and nothing else. No houses to go into and rob, no banks to rob, NOTHING.

* Achievements don't work - Want to get 100% in this game? Too bad, you'll have to use an achievement-unlocking app on Steam for that.

* Constant crashes - They should have fixed this in a recent patch (along with the achievements). Did they? No. I haven't played the game back then, it was probably worse, but damn, it still crashes A LOT.

* Why is this game in third person? - As if the ridiculous "fighting" system wasn't enough, they even decided to make a THIRD PERSON game in an engine designed for FIRST PERSON games. I wouldn't even have that much of a problem with that, if only it were well-made. It's a pain.

There are so many more things I could have said in this review, but honestly, I've already spent more time than I should have, both playing the game and writing this review.

If I can convince even ONE person not to buy this game, I'll be happy. If you want to play a GOOD sequel to Postal 2, buy Paradise Lost. It's the same price but it's much better (if your PC is a bit old, Paradise Lost might crash when you start it, but there are some tutorials on the internet on how to solve this).

column8: An underrated gem
column9: An underrated gem

Postal III is a game that leaves players frustrated and negative. Let's start with the graphics ‚Äì they were outdated even at the time of release, with textures looking blurry and unpolished, and character animations feeling cheap and unconvincing. This creates a feeling that the game is lagging behind modern standards and is not visually enjoyable.

The plot of Postal III also leaves much to be desired. It feels pointless, absurd, and often offensive. The characters are unlikable, and their actions and dialogue often feel primitive and inappropriate. The lack of an engaging narrative makes the gameplay monotonous and boring.

The gameplay of Postal III also leaves much to be desired. The controls feel awkward and unintuitive, making progression difficult. The combat system is dull and repetitive, and missions often boil down to simply killing enemies without any strategy or tactics.

Technical issues are also present in Postal III. The game frequently crashes, freezes, or becomes unstable, creating additional inconvenience for players. The lack of developer support makes fixing these issues nearly impossible.

Overall, Postal III is a game that doesn't deserve your time or attention. It offers nothing new or interesting, but rather disappoints and disgusts. If you value high-quality games with good storytelling, gameplay, and graphics, it's best to avoid this game and choose something more worthy of your attention.

column8:
Oh shit, where to start?

I purchased this game on sale (oh Steam Holiday sale, thou art a fickle temptress), and I wouldn‚Äôt have had it any other way. Except maybe having never purchased it at all, of course.

If you do a quick search of any other reviews of this game, you‚Äôre liable to find a whole lot of slander. And it‚Äôs sort of difficult to blame them. Rather than do the usual review format, I‚Äôm going to take you on a timeline breakdown of the shitstorm I endured to beat the game.

There‚Äôs a narrative string beginning at the start of the game with ‚ÄúPostal Dude‚Äù being interviewed by someone. This serves as a decent way to recap the previous game‚Äôs events in comic panel style, which also gives a bit of narration between missions. It actually comes across rather well, but can do little to save this game from itself, beginning with the tutorial mission.

The tutorial mission briefly introduces the new cover system, using grenades and using the gas can and match combo. The cover system is mildly important as Postal 3 has no health packs, but it does have auto-regenerating health. This takes away from some of the chaos as all you have to do to heal up is to duck out of combat for a little while, but since most of the enemies you‚Äôll face in the game are quickly defeated with one or two shots to the face, you honestly shouldn‚Äôt ever have to use cover unless you have crap aim or find yourself up against a dozen enemies at once.

Somehow, the gas can has actually gotten worse from a tech standpoint from the previous game. Even in the tutorial level where three zombies are ambling around in a pit, it‚Äôs extremely difficult to see where the gas has landed and if any is sticking to the ground or enemies. Even after emptying half a tank and throwing a half dozen matches, nothing caught fire. I ended up dancing around the pit and trying over and over for almost five minutes, as you cannot move on until the zombies are dead. This was about as shitty a first impression as you could get.

After escaping the fallout of the town from Postal 2, you end up in the city of Catharsis, possibly the only clever thing this game does. Unfortunately, the bad tutorial turns into a worse first mission as you‚Äôre employed at a local sex shop and given a shop vac to clean up the patrons‚Äô many discarded spunk rags around the place. The shop is raided by hockey moms, whose leader looks suspiciously like a failed vice presidential candidate, and since you‚Äôve been given no weapons so far, your only means of recourse is to shoot spunk rags from your shop vac at the hockey moms to repel them. It‚Äôs a bit unfair as some of them have pistols, and you have to protect the shop owner from dying. There might be some cheap thrill here with polygon tits, but anything graphically sexual has been censored so the first mission is just a tease of a mundane game to come.

The mediocrity continues in mission two as you‚Äôre given a single can of ‚Äúindustrial strength‚Äù catnip to subdue a bunch of crazed, HIV-positive cats before picking them up. There‚Äôs more catnip to be found near the mission start area, but the game has no helpful arrows or glowing item locators to assist with any mission objectives. To make matters even worse, after you pick up three of the angry felines, ‚Äúthe guys from the mexi-sushi place‚Äù (literally, Asian guys wearing giant sombreros ) come at you with machetes, pistols and assault rifles for stealing their ‚Äústock‚Äù. It‚Äôs impossibly unfair, as all you have is your fists, the non-damage-dealing shop vac, and a handful of cats to throw at them. There‚Äôs no point in trying to run from them as they follow you everywhere the cats could be for collection, so it‚Äôs necessary to murder one to get his weapon and thus defend yourself from the rest.

This highlights one of the worst problems of the game: The AI is either too dumb to escape a single exit room, or they‚Äôre robotic bloodhounds tracking you down without any line of sight or noise giving you away. This becomes problematic during missions where you have to exterminate everyone to proceed, as there‚Äôs no indicator of where these moronic NPCs might be. Like the absent mission objective indicator, this serves as just another mechanism to wander aimlessly through the map until you find your goal by accident.

You soon encounter eco-terrorists, a pop culture menace that was looking pretty tired in the late 90s, and Osama bin Laden, showing pretty clearly that this game was conceived in the early 2000s. A strangely fat Al Gore also shows up, owner of a Segway dealership and repeat cameo appearance in a number of missions.

It‚Äôs all very rote. The game latches on to its two gimmicks (the shop vac and Segway driving) for a few missions throughout the game, and every other mission is a matter of either shooting or tasering everyone between you and the exit. You play bodyguard at a mall, do a delivery mission in the same mall, break out of dog obedience school, break out of an animal testing lab, break out of prison, break out of a theme park‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs a series of flat textured office building interiors, small and poorly mapped towns, and the flimsiest of excuses to shoot people in the head.

Unlike the first and second games, there‚Äôs no sense of vengeance or even purpose to the objectives in this game. Each mission is either trying to earn some money, trying to find/free your dog or running away from the angry mob one of the previous two objectives riled up.

Most bizarrely, there‚Äôs a convoluted morality system to Postal 3. You can shoot, murder, and maim everyone you encounter like in previous games, or you can be a ‚Äúgood‚Äù guy by tasering and arresting people instead. Theoretically, this offers you slightly different missions and ultimately a different ending, but considering that using firearms is significantly faster than using the tazer and the whole notion of being a pacifist flies in the face of the entire franchise, it‚Äôs strange to even consider this as the preferred play style. And yet, after having finished this miserable game, I received ‚Äúthe bad ending‚Äù by not choosing the tazer path.

According to my Steam time played indicator, I finished off my first play-through of Postal 3 in a mere four hours, which I consider to be more appropriate for an Indie game than a full title, and yet this punchbowl full of turds is still priced at 30 bucks after being released in late 2011. Between multiple story paths and achievements which would be possible in a single play-through, Postal 3 presents itself as a full-fledged game but carries with it all the gimmicks of an XBLA game expecting multiple replays.

I can pretty safely say I won‚Äôt be revisiting Postal 3. I purchased it on sale and naively failed to check reviews, relying purely on fond memories of Postal 2.

It wouldn‚Äôt have taken very much to make this a much better game. Clear objective indicators, less use of gimmicks, a defined ‚Äúone way or another‚Äù story path that you could choose in menus rather than a penalty for killing the wrong group of people, more determination from the main character‚Ä¶ but instead we‚Äôre left with what feels like a half-finished effort, and the negatives simply drag this title down from being crude fun to being almost unplayable.

Final Score: Even if you got it for free, you‚Äôd regret wasting your time.

column8:
After 100%ing the achievements and playing the game alot, here is my definitive review.

Postal 3 has it's fans, Im one of them, people may hate this game's guts and I can see why, but this postal game is more fun than postal 2. my personal opinion. The gun play is well done enough for some enjoyment, the missions may not be the best ever but they aren't super repetitive, the story is postal enough, corey cruise does an excellent job at being a postal dude, and the level design does has some charm to it. the sound track is okay at best, some songs being better than any other ones.  postal 3 is recommended to be played with the ultrapatch mod, it fixes alot of bugs and makes the game so much more fun.

column8: Postal 3 is a disappointing sequel to the beloved Postal 2. The game abandoned the open world aspect that made its predecessor great, they instead opted for more liner and restrictive levels. The gameplay is very lacking, the combat is unsatisfying, with a bad case of an unreliable crosshair, the added karma system was poorly implemented, and the story is weak and questionable. The game takes place right after the events of [b] Apocalypse Weekend [/b] , the postal dude finds himself stuck in the town of Catharisis, running odd jobs for the promise of money, which usually doesn't go to plan. Sadly, the game's poor outcome is due to a heavily rushed development during the 2008 recession, giving us this poor excuse of a game. A lot of the problems have been patched, plus the addition of the fart gun DLC, but it still has a few problems. Achievements are broken, and the game still crashes. Postal 3 is a game that I would not recommend to anyone. I still can't believe this game runs on the Source Engine, the engine that brought us Half-Life 2 and Left 4 Dead. I highly recommend that you don't buy this game, the story has been recon, so you're not missing anything, but if you insist on trying the game, get it during a sale for like a dollar. You will regret everything when you play this game.
column9: Postal 3 is a disappointing sequel to the beloved Postal 2. The game abandoned the open world aspect that made its predecessor great, they instead opted for more liner and restrictive levels. The gameplay is very lacking, the combat is unsatisfying, with a bad case of an unreliable crosshair, the added karma system was poorly implemented, and the story is weak and questionable. The game takes place right after the events of [b] Apocalypse Weekend [/b] , the postal dude finds himself stuck in the town of Catharisis, running odd jobs for the promise of money, which usually doesn't go to plan. Sadly, the game's poor outcome is due to a heavily rushed development during the 2008 recession, giving us this poor excuse of a game. A lot of the problems have been patched, plus the addition of the fart gun DLC, but it still has a few problems. Achievements are broken, and the game still crashes. Postal 3 is a game that I would not recommend to anyone. I still can't believe this game runs on the Source Engine, the engine that brought us Half-Life 2 and Left 4 Dead. I highly recommend that you don't buy this game, the story has been recon, so you're not missing anything, but if you insist on trying the game, get it during a sale for like a dollar. You will regret everything when you play this game.

spoiled

Running With Scissors' Postal duology was for the gaming industry what Troma's provocative films were for Hollywood. Like films like Bloodsucking Freaks or Nazi Surfers Must Die, the hyperbolic violence, sexual perversion, and dark humor in Postal 1 and 2 juxtaposed sharp social themes and a vicious satire of modern society. Therefore, Running With Scissors head Vince Daisy, echoing director Lloyd Kaufman, could well have exclaimed, "I'm not making trash, I'm making art!"

However, when Vince decided to collaborate with Akella on the third installment, true trash in the worst sense of the word began. A studio with the appropriate name, Trashmasters, participated in the development on the Russian side. The result was not a hooligan provocation, but garbage in the form of computer code, which was burned onto disks for some reason and‚Äîoh, horror!‚Äîwas just a waste of time. ‚Äî they're trying to sell us. Postal 3 was conceived as the next step in the series' evolution. While in the first game, players found themselves in the role of the deranged Dude, primarily aimlessly shooting civilians and animals in various city districts, the second game had much more substance. A more or less coherent plot emerged, allowing the protagonist to freely roam the vast Paradise City and complete various missions. Vince Dazey promised that the new game would make the virtual world even more open, and that players would have personal transportation.

After the partnership between Running With Scissors and Trashmasters began, no one remembered these promises. Instead of developing into a hyper-violent GTA with a clear satirical message, Postal 3, on the contrary, degenerated to the level of the first game. The city of Catharsis, where the Dude moved after destroying his previous home with a nuclear explosion, is smaller than Paradise City, and there's not even a hint of freedom on its streets. The entire game is a series of simple missions across several districts. They typically revolve around shooting dozens of clones, and they all begin almost identically. Seeking a living, the Dude takes low-paying jobs, most often vacuuming up animal droppings, apples, or dirty handkerchiefs in a brothel. Then he's attacked by clones‚Äîin other words, identical enemies.

Identical clones of civilians wander aimlessly through the streets, unfazed by the corpses of your enemies. The developers didn't live up to our expectations when it came to transportation: the only rides available were the infamous Seagway scooters. But they're unpleasant to drive: the two-wheeled vehicles behave like irons on ice. However, even in this form, Postal 3 had the potential to be a decent parody action game. Here you can encounter Arab terrorists led by Osama bin Laden, work for a former porn mogul turned mayor, and assassinate hapless director Uwe Boll. You can throw beehives at your enemies, shoot them with a vacuum cleaner, torment them with a portable badger, and set your beloved dog, the Dude, cats, and monkeys on your opponents. Aggressive animals do very unpleasant things to people.

For fans of traditional violence, there are shotguns, machine guns, assault rifles, grenades, and even a cover system. The execution ruins everything. Running With Scissors wasn't directly involved in the development, and it shows: Postal 3 is made in the worst traditions of Russian action games. In short, it's a very buggy, unoptimized shooter with awkward controls (you can get neurotic while you're trying to find the right weapon), completely stupid enemies, and a pathetic, cheap design. The cover system is just there for show, and of the wide variety of weapons, only a couple of guns and, dare I say it, "gadgets" are actually useful.

As you know, the head of a company that produces Segways died while riding his creation. He lost control and fell into a river. A similar thing happened with Postal 3. Due to the developers' desire to shock the audience at any cost, the project has devolved into an unplayable trashy parody of itself. While the second game was perfectly playable, and many found it enjoyable, albeit in a peculiar way, the mechanics of Postal 3 are completely unsatisfactory and evoke associations with piles of manure that the main character regularly cleans up. It's a pity that there is no suitable vacuum cleaner at hand.

column8: I bought the game because I thought it was going to be the "funny" type of bad. I was wrong, it's the "boring" type of bad. It literally just feels like a poorly made fan game. Not to mention that it was made with source (not that I have a problem with source, I just feel like its immoral to make a bad game with the engine), and the game actually uses some source sound effects.
column9: I bought the game because I thought it was going to be the "funny" type of bad. I was wrong, it's the "boring" type of bad. It literally just feels like a poorly made fan game. Not to mention that it was made with source (not that I have a problem with source, I just feel like its immoral to make a bad game with the engine), and the game actually uses some source sound effects.

Before I decided to launch this game, I watched a bunch of videos about how terrible it was. Once I actually played it myself and figured out what it was, I came to the conclusion that it's a dubious game, but not as unbearable as many people say.

The achievements in this game are super cool, of course, in a bad way, since this was the first time I had to search through countless places just to get a coveted, useless medal, just to understand how broken and abandoned everything is. I didn't live through the moment when there were some achievements that were supposedly easy but incredibly difficult to obtain due to their quirks, and some worked in a really weird and crazy way. But I did live through the moment when RVS themselves, who had really pissed me off, decided to take the game back and fix it a bit, ultimately breaking the story achievements in an insanely stupid way: the trash masters specified in the game's code that a line had to be disabled using a specific number, which was causing a lot of glitches, but RVS, apparently not understanding what was written there, decided to enable it. That's precisely why I'll have to dig into the game's code and manually fix this absolutely stupid bug, which wasn't even the masters' fault.

The music is debatable: apparently everyone praises it, but I love some of the tracks, while others feel like they don't fit the game at all and were inserted by accident.

A few words about this point: the tutorial... Eh, they really have to try hard to make the game's intro so bad, with its clunkiness and stupidity. Why the hell do you need to learn how to throw grenades, set zombies on fire with a monstrously pathetic napalm, shoot soldiers in the face with pepper spray, and so on?

There are a lot of weapons in this game, perhaps even too many that are useless to the player, although for me that's not really a problem. For example, I like the badger: it's cool in concept, appearance, and damage, although even its operation is sloppy. At least the grenades are well-designed, seriously, and you can actually use them effectively, unlike in other games, where they're not particularly useful.

I really like the graphics in this game, I won't argue with that. The city of Catharsis itself is quite interesting in terms of design, but the idea that you have to complete the game to freely explore it is literally too linear (there are two storylines, but they remain linear). The people look...okay, basically. Personally, I just find the old and fat (well-fed) people a bit too cartoonish, so they're the only ones I don't like. In any case, the graphics of everything in the three are an order of magnitude superior to everything in the four.

The drawn cutscenes are okay, basically, the rest are just...ugh. They might be a bit cheesy at first, but then they get annoying with the constant whipping sound, unfunny captions for every occasion, meaningless gags, and the poor, half-comic-style filter. I won't even mention that these theatrical productions are so surreal that I don't want to waste my time on them, although I will say that Part 4 also has some ridiculous things going on, only it's even worse. The original voice acting is okay, but the Russian one is just awful. Kurazhik might be a laughing stock for some, but he really pissed me off from the very beginning, and yet I still beat the game with him. It was only later that I discovered the original version was in the files, but it doesn't count against your playtime. Incidentally, the guy has a cool voice actor in it; I probably even like him more than in the other parts, but that's just me, IMHO.

Gameplay features... So, for some reason, we have constant shaking while running; instead of various healing mods, you heal over time in an incomprehensible way; for some reason, in almost every mission, you have to finish off some stupid NPC who's stopped dead by some evil guy with a gun or a stick; for some reason, they made the gameplay third-person; it's unclear why they came up with so many bosses, which are ultimately very flawed, some of them downright broken‚Äîwhy do they even exist?

How can we avoid the most fun part: the withdrawals. The game is covered in it to the max: it's literally one of the things that greatly influences my attitude towards it. When it wants, it crashes; when it wants, it gives you that ill-fated achievement that makes you grind the same mission over and over again; when it wants, it makes enemies and allies too dumb for this world; when it wants, it breaks achievements for completing it one way or another (though I'm actually glad about that, since I didn't have to replay it that much); when it wants, weapons can work fine or they can malfunction. The game is so unfinished and broken in almost every aspect that it's obvious to the naked eye, and I don't care what those who try to cover it up say.

When the game wasn't even close to finished, its early versions won some good awards, so perhaps it even could have been that NEW BREAKTHROUGH GAME IN THE POSRAL FRANCHISE, but alas, it didn't happen. The game is generally tolerable despite its poor performance, but I can't hide my resentment for the game we lost. The idea that RVS is great, that they've been trashing the 3D for years, and that Akella deservedly took the crap, is so widespread. However, I believe they're all to blame for this hell: RVS barely did anything because they figured Akella could handle it themselves, would make them a cool game for free, and everything would be great. Then, when the fiasco happened, they supposedly rectified the situation by mocking the game in what I consider a good DLC for Part 2‚ÄîParadise Lost. After this, it would have been possible to admit that Part 3 was a failure, necessary for the next games to be good, so we shouldn't forget about it, but no, they still continue to make fun of Part 3, as if it never existed, while releasing an even worse game a few years ago, which is truly terrible. Akella is to blame for the fact that the game was turning out quite good, but they changed the development team many times during development, and also made the game from scratch, often doing useless nonsense instead of seriously working on such an important game, which, with its original mixture of the gloom of Part 1 and the fun of Part 2, could have become something unique. The more I learned about the whole situation, the more I was shocked by how much people want transparency: these are great, and these are bad. In fact, Postal 3 is an industrial tragedy for which both Akella and the RVS are to blame.

The bottom line is this: taking a crap three times is better than taking a crap four times, because the first time will stop the diarrhea, while the second will leave you with a long and painful wait in the toilet, oof!

I wouldn't say the game is perfect, but it's not too bad either. A couple of non-fatal bugs, optimization (which is being fixed), and some quirks (which are being fixed), but the AI ‚Äã‚Äãin this game is a mess. It'll hide in a corner and refuse to follow you. Would I recommend it? Yeah, why not, but only on sale, since buying it at full price is crazy. Fans of the "Postal" series, who enjoy absurdity, satire, and the like, will especially enjoy it. RWS called this game "Shit," but then released their own excrement called "Postal 4." Overall rating (as all sorts of idiots write) - 7.5/10

column9: It handles like a volvo its slow to start and once you start running it it handles like a fat whore on a tricycle

Some of the hate towards the game is unfounded. Well, let's begin:

1) Yes, there are a lot of bugs, but nothing critical; you can complete them. Some achievements are buggy, so you'll have to dig around.

2) The story is weak, but the absurdity and dark humor remain. I didn't give it a 2, unfortunately.

3) The controls are acceptable; you can have fun and play the game normally.

4) Regarding optimization... "AND THE MINI-PC WITH A 4090 IS LOGGING, AAAAH!!" Are you serious? You're complaining about lag and crashes, but my laptop with integrated graphics and 8GB of RAM only crashed once during the entire story, and the only lag I can call a drop from 50 fps to 30 fps is that much (PS: the settings are medium, almost maxed out).

I'm not forcing anyone to take my opinion seriously, because I'm just a player who loves the Postal series, and that's my opinion. I had fun playing the game, and it was a good experience, even though the criticism made me expect to abandon the project after about 10 minutes.

column8: I wanted to finish my first playthrough of this game before i made a review, to put it in simple words, this game is over hated, by no means does it live up to any of the other postal games but it was a good spin on the franchise. I genuinely enjoyed the game all the way through, I had one bug when the chief of police got stuck but I threw a grenade at him and fixed it no problem. For all the hate ive heard from this game i did not expect to enjoy it as much as i did, i only bought it to finish my postal collection and to try it, but i can 100 percent see myself playing this again for another ending. I can be a bit biased on the game because i love janky source engine games, i can proudly say, POSTAL III SUCKS, but good suck. i loved this game so much honestly. thank you for reading if you did
