column9: I bought it a few years ago, but because the developer pulled the game off the shelves, I can't play it anymore because I need some damn activation code and serial number. At that time, I went to find the learning version resources and played to the police station, but then I stopped playing. Today, I heard that it's back on the shelves, so I downloaded it to play it, and found that it seems to have been updated and optimized, and the optimization is much better than before. Before, my 2070s 16g3200 i711700 would crash, freeze, and become unresponsive, and the more I played, the slower it got. Now my r52600 rx580 18g1333 can run at 80fps, and after playing for a long time, I can get about 60 frames, but it still crashes and becomes unresponsive for unknown reasons. It may be because it consumes too much memory. The scenes don't update automatically, and the broken limbs and arms on the ground won't disappear. If I don't change the map myself, the game will get slower and slower if I keep playing in the same scene.

column9: Cool

Postal 3: Expectation vs. Reality

Postal 3 is a game that will definitely leave no one indifferent. Like its predecessors, it provokes, shocks, and makes you think, but this time it explores what happens when developers try to please everyone and end up pleasing no one.

What's Good:

Dark Humor. Some jokes are genuinely funny, and the game boldly satirizes stereotypes and social values.
Freedom of Action. As in previous games, you're free to do whatever you want: cause a bloodbath, help people, or simply wander the streets and observe.
What's Bad:

Gameplay. The game stubbornly tries to be a sandbox, but in reality, it's a boring, repetitive shooter with a clunky control system.
Plot. It's too drawn-out, illogical, and saturated with propaganda.
Characters. The gameplay "characters" are more like cardboard cutouts without souls, and the story's protagonists are disgusting, vile, and utterly unsympathetic.
Graphics: In 2011, the game looked pathetic, and now it's simply awful.

Bottom Line:

Postal 3 is a game that shows that even the most insane concept can be ruined by poor execution. Despite some interesting moments, it leaves far more disappointment than satisfaction. If you're looking for an engaging shooter with dark humor, you're better off checking out the first two Postal games.

column9: The game's story is good, and the choice system is a cool idea that works well for the game. The shooting system can be a bit strange at first, but you get used to it quickly because you just need to control the recoil and aim for headshots, so the game's gunplay works well. The game's humor is quite funny and fits the franchise's vibe, and the missions are fun, reflecting the dude's mishaps. The downsides include, for example, the melee combat, which doesn't work well, some minor bugs (which are few and can be avoided), and the linear nature of the game, which takes away from the potential enjoyment of exploring the map. All in all, I had a lot of fun playing the game and didn't mind the linearity, as it still works well.

W dodatku obra≈ºenia jakie zadajƒÖ te≈º sƒÖ strasznie ma≈Çe (nie da siƒô nimi odciƒÖƒá ko≈Ñczyny albo zmia≈ºd≈ºyƒá czaszki za pierwszym ciosem nawet na zwyczajnych przechodniach, co by≈Ço mo≈ºliwe w Postalu 2), a przez zepsuty system aimowania w kamerze z 3 osoby czƒôsto ciosy nawet nie trafiajƒÖ wrog√≥w

- Podobnie zepsuty jest kanister z benzynƒÖ, kt√≥remu zdarza siƒô kompletnie nie dzia≈Çaƒá i nie nak≈Çadaƒá tej benzyny na nikogo. Tworzenie ka≈Çu≈º na pod≈Ço≈ºu tez nie zawsze dzia≈Ça

- Niekt√≥re bronie podnoszƒÖ siƒô automatycznie przy przej≈õciu nad nimi,  jednak inne jak np. granaty czy kocimiƒôtka wymagajƒÖ naci≈õniƒôcia przycisku U≈ºyj

- W trakcie tych 2-3 misji z eksploracjƒÖ miasta, a tak≈ºe w free roamie dostƒôpnym po uko≈Ñczeniu gry mi≈Çoby by by≈Ço mieƒá jakƒÖ≈õ mapƒô

- Postaƒá czƒôsto zatrzymuje siƒô w trakcie biegu o elementy otoczenia (szczeg√≥lnie w budynkach)

- Brak otwartego stylu lokacji znanego z dw√≥jki

- Pasek karmy, kt√≥ry choƒá jest moim zdaniem fajnym i pasujƒÖcym do Postala pomys≈Çem, to jest on w tej grze zepsuty. Zmniejsza siƒô on, nawet gdy obezw≈Çadnimy (bez zabijania) cywila, kt√≥ry s z c z a na ≈õrodku ulicy na radiow√≥z i nie ma ≈ºadnego sposobu na zwiƒôkszenie go (bardzo polecam naprawiajƒÖcy to mod - Karma Fix na ModDB)

- Dobra ≈õcie≈ºka (je≈õli chcemy niƒÖ podƒÖ≈ºaƒá i utrzymaƒá nasz pasek karmy na dobrym poziomie) jest niezwykle frustrujƒÖca przez fakt, ≈ºe mo≈ºesz zraniƒá a nawet zabiƒá npc-e poprzez przebiegniƒôcie przez nich (sprint jest tak≈ºe swego rodzaju taranowaniem)

- Jest tak≈ºe frustrujƒÖca przez fakt, ≈ºe AI npc-√≥w nie istnieje. I tak samo przeciwnicy jak i sojusznicy bƒôdƒÖ regularnie wchodziƒá nam pod celownik

- W grze znajdujƒÖ siƒô misje eskortowe i w niejednej eskortowany NPC ma tendencjƒô do zacinania siƒô

- Strasznie kijowy efekt zaciemniania ekranu przy trafieniu, kt√≥ry sprawia ≈ºe gdy obrywamy seriƒÖ prawie nic nie widaƒá na ekranie. Okropnie zmniejsza to czytelno≈õƒá walki i niezwykle denerwuje

- Za os≈Çonami poruszamy siƒô zdecydowanie za wolno

- Fabu≈Ça jest kompletnie bezsensowna i g≈Çupia niezale≈ºnie od wybranej ≈õcie≈ºki, stanowi po prostu zlepek r√≥≈ºnych scenariuszy

- Napisy sƒÖ za ma≈Çe na wy≈ºszych rozdzielczo≈õciach i nie da siƒô ich zwiƒôkszyƒá...

- ‚Ä¶ nie ma r√≥wnie≈º ustawie≈Ñ jasno≈õci

-  Mimo aktualizacji, w grze nadal sƒÖ crashe. U mnie wystƒÖpi≈Çy one w misji ze zbieraniem kot√≥w i w misji na komisariacie (w dobrej ≈õcie≈ºce)

- Wiƒôkszo≈õƒá fabularnych archievement√≥w jest zbugowana
column9:
Postal 3 is known for its lackluster quality. Despite this, I desperately wanted to play it, as it's the only game in the series I still hadn't played. When I was about to purchase it, I realized it was impossible because it had been removed from Steam. At the end of 2023, however, the game returned to Steam with updates introducing optimization improvements, reducing crashes, fixing numerous bugs, and adding several new languages, including Polish. During a summer sale, I saw the game for under 5 z≈Çoty, so I figured there wouldn't be a better deal. I expected the worst, but overall, I was pleasantly surprised. It's definitely a bad game. It doesn't live up to the second game, Brain Damaged, or the first... However, I must admit, I had a decent time, and even more fun than with Postal 4. Both Postal 3 and 4 were poorly released games, riddled with technical issues, unfinished, and living in the shadow of the legendary second game they were modeled after. Despite this, Postal 3 felt more polished to me ‚Äì I experienced fewer crashes and glitches than in the fourth installment, and it was also full of interesting ideas, such as unique weapons and two different mission paths. The humor in the third installment also definitely fell flat for me compared to the fourth, and Corey Cruise, while not as good as Rick Hunter, is definitely better as Postal Dude than Jon St. John. I should note, however, that I completed the fourth installment a year and a half ago, so I don't know if its technical issues have been fixed since then.

Don't get me wrong, I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone but the series' biggest fans, and if you really don't want to waste your time, I recommend reading the details I've listed below before buying it. However, I'm giving it a positive review because, as I mentioned, I really enjoyed it and it made me laugh a few times. If you're curious about this game, (in my opinion) it's worth buying for the price it's currently on sale on Steam (around 5 PLN). I finished the game on the Good track in about 6 hours and am currently starting a new playthrough on the Evil (Insane) track.

EDIT: I just finished all the missions on the second track, and while they had some issues, I still had a pretty good time. Will I ever replay the game and try to get all the achievements? Definitely not, especially since they're bugged. Will I even play this game again in the future? I sincerely doubt it. My first playthrough was quite enjoyable, though, so I'll give it a positive rating.

+ Multiple choices during the story missions, as well as two completely different paths (Good and Insane) with different missions depending on the choice you make in the third mission. Unfortunately, many maps are shared between these two paths, but it's still nice that there's a choice.

+ There's even a bit of "post-Age" humor (similar to that from the second game) in there somewhere.

+ Corey Cruise does a great job as the Dude.

+ Many of the Dude's lines are funny, a lot of them are lifted from the second game, but there are also some new ones.

+ Pop culture references.

+ A surprisingly great soundtrack, probably the best in the series.

+ The wrong path involves joining the environmentalists and terrorizing the community.

+ The not-so-bad option of massacring enemy bodies, even after death.

+ The ability to stun and arrest enemies in the right path.

+ A fairly large arsenal. Iconic weapons from the second game return, such as the gas canister, the shovel, and firearms like the rifle and pistol. There are also a lot of new and very unique weapons, such as a vacuum cleaner that sucks up waste and then fires it, or... a rabid badger that acts as a saw. A chainsaw with an alternate mode of shooting urine that stuns enemies.

- Unfortunately, some of the arsenal is useless because it's broken. Melee weapons, for example, are one such thing. Their attacks are very sluggish and clunky, and we can't execute them smoothly like in Postal 2. Furthermore, the damage they deal is also terribly low (you can't sever a limb or crush a skull with a single blow, even on ordinary pedestrians, which was possible in Postal 2), and due to the broken aiming system in the third-person camera, blows often don't even hit enemies.

- The gas canister is similarly broken; it sometimes completely malfunctions and doesn't apply the gas to anyone. Creating puddles on the ground doesn't always work either.

- Some weapons automatically respawn when you step over them, but others, like grenades or catnip, require pressing the Use button.

- During the 2-3 city exploration missions, as well as in the free roam mode available after completing the game, it would have been nice to have a map.

- The character often stops while running for environmental objects (especially in buildings).

- Lack of the open-world style of the second game.

- The karma bar, which, while I think is a cool idea and fits Postal, is broken in this game. It decreases even when we incapacitate (without killing) a civilian who is pissing on a police car in the middle of the street, and there's no way to increase it (I highly recommend the Karma Fix mod on ModDB that fixes this).

- The good path (if we want to follow it and keep our karma bar at a good level) is extremely frustrating because you can damage or even kill NPCs by running through them (sprinting is also a kind of ramming).

- It's also frustrating because the NPC AI is nonexistent. Both enemies and allies will regularly get in our crosshairs.

- The game features escort missions, and in many of them, the escorted NPC tends to get stuck.

- A terribly bad blackout effect on hits, which makes almost nothing visible on the screen when hit by a burst. This terribly reduces the clarity of combat and is incredibly annoying.

- We move far too slowly behind cover.

- The story is completely pointless and stupid regardless of the path we choose; it's simply a patchwork of different scenarios.

- The subtitles are too small at higher resolutions and can't be increased...

- ...there are also no brightness settings.

- Despite the update, the game still crashes. For me, they occurred during the mission where you collect cats and the mission at the police station (in the correct path).

- Most of the story archives are bugged.

column8:
Well, it isn't as bad as people make it out to be that being said it isn't good, it's just ok i guess.

the 2D cutscenes are great so is the main menu, shooting was fine although i wish there was a roll kind of like in gta4/5 and enemies are often too tanky but other than that it was kinda fun.

The best Missions were obviously the shooting galleries and the rest were just forgetfull but atleast not frustrating as people make them out to be (exept the mayor escort mission).

Other than that, yeah the game isn't the best and it's a shame. I am not bothered by the fact that it isn't open world like Postal 2 and honestly it's better that they didn't just replicate the said game (unlike some other entry) but i wish it wasn't just a chore simulator akin to apocalypse weekend and it was more of a just straight up TPS with missions and a big open hub (something like psychonauts did for example).

If curiosity about this game is eating you up for some reason than try it, it isn't the worst but it sure isn't somekind of misunderstood creation either. it's just, nothing really.

column8:
Let's see... 

cons: 
-no crack pipe... so that's why the dude says he needs the good stuff whenver he's low on health
-no food
-no proper inventory for storing found items
-crooked melee and throwing animations. you barely realise when melee's hit anything, same with throwable melees, the one's that have a longer windup time like the shovel works better for understanding when you've hit something.
-rpg is alright, the projectile is alitle slow and the impact on hiting an enemy is very meh, and the first go arounds i kept hiting myself right when firing it, until i got a hang of it! turns out i was launching it with right-click without charging it
-enemies drop to the floor with anything hiting them that could be considered heavy, like the shotgun or shovel, and some times... they dont! but as long as there wasn't a massive blood pile on the ground from that last hit, or a broken body part, or you haven't shot or melee'd them at least five times, they're probably not dead, and will get back up and try to run away or shoot you. also, melee'ing them during their get up animation may cause them to tank the hit, immediately be put in their idle animation and slide away a few feet infront of you.
-boss characters get knocked over when hit like regular citizens, though you'd think they'd just stagger instead, taken how they're supposed to be an all mighty enemy with a larger than usual healthpool
-this rhino boss is dogshit, you dodge when it charges at you and then it hits a wall and takes damage, simple enough! though sometimes he just straight up gets stuck in the wall, or decides to run into one and take damage without you doing anything at all 
-incoherent story
-shity tutorial, these zombies take forever to granade for no reason
-linear level system, meaning no open word until beating the game and unlocking free roam mode
-no tackling errands by chioce
-a morality system in a postal game. choosing to hold back back your options in a fight because the game says you should, just to get a "good" ending isn't gonna cut it, and quite frankly, sounds like bad game design... like wtf, 'optional fun'? 
-the escort missions are easy to get through on their own, but geting the AI npc your supposed to protect to move their ass is on a whole nother level. the first time, i'd ran through the entire mayors building, run back upstairs just to find slave "boy" inside the bar, unwilling to leave through the front door. so i ended up restarting and not runing ahead this time, he wen't back into the bar and refused to exit. so i took him out the back door leading to the big uhhh meeting room? court room? and that worked fine. after finishing the level and returing after compleating the game, i took slave "boy" into the bar by choice and sure enough, he exited through the front door without problem this time. besides that little wonky situation, he also cowers way to much, which means he will oftan hesitate to move forward, even going backwords when you desperately want him to follow you.
-unfunny jokes. such as the asians whole shtick with having dibs on the antire cat or animal population apparently, and others like "haha, ugly soccer moms get mad at pretty woman because they look like asscrack and she doesn't" all pretty lame and tame stuff. reused jokes also function better in postal 2, such as postal 3's "is it politically correct to kill the women and the minorities first?" the dude backing down and is questioning his questioning with a question he woulld't be questioning if this was postal 2, compared to postal 2's "i suppose it would have been more politically correct to kill the women and the minorities first"
-has a cover system. also, moving while in cover mode is to slow and generaly a little wonky
-regenerating health
-this is a corridor shooter
-the game feels so easy you forget at times when your about to die because you ran in guns blazing
-after the zoom re-release, the game crashes way less than i've heard it used to (it can still happen though)
-did anyone ask for more celebs in their postal game? i mean, i guess they we're trying to ride of off Gary Coleman's success in the last one and thought more was good? maybe if the game was better over all, thay'd have been handled better
-postal babes, can't go wrong with those! perhaps in an alternate universe we're the game wasn't linear, had good humor and structure!
-'iyo iyo!' is relegated to a corner store you can't even enter... how could you do this to me. 

pros: 
-movment feels really nice and smooth, has a kinda meaty weight to it
-who knew a third person source game could function so well, i remember thinking the only thing possible looking the same as going into 3rd person via console in any other source game when i was a young teen, because simple firstperson felt so distinctly source.
-the sprint to 'mouse1' attack with the shovel, hammer and axe are pretty cool! just make sure your not standing too close, or else you'll knock them over with your body rather than hiting them
-nice gun play, whrather strafing from side to side firing the m16, or runing upfront and balsting someone with the shotgun. even the standard pistol gets use! (poping heads and watching hats fly straight upwards will never stop being entertaining to me)
-the fart gun (very a-nice!)
-in the champ rescue mission, champ can properly follow the player, unlike the others...  or i don't fucking know, i just went to the end of the sewers and the game seemed to count it (maybe having champ right besides you when reaching the exit dosen't matter?)
-it actually has some pretty good music (even if allot of it is seems to be licenced or edited songs from real bands or artists) 
-the game also hsa a consistant art direction.
-after the zoom re-release, the game crashes way less than i've heard it used to.
-with the zoom re-release, updates have been made to fix bugs and help moders 
-pretty good level design, almost like it was made for a non linear game
-nades that show where they're landing before you throw them, nice!
-even though the game has a covering system, it's good for looking around corners without geting shot or just taking cover in general
-video game mockups! i love me some good game name puns. gamecave has like 11 covers that you actually get to see the front of (8 have text). all other covers are stacked sideways and with lower texture quality, so reading the lable texts can be hard
-the dudes model! i used to like his beta and alpha design more before playing the game, with how they looked more rough and tethered compared to the final model. though now, having originaly switched to the beta model after playing the first level. i just found them strangly cartoony compared to the environments in the actual game, and thus switched back almost straight afterwords.
-oh yeah, this game is modable! check 'moddb' and or 'gamebanana' for in the work or finished mods 

eveything i liked despite being bad: (or tolerated? dissmised? just didn't care about? i don't fucking know...)
-everything listed in cons
-the game technically isn't being funny most of the time with it's sexual, asian, or social comedic jokes compared to postal 2, though taking how my weird ass sense of humor can function at times, atleast i can say it 'has' a sense of humor. 

all in all, shitiest best time ever spent! the kind that makes you feel good when others hate it because "whaaat? no way! i had no enjoyment hampering problems with that section, and you did? who could have ever thought...", a guilty pleasure if you'd say! (and i haven't even finished postal 2 yet) the game feels like a destructive kid you can't stay mad at! basically "cover mechanics? level starting and ending cutscenes? morality? aawww, you postal 3!" and then he just goes "b-b-but mom! i'm serious...". also, would run around free roam mode again! also, killed everything and got the bad ending. also, time to listen to 'iyo iyo!' for the 100th time.

verdict: i regret nothing!

column9: I regret everything
There are a lot of crashes and bugs, but overall the game is good and interesting.

A very controversial game. On the one hand, the story, music, graphics are great for the era, and the gore is fun. Woohoo, but on the other, it's an unoptimized Call of Duty game that crashes because the rhinoceros is bugged and spews out a lot of smoke, which crashes the game. I love the Postal series, but this game disappointed me, plus the third-person gameplay isn't very user-friendly. The NPCs are dumber than hostages in the CS:GO beta. They'll lean against a table and won't move, forcing you to restart your save. It's especially frustrating when this happens at the end of a mission, and the game doesn't have autosaves. Play at your own risk, but it's better to get 4; it's much better and more fun.

For a long time, I thought the game was simply underrated. I was wrong. It's a constantly crashing piece of crap that I only want to complete for the sake of it! But the humor is pretty good in places, by the way.

I haven't tried playing this game for 13 years. It's a great game on Steam at a discount of 40 rubles. Everything works out of the box. If only Alexander Gruzdev had voiced it, it would have been a great sequel, unlike the skufian, old-fashioned, and cloyingly crap version. I gave it a 4.
It's a cool game, why are they so upset?

I really love Postal 2. Postal 2 became one of the most popular games in Russia (largely because it was banned in other countries). Our Russians made two expansions. One was the weekend expansion and the other was a truly awful expansion that I don't even want to talk about. If you need to, Google it. And RWS commissioned us to make the third installment because our market was their priority, and that's what we got.
[h1]A little history[/h1]

Many will probably say: well, the game was in terrible technical condition, it didn't run properly anywhere, and even now it lags on high-end computers. But the problem is a bit deeper than it might seem at first glance.

What is Postal? Postal 1 was a kind of progenitor of Hatred, a brutal top-down shooter where you kill everyone without any particular goal. But Postal 2 became an exaggerated, crazy, ridiculous version of GTA with a ton of black humor and absurdity. The game was full of idiotic, yet funny decisions. What game allows you to pee? What game allows you to slap cats on the head? All the missions were absurd, frantic, and funny, bloody surrealism, with a charismatic main character, largely thanks to Gruzdev's voice. Even the main character is called "dude," implying that he's a complete moron and doesn't give a damn about him as a character. Why am I talking about Postal 2? The reason is that you need to know the context of the game series, why it became iconic and won the hearts of GAMERS. 
[h1]So why did Postal 3 fail?[/h1]
The game stopped being crazy. Let's take the first mission of Postal 2 and Postal 3. In Postal 2, depending on the order you complete the missions, you go to the store for milk, nothing foreshadows trouble, but it turns out that the store is run by shahids and you need to kill everyone. If you go down to their basement, there will be immortal zombie dogs. And what about Postal 3? Skipping the tutorial, the first mission is to collect sperm wipes, shoot them at mothers and that's it. It feels like the idea belonged to a 14-year-old kid, seriously, shoot sperm at mothers. And it's implemented in the most boring way possible: you just vacuum up the wipes, shoot them, they puke and leave. That's all. This is not a satire of anything. For example, the mission with the store was exaggerated, because in America there are a lot of immigrants, and if a dude from the Middle East runs a store, then he's 100% a terrorist. And the third one just shows sperm, moms, and, haha, shoots them out of a vacuum cleaner. It reminds me of the scene from the movie Idiocracy, where they showed a butt and everyone laughed. It's just napkins of sperm that they shoot. 
[h1]0 variety[/h1] 
The whole game is the same. 0 variety. There's no open world in the game, you just complete missions according to the story. All the missions are based on some gag, haha, cats with HIV that kill people, haha. Haha, the Chinese make food out of cats, haha. Haha, the mayor is a man and from a porn club. God, this is the lowest form of humor, no exaggeration, just an ass with a finger. The madness itself is no longer madness, all madness lies in performing absurd actions. I'll repeat, the second post-production was a disappointment. You were on a routine mission, like picking up a book from the library, for example, but it ended up being set on fire by some anti-book guys, and you had to escape the burning library. There's no disappointment or absurdity in the third post-production. You were told to collect sperm? You collect it. You were told to chase away the mothers? You chase them away. 

[h1]Do I recommend buying it?[/h1]

Definitely not. The game is empty. Anyone who wants to immerse themselves in that atmosphere of madness should replay post-production 2. I didn't say anything about the technical aspects of the game, because who cares if the game lags or not? Cyberpunk worked like crap, and people were still happy because the game itself was good. Yes, the game has been polished a bit now, crashes and bugs have been fixed, optimization has been tweaked, but that won't help. The game is pure garbage, and I don't recommend anyone buy it. That's how it is.

column8:
Well. That was one of the worst games I've ever played.
Postal is a series I've always held in high regard, even despite its controversial reputation. But being a relatively new fan of the series, I was always confused on why there was no Postal 3 listed on Steam despite there being a Postal 4. I thought it was some kind of joke, like how Goat Simulator skipped 2 and went straight to Goat Simulator 3. But after getting involved with the Postal community a bit more, I learned that there was indeed a Postal 3... and not a very good one. Skip to October of last year and RWS announces that Postal 3 would make its grand return to Steam with some fixes. So I bought it and eventually played it.
Postal 3 is a complete mess of broken mechanics, terrible writing, mind-numbing gameplay and enough bugs and glitches in it to make you want to punch a hole through your monitor. First, why is this a cover shooter? I get that at this point each Postal game had experimented with a different subgenre of shooter (Postal 1 was a twin-sticks shooter, Postal 2 was an FPS) but if you're going to make a cover shooter at least make the cover mechanic damn work! This thing is completely useless in the game, not only because its much more effective to just get right up in the enemies faces but also because the enemies will just go behind whatever you're covering yourself with and shoot you anyway. On the topic of enemies, the AI in this game are incredibly annoying to deal with. The enemies themselves constantly chase you around whatever map you're on instead of actually moving to spots to try and shoot you, the random NPC civilians constantly get in the way of your gunshots which affects the karma system (which I'll get to because its complete bullshit) and NPCs that you're meant to protect during escort missions will not following you and instead actively try and get into fights with the enemies. The gameplay itself is insanely bad. There is a reason the Source Engine is only really used for FPS games and this game is proof of that. Trying to aim with your gun is like trying to push a boulder with your legs. It is incredibly stiff for no reason, making it somehow more effective to just not aim at enemies and just shoot at them normally. Not that it even matters because there is no gunplay in this game at all. You can very much just beat the entire game with only the AR because of how ridiculously overpowered it is with its rapid fire and that you get crazy amounts of ammo for it throughout the game, rendering all other guns useless.
Now that karma system I mentioned. Why would you add a karma system where you lose good boy points by killing civilians in a POSTAL game?! You know, the game series that built its reputation up by making it so you are neither rewarded or punished for killing innocent NPCs and all comes down to how far you're willing to go? Yeah, lets add a karma system in the next game! I'm sure that doesn't completely go against everything the series is known for! Not to mention this karma system does nothing to affect the actual gameplay and only leads to one of two different endings depending on if you were good or bad. And both of them are shit.
I knew going into this game that it was bad but I'm still shocked at how a game like this can even be released in the state its in. I can see why RWS never licensed the Postal IP out again until Brain Damaged because I wouldn't trust anyone with my property if they made something like this out of it.
Fuck this game. Don't play it.

I gave it a 3... The most hated part of the series. Almost everyone gave it low ratings, etc. Me among them. I thought it was a mammoth's diarrhea. And you shouldn't play it. But after playing it a bit... I reconsidered my position.
YES, it's not ideal.
YES, it's not like the postal everyone loves.
YES, the stupid plot about throwing sperm at femme girls.
YES, the voice acting is stupid.
However, I had fun. I completely understand the people who didn't like it. I myself, again, thought it was diarrhea. Having played the second part for 150 hours, but I liked it. There's something in all this stupidity. I just had fun. If it had been a different game, it wouldn't have gotten so much hate. In any case, it would be good just for familiarization. And whether to play it further or not. It's up to you.

This game gets progressively worse over time.

Killed a few people - the game crashed.
Neutralized three people - the game crashed.
Took a few steps - the game crashed.
Loaded a save - the game crashed.
Logged into the game and the game fucking crashed again.
I got 3rd place - this isn't just a game, it's a piece of crap. And here are the fucking biggest problems:

1. Constant crashes, even with a powerful PC.
2. A simple lack of understanding of what's going on.
3. Fucking broken mechanics, but thank God the achievements associated with them were removed.
4. And of course, sound problems, which make you enjoy phrases like "FFFFGGRGSHCHPYFSHCHZZZZ" on an ultrasound.
The game is crap, don't buy it.

column9:
This is the sequel to the infamously crappy Postal Dude, who escaped Paradise City and wreaked havoc in the new world of Catharsis.
Available in Japanese.

Good Points
The DRM has been removed, so the game now works until completion.
Comic-style illustrations.

Bad Points
Stage system with no flexibility.
Unstable as expected.
Full of bugs.
NPCs that don't behave properly.
Boring gameplay.

Completed.
Released in 2011, the game was unplayable for many years due to DRM issues.
Sales were discontinued in 2022, but the NO-DRM update in 2023 removed the DRM and the game now works.
In my opinion, it does work, but...
When I changed from HD resolution (1280*720) to Full HD, the game crashed constantly. Even when I changed the resolution back to normal,
the enemy's attack and my own attack would occur simultaneously, causing the game to freeze with a muzzle flash, and then my PC would blue screen.
It's far from stable. (It's been a while since I've seen a blue screen on my PC.)
The game becomes unstable every time I play, and when I run a file integrity check before each play,
it always ends up corrupting some game file...
There are also a lot of bugs, like a movie not starting even after completing a mission, an NPC remaining frozen, or the Dude getting stuck in a wall and not moving.
There's a mission where you have to protect an NPC, but the NPC won't move to the goal, and you have to gradually guide him to follow.
I get 100-160 FPS at HD resolution on an RTX 2070, which is comfortable, but the game itself is so unstable that I only use it as a guideline.

This time, instead of a free-roaming open-world experience, it's stage-based.

It's a mission-movie-mission-repeated cycle with no real freedom.

The missions are all boring, like "Kill 30 people of XX" or "Protect XX."

The story branches into good and evil based on the karma meter, so I understand what they're trying to achieve, but

the content just doesn't keep up. (Even good deeds don't change the karma meter...)

The Postal-esque, playful vibe, music, and illustrations were good, but... (This is typical of crappy games.)

My first reaction was, "Wow, it worked!" I was thrilled that the game finally worked after years of inactivity.

But after completing it, I realized it was just as awful as rumored.

Not only did it run improperly due to the DRM, but the gameplay was subpar, even for a 2011 TPS.

Add to that the buggy and unstable nature of the game, and it's no wonder it got such a bad reputation that RWS became a dark memory and drew so many negative comments. Despite the detailed weapons and settings, it feels very unfinished.
It feels like the gap between what the developers wanted to do and what they were aiming for and their actual development ability has shown.
I can only recommend this to people like me who have a lot of free time and play it just to have something to talk about.
Normal people should play Postal 2 or 4.

column8:
This is one of those games where you should really watch a playthrough of it on YouTube instead of playing it.
Most of this game's faults are due to the economic situation during it's development but the final product is just really shoddy, the gunplay feels weak (I spent longer attacking enemies during missions than actually doing the missions because I never felt like I was able to fend them off successfully) and a lot of the humor is either extremely dated ("look this guy looks like Super Mario from an 80's TV show!"), something Postal 2 already did (terrorist jokes, gimp suit people, etc), or really obscure Russian jokes. There is a lot of good to the game like the map design or the voice acting and music, but most of it ends up being mixed with the bad to just create an overly mediocre game. I wouldn't blame you for buying the game for the cheap price it's being sold at now even if you just wanted to own every Postal game, but I really don't recommend playing it looking to enjoy the good it has to offer.

POSTAL 3 was developed with the Source Engine.
POSTAL 2 was an FPS, but this one is a TPS.
Dirty jokes, violence, and comedy.
It's still got the same vibe, but I agree with other reviewers that the story isn't quite what you'd expect.
Since the original development was different, think of it as a different game, like it's set in a parallel world.

column8:
Lets start of by saying that this game is bad everyone knows that including your grandma. Although this is a dumpster fire of a video game I didn't hate it. I found the basic shooting in this game to be in a some sick twisted way to be enjoyable even with its bad aiming and hit detection and some of the jokes weren't that bad. I got through this game mostly without problems like yeah crashes and bugs but they didn't show up often enough to make me want to stop playing. It's really hard for me to explain why I don't hate it but I've played far more frustating and broken games (looking at you Konami and Rockstar) which won't even run without fan patches and I don't care what anyone one says the soudtrack is a banger.
I want to thank Running with scissors for allowing people to buy this game despite it's reputation it really shows you how much they like their fanbase to make them able to experience the game that they are not proud of.

10/10

I'm a fan of the Dude series. This game is one of the worst for me.
Graphics 5/10. It's kind of old-school, but it's also kind of clunky.
It plays like I'm in Max Payne 3. There were some bugs, but they were fixed quickly.
Voice acting 9/10, although the music occasionally drowned out the dialogue.
Soundtracks are 100000/10.
The biggest drawback is the lack of an open world.
I liked the multiple endings; it's funny, although I don't want to play through it a second time.

A terrible game. The developers took everything that was worst about the second game and made it three times worse. Terrible controls, completely unfunny jokes (with rare exceptions), and constant bugs and crashes. While I didn't notice it when I played as a kid, I couldn't play it for even an hour now. I bought it mostly just for the collection.
Pros:

Wonderful soundtrack (too good for such a crappy game, and for the series as a whole);
Variety of endings (yes, only three, but still more than in other games);
The dude has become more alive.

2/10
P.S.: Better than the fourth one.

This isn't a game, it's a piece of unplayable crap... But first things first:
1) This game is riddled with bugs...
2) The voice acting feels like it's pirated
3) Scripting issues (either an NPC's arm won't be chopped off with a machete, or an NPC without a leg will stand, etc.)
4) Bugly controls and a shaky camera
5) Awkward aiming and gun arsenal
6) NPCs are so stupid that civilians run into the barrel of a machine gun, ruining your karma, and in some missions, bosses can get stuck and not progress...
7) The sound can sometimes freeze even during cutscenes.
But the game does have one positive: the music.
How do you even play this?

column9: I tried it, I liked it, yes I admit it, I am a big fan of the postal saga and personally I liked its story of this postal all bugged and random it is a headache to play but I ended up having fun I do not recommend buying it if you do not have a lot of patience since if the game gets you out of desire and if you want to buy it I recommend only on sale

A game that was just a throwaway.
Bugs, crashes, and achievements are all over the place. They made the game half-heartedly.
The game is incredibly casual; you have to try hard to die. The shooting and aiming system is terrible (the aiming HUD is useless). The game is extremely linear (although you can choose two paths). You can easily beat the game in two hours by holding W+RMB.
It's not even worth the 40 rubles you paid.
I feel sorry for this terrible purchase, but at least I feel nostalgic, you can love it or hate it, this is my favorite childhood.

column9:
After completing the good storyline in the first game, you likely won't even attempt the bad storyline in the second, as the game is profoundly flawed in every way. If you've searched Bilibili or YouTube for Postal 3's development history, you'll likely understand how the 2008 global financial crisis and publisher Akella's brilliant response ruined Postal 3. I won't go into detail here. What happened next is well known to anyone who follows the series: Running With Scissors (RWS), the original IP holders, slammed Postal 3 and even refused to acknowledge it as a legitimate sequel. So, 12 years after Postal 2's release (April 13, 2003), RWS personally updated it with the massive story-based DLC, Paradise Lost, which they considered the third legitimate sequel. As for the actual "Blood Street 3," aside from P3 Dude's voice actor, Corey Cruise, who also voiced the character in "Blood Street: Brain Damage" and "Blood Street 4," ultimately redeeming himself, this so-called third legitimate sequel appears more as a mockery than a joke in all future Blood Street updates.

This writing was rushed, so I'll go into some details and briefly touch on others.

‚ë† Scenery: The game's map was clearly intended to be open-world, but due to funding and manpower shortages, it was ultimately cut up piecemeal (early versions even had seemingly traversable areas with only air walls, while others were blocked by cones). The final result is a jarring, cut-and-paste world that abruptly switches between chapters, creating a strong sense of discontinuity (perhaps due to the Source engine's inherent inability to create open-world maps). However, the map's setting is actually quite acceptable, and the architecture, reflecting the game's setting of a small town on the US-Mexico border, has a distinctly Mexican feel, making it a passable Gmod map.

‚ë° Control: Tsk, this is truly outrageous. I don't know if it's because this game is in third-person, but the spacebar jump function has been removed (and you'll get stuck on steps because you can't jump), replaced by taking cover. Cover, however, is completely useless, forcing you to blind-fire instead of aiming with the right button, and most of the time, enemies can still hit you even through cover... Uh? So why would I take cover? To be a target? And then there's the sprinting, which is inexplicable. The screen jitters while I'm running, and the artificial nausea is even more unpleasant than playing other Source engine games. The combat is also disappointing. Melee attacks are impossible to hit unless you aim directly at the target, and Postal Dude's minimal bending means that you can't land last-hit damage with melee attacks, except for his incredibly low-damage kicks. The guns are pretty standard for an action shooter, with both standard firearms and Postal's uniquely bizarre and hilarious quirks. Aside from the M-Gun's recoil, which is so strong it could make Postal Dude spin half a circle, everything else is passable.

‚ë¢ Intelligent AI: You say the AI ‚Äã‚Äãis strong, but the pathfinding is a mess. Sometimes you'll trip yourself up in combat, and enemies won't engage unless they're right in front of you. You say the AI ‚Äã‚Äãis weak, but the AI ‚Äã‚Äãcan see through lower floors to lock onto enemies on higher floors, and can also shoot with impulsive hip-fire from dozens of meters away. It's so complicated, I can't understand it.

‚ë£ Plot: Perhaps due to the widespread criticism of the first two games, this is the only game in the series to feature a morality bar, which places you on either the Good Path or the Bad Path depending on your choices. Entering the good storyline, Postal Dude becomes a police officer, diligently combating the town's criminal underworld. Entering the evil storyline, Postal Dude persists with his usual rampage of looting and burning, spreading Paradise's chaos to Catharsis. While the two plotlines complement each other, there's essentially no fundamental difference between the good and evil paths. The people Postal Dude works for are all selfish, self-centered individuals who applaud his achievements and dismiss them as if they've made a mistake. Midway through the game, Postal Dude, regardless of whether he's good or evil, begins to question his initial choices... I don't know how you all feel about this, but the lack of a clear tonal distinction between the two paths really makes it hard to keep playing. Regardless of which path I choose, I feel frustrated, like a tool being tossed around and ordered around.

1. Gameplay/Mechanics: 3
2. Story/Text: 5
3. Performance/Accomplishment: 5 (The cutscene noise filter is overly aggressive, blurring and distorting, and the rest of the character dialogue is completely static and stiff.)
4. Control/Action: 3
5. Art/Modeling: 6 (One of the few areas worth praising)
6. Music/Sound Effects: 4 (The music is okay, but using the Source engine for most of the sound effects is really lazy.)
7. Optimization/Bugs: 1 (Needs community optimization mods to improve) Stable operation, otherwise crashes are the norm)

8. Difficulty/Entry Points: 10 (If you can tolerate poor optimization, welcome to jail)

9. Replayability/Durability: 2 (‚Ä¶don't)

10. Value/Price: 4 (It's only 3 bucks, so I feel bad about it.)

11. Bonus Points/Deductions: -0.5 (Official disapproval of this game)

[h2]Final Score: 3.9/10[/h2]

I can only say, "I regret something" this time.

As for those who praise Postal 3 as the best in the series solely based on the irony within the plot, I can only say:

I like Postal 3 and think it's the best in the series;

I can independently judge the quality of the game instead of just listening to what gaming bloggers say;

It's not necessary to complete Postal 3, just play it‚Äî

[h2] Only two of the three can be true. [/h2]

‚Ä¶Hey, you know what? Could "Bullet 3" be one of the few third games in the series built using the Source engine? That's a third twist now. ^_^

column8:
You know, I thought that RWS was overreacting it's stance towards this game.
I was horribly wrong. This is one of the blandest, most unpolished and apologetic games I've ever played in my life.
Everything about it is terrible. The game is so fucked that it crashes fairly constantly, some enemy types are A-posing while trying to attack you, the gunplay is unintuitive and generally shit while most of the time not even the achievements are functioning.

Fuck this game, I've wasted 4 hours of my life just so I get shat into my own throat voluntarily.
My mistake I suppose for having the masochistic curiosity, but still that was a whole Euro and 4 hours of my life that I'll never get back ever again and that makes me sad.

For your own sake. 
DON'T TRY THIS GAME. 
IT'S TERRIBLE. 
JUST PLAIN TERRIBLE, NOT EVEN FUNNY JANKY TERRIBLE.
RUN! 
FAR AWAY!

Postal 3 to przyk≈Çad gry absolutnie fatalnej i mam nadziejƒô, mam do cholery nadziejƒô, ≈ºe nigdy nie powstanie kolejna tak bardzo okropna ods≈Çona tej serii jak Postal 3.
column9:
Postal 3 is, without a shadow of a doubt, a terrible mess, but not because of the shift from a psychedelic to a strictly comedic atmosphere, not because of the change in the protagonist's personality and voice, not because of the shift from a linear game to a more linear format. No, absolutely not. Even the first two Postal games were already quite different in terms of gameplay and atmosphere. So what went wrong with the third? I'm not exaggerating when I say that absolutely everything but the soundtrack was flawed. The game went through absolute hell during its development. The developers' greed, the economic crisis, Akella's appalling treatment of employees, and the lack of access to the game by Running with Scissors, the creators of Postal 1 and 2, all contributed to the release of this stinking, awful, rotten, and rotting piece of garbage that infected players' computers with its incredibly repulsive presence.

It all begins with the introduction of the plot, which is literally nonexistent here. Yes, Postal 1 and 2 didn't have it either, but everything there had a cause-and-effect chain, but here? The guy first wants to find fuel for his wagon in the city of Catharsis, then joins one of the factions, completes completely random tasks for them, and then magically escapes the city with his dream fuel.

The gameplay we're treated to is unbelievably BAD. To create it, Akella had to sign more and more pacts with hellish beings, because I don't believe, I simply don't believe, that there's any other way to explain this aspect of the game. The missions we'll have to complete are some of the worst, absolutely, WORST missions we'll ever experience in gaming. None of the missions are connected, each one is poorly designed from the ground up. The guy just keeps completing tasks without a SINGLE funny gag. Seriously! The missions don't lead to a single entertaining conclusion like they did in Postal 2. In Postal 3, absolutely every mission is boring, and none of them are varied despite their linearity.

A note of caution has also been added to the game: the KARMA SYSTEM. And here I have to give the developers the crown, as they managed to achieve the worst karma system I've ever seen. Let's start with the fact that the game offers a choice of paths. You can join the local police or the environmentalist gang. Choosing the former is the biggest mistake you can make. It's the path of justice that will offer you the worst, most boring missions. By the way, remember karma systems from any other games? You could replenish them in any way you wanted. In Postal 3, the creators probably threw pointless suggestions at the programmers during the design process, telling them to just back off and let them keep playing a game called "Fish an apple with your teeth from a bucket of thin excrement." As a result, karma in the game can't be renewed in any way if you make a mistake. In addition, to achieve a good ending, we can't freely kill people, even if we're considering DAMN TERRORISTS. What does that mean? It means our arsenal is limited to a stun gun, a fart blaster, and pepper spray. This incredibly limited arsenal adds to the boredom of dealing with this already terrible title.

Even if we're given the option to use the entire arsenal, it's completely useless. Melee weapons never hit anything, they're cumbersome, and we never need to use them because they're broken. Firearms are equally superfluous. From the purely theoretical scope, to the devastating recoil, to their questionable functionality. To this day, I don't know why firing the left-click from a rocket launcher causes my own self-destruction.

Combat will never be enjoyable; during combat, the only thing we'll want to do is unlatch a grenade with it stuck in our butts, and I'm not talking about doing it in the virtual world. The entire screen is littered with various nauseating effects. Blur is constant, sprinting causes the screen to shake, shooting causes the screen to shake, damage taken also causes the screen to shake, bugs cause the screen to shake, and everything shakes and obscures the screen for the entire duration of the game. I've already discussed the terrible weapons, but the situation is not saved by the terrible AI. I've never encountered worse AI in games, and I don't even know where to begin. The battlefields of both sides of the conflict essentially involve running across the map and shooting from random locations. Characters don't take cover from fire, sometimes don't shoot at all, escorted NPCs get stuck on walls, sometimes don't move at all. Everyone runs into our sights, and many times I wanted to throw my computer out the window because of it. However, the game's greatest sin is its technical state. Even in 2024, the game is simply unplayable. FPS can drop from 100 to 15 during action scenes. The optimization is abysmal. The game crashes at random moments, sometimes even forcing a restart. Cutscenes suddenly cut out, or the audio from them and the game overlaps. NPCs make completing missions difficult because they stop cooperating. All of this causes fits of rage and uncontrollable genocidal tendencies in the player.

You know, Postal 1 and 2 weren't perfect games; they had their flaws despite a satisfying gameplay formula, but Postal 3? Postal 3 is the apogee of mediocrity, a dam exploding against oceans of septic tanks. And I swear, I swear on my arm, my leg, my crotch, my head, my dog, and the sleeping Cthulu beneath the Pacific Ocean, that Akella, that disgusting Akella, and her family will spend the rest of their lives scrubbing the decks of sunken ships with their fingernails. Postal 3 is an absolutely terrible game, and I hope, I bloody hope, that there will never be another installment in this series as awful as Postal 3.

The reasons why the game is terrible are: 1. The voice acting is incomprehensible. 2. It's hard to hit people, but I want to hit NPCs, but the hero misses, so what's the point? 3. Finish the game first so you can release it to the public, not release it with bugs and then embarrass yourself over it!

column8:
This game proves 2 things.
1. Why a 3rd-person Postal game wouldn't work. The melee weapons only line up with where the Dude is facing, not the cross hair. If you want to get melee kills you'll have to get REAL up close and personal. The guns work the same way as well. They only line up with the crosshair when the enemies are mid-to-far range.
2. Why Running With Scissors had disassociated themselves from and made fun of this game constantly. The only good things about this game are the models, The voice-acting (mostly Corey Cruise), and the music. Everything else is a complete dumpster fire, from the AI to the gunplay to the mess of a story with diverting paths, playing this game was a living hell throughout. Not to mention the unobtainable achievements that, even if obtainable, would still be an absolute mess to play through and obtain.

Moral of the story: Don't buy this. It isn't even worth $6 let alone anything at all.

column9:
Overall, it's a good game for those who enjoy the genre.

If you're playing Postal 3 based on Postal 2, you'll certainly be disappointed, as the games are quite different.

Of course, I also have my criticisms, like the weird camera, the strange way the character takes up the entire screen while running, and the way they eliminated Postal 2's *AWESOME* mechanic, which was being able to approach like a boss by slamming your nose into doors.

I don't know if I'll finish it, as I encountered several bugs. Several black screens and crashes.

column8:
K√ºnstlerische Freiheit hin oder her, man k√∂nnte denken, dass "Postal 3" eine Erinnerung daran ist, dass manchmal weniger mehr ist. Oder, um es genauer zu sagen, dass manchmal gar nichts besser ist als ein schlechtes Spiel. Aber hey, wir k√∂nnen ja versuchen, das Positive herauszuarbeiten, auch wenn es so d√ºnn ist wie das Papier, auf dem die Entschuldigungen der Entwickler gedruckt wurden.

Wenn du schon immer davon getr√§umt hast, die Welt als durchgeknallter Psychopath zu sehen, der sich selbst und allen anderen das Leben zur H√∂lle macht, dann k√∂nnte "Postal 3" genau das sein, was du suchst. Das Spiel wirft dich in eine Welt voller Obsz√∂nit√§ten, sinnloser Gewalt und einem Haufen fragw√ºrdiger Entscheidungen, die selbst den abgebr√ºhtesten Spieler dazu bringen k√∂nnten, den Kopf zu sch√ºtteln.

Die Grafik? Nun ja, sie ist... existent. Zumindest k√∂nnen wir sagen, dass es Pixel gibt, die versuchen, wie Menschen auszusehen. Aber hey, wer braucht schon realistische Grafik, wenn man stattdessen eine Karikatur der Menschheit pr√§sentieren kann, die so schmerzhaft ist wie ein Kaktus im Schritt?

Das Gameplay? Nun, lass es mich so ausdr√ºcken: Wenn du schon immer davon getr√§umt hast, Waffen abzufeuern, die sich anf√ºhlen, als w√ºrden sie aus einem Spielzeugladen stammen, und Gegner zu bek√§mpfen, die d√ºmmer sind als ein Sack Steine, dann ist "Postal 3" vielleicht das Richtige f√ºr dich. Aber sei gewarnt: Selbst der abenteuerlustigste Spieler k√∂nnte sich dabei erwischen, wie er sehns√ºchtig nach einem Exit-Knopf sucht.

Aber hey, wir sollten das Positive nicht vergessen, oder? Nun, das Ende des Spiels k√∂nnte als solches betrachtet werden - immerhin bedeutet es, dass es vorbei ist und du endlich deine Zeit mit etwas Sinnvollem verbringen kannst. Wie zum Beispiel das Anstarren einer Wand oder das Lesen von Steuerformularen. Denn hey, selbst das w√§re wahrscheinlich unterhaltsamer als "Postal 3".

Insgesamt ist "Postal 3" wie eine schlechte Pizza: Es ist schnell konsumiert, hinterl√§sst aber einen bitteren Nachgeschmack und l√§sst dich fragen, warum du √ºberhaupt angefangen hast. Aber wer wei√ü, vielleicht gibt es ja irgendwo da drau√üen jemanden, der wirklich Spa√ü daran hat, sich durch diesen digitalen Albtraum zu qu√§len. Aber f√ºr den Rest von uns? Nun ja, es gibt immer noch genug andere Spiele da drau√üen.
column9:
Artistic license or not, you might think that "Postal 3" is a reminder that sometimes less is more. Or, to be more specific, that sometimes nothing is better than a bad game. But hey, we can try to find the positive, even if it's as thin as the paper the developers' apologies are printed on.

If you've always dreamed of seeing the world as a crazed psychopath making life hell for himself and everyone else, then "Postal 3" might be just what you're looking for. The game throws you into a world filled with profanity, senseless violence, and a slew of questionable decisions that could make even the most seasoned gamer shake their head in disbelief.

The graphics? Well, they're... there. At least we can say there are pixels trying to look like people. But hey, who needs realistic graphics when you can instead present a caricature of humanity as painful as a cactus in the crotch?

The gameplay? Well, let me put it this way: If you've always dreamed of firing weapons that feel like they came from a toy store and fighting enemies dumber than a bag of bricks, then "Postal 3" might be for you. But be warned: Even the most adventurous player might find themselves longing for an exit button.

But hey, let's not forget the positives, shall we? Well, the game's ending could be considered that‚Äîafter all, it means it's over and you can finally spend your time doing something worthwhile. Like staring at a wall or reading tax forms. Because hey, even that would probably be more entertaining than "Postal 3."

Overall, "Postal 3" is like a bad pizza: It's quickly consumed, but leaves a bitter aftertaste and makes you wonder why you started in the first place. But who knows, maybe there's someone out there who actually enjoys plowing through this digital nightmare. But for the rest of us? Well, there are still plenty of other games out there.

The most controversial of all the POSTAL games. The well-known Akella studio was developing this game, but since they don't know how to make games, they handed it over to Trashmasters under the supervision of Running With Scissors. As we all understood, they didn't even look at anything. The game turned out to be heavily bugged, BUT! While Running With Scissors wasted all their money on drugs and whores, Akella and Trashmasters were developing Postal III alone. As bad as Postal III is, it still has a pleasant vibe. The voice acting isn't as great as in Part 2, but still. The cutscenes are enjoyable, and the plot is much stronger than in Part 2. There are three endings, depending on your behavior. My subjective rating: 5/10. It's a good game with a beer after a night shift at the factory.

column8:
I think if everything went right with the development, the 2008 crisis didn't happen and the game was close to the original design documents, it would have been genuinely amazing. What we have now is a tragic shadow of the game we were supposed to get. This game is a broken unfinished mess that was rushed together and thrown out into the world just to salvage the work that was put into it while the development was going well. 

So why do I recommend it? Because going in I expected something far worse and I genuinely had fun. There is a foundation of a good POSTAL game here and sometimes, when the game decides to actually function, it is so much fun. There's still a charm here, the music is great, corey is great, the look of the game is raunchy yet stylized. 

Postal III sucks, everyone knows that, but when you experience it you really can't help but feel like it was a labor of love that failed miserably. I don't recommend you get it unless you can get it for free or at least not more than 2 or so bucks. That being said, if you can get it for anywhere between 0 - 2 dollars, pick it up and play it, just so you can say you have instead of bashing it because everyone else does. Playing it for myself was at the very least interesting because it gave me an idea of what we could have had. 

I regret nothing.

I gathered several achievements in the time I played this game, however, the only achievement the game actually awarded me is "EMO" with the description being "Injure yourself". And you know, I think I DID injure myself playing this game. The amount of blunt trauma applied to me by the cyber STINK waves this goddamn game emits from all of its orifices would be enough to kill the average person. If I had to pick one thing I liked about this game, it would be the fact they had it in their good graces to add a "quit" button. Whoever's pea brained idea this was to distribute to the masses deserves a life sentence in a prison for apes. 
If I wanted to feel like I just got shit shoved up my asshole until it spewed out my ears, I would just play this game. This game is like overdosing on 10 different types of painkillers, yet still having a goddamn migraine at the end of it. I bought this game for one dollar, but I think it would be better spent bribing 10 burly men to rape me in the eyes. Anyways, 10/10, best birth control on the market. So good, I don't think ill have a single woman in my presence for the next half century. They'll be burying me in my early grave, and even my own mother would be too disgusted to attend. So to postal 3, have a good night, and go fuck yourself.

column9: Pew-pew zombies, a zebra-style rhinoceros rodeo, and a third-person perspective‚Äîcan you guess what this game is? No, it's not GTA 5 with absurd mods, it's Postal 3! The only difference is that the tutorial can be buggy, and the official Russian voiceover leaves much to be desired, as only cutscenes are voiced, while the Dude's lines are always in the original. And the Russian voiceover is OVER THE ENGLISH! But in any case, the game is interesting, funny, and entertaining. What's more, the Dude himself makes fun of the game with the same phrase, "Nah, GTA physics is better." Ultimately, the game is good for a laugh and a good time.

column8:
It's jank. It's playable. It's painful. Get over it you little sl*ts. Sorry, this review needed that RWS-type edge that this game never really got.
No need to review bomb when every single living organism knows this game is a piece of shite. But then again, I don't think the publisher OR the developers care! I think they are all defunct. So this is just an echo chamber! But either way, Running With Scissors (still operating) HATES this game. They actively disown it. They even gave it away for free at one point, for hells sake. Anyways $6 isn't even that bad. If you don't want to waste a fiver, it'll probably go on sale again. I got it dirt cheap when it was reinstated. Probably a dollar, honestly. But on a base level, the game functions and runs well on modern systems so I can't say it wasn't entirely optimized. If you already knew about Postal III, then you knew what you were getting into. You asked for trash and you got it! People who are new to the series, play Postal/Postal Redux/Postal2. They are much better and are mainline games. With that being said, Cory Cruise is a good Dude. Props to him for lending his voice. It may be the one redeeming factor of the game.

column9:
Well, the game is extremely buggy. I can't get the tutorial achievement. The game mechanics themselves, like being a cover shooter, don't work and are glitchy. Everything in it is buggy to the point where it doesn't count as achievements. It has good jokes and quite amusing missions, as they're quite varied. But the game is more like a bullet hell than a cover shooter. For those who like to laugh at a shitty and buggy game, it's good. But for those who've never played the franchise and for those who care about these problems, it's terrible.

Rating: 5/10
Platinum difficulty: unplatinable because it's buggy and doesn't count as achievements.

column8: I'm writing this review years after finishing Postal 3 and just almost beating Postal 4. I played this as a buggy mess in 2011 and still came out with some enjoyment, I cannot say the same for Postal 4. Though a sub-standard game in general, Postal 3 is far more fun and a proper successor in spirit to 2 in spite of RWS's unreasonable hate for it. I highly recommend this game when it's on discount (which is a dollar as of this review). I recommend fans compare the two and reassess their opinion of this old, jaded gem from Akella.

column9:
A game panned upon its release by fans of the series, reviewers, and the entire world. A game built on the engine of Half-Life, LFD, Portal, and other Valve games. A game whose original creators had an idea for it, but due to lack of budget, it was finished by a few Russian comrades. A game that even Running with Scissors distances itself from and refuses to discuss. Hailed as a mistake, a Russian bolt, and the worst game ever. That game is Postal III. But is it really so? Pros (yes, they exist):
+ decent character models, less so with the environments,
+ voice actors, including Corey Cruise as The Dude, who will be in the Postal series for a while,
+ diverse arsenal,
+ the drawn cutscenes are great, probably the best part of this chaos,
+ varied quests,
+ the music fits the game's atmosphere,
+ dark humor and racist attitude towards every nationality, ever,
Cons:
- stability is a joke,
- most of the arsenal doesn't work properly,
- the third-person camerawork gives me seizures when I sprint,
- the source code was written by someone who had a stroke,
- while the humor in Postal 2 was based on various themes, here there's one overarching one - cimcirimcim,
- the game isn't open-ended, it's linear,
- the cutscenes in the game engine don't even try to look acceptable,
- the punishment system - if you kill someone, you're on the wrong track,
- quests are often impossible to complete because, for example, an enemy runs through a wall, and that's it. Reload
- Bugs, bugs, and more bugs
- The game frequently freezes
- The melee combat system is nonexistent; it takes at least 30 punches or 40 kicks to kill someone
- The physics are inconsistent
- An unnecessary cover system
- No jumping option
There's more, but a book could be written about it.
Is it worth it? Definitely not. Even if you're a fan. It's better to go back to Postal 2, replay Postal 1/Redux, or Postal Brain Damaged. These are far superior games. And Postal 4? At its current price...it's hard to say.

column8: To all new fans to postal series, do not get this game not even if it is on sale. You will actually start to regret it as you progress becuse gameplay sucks, third person is sometimes painful to play with becuse of the melee weapons, the guns in this game are pretty hard to use becuse you waste a whole mag on one enemy which leaves you easily vunrable to the enemies, i mean i was good enough in gears of war 1 on xbox 360 but this is something else even the cover system doesn't do it's job, sometimes cover system gets broken and makes you get stuck in one place making you relaunch the game, the a.i in missions does not work how it says it should on those wall of text intro missions, sometimes the characters that you are supposed to protect get stuck in one place making you reset the whole level and starting all over again, the humor gets worse over time, to point i was asking my self why did even buy it in first place. I did not played it from start to finish becuse i gave up but if it was a cannon game i got a cool theory, what if postal III dudes voice was the voice of the doctor from redux like his attempt on testing the postal dude. But the dude refuses him and gives him the worst story he could come up with (idk how the lore in postal works but i think you get the idea). Also the only good thing from postal III is the soundtrack, that is the only decent thing that is atleast okay. So please don't get it, i am saying it for your own good. Even if some people say it is a not that bad, they did not played it enough to see how bad actually is even after all these patches this game is not worth it.

column8: I played with mods.
column9: I played with mods.

A game that had been hated for 13 years has once again become popular, including with me, thanks to news of its updates.
I was extremely surprised that someone was trying to revive the game and bought it.
And frankly, I've come to love and venerate the game; it's a true relic, a miracle of the '00s.

It's something that can't exist now; pure trash without brakes. A game that can go too far, and you'll be spitting at it, especially the tutorial, which drove away all reasonable people with its awfulness, stupidity, and crookedness. But as they say, the ozone endured and ordered us to, and after such an act of self-humiliation, one can appreciate the schizophrenia that follows.
Now it's perfectly playable and enjoyable, and I feel so sorry for the people who bought that piece of unplayable code. My God, I beat the game on max difficulty (I'M FUCKED).

The main thing is to install a couple of mods on the camera (which is still flawed without mods) and more dismemberment so that it's like blood, guts, and skulls.

Of course, even now the game has its pitfalls, namely:
You still have to occasionally kick an NPC in the face to make them follow triggers and scripts.
THE COMPLETELY BROKEN LASER IN THE RHINO MISSIONS IS A BITCH.

This is just fucking insane, comrades. To beat these two assholes, you have to bug them. I really hope the people patching the game now will fix this issue over time, and it will be possible to play this rather tolerable game without any pain in the ass.
I recommend every trash fan try this game at least once. It has charm and can truly make you laugh and evoke emotions with its absurdity and sincerity.

Even trash like this needs to be appreciated these days; it simply doesn't exist anymore, and it's a relic of the great 2000s, with its trash and hilarity.
(And yes, Posral 4 is still worse than Postal 3. Change My Mind)

Were the cutscenes and story in general pretty mediocre? Also yes.
Did I still have fun? Fuck yeah.
Corey Cruise does an amazing job as the VA of Dude, and it was great seeing him in the DLC for Postal 2, the weapons were fun too but shame you couldn't befriend the dogs that roam around. The Den reminded me a lot of Paradise Lost when you're heading down to the boss.

column8:
[h2] ¬°El mejor Postal! [/h2]

Mentira, no lo es, pero quiero salir a defender esta obra ya que al mi parecer su odio esta un poco exagerado.
Sabiendo todo el contexto detr√°s del desarrollo y la crisis econ√≥mica que sufri√≥ Rusia en su momento, es entendible el estado en el que se lanzo el juego, pero hoy en d√≠a es jugable [i] en el sentido literal, ya que, por los testimonios que vi, antes de los parches el juego era casi injugable por varios bugs, crasheos y pesimo rendimiento [/i]
Es cierto que sigue teniendo algunos bugs molestos y una inteligencia artificial altamente est√∫pida, pero hay otros aspectos en los que siento que el publico fue muy duro contra el juego.
Yo lo llegue a disfrutar por el hecho de que [i] adem√°s que lo parchee, [/i] no esperaba gran cosa, sabia perfectamente que clase de cosas me iba a encontrar y aun as√≠ llegue a disfrutarlo genuinamente [i] incluso me llegue a re√≠r m√°s que en el Postal 2 [/i]
Cada persona tiene sus gustos y entiendo a la gente que no le gusta Postal 3, pero quisiera invitar a las personas que no lo jugaron e incluso a las personas que ya lo hicieron, que le den una oportunidad [i] o una segunda oportunidad, [/i] ya que, a d√≠a de hoy, es una experiencia disfrutable y puedo decir, [b] I Regret Nothing [/b] about playing Postal 3

[spoiler] Algo que me falto aclarar, USEN LAS GU√çAS, si tienen un problema con algo, usen las gu√≠as de la comunidad, hay much√≠simas muy √∫tiles, como una que traduce el juego al espa√±ol, otra que explica como mejorar el rendimiento, etc. No miento cuando digo que usar las gu√≠as mejora incre√≠blemente la calidad de experiencia del juego [/spoiler]
column9:
[h2] The best Postal! [/h2]

It's not a lie, but I want to come out and defend this game because, in my opinion, the hatred is a bit exaggerated.
Knowing the full context behind its development and the economic crisis that Russia suffered at the time, the state in which the game was released is understandable, but today it's playable [i] in the literal sense, since, from the testimonies I saw, before the patches the game was almost unplayable due to various bugs, crashes, and terrible performance [/i]
It's true that it still has some annoying bugs and a highly stupid artificial intelligence, but there are other aspects in which I feel the public has been very harsh on the game.
I enjoyed it because [i] besides the fact that I patched it, [/i] I wasn't expecting much. I knew exactly what kind of things I was going to find, and I still genuinely enjoyed it [i] and even laughed more than I did in Postal 2 [/i]
Everyone has their own tastes, and I understand people who don't like Postal 3, but I would like to invite people who haven't played it, and even those who have, to give it a chance [i] or a second chance [/i] because, as of today, it's an enjoyable experience, and I can say, [b] I Regret Nothing [/b] about playing Postal 3.

[spoiler] Something I forgot to clarify: USE THE GUIDES. If you have a problem with something, use the community guides. There are tons of very useful ones, like one that translates the game into Spanish, another that explains how to improve performance, etc. I'm not lying when I say that using guides incredibly improves the quality of the game experience.

Postal 2 is one of the best satires in the industry and a timeless game, incredibly relevant right now, judging by the phrase.
How I waited for Postal 3!!
I watched videos on Igromania discs until they were worn out... I went to the post office to get internet access, read foreign forums, etc.
And then it came out.
And they've shit in my soul.
I absolutely love everything about RWS in this game ‚Äì the art, the design, the style.
There's no point in describing the downsides here.
I know some RWS are reading this right now -
TELL ME HOW TO INSTALL MODS THAT FIX AND ADD TO THE GAME!!!
BRING BACK THE ACHIEVEMENTS!!
And if the fans finished VTMB on the same engine and brought back everything they could and even more, then Postal 3 can definitely be brought back. Give the source code to the fans!!

column8: This cant be good for me, but i feel great.
column9: This cant be good for me, but i feel great.

The game is actually pretty good. I actually played it myself and enjoyed it more than I did the other two.
I finished it in 5 hours. The only thing I don't like is the bugs. It crashed once and I couldn't finish it.
And of course, the crashes and achievement issues. For example, I killed Krotchi but didn't get the achievement.

Well, in the end, it's worth buying for 40 rubles.
But it's a shame I bought it today and finished it today.

column8:
One of the WORST games I have ever played it feels like i have been violated and subjected to a weeks worth of Guantanamo bay torture in one sitting in fact that would be less harsh than playing this garbage.

i'm so bored and feel I've given this ''game'' enough attention so here's a list of all the content that was cut or removed for some dumb reason and hopefully this will prove to you why you shouldn't play this garbage even if it was free 

-No free roaming in the story mode
-There is no map cause you don't need one
-There is no currency
-You can't collect any items like food, health pipes ect.
-You can't really interact with the NPCs
-The aiming is terrible
-Bugs everywhere
-Constant game crashes
-The story doesn't make much sense
-New voice actor (even though I got used to him by now)
-The 3rd person is a pain in the ass
-The story is actually really short, there are like 20 missions which all take like 3 minutes
-It has no replay value
-Most of the weapons are useless
-The weapon switching is also a pain in the ass
-You can't buy stuff from stores
-The enemies are a joke
-No option to set difficulty
-The life system is like Watch_dogs
-No jumping
-Cutscene every 2 steps or so

column9:
The game literally crashes at the point where you have to catch the sick cats. I couldn't play practically anything. It just crashes and crashes. The hand-to-hand combat is a bit strange. Without a melee weapon, you can't hit much. With a melee weapon, it's even weirder. It seems like the aiming doesn't work with the melee weapon.

In short, the game crashes at the point where you have to catch the cat with HIV. Melee combat doesn't work properly. The aiming seems useless in melee combat. I don't recommend it.

This review was written specifically for Wolfstalker. After 7 hours of play, I encountered: 1) Freezing, 2) Crashes, 3) Bugs like getting stuck, 4) NPCs that don't want to follow the story, 5) I got one achievement first and that's it. 6) I finished the game, but the mission with killing three bosses was the most laggy, with constant crashes; I barely made it. The first mission about porn was enjoyable, and that was it. After that, it's just the same old thing. I'm tired, I'm going to take a rest. If it weren't for the crashes and character freezes, I would have finished it faster.

column8:
overall pretty shit
this game is like hunt down the freeman before hdtf released (except it was supposed to be a mainline game)
the overall shooting mechanics are fun and the level design is also great, and dont get me started on the ost.
the rest of the game is complete bullshit, the escort missions are the worst mechanic introduced in the entire game, i had to look up a tutorial half of the time to know where to go, and when i first started playing the game, i didnt even get achievements, i had to change some settings in the config (thanks to a member of the rws discord telling me about it), and i had to play through the game all over again just to get the achievements, and the good path and bad path system really does not fit for the postal esque, in postal 2 for example, you could kill people without any consequence, except in postal 3, if you kill people, say on the good path, then your karma score decreases and you go on the bad path, and dont even get me started on the fact that this game runs in source, the physics and source sfx kind of have a "its so bad its good" feeling to them, but besides that they could have used unreal.
i get that the team was facing alot of economic problems due to the entire team being russian, but atleast test the game more than once, this is pathetic, would not recommend UNLESS you want to see how bad it is
in short: I regret everything.

[h1] The game is so good it's risen from the dead [/h1]
If you look at some modern games like RedFall, Starfield, Russes vs. Lizards, and all sorts of "simulators" of all sorts, it turns out that Postal 3 wasn't such a bad game. They really put effort into creating cutscenes, locations, and so on. The only annoying things were a few bugs and the rather stuffy final missions. Overall, I think the game deserves at least a 5/10, because compared to modern trash, it's at least a game made with heart. The humor in the game, while not as "subtle" as many like, is still capable of making you smile at the absurdity that unfolds.
