column8:
Just don't. This game is beyond the word garbage. Likely one of the WORST games i've played and it's not worth it for you, the reader, to buy this game under ANY circumstances. I wouldn't even tell the most die-hard Postal fan to buy this or pirate it. This game can be thrown back into the fiery chasm from whence it came. 

If you're still willing to read all of my thoughts on this festering parasite plaguing the Postal franchise, i'll indulge.

Set after the Apocalypse Weekend of Postal 2, the Postal Dude and Champ decide to find somewhere new to call home while the Dude looks for a job. Calling Catharsis their new home, the Dude will find his first job in a sex shop ran by Ron Jeremy. From there the Dude finds no success with other jobs and getting paid before stumbling across a robbery and... Is given the choice of siding with a group of Eco-terrorists or the local police. This choice introduces the MORALITY METER. Yep. Postal has a MORALITY METER now. The "Insanity" path with the Eco-terrorists becomes a very Postal-esque story with the Dude still going around looking for work and not getting paid while the "Good" path has the Dude become a cop. 

With a predecessor that allowed you to do whatever you want in terms of your daily objectives, the choice of a binary system waggling it's finger at you for you being a good boy or a bad boy is just stupid. Not only that, but the game actively tells you off for going along the "Insanity" route and reaching the ending. Just a big "Screw you for being bad, maybe be nicer and get a better ending." 

The weapons are atrocious. Like if i have to hit a civilian or a cop five-six times point blank with a shotgun and they STILL get up, we have a problem. The molotovs don't linger for long and people on fire don't spread it by running into other people (WHICH POSTAL 2 HAD). The grenades can barely kill ANYTHING. The guns have the worst spread and accuracy ever, even aiming with the pistol i've seen shots miss my target because the bullet decided to go off in another direction entirely. 

I've had textures pop in and out of existence or flicker (very obvious when arresting people since the camera spins around) to the point where the sides of the bridge in the tutorial never appeared unless my camera was pointed in certain directions. The top of the bridge was fine, but the sides? Mostly non-existent. 

The game crashes are numerous and beyond intrusive. 

The achievements? Good luck. Most of them don't trigger properly after story segments, others don't count properly and some are just broken with no fixes or workarounds. 

Despite RWS coming out and removing the DRM and taking out three absolutely broken achievements among other fixes, this game still isn't worth your time. They don't even see a dollar from the sales still. This game completely shut down a Russian dev team (TrashMasters, how ironic since they made this piece of filth) and have almost rendered publisher Akella out of business. 

My good takeaways from this game is that i found one joke absolutely funny. The cutscenes were pretty well done. Corey Cruise did a pretty good job with voicing the Postal Dude. He came recommended from Rick Hunter himself as he was facing personal challenges as the game was in development. But most of all, Running with Scissors are some of the best developers around. They didn't need to bring this hellscape back on sale or bother making some fixes. But they did. All the while still working on Postal 4. 

I'm solely reviewing this game before Postal 2 since the Paradise Lost DLC rendered this entire campaign of nightmares non-canon. 

The real Champ died in 2011 and was given a tribute screen at the beginning of the game. Such a lovely animal doesn't deserve to be given a tribute as degrading as Postal 3.

column8: No lo recomiendo por lo divertido, este juego lo compre por 3 razones 1ra. Para poder tener otro juego mas de la saga posta a pesar de este es el peor de todos pues por 1,01$ no esta nada mal, 2do. Para poder sacar los logros (saque el 100%, aunque algunas misiones osea "3" las borraron del steam al ser imposibles de hacer en el juego), 3ra. Y ultima pues lo compre para poder matar a unos de los jefes finales menos esperados que e visto nunca "Hugo Chavez" o como le dicen aqu√≠ "La Mortadela Galactica" ya que para poder disfrutar matarlo a mas de 10 a√±os despu√©s de su muerte una y otra y otra y otra y otra y otra y otra y otra y OTRA Y OTRA Y OTRA vez hasta que me aburra matar al peor dictador que a tenido mi pa√≠s que es Venezuela. As√≠ que.... JUEGAZO 1/10, la historia es casi un sin sentido, los npc se vuelven locos y DIOS MIO LAS MISIONES DE SEGUIR O PROTEGER A ALGUIEN QUE ME DA LADILLA (FASTIDIO) HACER ESOS TIPO DE MISIONES!!!
column9: I do not recommend it for how fun it is, I bought this game for 3 reasons 1st. To be able to have another game in the saga really despite this being the worst of all because for $ 1.01 it is not bad at all, 2nd. To be able to get the achievements (I got 100%, although some missions, that is, "3" were deleted from Steam because they were impossible to do in the game), 3rd. And lastly, I bought it to be able to kill one of the least expected final bosses I have ever seen "Hugo Chavez" or as they call him here "La Mortadella Galactica" since in order to enjoy killing him more than 10 years after his death again and again and again and again and again and again and again and AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN again until I get bored of killing the worst dictator that my country, Venezuela, has ever had. So... GREAT GAME 1/10, the story is almost pointless, the NPCs go crazy and MY GOD THE MISSIONS OF FOLLOWING OR PROTECTING SOMEONE GIVE ME ANNOYANCE (ANNOYING) DOING THOSE TYPES OF MISSIONS!!!

The worst Source Engine game ever. Just as the Nintendo 64, a console that brought back memories for Yankees, had Superman 64, I suspect this was created for balance reasons.

It was suspended from sale due to DRM issues, then revived and updated, but improvements are still far from complete.

The game has only [b]slightly[/b] fixed the crashing issue, but no matter what improvements are made, it's hopeless, so I recommend not playing it (the price has been reduced to 6,700 won).

Postal 3 was one of the worst RWS games... until Postal 4 came out.
And as strange as it may sound, the game actually turned out to be not as bad as I previously thought. Yes, yes. I'm saying right now that I liked Postal 3 more than the fourth game.
I don't know who worked on the recent (as of fall 2023) patch, but I take my hat off to them. Because from a piece of crap, they turned it into a PLAYABLE Postal 3, which I actually enjoyed.
Despite the irrelevance of some of the jokes (why the hell is Mavrodi even here?), the game gets a solid B-, while Postal 4 gets a C.
That's all for now, I wish everyone well, happiness, and peace.
P.S. Vince (or whoever else), you're tired of wasting money on whores and powder >:/

As soon as the game returned to Steam, you could buy it for just $1, and I'm telling you, it was the best dollar spent on a game. Postal 3 is a masterpiece of crap, where everything works half-assed and almost everything is fucked up (except the soundtrack and the dude's voice acting), but for some reason it's simply impossible to tear yourself away from this bug fest (even though the game kicks you out every 20 minutes). It's a living example of how not to make a game, but nevertheless, you can have fun here. If you enjoy cheesy toilet humor and senseless violence (that is, purely for fans of the series), and if you feel like a philanthropist and want to support the Russian gaming industry, then go for it.

I played Postal 3 a little after the last patch. 

The game is not bad but it still needs to be fixed. 
The game sometimes freezes or crashes, in cut scenes the music may overlap each other, the Dude‚Äôs lines may break under certain conditions and he will remain silent until the end of the mission, and sound artifacts may also appear at moments when many NPCs are shooting, and I also noticed that textures sometimes lag. The game definitely still needs some fixes. But despite all this, I liked Postal 3, I hope that in the future the game will be completely corrected.

I hope that these problems will be noticed by one of the developers and they will be fixed soon.

La storia della creazione di Postal 3 √® molto travagliata (e non star√≤ ora a spiegarla). La qualit√† del gioco √® molto scadente, e anche con la patch per la rimozione del DRM russo (che ha portato anche qualche piccola miglioria), il gioco rimane pieno di problemi e bug che lo rendono non giocabile, con livelli insuperabili (senza utilizzare skip o manovre particolari con gli NPC che ti seguono).
Non voglio concentrarmi troppo sulle caratteristiche del gioco, ma a mio parere, aver tolto la mappa libera, in favore di singoli livelli, √® un grande punto a sfavore (originariamente doveva essere come il 2, ma √® stata eliminata questa possibilit√†). Togliendo tutti i problemi presenti nel gioco, alla fine risulta comunque divertente da provare, ma sconsiglio comunque l'acquisto, a meno che non lo troviate a 1‚Ç¨ e vogliate provare questo strano gioco.
column9:
The story of Postal 3's creation is very troubled (and I won't go into it now). The game's quality is very poor, and even with the patch to remove the Russian DRM (which also brought some small improvements), the game remains riddled with problems and bugs that make it unplayable, with unpassable levels (without using skips or special maneuvers with the NPCs that follow you).
I don't want to focus too much on the game's features, but in my opinion, removing the free-roaming map in favor of individual levels is a major drawback (it was originally supposed to be like Postal 2, but this option was removed). Even with all the problems present in the game, it's still fun to play, but I still don't recommend buying it unless you find it for ‚Ç¨1 and want to try this strange game.

column8: Worst game I have ever played, however I regret nothing.
column9: Worst game I have ever played, however I regret nothing.

[h1] POSTAL III - Between "Okay" and "Crap" [/h1]

Hmmm... Well, I have mixed feelings about this game. On the one hand, there are issues with optimization, crashes, and even sound (not as critical as I imagined, but they're there). On the other hand, the references are okay (in my opinion), the story is pretty decent, and the voice acting (though many people aren't happy with it, I like it). But let's take things one step at a time. I also want to thank one guide for providing a selection of good mods, some of which I downloaded. Here's the link:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2913776987

[b] Now we can begin. [/b]

[h2] 1 - Optimization [/h2]

I don't even want to justify it. The optimization here is a piece of crap. I know my computer is old (built around 2009), but for the game to run THIS BADLY is just insane. Even if you want to lower the graphics settings to increase your FPS, it's ABSOLUTELY USELESS! The game doesn't care what your graphics settings are (it won't change your FPS anyway). I also want to mention the CRASHES. At first, they were rare (and I didn't really care), but then it got worse. I experienced 4 PERMANENT CRASHES in about 40-50 minutes. By "permanent," I mean I had to restart my computer to restart the game (because the game would freeze the entire computer). But after I downloaded some mods from the guide (which is above), the crashes stopped and I was able to complete the game (albeit with critically low FPS at some points).

[h2] Soundtracks, Audio, and Voice Acting [/h2]

First, let's talk about the sounds. They're okay. Well, just okay. Personally, I didn't dislike them. But if you don't like them, there's a mod in the guide that replaces some of the soundtracks.
Now, the sound. Same as with the sounds ‚Äì okay. Nothing more to say.
Lastly, the voice acting. I liked it. I understand that everyone would like to hear Alexander Gruzdev (the voice of the Dude from the Second Postal), but I like this voice acting too. It's so "cinematic-cartoonish" (I can't describe it any other way), and I like it. But there's one bug: when playing one of the Dude's lines, a machine-like crackling sound plays instead (as if you've submerged the speakers in water). But then I entered "snd_rebuildaudiocache" in the console, and everything was fixed.

[h2] Graphics and Effects [/h2]

The graphics overall look fine. There were no texture bugs (and I don't really care about graphics anyway), so I have no issues with them.
The effects are about the same. Fire, grenade explosions, and blood effects are all fine.

[h2] Interface and Controls [/h2]

We now have a third-person view, and I didn't like that. I find the first-person view more immersive (firstly, I like it better, and secondly, I have trouble aiming in third-person). I also want to mention the "weapon distribution." At first, I was extremely unhappy with the fact that they shoved all the weapons into one "line" and told me to "figure out where everything is yourself," but then I got used to it and even found it more convenient to use the weapons through the "line" than through the "sections" in the second post. Everything else was fine.
Now the controls. They're also fine. Nothing else to say.

[h2] Plot and Gameplay [/h2]

The plot continues the story from Post II. After escaping Paradise, we find ourselves in Catharsis. Throughout the game, the Dude tries to earn money, but each time (for various reasons) he can't get paid. At the end of the game, we escape Catharsis, and all our enemies and those who couldn't pay us are punished. I could tell you all about the Dude's attempts to earn money, but I'm too lazy.

Now about the gameplay. We go on various missions to earn money. At first, they seem monotonous (like "collect 15 cats"), but after a while, some kind of conflict arises between the Dude and a group of people, which forces you to not only complete the assigned mission, but also try not to die (basically, like in Post II). Unfortunately, you can't change the difficulty, and that's frustrating.

[h2] Summary [/h2]

POSTAL III is a decent game. On the one hand, there are few things that make me hate it, but on the other hand, the FUCKING OPTIMIZATION, CRASH BUGS, and THIS CRASHING FPS overshadow any positive emotions I might have had from the game and make me want to immediately refund my money.
My rating: 6.9/10
If you have any questions about my review or would like to add any arguments about "why I don't like the game" or, conversely, "why I liked the game" (which will rarely happen), please write in the comments below (I'll be sure to answer them).
Want to chat? My DS (stream_boy)
See you soon!

I bought this "miracle" at a discount for 50 rubles, right after the release of the patch in which the developers removed the DRM protection and "optimized" the game for modern hardware. I wanted to play some trash. I played it, thanks. I don't want to play it again.

Pros:
+ The game costs pennies.
+ Runs on your computer.
+ Similar to Postal (in the sense that the game contains that same ultra-violence).
+ Dumb humor and voice acting, which some might find funny (so we'll chalk that up as a plus).
+ Non-linearity. You can choose to be a good cop and not kill civilians. Or become a psychotic terrorist, shooting everyone left and right. Your choice will change the levels and missions.

Cons:
- Uninteresting missions where you're forced to do mundane things like collecting items or shooting enemies. - Terrible graphics. Even by 2011 standards. The game looks poor and very cheap.
- There's no open world. The entire game is a series of missions. Yes, it has relatively large locations, but they're nowhere near the level of the map from the second game.
- Stupid enemy and teammate AI: they stare at walls, run away from you, or can get stuck at the beginning of a level, preventing you from completing a mission.
- Terrible shooting. To kill an enemy, you need to shoot them 3-4 times. The enemy won't react at all to the first 2-3 shots.
- Horrible close-quarters combat, where standing close to a crowd of enemies and swinging an axe won't kill anyone.
- Long loading times.
- Lack of optimization. The FPS constantly drops. So you'll have to put up with frame rates dropping to 40-50 frames, especially in large locations and during firefights. The game doesn't care what hardware you have.
- Constant bugs and broken scripts. The main character's sound started to malfunction on the third mission (I was able to fix it). And during the city patrol mission, the script broke, completely freezing the game (I had to restart the level).
- Crashes. During the mission with Uwe Boll, the game just crashes in the same place. I couldn't find a solution to the problem, even if it was possible. I didn't want to. That was the last straw for me.

So what's the bottom line?
Considering the game's low price, a lot could be forgiven. Bugs, lag, and everything else, but unfortunately, not crashes that make the game simply unplayable. So I issued a refund. It's a shame to spend even 50 rubles on something like this.

I disliked this game almost halfway through, but after finishing it completely, I changed my mind and rating. As a big fan of the dude and Postal, I was pleased to see everything I saw in Postal 2, only packaged differently and powered by a new engine with a ton of new features. Obviously, if you were a Postal 2 fan, you'll probably enjoy this game 90% of the time, but if you're a Zoomer looking for the same old experience and atmosphere, you'll get nothing but a ton of crashes and bugs. 
For those looking to immerse themselves in the world of Postal, I recommend starting with Part 2 (the first one is a bit of an acquired taste), as Part 3 has a lot of references to Part 2 and a smooth transition between them. If we go by criteria:
Graphics: 7/10 (decent for its time, not too jarring)
Story: 9/10 (the repetitive nature of the missions is evident: kill this, save that, etc.)
Mechanics: 10/10 (I didn't encounter any issues)
Bugs: 5/10 (some are funny, others require a restart)
Characters: 10/10 (no boring characters, all crazy with cool lines)
Overall: 8.5/10

P.S. I got this on sale for 49 rubles; for the discounted price, it's 1000% worth it.

Postal 3 is a good game (especially with the patch after its return). Yes, there are some complaints about it, like the shooting and optimization. But despite all its flaws, Postal 4, in my opinion, is still worse than Postal 3. I hope they don't abandon the game, but rather patch it, and maybe then Postal 3 will be a great game to say without tears.
#FIXPOSTAL3

column9: FUCKING SHIT, POSTAL BRAIN DAMAGE & POSTAL 2 BETTER DRINK

[h1] A Brief About Postal 3 [/h1]

[b]You know, I first tried the game back in '14, but I vividly remember those moments when everyone was trashing it.

And you know, I agree with those statements.[/b] 

[h2] The Russians, who didn't even try to make it good.[/h2] 

[b]As everyone knows, the game was worked on by the equally famous guys from Akella. And some year they bought the rights to develop a third installment in the notorious Postal series. And that was the first warning sign. But I won't talk about the development and other consequences now. The only thing that bothered me in this regard was the many references to Russia. I agree, the game is more popular here. But damn, one small reference could have been enough. But damn, there are quite a few of these references; Mavrodi alone is worth something, and the Russian song about vodka in a bar. Damn, this doesn't really fit into the game's flavor, especially considering that the game originally had references to American culture. They're not in this game either, but they migrated from the second game. [/b] 

[h3] Years later, forever.[/h3]

[b]What's changed over the years? Oddly enough, Akella disbanded in 2012, I think. And accordingly, the game hasn't been improved at all; all the bugs, freezes, and everything else remain to this day. The problem with the guy's garbled lines alone is enough to make me play without headphones in some parts (I know it can be fixed). There are tons of bugs in the game, including the police station bug where, if you run past the policeman, any subsequent door might not open, and you have to replay it all over again. Optimization is a weird thing. It seems like it's 100 fps, but then it drops to 23 seconds later, and these fluctuations persist throughout the entire game. And there are all sorts of minor issues, but they manifest themselves differently for everyone. [/b] 

[h2]Short overview, short summary [/h2] 

[b]Damn, even the storyline is short. If you don't screw up the entire game and stick to one path, you can complete the game in 4 hours or less. By the way, yes, the game does have paths, like good and evil. And it doesn't really make a difference; in any case, the game is quickly completed on either path, but the endings always boil down to us punishing everyone and everything.
Yeah, it's great, I agree. It's cool that this game is back on Steam. It's a bit of a nostalgia thing, and all that. And I agree that you can buy the game for the collection. I did that myself, but I also decided to play through it at the same time, since I've never done that before. And I'll say one thing: I won't be playing it again, because I simply can't stand such nonsense. It's good for a raw indie project, but it's not exactly a AAA title. So even if you decide to pick it up, get it on sale, because 40 rubles isn't much. I recommend it for the price, nostalgia, and collection, nothing more. Because it's impossible to play, at least not at all.

In short, this was my subjective opinion, which you shouldn't really take into account; you'll make your own judgment anyway. But I'd be glad if you gave this review a rating; maybe I told you something useful about the game that contributed to your purchase decision.

[i]That's it, hugs[/i]

[i]Aaaaaahhh..... (By the way, this sounds after almost every scene, and it was also annoying). Courage Bombay prod.[/i]

column8:
Postal III was originally set as a sequel to Postal 2, but the game was so notoriously bad and buggy, the creators of the franchise disowned it. However, now its status is semi-canon, with the events here taking place during Postal Dude's coma and the Dude we play here is his alternate personality as stated in the P2 DLC Paradise Lost. A major update in October 2023 fixed many things, making the game more stable and fully playable, at least in my experience.

Unlike P2, which was first-person and open-world, P3 is played from a third-person perspective and the missions are more similar to Apocalypse Weekend, being one missions after another instead of errands we do in a free-roam city. And I think it's a weird choice, since there is a free-roam map, but it's only purpose is for you to walk around, no missions. Maybe they're trying to make a more focused linear experience, but instead it makes the game feel disjointed.

Story-wise, there are 2 paths you can follow, Good or Insane, with similar, but sometimes different missions. It's recommended to try both paths, since if you play only one, the game isn't actually that long, and they have different story achievements. While adding a good path on Postal game might seem like a weird choice it doesn't seem that out of character since he still retains a similar sarcastic view and humor.

One of the biggest issues with this game is that it feels unpolished and unfinished, even after the update. And yes, sadly it's true. The movement feels stiff, weapon switching is messy, a useless open world with no map, no subtitles, and its unoptimized, sometimes it lags despite not being a heavy game. Some broken achievements have been removed, but some are still broken, only counting during specific events or something unrelated at all. Like how the "capture terrorist" one only counts when defeating the meth rhino boss.

While it's obviously still a broken game, with the update I think Postal III is worth a try, and if you enjoy the franchise and want more you might as well play the semi-canon content. It's honestly not that bad, and still has a pretty similar vibe to Postal 2, just not as good. If you don't expect a masterpiece you'd still have fun here.

column9: The only Source game with a 3 in it's name.

"I regret nothing" - Postal Dude
Oddly enough, despite the game's flaws, it's... Good? Yes.
After applying a couple of mods, fixing a couple of flaws with patches, and ta-da, it's playable! I've only played a little over an hour at the time of this review, but I think I can handle the most disappointing game in the series, although 4 will be joining soon.
It lags worse than RDR 2

Rostaline 3, or "Champa's catnip dream"

A Siberian dog gave me this piece of crap with the "dog's dream" plot, and I basically completed it as a challenge. The bugs, the awkward controls, and the public perception that this is supposedly the worst game are frustrating.
Sam 2 gets trashed too, but it's awesome. Doom 3 gets trashed, but it's good in its own way.
This game can be given a chance, but it's still buggy in places, especially the achievements, has awkward controls, is a bit unbalanced, and is rather short.

The plot is a mess, as if after the events of the second game we ended up somewhere else and now we have a choice like "two chairs," i.e. Whether Dude is a friend or a cop, it won't be a bad thing either way... At least he doesn't give a shit about the others.

The gameplay is fucking awesome: we walk around, complete missions‚Äîsometimes you have to kill, sometimes you don't. For the "good" ending, it's best not to kill anyone at all, and for the bad ending, you have to immediately choose the side of the assholes. In this part, there's SUDDENLY TRANSPORTATION, but they're fucking faggot-like Segways... From which you can only shoot with a pistol, "HOW MANY PASTELETS ARE IN A CARTRIDGE? Sulka!" (c) Tuplinov.
Another cool thing is that here we kill Tablios, Venezuelans, "Yazhemamok," and "Ecotologists," but at the same time, we leave gays alone and even defend Uwe Boll, even though he wants to kick our asses... Although, on the bad side, from the alternative side, we probably kill everything that moves.

The view from the 3rd game is a bit unusual, the controls are a bit sloppy ‚Äì the spacebar doesn't jump, but rather takes cover, inventory, and weapons all in one place, the gasoline often doesn't ignite, there are still a ton of bugs, and throwing grains is kind of tricky.
AT THE OTHER THING, there's the BADGER weapon (like a chainsaw), bee bombs (hello, Thunderosaurs), and you don't need any money.

Someone might say, "Akela missed," but I'll say, "The Scissor Runners ran too long and messed with the wrong people."
Oh well, you can play this for free. They say the 4th game is even worse.
9.5 badgers out of 10, and one badger tail right up to the belly...

column8:
"This can't be good for you, but I feel great for this. Buckle Up"

Those were the words my brother told me when he gifted me this game to play as he knows how much I enjoy the Postal series. I admit I was a little worried at first knowing of the reputation this game had but at the same time excited to see just how truly horrible this game was.

First off the game is buggy especially in the achievement department making them a rather pain to get and it had nothing to do with player skill. I also did not enjoy using melee weapons at all where they were a joy to use in Postal 2 and in Postal 4. 

During the opening mission in the game where it taught you how to use the gasoline can and matches to set fires, it felt really awkward to do and I had trouble trying to set the zombies on fire where as in Postal 2 and Postal 4 it is nowhere near as difficult to do. This made me think that either Postal does not translate well as a third person shooter game or the team just had a rough time trying to make it work. In this regard Postal 2 and Postal 4 are more fun to play in the first person perspective and I wonder if staying first person would have helped Postal 3.

Another thing that felt off for me was the urine mechanics. Usually if you were on fire you get Postal Dude to look up and urinate and the fire would be extinguished, it was in no way shape or form an easy task in Postal 3 to the point where I don't even know if that mechanic even works.

As for crashes the game surprisingly did not crash nearly as much as I was fearing it would. I honestly had more crashes trying to play an Elder Scrolls and Fallout game. There was one particularly bad time however in the mission where I was escorting a cop to the basement where I honestly thought about quitting the game. I however restarted the mission from the beginning and got it to work without crashing. Honestly I have never quick saved so much in a game in my life.

Thankfully I was able to get my Xbox controller to work after going into the config.cfg file and changing joystick = 0 to joystick = 1 but the keyboard and mouse were still necessary for using the main menu. 

Upon completing the game going down both paths I feel that Postal 3 is the weakest Postal game and feels more like a fan game made by people who really love the series, but didn't let it fully cook. As janky as the game maybe and frustrating parts that I would never want to deal with again (I am looking at you rhino boss fights), I do not think Postal 3 is as horrible as it's reputation would have you to believe.

There is some fun to be found in this game. I had way more fun arresting people than I thought I would have and really like how that was brought back into Postal 4.

At the end of the day Postal 3 is janky, that cannot be denied, however I feel that if you are a fan of the series and have never played Postal 3 it is worth a shot if you catch it on sale. Postal, Postal Redux, Postal 2, Postal 4 and Postal Brain Damaged will always be the superior Postal games and the ones that should be recommended to new comers to the series, but Postal 3 deserves a little bit of love too. I can see myself coming back to it again even though the rhino fights annoy me greatly, perhaps I will just skip those.

The game is top-notch! Tons of meat, tons of shit, and tons of brutal machilov!!!

Honestly, this is a very mixed bag for me. I'd give it a "neutral" rating, but that's not an option, and this game has more downsides. Postal 3 could have been a good installment and a decent successor if RWS had made it themselves. It suffers from poor optimization, physics, and even the story. The gameplay hasn't changed much. There are some new features, but they're so minimal that you don't even notice them. I liked the cutscene style, but the jokes have become more obvious. Only the Taliban disguised as Mexicans was a bit funny. And the Persians are a bit underwhelming, just slapdash. Overall, it's a failed experiment and a big mistake for RWS. They shouldn't have given Akella control.

column8:
Grenades need to explode an inch next to the target, any further and they don't die.

Pouring gasoline in the tutorial hole was extremely difficult. And pouring gasoline on a fire does not ignite it, it makes the gasoline disappear.

Enemies get to a safe distance and THEN they start blastin'.

Had a bug after I loaded an autosave where no matter what directional key I pressed the dude insisted in going in a single direction. I manually saved and loaded that save and it seemed to fix that issue.

Could not do the human shield thing that the game instructed me to do.

Started to fist fight soldiers with automatics, started to win and the game did not like me doing that, so it crashed.

10/10 would not recommend to anyone. It was 1 euro so I'm not returning it, but I'm not playing it anymore, either.

column9: Hello, if you're French, the French version of the game isn't playable; you'll get an error message. Don't bother trying to get the file elsewhere, as the textures will be buggy (purple/black). So, go to Properties/General and select the English version. And there you have it, you can play. It's unacceptable for games to be sold in a non-functional state.

Fuck, I didn't think I'd screwed up 3 so much. It's such a huge piece of crap.
I don't even want to play this piece of crap, but thanks to my friend for giving it to me.

This is really bad.
Stupid, not funny, annoying.
There's a great add-on called Paradise Lost for the second game; play it.

Surprisingly, I haven't encountered a single bug in all my time playing.

Let's just say that despite all the hate, this installment, which was "declared non-canon," is better in every way than the canonical Postal 4.

Post-player update: yes, this installment is definitely better than Postal 4.

Post-SECOND playthrough update: yes, the bosses in Postal are definitely the weakest part of the game, no matter which one. Bosses in the series aren't just bad, they're terrible.

Well, except for Brain Damaged and the first installment, but that's a whole other story...

The game is just a bomb that was planted.
In one mission, you have to collect milk. Vacuum cleaners.
9/11.

Well, what can I say? It's a cool game, and for fifty bucks, it's a must-have. It's just not without its flaws.

[h3]Glitches[/h3]

It felt like more than 10 years had passed, and the glitches were still there. The glitch with the guy's voice acting was so bad I had to go to the console to find the manual. The game also crashed periodically, which, for obvious reasons, didn't exactly thrill me. At the beginning, I got a bug with the controls, spent 10 minutes trying to kill zombies with gasoline, and blew up an enemy three times with a grenade. As the game progressed, I mostly had problems with the same canister and bazooka, but otherwise, I didn't notice any major issues.

[h3]Plot[/h3]

It's unclear why they even included a karma system in a silly shoot-em-up. Having reached catharsis, the Dude faces a problem: he's out of money, but you hang in there (all the best and good cheer to you). Trying to earn a little cash, he begins to roam the new city in search of work. I don't know why, but I thought the second game was better in terms of humor. Speaking of storylines, there are roughly two: for the police and for the homeless [spoiler]if you want a good one, then you're on the cops[/spoiler]. Well, you'll figure it out for yourself. One of the downsides I didn't like was that both plots more or less repeat certain elements, which... well, how can you explain it? In one case, the Dude himself provokes the events, in the other, the same thing happens, but it's... sort of... created by some unknown... In short, the game is old, so don't dwell on this too much. It took me six and a half hours to get through the two endings.

[h3] Filling the World [/h3]

The same old favorite "activists," ready to kill anyone for any reason. Representatives of the "most peaceful religion" (I hope they don't kill me for that). Just how we love absurdity upon absurdity, and absurdity upon absurdity! You can't even enter most of the locations; they're just there for show. I don't know why, but the second part also seems more expansive to me in terms of maps. However, for a game from 2011, even for a 50-dollar game, it's forgivable.

[h3]Also:[/h3]
-NPCs groaning at a decapitated corpse.
-enemies that can withstand three shots to the gut.
-enemies' skulls, either cardboard or steel, can sometimes withstand two or three hits in a row.
-a homeless person "marking" corners.
-a flare gun that explodes in your hands.
-OOOOOH! Hey, Krotchi! You're still alive? We'll fix it in a minute!
-"Why do you hate America?"

column8: Actually pretty decent for a shooter, once they removed most of the crashy bits and crust. It is held down pretty flat by the fact that it is not a traditional Postal game, e.g. it's mission-based, and by being mission-based it has some of those traditional hangups on game design that mission-based games have, like escort missions, escort missions where your escort gets stuck on a wall or door and needs to be prodded or shot to get moving, do the thing 20 times missions.... You get the idea. It gets some points back at the parts where you have free license to do anything you want, particularly the places where you can freely shift the branch meter as you like, but loses those points again when you have to ensure a specific person lives, and if you lose track of them God help you. These things thankfully tend to be few and far between but this game is labelled the black sheep of the Postal series for a reason. It's just not the Postal we know and love - it's a Postal-themed physics simulator instead. Still pretty decent shooting though, and arresting anyone you want is the best part of the game.

column8: This game is not as bad as everyone says. Don't be a sheep and start hating on it because a lot of people said so, I played it and I faced no problems, the punch control is bad, but honestly the Rifle and Pistol are amazing, and I love using them more than anything, the gore is satisfying and snapping the necks of the human shields you take are bound to make you smile guaranteed. The story is meh, but the humor is okay, unlike some games... (We're looking at you, POSTAL 4.)
column9: This game is not as bad as everyone says. Don't be a sheep and start hating on it because a lot of people said so, I played it and I faced no problems, the punch control is bad, but honestly the Rifle and Pistol are amazing, and I love using them more than anything, the gore is satisfying and snapping the necks of the human shields you take are bound to make you smile guaranteed. The story is meh, but the humor is okay, unlike some games... (We're looking at you, POSTAL 4.)

Once upon a time, after school, I'd go over to a friend's house to play Postal 2, chase people around asking them to sign a petition, stroll past beautiful women with my fly unzipped, and simply cause a bloodbath by walking into a neighbor's house, where hard rock was blasting at full blast. Later, when I started playing it on my own, with purpose, feeling, and deliberation, I was delighted by the dark humor, interesting, and fun missions in the cozy and now familiar Paradise. The developer and publisher was the American computer game group Running with Scissors, releasing this creation in 2003. By the time the third installment of the series came out, I'd already forgotten about it. After looking at the gameplay footage from the screenshots and the positive-to-negative feedback, I thought it was definitely the wrong coat, and it wasn't made right. And, as it turns out, I was right.

The publisher here isn't some punk, but Akella, whose logo was designed by either Artemy Lebedev or a homeless person for a penny based on the appearance of a stoned wolf. And the *developer* is the wonderful studio behind the hellish Xyeta ‚Äì Trashmasters. The name speaks for itself. How they even ended up participating in the development and publishing of the franchise is a mystery to me. And since the game was made by [b]OURS[/b], it turned out to have [strike]soul[/strike].
My ears immediately started bleeding from the volume of the music and the sound in the menu. I had to turn it down to the lowest setting. Before that, I had to peer into the settings window with three magnifying glasses, because on Full HD, that Source-specific square, it turns out, doesn't stretch.

Just when I thought things couldn't get any worse, the long-awaited gameplay begins. The controls in this game seem to have been ported from some mobile crap, because in 2011‚Äîthe year the Assassins' Secret Service sequel and threequel were released‚Äîseeing this and navigating the map without swearing and engaging in combat with enemies was a challenge even for Shaolin monks. A tutorial on the basics begins on a bridge‚Äîwe need to cross it. A cutscene plays, featuring graphics and character development that the second game gives to the fang. A red arrow flashes next to the red car; we clearly need to go there. So, I walk over there and stand. What? WHAT THE FUCK am I supposed to do here? Crouch? No, there are no squats here. Ram the soldiers shooting? No, he can't run out of there. I'd already pissed myself in that fucking corner between two cars, and just when I was about to close the game, the second cutscene started. I won't describe my entire playthrough, especially since after 20-30 minutes, during the cat-catching mission, it closed on its own, giving me some kind of error. Although, maybe the game is reading your mental state and deliberately closing at the most critical moment, I don't know. At that moment, I was desperately fighting like a lion with the restaurant workers who serve these cats. HOW THE FUCK CAN YOU CREATE SUCH A CRAPPY CONTROLS AND COMBAT SYSTEM, YOU CLUELESS MORONS.
Ultimately, for 40 rubles, I'd rather have the Baltika 9 on sale, and that's another trash game for my library.

What a piece of crap this is
At first the game is fun, but after a while it turns into a Donbass simulator.
It's actually not as bad as they say. I played through it twice and didn't see any really annoying bugs.
Don't buy this shit, the sounds are buggy and boring. Save up and buy part 2.

I didn't even get past the first level because it was unplayable. The controls are unintuitive. I spent two minutes searching for the "action" button. The camera shakes as if someone with epilepsy were holding it while running. For some reason, the Dude isn't centered, but rather to the left of center. But the worst part is the Dude's voice acting. Was it really that hard to get Gruzdev to voice the Dude? He translated the Dude perfectly.

In short, it's a complete disaster; even for 40 rubles, it's too expensive. I've requested a refund.
It lags when I move the mouse, but the PC handles it.

column8:
Postal and especially Postal 2 were quite the controversy when they came out, in my part of the world Postal 2 was actually completely banned so naturally I had to have it no matter what. As it turned out Postal 2 was amusing for a few minutes but it quickly became apparent it was not a very good game, whereas Postal 1 was actually pretty good even if a very old game. 

Unfortunately by the time this game came out the joke was already very old and controversy was not going to give a free pass. Trying this is 2023 it is immediately apparent this is just an awful game that cant be saved by its shock value (that doesn't exist anymore) or quirky humour. 

I think it may be worth picking up at the AU $1.50 I got it for, even if just to own a Postal game. Otherwise I feel life is too short and time too precious to waste on awful low quality games.

column8:
Worth a try for 84p, but the game is still terrible. Postal 3 is an absolute abomination of a video game, and I wouldn't wish the experience of playing it on my worst enemy. It's a steaming pile of digital excrement that somehow manages to make its predecessors look like masterpieces.

First and foremost, the graphics in Postal 3 are an eyesore. It's as if the developers intentionally set out to create the ugliest, most visually offensive game possible. The character models are blocky and grotesque, the environments are bland and uninspired, and the overall art direction is an affront to good taste.

The gameplay is equally abysmal. The controls are clunky and unresponsive, making even basic tasks a chore. The AI is laughably bad, with enemies that either stand around like cardboard cutouts or engage in erratic, unpredictable behavior that makes combat a frustrating exercise in futility. The game's open-world structure is a complete mess, with a lack of direction and purpose that leaves you wandering aimlessly through a world that's about as engaging as a post-apocalyptic wasteland without any of the cool factors.


The technical issues in Postal 3 are too numerous to count. It's riddled with bugs, crashes, and performance problems that make it nearly unplayable. It's clear that this game was rushed to release, with little care or attention to quality.

In summary, Postal 3 is an absolute trainwreck of a game. It's an embarrassment to the medium, a stain on the Postal franchise, and a waste of your time and money. Do yourself a favor and steer clear of this abomination. There are countless better games out there that deserve your attention, and Postal 3 is not one of them.

column8: To be honest despite very negative reviews I quite enjoyed playing. So far I finished one campaign, insane mode. Maybe because I played after ,,No DRM'' update but it was not as buggy as everyone says. I really liked it. I didn't mind change of camera and controls, after getting used to it went quite smooth. Music is excellent. 3D cutscenes are kinda weird, especially type of animating they used, 2d were fine. I really, really enjoyed having more Champ in game, especially having him as a part of a plot. Some Dude's lines got me, but it is nothing extraordinary. Game crashed on me only twice, which is suprising when seeing other reviews. I have to complain about small selection of weapons in comparasion to Postal 2, at least from what I expierienced in my gameplay. In my opinion it is fine (not revolutionary, not genre changing, just fine) game and I see a chance of me coming back to it to try other modes even if bad path ending is bs. I'd rate it 5-6/10. In my opinion worth picking up on sale (I bought it for like ~2$). Have a krotchy day.

column8: It sucks. That's why i wanna play it.
column9: It sucks. That's why i wanna play it.

This game is unfairly trashed.
Let's get it some "Very Positive" reviews!

Postal 3 is undoubtedly an underrated masterpiece of the gaming industry, surpassing Postal 4, but RVS screwed up again even with this.

So they (not really them) created a "patch" that fixed the game and returned it to retail, even though they'd previously actively trashed the game, campaigned for its removal from the Steam store, and posted disparaging posts about Postal 3 (come on, they even have a banner for one of the Postal series bundles saying Postal 3 is crap and should be returned to the sender). But it would have been fine if they'd made a patch, but they didn't even bother to finish it.

It's worth starting with the fact that this patch with the fixes wasn't made by RVS; they simply took the ZOOM version. RVS only removed the DRM and took the rest of the credit.

Of course, optimization was improved, some bugs were fixed, the annoying DRM was removed, and the game reached a playable state that Trashmasters and Akella couldn't achieve, but RWS didn't bother adding half of what they promised in the patch notes. The Gama Gun, which makes playing on the Pacifist much easier, was never added, which left me personally disappointed, even though I read the patch notes before purchasing the game. Voice acting bugs (for example, unpleasant audio artifacts) were never fixed. The promised FGD was not added, which could have spurred modding.

Basically, RWS fed players with empty promises and then delivered nothing, claiming to be busy with the extremely flawed Postal 4.

column9: To the haters' GULAG!

column8:
[h1]So bad, that it killed Akella, Trashmasters and almost killed RWS.[/h1]

Don't get me wrong, I know the game started with good intentions, and wanted to be the best episode in the Franchise. But Akella stopped working with RWS and tried to save everything they could when the Russian economy crashed.

In the end, we have a game with flawed, and sometimes, broken mecanics. Distanced itself from a lot of the classic gameplay of the franchise, just to play awfully as a third-person in itself, and horrible as a Postal game.

[h3][b]There is still fun to be had however[/b], with perhaps a couple of mods, you can probably squish some broken mechanics like the pacifist system or the camera weapon aiming. At its core, it is a subpar game and an awful entry into the Postal series.[/h3]

Wait for [url=https://www.moddb.com/mods/catharsis-reborn]Catharsis Reborn[/url] if you want to see how it could have looked and played if it wasn't rushed, or [url=https://www.moddb.com/mods/postal-3-unreal]Postal Unreal[/url], if you want a more classic FPS Postal experience akin to Postal 2. Or even play [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/707030/POSTAL_4_No_Regerts]Postal 4[/url] currently, which is being developed by RWS themselves, who managed to get up from this episode, and are making their best with a far smaller, and fewer available resources, a game more worth of your attention.

A tak ju≈º bez mem√≥w i po przej≈õciu: 

Ta gra to czysty zmarnowany potencja≈Ç. Boli jak w to siƒô gra z wielu powod√≥w, optymalizacja i beznadziejne wykonanie to jedno, ale najbardziej boli fakt ≈ºe chcia≈Çoby siƒô zobaczyƒá tƒÖ produkcjƒô dopracowanƒÖ technicznie chocia≈º na poziomie postala 4 (czyli beznadziejnie, ale dzia≈Ça). Tak, ona mog≈Çaby byƒá a≈º tak dobra. "Mog≈Ça" to jednak s≈Çowo klucz. 

Nie bƒôdƒô owija≈Ç nie warto w to graƒá, bo to po prostu nie dzia≈Ça. Sterowanie, strzelanie, podpalanie, siuranie- wszystko dzia≈Ça ≈∫le. Ostatnia misja to nieporozumienie i bez godmoda ≈ºadnej przyjemno≈õci z tego nie idzie wykrzesaƒá. Wrogowie spawnujƒÖcy siƒô na potƒôgƒô, HP w formie odnawiania, ograniczony arsena≈Ç- to sƒÖ kroki wstecz wzglƒôdem wiekowej 2 czƒô≈õci. 

Technikalia to jedno, druga rzecz to klimat. Postal 3 ma klimat i ma duszƒô, ale widaƒá ≈ºe tw√≥rcy siƒô ≈õpieszyli i by≈Çy jakie≈õ spory w trakcie produkcji. Fabu≈Ça jest chaotyczna, otrzymujemy wrƒôcz streszczenie streszczenia z najwa≈ºniejszymi momentami i to w postaci tablic tekstu xD Tu ewidentnie co≈õ posz≈Ço nie tak a wielka szkoda. Potencja≈Ç by≈Ç ogromny, za≈õmia≈Çem siƒô pod nosem w wielu momentach- czyli gierka wywo≈Ça≈Ça u mnie efekty kt√≥rych nie wywo≈Ça≈Ça 4 czƒô≈õƒá. Niestety mamy dramat. Lepsze od postala 4 pod wzglƒôdem fabularnym i przedstawienia Kolesia, ale nie warto siƒô mƒôczyƒá i graƒá w to. 


Na zako≈Ñczenie, jest fanowski projekt przeniesienia P3 na silnik Unreala- ≈ºyczƒô im jak najlepiej. Postal 4, Lost Paradise i Brain Damage czerpiƒÖ gar≈õciami z oryginalnej tr√≥jki, warto jej wiƒôc daƒá jeszcze jednƒÖ szansƒô.
column9:
Better than Postal 4

And now, without the memes and after beating it:

This game is pure wasted potential. It hurts to play it for many reasons. The optimization and terrible execution are one thing, but what hurts most is the fact that you'd like to see this game technically refined, even on the level of Postal 4 (which is to say, terrible, but it works). Yes, it could have been that good. "Could have" is the key word.

I won't go into detail: it's not worth playing, because it simply doesn't work. The controls, shooting, setting fires, peeing ‚Äì everything works poorly. The final mission is a mess, and without a godmod, you can't derive any enjoyment from it. Enemies spawning in droves, HP regenerating, a limited arsenal ‚Äì these are steps back from the age-old second installment.

Technical aspects are one thing, but the atmosphere is another. Postal 3 has atmosphere and soul, but it's clear the developers were in a hurry and there were some disputes during development. The plot is chaotic; we're given a summary of the most important moments, all in the form of text tables. xD Something clearly went wrong here, and it's a real shame. The potential was enormous; I laughed out loud at many points ‚Äì meaning the game evoked emotions in me that Postal 4 didn't. If you have the time, watch the gameplay on YouTube; Postal fans are the first to do so.

It's a shame this game was treated this way. There are plenty of good moments, funny plot twists, an absurd but interesting plot idea, gameplay with a good and refreshing karma mechanic for the series, weapons and gadgets on par with the creativity of Ratchet and Clank ‚Äì it could have been made into a good game. Unfortunately, we get a disaster. It's better than Postal 4 in terms of story and the Dude's presentation, but it's not worth the effort and playing.

Finally, there's a fan project to port Postal 3 to the Unreal engine ‚Äì I wish them the best. Postal 4, Lost Paradise, and Brain Damage all draw heavily from the original three, so it's worth giving it another chance.

column9: The game is cool, but it's a shame there's no Steam Workshop. Otherwise, everything's fine.

Most people dislike Postal 3 citing (1) the game's lack of open mockery of everything.
2) the removal of freedom of action and the addition of "useless" missions.
3) and the replacement of the LEGENDARY Gruzdev's voice with Courage Bambaem.

As someone who loves the series, I can say that these quibbles haven't made the game any worse. What do I think of Postal 3?

1) The mockery of human culture hasn't changed a bit in the third game.
Postal 2 mocked everything with advertising signs, company names, and the behavior and dialogue of the guy and the pedestrians. The third game mostly mocks our protagonist's lines and mission scripts. Where in other games will you find a mission where homeless people attack a police station? That's right, nowhere. And I find it funny, but some people don't find it so funny.

2. YES, there's no open world during missions! But the entire map opens up after completing the story! (The story takes 4-5 hours to complete). I think the missions are a cool feature of Postal 3. In the second game, we simply completed daily assignments, but in Postal 3, we're simply trying to earn some money by completing these missions, as part of the story.

And 3. Kurazh Bambeya's voice is every bit as good as Alexander Gruzdev's. Because we were expecting Gruzdev to be playing again, we significantly lowered the game's rating. The developers wanted to give the voice that same feel of old-school movie voiceovers, but they miscalculated slightly, and it all sounds like a cheap TV series. But that's a matter of taste.

*The only downsides are minor frame drops and the broken sound of some of the guy's lines.*
I can confidently give it an 8.9/10.

column8:
Playing this game I didn't expect much, I basically only got it to complete my postal game collection. Everyone says this game is bad, and well, it is. But, I think RWS have actually gone and patched a lot of bugs throughout the game actually making it playable! Here i have made a list of pros and cons I experienced with the game:

Pros
- Humour can be funny at times
- Lots of interesting weapons and features we never got in any other postal games
- Mostly fun achievements 
- Not always a completely boring game, some missions I found to be quite fun in fact
- Better gore, nothing more satisfying than shooting an innocent bystanders face off
- Runs better than it did at og release, I experienced little crashes and little to no frame drops more than what can be said for postal 4
- Cory is a really good voice actor for postal dude and was probably the best part of this game character wise, not that there was any competition for that title in the postal series
- Regenerating health, say good bye to your crack and fast food because now you regenerate your health back, some people could see this as a pro or con but as much as I love the infamous 'Health pipe' gag in postal, being stuck without healing items on hard levels is a complete nightmare.

Cons
- Bad voice acting, no really, its bad
- Seems to be a bit hateful towards people of non hereto sexuality especially, although sometimes it can be funny
- awful fucking dialog on behalf of everyone but Cory, omfg they put in a cut scene every 2 god damn seconds with the most atrocious fucking filter known to man kind, they also for some reason put in a dude screaming all the time
- Awful hit registration with some guns especially the LMG, I also tend to see some weapons have massive inconsistencies, one time a gun can be a sniper and the other time its like the bullets are allergic to the target 
- The dumb fucking karma system, you cant receive karma for doing good tasks and bumping into an NPC reduces karma so have fun with the 'good run' achievement
- Repetitive, I seem to find only Postal 2 was able to nail the 'go do task then be attacked by violent mob' formula and make it genuinely fun, both postal 3 & 4 sometimes feel like its just too much of the same shit
- No jumping, a game made in source with no jumping??? The no jumping mechanic can make movement feel quite clunky at times
- Map, jeez the map, not only can you not see where you're going but load zones are most of the time out of the blue, not a mini map in sight either.
- Enemies, "How to make a game challenging? hmmmm... spawn 600 enemies 5 metres from the player, that'll be cool"
- Fucking. Flinching. Most enemies have access to LMG's and AR's and god fucking damn it, the flinching you do when you're shot, it's... annoying to say the least. 

All that being said, let me give you some advice when playing:
- Saving still saves your EXACT progress so you can get right back into whatever you saved
- Under NO CIRCUMSTANCE (except when achieving the 'Emo' achievement) are you to press left mouse (the universal shoot button) when using the rocket launcher, idk if this was just for me but the rocket blows up in your face and most of the time results in an instakill, only use right fire button which is the heat seeking option.
- On the topic of the rocket launcher, with only being able to use the heat seeking option, the projectile will put any bosses out of priority and instead goes for normal hostile NPC's this is a good tip for the final boss fight that can only be stopped with the rocket launcher, kill all the ground men first, otherwise you're just wasting rockets.
- If you want that good run achievement then the taser is your best friend, run slow as to not hurt any innocents and DO NOT tase innocents, do not kick nor punch them either, this can be extremely difficult.
- I'm pretty sure the bi-polar achievement is impossible to you may have to get out ol' Sam to unlock this one.

All that being said. Not a good game, but, when taking into account this games production history, I learned to roll with the jank, and if you accept this game for the trash it truly is and don't take it too seriously, you may actually have a bit of fun.

column8:
Awesome game with awesome gore, the best part of the gore system is - easy tweak, all you have to do is put the console commands from to the autoexec.cfg that located in common/POSTAL III/p3/cfg

g_ragdoll_maxcount 500
g_ragdoll_important_maxcount 500
r_decals 99999
g_ragdoll_fadespeed 0
r_decalstaticprops 1
r_drawdecals 1
r_drawmodeldecals 1
r_maxmodeldecal 99999

These console commands will give you the awesome aftermath - bullet holes/wall impacts/blood stains on wall/floor, blood decals over the bodies, max corpse/gibs limit 

Must have! All of the above will stay until the loading zone - completing the missions. 
Awesome game. I think I just fell in love.

Damn. For its price of 240 rubles, it's a shame to even give it a thumbs down.
I finished it. After I found out about the update. After all this time. Honestly, the second part is still top-notch. And this game, maybe a couple of playthroughs. Just to see the story. There's karma and all that.
Third-person view. Source engine. Honestly, it lags a lot when there are a lot of enemies. It got on my nerves in the later levels.
But still, a thumbs up. Gritting my teeth.

First we give the game to Akella, tell them how good it is, then how terrible it is, delete it from Steam, give the game again to the Poles, then make a game themselves that turns out to be worse than the 3rd part, then we trash it, and then return it to the shelves. Excellent plan.

[h1]"I took a shit 3 times and after 12 years I finally washed it off..."[/h1]

Two years of waiting (mine) and the 240 rubles I spent turned out to be well spent.

!!!SPOILERS!!!

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Let's not compare it to Postal 2, it's just... I don't want to, and I've forgotten what it's like there.

The gameplay itself seems a bit barebones at first (collecting cumshots and beating up mothers, collecting cats and beating up Chin Chan Chung and protecting a porn actress), but then it gets interesting: you're given choices that influence the ending: either join the 50 blessings, the cops, or give them both a beating (though if you do, you'll be in the 50 blessings). You can shoot off NPC heads, which makes the 240 rubles worth it. Who would have thought there was a reputation system, like the one implemented well in RDR2 (Watchdogs has one, but it's poorly implemented there). Instead of the usual first-person view, it's third-person, which, by the way, is a big plus! There aren't many guns, but some are usable, like catnip (I only figured out how it works at the end), the M16 and M249, cats (who would have thought), a very small pistol, a machete, a taser, a shotgun, your own bolt, etc. The introductory text before the mission starts is pretty well done, and the cutscenes... You'll buy the game and understand.

[h1] Soundtrack [/h1]
Oh my god, it's just fucking awesome, in a good way. It's the same old story at the beginning, the soundtrack is mediocre, but then it's just plain awful, you can't even describe it.

[h1] Voiceover [/h1]
In the English dub, the dude was voiced by Corey Cruz, and in the Russian dub, by Kurazh Bombay (aka Denis Kolesnikov). If the voiceover hadn't been overlaid on the English dub, it would have been an 11/10, but as it is, it's a 9/10.

[h1] Plot [/h1]
[spoiler]I'm too lazy to tell you, so stick your finger up your ass and buy the game [/spoiler]

[h1] Summary [/h1]
Of course, fixing a game that only ancient people remember is trivial, but the GTA trilogy remaster and Postal 4 releases are still worse than this. My rating for the game is 3 lifetimes/10.

P.S. Some achievements don't work (either it's me or someone else).
The game is great, but the bugs are really annoying, the game crashes every five minutes.

This game is crap and keeps crashing, I'm so fucking sick of playing it a hundred times and it keeps crashing. In short, this game is complete crap. Please let me know in the comments if this problem can be fixed.

Postal 3 came out 12 years ago, and this is the first time I've played it. The only reason was that the game was constantly being trashed, with such confidence that it was almost a given.
Now the game's back on Steam, curiosity has taken over, I've finished it, and... in a sense, for me, it's the game of the year (read: "discovery of the year"), because it's not such a piece of crap.
Years have passed, so I can't judge what it was like at release; some things have been tweaked over time, but now, technically, it's quite playable.
I guess you can understand those who were waiting for it 12 years ago and were dissatisfied, because those waiting for it were likely already familiar with the first and second games, which were provocative, borderline-pushing, and satirical. Unfortunately, few can create a legend every time, and Postal 3 is very different from previous experiences. If you take this game for what it's worth‚Äînamely, a casual evening of drinking fun with some silly sitcom-esque jokes‚Äîthen the gameplay is fine, the voice acting is immediately appropriate, and so on and so forth.
Don't get your hopes up too high, and you won't be disappointed. It's a one-time encounter, get the job done and then run away, nothing more. With the passage of time, I think we can absolve the 3rd party of responsibility for not being a masterpiece sequel to a masterpiece.
I especially want to defend it because not only are fans throwing crap at the game, but RWS is also busily delivering new supplies of throwable crap. They made fun of the 3rd party in Paradise Lost, in Postal 4, seemingly made unflattering comments about it on social media, and even recently commented on it on their stream along the lines of, "Well, we returned it to Steam, we can't fix anything, take it for what it is." So, even years later, there's a certain resentment that makes me say things like, "If you're a coprophiliac, then here's some excellent crap for you." And everything seems fine, but before Postal 3, I completed Postal 4. Twice. Including six months after its release. And if Postal 3 is crap, then no one has made a better numbered entry in the series yet.

UPDATE: Delayed, as of October 14, 2024
Dear diary, I've now completed Postal 3 twice, with different endings. Postal 4 is still laggy and buggy from the very first steps after launch, and Postal 3 is still better.
Don't confuse the numbers when choosing.

A voiceover by Kurazh Bombay?! Hahaha! It's a fucking NIGHTMARE. This voiceover is a disaster. It's a complete disaster. You won't hear such a fake reading of the text from a piss-stained, crumpled piece of paper ANYWHERE in the last 20 years. I simply couldn't get past the prologue because of this translation. What a fucking mess it is, just look at it!

Remember the amazing Gruzdev in the second Postal: "Ooooh, that must be... PAINFUL!"
In Kurazh: "Ouch, that must be painful."
And that's it! There's no emotion in this postal. In Postal 2, Gruzdev slowly and disapprovingly tells a player who's killing another NPC: "I KNOW what you're thinking, but I... NEVER PLAYED... a video game..."
Courage after the first NPC: "I know what you're thinking, I've never played a video game..."
Shut up!!! Shut your mouth! Oh my God! Where can I change the language? I feel sick...

About six years ago, I reached the city (the beginning of the first chapter). At that point, I was playing on a laptop and don't remember what the stats were. But it was on Postal 3 (!) that the FPS in the city started dropping to 5-15. Well, I thought, I'll put the game aside for later. I had no negative emotions at all then.
I'll think about it again ‚Äì I'll put it aside for later. But now I'll add the phrase "possibly, but unlikely." I might play it in the future, but unlikely. This game is bad in every way: the cringe in the first chapter made me shudder, the tutorial prompts made me sick (white text on a black background tells you: "Use extra taka to throw a grenade!!! "And which button do you press for extra taka?!!!!" you yell in the game. "Find it yourself, damn," the game tells you), the cloak physics, which have almost zero gravity, are bad, the graphics are bad (I made some concessions for the release date), the sounds in general are bad, and the game's premise is bad. The same humor... Oh my God, what have you done to my boy... This isn't humor, it's just a horse show... ugh, you get it, right? A horse show... ah-hah-hah-hah
After the second launch, I had no positive or neutral emotions left. Purely negative.

But for me personally! The voice acting is what really hurts me the most. Even if we ignore the incredible ACTOR, Alexander Rudolfovich Gruzdev (he voiced the main character in Postal 2 and a HUGE number of other roles)... Even if we ignore Part 2...
In Part 2, you have a living protagonist with emotions and feelings! But in Part 3, the voice acting is rock bottom. In Part 3, it's the same protagonist, but a mechanical, shapeless puss.

Don't touch that rock bottom. All the best to you all.

Thanks to two recent patches, the game has breathed new life.
The game plays great, but there were some frame rate drops in the final area due to the numerous NPCs in the game.
Despite this, I completed both endings of the game and don't regret it.

I like Postal III for its atmosphere, unlike the soulless Postal IV. I played through the 3rd game on the 2011 disc version, and while there were some crashes due to grenades, I didn't really use them. Yes, there are technical issues, but what game doesn't? All games have bugs, and Postal III is no exception. And quite a few of them were fixed recently, and the broken DRM was removed. I liked this game. I don't know about you, but that's just my opinion, and everyone has their own.
Excellent game, I really liked its own mechanics, in general, Postal fans will like it!!!!

column8: This game can be funny sometimes, it's graphics are pretty good and the soundtracks are fantastic. The AI sucks obviously, but at least this game tried to be something new and original. Unlike Postal 4, which is a boring game and just recycled the some of the plots Postal 2 had, and even one of its looks. Postal III is definitely a fun game if you can see past its flaws, or if you just laugh at how ridiculously stupid this game is, it's not an extremely bad experience.

column9:
No matter how you rate this game on a scale of 1 to 10, and the overall crappiness of the game itself, there's no denying that it's far more cohesive and better than Postal 4.

Still, this game does have some merits: decent graphics, solid gameplay, and, while very awkward and clearly written in Russian, an interesting plot, high-quality art and animation in cutscenes, and of course, the two main arguments in its favor are the Axy soundtrack and nonlinearity (which is certainly unique and flawed, but it's there).

This game is mostly hated because of its extremely poor optimization, idiotic AI, terrible location design, terrible Russian localization (I see Kurazh Bombay didn't put any effort into the game's voice acting here), frequent crashes to desktop, broken achievements, and so on. And yes, that's how it is.

But all this costs about the same as two shawarmas at full price (on sale, it's comparable to a pack of crackers), while Postal 4 costs nine shawarmas, and is also far worse in all the aspects I mentioned above.

Overall, Postal 3 is an example of an underrated project that tried to become a hit in the Russian gaming industry at the time, but it failed because the gaming audience and tastes were apparently different back then. It only achieved a hit in 2023 with the release of Atomic Heart, but that's another story.

But overall, I'd give the game a 7/10. It's still enjoyable, especially with the recent Zoom Platform patch, which removed non-working achievements, removed that damn DRM, and even gave everyone Fart Gun, which was previously only available in Russia, and only if you pre-ordered the game. I don't even know what to do here, recommend the game or not, but I think it deserves the attention it unfortunately didn't get back then.

column8:
Postal 3 is a trainwreck, but sometimes it still makes me smile because of how ridiculous it is. If it gets some more TLC from RWS, it could be a more solid entry in the series. It has the ideas, just not the execution. Postal 3 is not a well made game. It's not on par with Postal 2. So why would I give it a positive review? Because, at its core, I can tell that the devs wanted to make something good. The mod they made for Postal 2 had that spirit behind it as well. I can still enjoy both projects because of that. I don't think Postal 3 is so bad it's unplayable; it feels like an overly ambitious fan game that is technically 'finished' but requires a lot more polish.

In that light, unfortunately, the original devs (not RWS) really botched the quality control of Postal 3. I think using the source engine was a really bad idea; had they stuck with Unreal Engine and re-used Postal 2 code (and potentially art assets), I think they would've been able to make a much better product.  If you want more of what Postal 2 brought to the table, that is not what Postal 3 is. Honestly though, I'm happy to see it back up on Steam, and that RWS removed DRM and bugfixed a bit. Plus, new fart gun DLC? I've gotta see what that's about lol.

Funnier, bolder and generally better than the super safe and unfunny Postal 4. Postal 3 is a pretty decent entry in the series, the technical issues are the only real problem with this game. I wish the Steam version would receive all the patches recently released on the Zoom Platform. The "No DRM" update is a good start, but the game received more bugfixes on the Zoom Platform compared to Steam.
If Postal 4 was outsourced like 3, i bet it would be considered the worst game in the series by fans.

column9:
"Postal 3" is a controversial action game that has earned a reputation as one of the worst games ever made. My review of this game is very harsh and negative.

One of the main problems with "Postal 3" is the poor build quality. The graphics are outdated and unattractive, the character animations are stiff and unpleasant to the eye, and the sound effects are low-quality. All of this makes the game look and sound like a game from a decade ago.

Another problem is the weak plot and lack of a meaningful structure. The game's events are chaotic and disconnected, and the dialogue is childish and devoid of any artistic merit. The lack of coherence and logical progression of the story makes it difficult to engage with.

The game mechanics also leave much to be desired. The controls are imprecise and unintuitive, and the combat is monotonous and boring. The lack of gameplay variety quickly makes the game repetitive and boring.

Furthermore, "Postal 3" is full of controversial and inappropriate content. The game promotes violence, obscenity, and gore, which may be inappropriate for many players.

In summary, "Postal 3" is a game that falls short of expectations. Poor production quality, a lack of a coherent story, weak game mechanics, and controversial content make it one of the worst games ever made. I do not recommend this game to anyone unless you're curious about the absolute worst of video games.

This is the last great game from Russian developers.
The game will definitely be remembered after the release of those two mods: Catharsis Reborn and P3 Unreal.
+ The game has been put back on sale.

column9:
I enjoyed this game a lot, the game has its flaws either some bugs or glitches, if it were fixed it would change the opinions on this game.
The game will show something original and that is that you can choose a side as a cop who does ordinary police work to an abnormal one, one day you are in a poor area and solve crimes and the next day you go to a rhinoceros who is on crack. You can play as a maniac who urinates on innocent people and then sets them on fire and calmly beats them to death with a shovel which is perhaps the original mission of Postal 2 where you can be a maniac or a pacifist and survive a week as a normal person.
I bought the game to play all the Postal games, I expected it to be much worse just because of what I heard and I read about Postal 3, everyone has to make up their own mind about it, but the game has hate because of its mistakes, but those mistakes are perhaps the best part

Pros
+ The missions are original in my opinion
+ Pretty well done even though it's from TrashMasters and not from our beloved RWS 
+ Weapons are sometimes usable
+ Possibility to arrest innocent residents as a cop

Cons
- Sometimes when you throw a grenade the game crashes
- You can't restore good reputation if you play as a good guy

Rating 8/10

column8:
[h1] A decade later we start to cherish things, even if they were bad [/h1]

Postal 3 was a bad game. Postal 3 can still be considered a bad game with it's toilet humor, lackluster AI, copy-paste missions along moving away from formula of FPS open world where you can enter every building and find some goodies. Back in the days the hate was deserved. I can understand why RWS would hate it, it's a stain on franchise's reputation. But it's been more than 10 years since it's release. RWS released a DLC for Postal 2 that was simply a giant middle finger towards Postal 3. Fourth part of the franchise grew from a protorype to a full game. An arena shooter spin-off from Hyperstrange was released. All of this should showcase franchise's redemption and resurrection. But hatred remained. It remained till people tasted "full version" of Postal 4. 

Game recieved some patches, but only for russian version of the game, so majority of players were left with a broken, unoptimized, unfinished and overall poorly made product. On November 21st 2022 players were unable to even launch the game due to DRM issue. Quote from RWS Twitter: [b]With Postal 3's DRM issues and overall sh!tt!ness of the game itself, the game is officially no longer being sold on Steam.[/b] However on October 14th 2023 game received a patch that fixes many issues that community was facing for a whole decade. Same tweet states that RWS didn't have control over game's Steam page, but what stopped them from gaining this control for the past decade is unknown. In 2020 source code of many Source games was leaked and rumors say that despite Trashmasters refusal to give RWS the source code of Postal 3, they still recieved it.

This is where I want to focus on the hypocrisy of the whole situation. Postal 4 is objectively a bleak shadow of Postal 2. The Cyber Den's interview with RWS leaders on YouTube got an interesting part where big man Vince Desi states that he likes the change. What is Postal franchise? An isometric shooter, a first person shooter in open world, a third person shooter with focus on linear storytelling, a movie, an arena shooter and a mobile top down shooter. All products bring something unique to the table, everything stands out and holds up on its own, except for Postal 4. It sinks more and more into the absurd, has the same humor, terrible mission design, non existing bizarre plot, empty open world, awful performance and the only good thing is vehicles. Postal has vehicles now, very funny @ssholes.

Instead of continuing to pretend P3 didn't happen and playing the same "haha look Postal 3 bad" joke, just accept that it exist, say it's a spin-off like Brain Damaged or something. There is no way that you are calling P3 bad when P4 exists in its current form when RWS has full control over development. On paper It's not hard to be better than Postal 3, but apparently it is.

Postal 3 has incredible soundtrack with such bangers as [b]A Fall To Break ‚Äì Lost, Left, All Alone; Tokyo Rose - Goodbye Almond Eyes[/b] and [b]Hint Machine -  The Nearning Light[/b]. Great performance from [b]Corey Cruise[/b] as Postal dude. A morality system that gives option for [b]replayability[/b] since you get different missions and different endings. Subjectively funny [b]toilet humor[/b] throughout the entire experience. Unique weapons like bee grenade, badger saw and fart gun. Celebrity collaborations like [b]Ron Jeremy, Randy Jones, Jennifer Walcott and Uwe Boll[/b]. There are many good things I can say about the game, but internet will only remember the bad.

This game is a time capsule of a certain era and it's beautiful. Postal 3 might be a bad game, but it's not a bad Postal game, and definitely not the worst Postal game.

column9:
Postal 3 is better than Postal 4
Change my mind

Yeah, listen up, Postal III is a piece of crap that's still worth checking out. Sure, it's not quite up to the level of Postal 2, that classic where you could do whatever you wanted and nobody gave a shit, but compared to that trashy fourth installment, it's definitely a lot better. The gameplay is quite lively, even joyfully chaotic in places, as befits a true Postal. You can at least feel that hellish madness a little bit, even if everything is a bit clumsy and unfinished. But damn, at least it's not a complete shambles, like in the fourth.
Basically, if you enjoy having a blast with total chaos around you, rather than completing boring quests, this is definitely your thing.
