column8:
Introduction:
Prepare for a wild ride as you step into the surreal world of Postal 3, a video game that embraces chaos and absurdity with open arms. Published by Akella and Running With Scissors, Postal 3 ventures beyond the conventional boundaries of gaming, delivering a rollercoaster of laughter and mayhem. While it's not without its quirks, this unorthodox experience is a breath of fresh air for those seeking a break from the norm. With a quirky sense of humor and sandbox-style gameplay, Postal 3 offers a unique, unforgettable journey that leaves players wondering, "What did I just play?"

Graphics and Art Style:
Postal 3 adopts a vibrant and cartoonish art style, which enhances the game's humorous undertones. The character designs are over-the-top and distinctive, making them memorable and instantly recognizable. The environments are surprisingly diverse, from the rundown streets of Paradise to bizarre settings like the amusement park and nuclear plant. While the graphics might not be cutting-edge, they perfectly complement the game's tongue-in-cheek vibe and immerse players in the zany universe it presents.

Gameplay:
One of Postal 3's greatest strengths is its open-world, sandbox-style gameplay that grants players freedom to tackle objectives in their unique way. Whether you want to go on a mad rampage or choose a more diplomatic approach, the game accommodates your choices, resulting in different outcomes and experiences. The sheer variety of weapons, from mundane to utterly absurd, provides endless amusement and keeps the gameplay fresh throughout.

The mission structure, while loosely connected, adds to the game's surreal charm. You'll find yourself completing a series of wacky errands that often veer off into comical tangents, like joining a marching band or working at an unconventional animal shelter. This unorthodox mission progression might not appeal to everyone, but for those with a taste for offbeat humor, it's a delight.

Story and Humor:
Postal 3 takes its narrative cues from a blend of dark comedy and satirical absurdism. The story follows the protagonist, the Postal Dude, through a sequence of bizarre misadventures in the fictional town of Paradise. While some plotlines feel disjointed and lack a cohesive thread, the unpredictable nature of the narrative serves to amplify the game's chaotic appeal.

What sets Postal 3 apart is its audacious humor. The game fearlessly tackles controversial topics with a mix of clever satire and slapstick comedy. It doesn't shy away from pushing boundaries, which may not resonate with everyone, but for those who appreciate a dose of dark comedy, Postal 3 is a gem. Be prepared for moments that will leave you laughing out loud while questioning your own sense of humor.

Sound and Voice Acting:
The audio design of Postal 3 deserves applause for enhancing the overall immersion in its peculiar world. The soundtrack varies from catchy and upbeat tunes to eerie atmospheric music that complements the game's changing moods. Voice acting, while not always Oscar-worthy, suits the characters' eccentricities and brings them to life in all their quirky glory.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Postal 3 is a rollercoaster ride of irreverent humor, bizarre antics, and an unapologetically chaotic experience. While not without its flaws, the game's charm lies in its willingness to push the envelope and entertain through sheer absurdity. If you're seeking a break from conventional gaming and have a penchant for dark comedy, Postal 3 is a carnival of mayhem worth exploring. Embrace the insanity and embark on a journey that'll keep you entertained, confused, and laughing all the way!

column8:
Postal 3, developed by Running With Scissors, is an audacious masterpiece that defies conventional gaming norms to deliver an uproarious, chaotic, and unforgettable experience. If you thought the Postal series couldn't get any more outrageous, think again! This third installment elevates the franchise to new heights of absurdity, resulting in an uproarious adventure that leaves players laughing until their sides ache.

From the very beginning, Postal 3 hooks players with its razor-sharp satire that takes a no-holds-barred approach in lampooning modern society and popular culture. The game's narrative serves as a brilliant social commentary on the absurdities of the real world, masterfully parodying political figures, celebrities, and everyday life occurrences. Postal 3 has a way of poking fun at everything and everyone while maintaining a light-hearted tone, effectively balancing between controversial humor and pure hilarity.

One of the standout features of Postal 3 is its unrestricted gameplay mechanics, which encourage players to unleash their wild imaginations and embrace the insanity. Whether you prefer to engage in mind-boggling mayhem or take a more subtle approach to tackle the missions, the game accommodates all playstyles with equal enthusiasm. The freedom to make choices and the multitude of unpredictable consequences add an immense level of replayability, making each playthrough a fresh and captivating experience.

Visually, Postal 3 may not boast cutting-edge graphics, but its stylized art direction fits perfectly with the game's satirical tone. The bizarre and quirky character designs add a unique charm to the world, and the exaggerated animations further enhance the comical nature of the game. Additionally, the absurdly detailed environments offer countless opportunities for emergent gameplay, ensuring that players will stumble upon hilarious scenarios around every corner.

The voice acting in Postal 3 is a true gem, with perfectly delivered lines that capture the essence of the game's dark humor. Notable voice talent brings life to the various eccentric characters and adds another layer of enjoyment to the overall experience. The script's sharp wit and laugh-out-loud dialogues are a testament to the writers' brilliance, making every interaction a joy to behold.

It's essential to acknowledge the courage of the development team for crafting a game that unapologetically stands against the tide of political correctness. While some might argue that Postal 3 pushes the boundaries too far, it's precisely this audacity that enables the game to maintain its unique identity and deliver a truly unforgettable experience.

Furthermore, Postal 3 isn't just about chaos and laughter; it also features subtle moments of introspection. It encourages players to reflect on society's flaws and ponder the repercussions of our actions, albeit in a twisted and unconventional way. This thoughtful undertone amidst the absurdity adds depth to the game, proving that satire can be a powerful tool for provoking meaningful contemplation.

In conclusion, Postal 3 is a triumph of satirical absurdity that stands as a bold testament to the creativity and fearlessness of its developers. It dares to challenge conventions and make players confront uncomfortable truths while keeping them entertained with an avalanche of laughter. If you have a penchant for dark humor, satire, and non-linear gameplay, Postal 3 will undoubtedly leave you grinning from ear to ear. Embrace the madness and embark on an exhilarating adventure that will forever leave a smile etched on your face.
column9:
Postal 3, developed by Running With Scissors, is an audacious masterpiece that defies conventional gaming norms to deliver an uproarious, chaotic, and unforgettable experience. If you thought the Postal series couldn't get any more outrageous, think again! This third installment elevates the franchise to new heights of absurdity, resulting in an uproarious adventure that leaves players laughing until their sides ache.

From the very beginning, Postal 3 hooks players with its razor-sharp satire that takes a no-holds-barred approach in lampooning modern society and popular culture. The game's narrative serves as a brilliant social commentary on the absurdities of the real world, masterfully parodying political figures, celebrities, and everyday life occurrences. Postal 3 has a way of poking fun at everything and everyone while maintaining a light-hearted tone, effectively balancing between controversial humor and pure hilarity.

One of the standout features of Postal 3 is its unrestricted gameplay mechanics, which encourage players to unleash their wild imaginations and embrace the insanity. Whether you prefer to engage in mind-boggling mayhem or take a more subtle approach to tackle the missions, the game accommodates all playstyles with equal enthusiasm. The freedom to make choices and the multitude of unpredictable consequences add an immense level of replayability, making each playthrough a fresh and captivating experience.

Visually, Postal 3 may not boast cutting-edge graphics, but its stylized art direction fits perfectly with the game's satirical tone. The bizarre and quirky character designs add a unique charm to the world, and the exaggerated animations further enhance the comical nature of the game. Additionally, the absurdly detailed environments offer countless opportunities for emergent gameplay, ensuring that players will stumble upon hilarious scenarios around every corner.

The voice acting in Postal 3 is a true gem, with perfectly delivered lines that capture the essence of the game's dark humor. Notable voice talent brings life to the various eccentric characters and adds another layer of enjoyment to the overall experience. The script's sharp wit and laugh-out-loud dialogues are a testament to the writers' brilliance, making every interaction a joy to behold.

It's essential to acknowledge the courage of the development team for crafting a game that unapologetically stands against the tide of political correctness. While some might argue that Postal 3 pushes the boundaries too far, it's precisely this audacity that enables the game to maintain its unique identity and deliver a truly unforgettable experience.

Furthermore, Postal 3 isn't just about chaos and laughter; it also features subtle moments of introspection. It encourages players to reflect on society's flaws and ponder the repercussions of our actions, albeit in a twisted and unconventional way. This thoughtful undertone amidst the absurdity adds depth to the game, proving that satire can be a powerful tool for provoking meaningful contemplation.

In conclusion, Postal 3 is a triumph of satirical absurdity that stands as a bold testament to the creativity and fearlessness of its developers. It dares to challenge conventions and make players confront uncomfortable truths while keeping them entertained with an avalanche of laughter. If you have a penchant for dark humor, satire, and non-linear gameplay, Postal 3 will undoubtedly leave you grinning from ear to ear. Embrace the madness and embark on an exhilarating adventure that will forever leave a smile etched on your face.

-IA che si incastra con gli oggetti o si perde per la mappa

-Il pacing della storia √® incredibilmente veloce (finisci una quest, parte la cutscene che introduce un'altra quest e cos√¨ via fino alla fine del gioco. Non c'√® un secondo libero tra una missione e l'altra)

column9:
2/10
There's more than one reason why it's the worst Postal, so here are some of the issues I've encountered:

-At startup, it asked for a serial number. I didn't understand what I was supposed to enter, but the official FAQ site doesn't work. I ended up having to download a patch to start the "game" without having to enter anything.
-The camera makes you nauseous when running.
-Enemies shoot even if you're behind cover (and still hit you).
-Grabbing a stunned enemy causes the game to crash.
-The audio from all weapons overlaps during gunfights.
-You can't skip.
-Quests are boring, repetitive, and unnecessarily long.
-Absolutely no freeroaming. Additionally, map areas are rotated throughout the various quests.
-AI gets stuck on objects or gets lost on the map.
-The "game" saves ONLY at the start of each quest, so if you lose, you have to start the whole quest over again.
-The story pacing is incredibly fast (you finish a quest, a cutscene starts, introducing another quest, and so on until the end of the game. There's not a spare second between missions).

Rest In Piss Postal 3

column8:
I played this because I got a case of POSTAL autism, my hyperfixation for a while was POSTAL for some reason even though this whole franchise goes completely against my other hyperfixations. Regardless, I wanted to play POSTAL III before playing Paradise Lost...and wow who knew, the bad game is BAD. There is very little reason to play this. Eventually if I'm in an awful enough mental state I might finish 100%ing it, but I fucking hope not. 

This game is one of TWO ever to make me want to vomit just playing it, and I can play fast movement parkour VR games. The only other game was Hunt Down The Freeman by the way. The only way I got nearly 15 hours in this was by installing several mods to keep the game from 1. crashing, 2. reduce game breaking bugs, 3. have a camera that doesn't make me want to puke. And the amount of time I put into it was absoloutely not worth it. 

Even WITH that, within 12 hours of playtime I had 32 crash logs, and some of the crashes didn't even cause logs to appear.

To even get the game to WORK on modern systems, even with just vanilla, you must go out of your way to funny websites to generate an activation key, because the key included with the original purchase, ISN'T THE ACTIVATION KEY??? Just...just don't.

EDIT: Since I've wrote this review, the game is back up on Steam without the garbage DRM! I still wouldn't recommend playing it unless you have a touch of the POSTAL 'tism, but I felt like I should mention the game does at least run now with some critical bug fixes, but you'll still want the camera mod.

[h1] [b](„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø[/b]Postal III[/h1]
[code] Review by [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/maxiisteam/] Maxi [/url][/code]
There's no denying that Postal III didn't meet my expectations for this game. Although the game was widely talked about at the time and attracted attention by being associated with Postal 2, I think it would have been better received if it had been developed by Running With Scissors.

But back to the game. We play as a guy after the apocalyptic ending of Paradise Lost in Postal 2 and are transported to the town of Catharsis. And it's up to us how the gameplay will unfold. (In theory, that's how it was supposed to be.)

But...

The gameplay is quite tedious, due to the game mechanics and the irritating bugs we experience almost from the very beginning. Hand-to-hand combat is torture; it's hard to hit anyone, and with access to weapons, you'll only be able to use two or three of them; the rest are useless.

The graphics are very poor for a game with such a high profile. Unfortunately, the game leaves much to be desired. I don't recommend it.

[list]
[*] If you found my review helpful, please leave a positive rating.
[*] You can find more reviews on my profile.
[/list]

column8:
Title: Postal 3: An Outrageously Absurd Adventure That Pushes Boundaries

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ

Postal 3, developed by Running with Scissors, is an unapologetically over-the-top and irreverent game that dares to explore the boundaries of comedic absurdity. While it may not be for everyone, if you have a dark sense of humor and enjoy a healthy dose of satire, this game is an absolute blast.

One of the standout features of Postal 3 is its relentless commitment to pushing the envelope. It takes the concept of political incorrectness to new heights, satirizing society and its various taboos. The game throws caution to the wind and isn't afraid to make fun of anyone and anything, resulting in some truly outrageous and hilarious moments. It's a refreshing departure from the safe and sanitized approach of many mainstream games.

The gameplay mechanics in Postal 3 are solid, offering a mix of open-world exploration, mission-based objectives, and sandbox-style chaos. You can choose to play through the game's story, which is a wild ride filled with unexpected twists and turns, or simply engage in mayhem throughout the city. The vast array of weapons and tools at your disposal adds to the sheer fun of wreaking havoc in creative and imaginative ways.

Visually, Postal 3 delivers a gritty and immersive experience. The environments are detailed and filled with plenty of interactive elements, allowing for spontaneous and unpredictable gameplay moments. The character models are well-designed, capturing the essence of the game's outrageous nature. The sound design is equally impressive, with voice acting that perfectly complements the game's irreverent tone.

While Postal 3's humor and gameplay are its major strengths, it's important to note that this game is not for everyone. Its controversial themes and dark humor may offend some players, and the satirical nature can be seen as a double-edged sword. However, if you approach the game with an open mind and a willingness to embrace its absurdity, you'll find a unique and memorable experience.

In conclusion, Postal 3 is a game that pushes boundaries and challenges societal norms, offering an outrageous and satirical adventure. With solid gameplay mechanics, a visually immersive world, and a commitment to dark humor, Running with Scissors has created a game that stands out from the crowd. If you're a fan of irreverent humor and enjoy games that aren't afraid to be controversial, Postal 3 is a must-play

column8:
What else is there to say about Postal 3 that hasn't already been said? Well, [strike]besides the fact that you can't even buy the game directly on Steam anymore and need to activate a product key for it (such as the one included with the Postal XX box set that RWS sells on their site, which is how I got the game and how I'll recommend getting the game if you're either curious about it or want to complete your Postal collection),[/strike] (NOT ACCURATE SINCE 10/13/2023) everything about the game is just... nothing. It's a large nothing burger that ultimately left me feeling hollow after completing the two paths it has to offer. Not angry, not happy... just empty.

At best, the game's a painfully average third person shooter. At worst, the game's a frustrating collection of "kill X amount of Y" or escort missions with AI that's as intelligent as a pile of bricks (which is an insult to the bricks, in all honesty), weapons that feel unsatisfying to use, and overall it's just not fun or interesting. If you want to play a Postal game, you're better off just sticking with 1/Redux, 2 and the Paradise Lost DLC (which retcons 3 into a coma-induced nightmare), 4: No Regerts, and Brain Damaged instead, and there are much better third person shooters out there.

column8:
Public outcry to support the mod community to this game.
There are a couple reasons why you would buy this game, and almost all of them are mod-related.

- UltraPatch / AngelPatch - This one's the most important - makes this game playable (in it's current state, as a linear title) and even more modifiable. There are several, competing (for some reason) overhaul / remake mods out there for this game, and I am almost certain all of them rely on AngelScript in some capacity. Pretty sure a lot of this was made alongside, and to service, Catharsis Reborn. Not only that, but they've added multiplayer already. AND IT SEEMS LIKE NEXT UPDATE WILL HAVE A FULLY ANIMATED FIRST PERSON MODE. Kizoky doesn't even know who I am, but I am Kizoky's biggest fan.

- Postal 3 Redux and Postal Source - I'm not sure, entirely, how I feel about these guys. On one hand, they have brought back integral features, such as inventory (Let's go health pipe), have broke new ground on custom mission-scripts and have promised to keep their story / setting relatively similar to the release title. However, every new update seems more scattered, the Postal 3 team, with their unmatched level of talent, seem to be focused on adding unneeded features, such as variants of the health-pipe based on real-world substances (rather than the silly, parody ones in the Postal mythos), and a full car-driving system for Postal Source. This seems to be the bane of every mod team, scope-creep and unneeded additions. At least these guys are staying similar to the glamorous, comedy-focused vibe of Postal 3.

- Catharsis Reborn - Every other year this mod seems flip-flop on whether it's a dead mod or not. The developers have to remind the fans non-stop that it's still in work, which is reasonable as what this team has decided to do takes a substantial amount of effort, comparatively, to it's competitors. They aim to make a completely different Postal 3, with a new story and a whole new set of cut mechanics that deserve to be in Postal 3. What's even more impressive is how focused these guys are on NOT adding unneeded code and features, as far as gameplay goes, these guys are pure. Problems start to arise when you consider the narrative direction of this mod. If you ask me, Postal 3's story isn't completely terrible, it's its presentation that is. Some of these jokes are incredibly on-brand, but the mission-structure of nightmares and lack of time to explain itself is it's demise. Some of the public-release story information (such as it's cutscenes) make this mod seem more doomed from a story-telling and atmospheric level than the game it aims to repair. If I had any advice for this team, it's that what you are doing for the engine is extremely impressive, you guys are some of the most organized modders in the world - even more than Black Designer in some capacity - don't let your narrative ambitions swallow your project alive.

- Finally, it's that the Production Quality, not the Game Development Quality, for this game is really good. RWS wasn't lying when they said they put a lot of money into this title, this was supposed to be their "big game". There is a lot of things that you will not see in this game that RWS put a lot of effort into, simply because there was no time or money to implement it. Postal 4 is a terrible narrative with a great front-end and gameplay. Postal 3, in a world where the game was good and it had the platform to express itself in full, had an alright story - in some regards it was more cohesive than Postal 2, but, once again, it has no ability to express that story to us, as it just simply needed to be done.

TL;DR - This game will finally be good in like 2030, whenever the mod community stops competing and decides it's more productive to work together to get a better minimum-viable-product out.

column9: normal

After hearing so many negative reviews about the third game, I didn't buy it on Steam while I could. But I pre-ordered the fourth and waited for it to leave Early Access, and guess what? After a couple of hours of playing, I finally decided to buy a key for Postal III, immediately installing the patch from the latest guide. [b] And I was instantly hooked. [/b]

Firstly, the cool main menu sets the tone immediately. And although YouTube reviews had pretty convincingly convinced me that the cutscenes and voice acting were cringeworthy, I actually really enjoyed them in the game itself! Throughout the game, I constantly couldn't understand how the reviewers could have had any significant issues at any given moment. I only got stuck twice during my playthrough: Helmet Sucker refused to run along the route (Tip: just let him run to all doors and doorways first) and while guarding the border, but I just wanted to get a perfect score there, which isn't necessary. Yes, there were crashes, often due to attempts to throw things, even though the game allowed it in some episodes. Because Postal 2 is so unique in terms of weapons, it's quite difficult to come up with new mechanics, but they are here, and they're fun to use‚Äîthe badger chainsaw alone is worth it! And yes, unlike Postal 2 and 4, it's easy to switch items here.

Bottom line: I sincerely feel sorry for the developers whose efforts were wasted due to technical flaws. After all, the game is very good in terms of design, music, mechanics, and overall gameplay. Reading the end credits and artbook, I truly believe they wanted to create a worthwhile game and live up to the fans' expectations! This was a worthy attempt by Russian game development, which, unfortunately, was not brought to fruition.
It's a good game for a one-time playthrough. I second those who don't criticize the game; yes, it's not like the first two games, but it's still quite fun and won't let you get bored.
Took a shit for the third time

column8:
The creators of "Postal III" were ahead of its time.
This might be the best game I've ever played in my ENTIRE life...
Honestly im flabbergasted after the climax on the main story, its an astounishing experience that every person that likes to play videogames should experience.
I almost cried when right at the start of the game, the protagonist said: "Hello guys I'm the Postal Dude", that scene was delivered in such a pace and grace that made every other type of cinematic of any other game feel underwhelming.
Right now I really dont know what to do, after Postal III there is no other reason to play videogames, because this right here, this is peak gaming.
Can't wait for Postal III 2. (It's so good it deserves a sequel)
It's not available in the shop anymore, but I feel like I just stole from the developer, this game should charge everyone like an AAA tittle, if not more.

Solid 11/10.

column8:
Postal 3 is a first-person shooter game developed by Running With Scissors and released in 2011. The game is a sequel to the controversial Postal 2, which gained infamy for its excessive violence and crude humor. While Postal 2 was criticized for its tasteless content, it still managed to be a fun and entertaining game. Unfortunately, Postal 3 falls short in almost every aspect.

The game's storyline is disjointed and lacks any meaningful direction. The humor is forced and often falls flat, relying heavily on shock value and cheap jokes. The graphics are mediocre at best, with poor textures and low-quality character models that make the game feel outdated and unpolished.

The gameplay in Postal 3 is also a significant letdown. The controls are clunky and unresponsive, making it difficult to aim and shoot accurately. The game also lacks any real challenge, with enemies that are easily dispatched and little variety in weapons or tactics.

One of the most frustrating aspects of the game is the frequent bugs and glitches. The game often freezes, crashes, or becomes unplayable, requiring the player to restart from the last checkpoint. These issues make it difficult to enjoy the game and often result in a frustrating and tedious experience.

Overall, Postal 3 is a disappointing game that fails to live up to its predecessor or offer any real value to players. The game's humor is tasteless, the graphics are poor, and the gameplay is lackluster. With so many other great first-person shooter games available, there is little reason to waste time or money on this lackluster title.

column9: After the update (patch) the game improved quite a bit, mind you, only in the tactical aspect, but in reality it is still a mediocre game and not recommended for fans of Postal 2, but nevertheless you will be able to enjoy it better than before. It is still a bad game but it is already better in the technical aspect and that is why I think I would recommend it 6.1/10, although I would recommend it more for the mods.

It doesn't work out of the box‚Äîyou need to install a security bypass (which is currently broken). The achievements are buggy, and there are a lot of crashes‚Äîeven with unofficial patches. And of course, it doesn't compare to Postal 2 in terms of atmosphere.

Which game is better?

column8:
I hunted down a product key for this game because I just wanted to say I owned the full Postal series in my Steam library. There's DRM that makes the game unplayable without a community patch because its servers are down. No big deal, the patch is easy enough to find and install. I got in, excited to see how terrible this really is. It crashed as soon as I threw my first grenade. 10/10, I was not let down. Go buy Paradise Lost.

EDIT: Well, the mad lads did it. RWS swept in and fixed the DRM issues. That doesn't change anything, however, because at its core Postal 3 is still an insufferable mess of poor design. However, I'm seriously glad it's still up. It's important for this sort of thing to be preserved. We can all say "Postal 3 is the worst thing ever, it's so bad that it doesn't even exist!" and have a laugh, but that loses meaning if we don't actually have the game to base that claim on. Good on you, Running With Scissors.

Don't buy this, not even "to complete your collection", Running with Scissors has the following to say about this game:
Let us stop you right there and explain everything there needs to be said about that game. First of all, the game is shit. It wasn‚Äôt developed by us and it‚Äôs the result of a company taking our pride and joy just to turn it into trash. This video ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WJnivzm-WjA ) further explains what went wrong.

If you really want to play the game, you can buy it on Steam but we won‚Äôt get any money for it. If you want to get the game and support us, we still have it included in our Postal 20th Anniversary Edition. Contrary to what some say, we are NOT handing out keys for POSTAL 3 right now, please refrain from asking.

In closing, this was a chapter of POSTAL history that we keep joking about but wished it never happened. We will never remake the game or try to fix it.

column8:
This game is a hard one to suggest to anyone but someone who wants to play all the postal games for some reason like i did. Its a buggy mess, but one of the prettier postal games. For me it played better on steamdeck, with a patch download to bypass non working activation software. I still had crashes and eventually my auto saves would not load only manual saves. I enjoy the story a bit and it does seem like it tried to be a postal game.
A steam key for this + the postal movie comes in the Postal 20th anniversary edition sold on the RWS website, and at the time of this review is for sale for 30 dollars. Both of those are delisted.
column9:
This game is a hard one to suggest to anyone but someone who wants to play all the postal games for some reason like i did. Its a buggy mess, but one of the prettier postal games. For me it played better on steamdeck, with a patch download to bypass non working activation software. I still had crashes and eventually my auto saves would not load only manual saves. I enjoy the story a bit and it does seem like it tried to be a postal game.
A steam key for this + the postal movie comes in the Postal 20th anniversary edition sold on the RWS website, and at the time of this review is for sale for 30 dollars. Both of those are delisted.

I don't understand why there's so much hate, especially since the game is genuinely fun and has a Post-it feel. The only downsides, in my opinion, are the really poor optimization, the unlootable nature of the game without any config settings, and the questionable weapon balance. Otherwise, it's the same Post-it feel, just more colorful and less dark (though that's a question).

And yes, I bought this game and I DON'T REGRET ANYTHING!
Absolutely everything is terrible

column9:
What a fucking underrated game!

The game begins at the bridge that marks the conclusion of Postal 2 and references a lot throughout. The humor is extremely distinctive, and the over-the-top violence is still present. It's not the best sequel a game can have, much less the best game anyone will ever play, but it's minimally playable and relatively short, so even though it's limited, it doesn't get boring. Plus, you can choose the pacifist path instead of pleasing the devil in the Postal way. For those who enjoy the series, it's definitely worth it.

Final thoughts:
If you want a BAD game, the advice is according to the protagonist himself: GTA's physics are better.
If you want a POSTAL, you can play without fear of being happy or traumatized by a third-person mechanic that makes you want to be run over by a rhino irl (if it ever returns to Steam, or another platform).

And if I'm wrong, I blame Christian metal, SpongeBob SquarePants, traditional media, and other media as well.

column9:
This inappropriate TPS is notoriously considered an outcast by RWS, the developers of the other games in the Postal series.

In fact, only the menu screen is localized in Japanese.

When you actually play it, the first thing that stands out is the camera, which is difficult to see because the main character is displayed large on the screen.

For the same reason, it's hard to tell if your aim is correct, and it's also hard to tell if your bullets are hitting your target, which is a common flaw in TPS games that's annoying.

The character movements are sluggish, and there's not a trace of exhilaration in the slightest, making it an old-fashioned, low-quality TPS that's painful to play.

It's been over 10 years since its release, so it's only natural that it feels old-fashioned, but I don't recommend playing it now.

The game itself has its own flaws, but the biggest problem is that as of December 2022, the game's [url=activate.actcontrol.net] activation server [/url] is down, making it unplayable as is.

The only way to play the Steam version is to find and apply a NoDRM patch from somewhere.

It's no wonder that it's been taken off the market.

Although this is common with crappy games, I think the art aspects, such as the music, the title screen, and comic-style illustrations outside of the main game, are good.

Well, I had enough energy to replay Postal III. The first playthrough was neutral, and the second one was bad, but I don't have the nerve to play it well. The game isn't good, but it's not as crap as many people think. Yes, it has a lot of terrible moments, like the AI, optimization, sound breaks, freezes and lags, and crashes (it happened once during the second playthrough), but the game isn't that terrible. I was, like everyone else, of the opinion that Postal III was complete crap, looking at other people's reviews, but after playing it, I realized I even liked it more than Postal 2. Well, let's be honest, objectively speaking, in 2022, Postal 2 is a boring game where you have to run long distances. No, I'm not saying Postal III is better, I just didn't like Postal 2 as much. And, if you look at modern games, Postal III is even better compared to them. I don't understand why RWS has been harping on the same "Postal III is crap" refrain for 11 YEARS now? Why can't they calm down, considering they even pulled the game from the store? Postal 4 had even worse problems than Postal III, and the garish, bright colors are just too harsh. I understand I might get trashed for this opinion, but I don't give a shit :)
Goodbye, Postal III Dude, we won't forget you.
R.I.P 2011-2022

column8:
[h1]Its back ¬Ø\_( Õ°¬∞ Õú ñ Õ°¬∞)_/¬Ø[/h1]

11 years has passed since its release aaaaand its gone. Rest In RIP, Postal 3, you will never be forgotten. 

Then some time passes again aaaaaaaaaaand its back.

You sucked in every way possible but at least in this game you could be misogynistic, racist AND misantropic all at the same time without any woke Twitter modern consequences.

Also, this game was so bad, that RWS actually got their shet together and made Paradise Lost and Postal 4.

Soooooo, No Regerts I guess?
Anyways, I've used SAM for about 5-6 mins so that I could just write this review, enjoy your day, gentlemen and not.

For the record:
The graphics engine - is Source but Bad and very poorly optimized. Blood is meh, models are outdated, physics are glitching out everywhere. As for the bugs - its simply a mess, from broken scripts to straight up crash-to-desktop.
Music is...present but the sound department failed completely, sometimes you could hear things far away despite gun shots near you and sometimes - the opposite.
The characters and actual plot - very badly written South Park episode. But at least Postal Dude VO tried his best in this one.
As for the gameplay - its tedious and completely broken in balance, enemies are either too many in numbers or bullet sponges.
So yeah, the game dissapointed most people hard back in the day. I actually own this game only for the collection.

[h1]Update - holy shet - they actually let Trashmasters to earn even more money from this "product"[/h1]

column8:
I believed that the negative reviews of the game were exaggerated after looking back at the history of the game in relation to the series. After getting the game to work, I made the decision to give it a try. Looking back, I can see that I should have listened before playing. The game's structure is fairly simple, and it features a notable cast. The 3D models are decent for their time. Depending on how well-made the game was, the humorous and funny cut scenes might have been a major plus. There are some original ideas for weapons.

Some of the game's issues include awkward aiming, mediocre m/kb controls, poorly matched (slow) animations for actions like "kick," and terrible physics (such as pouring gasoline or sucking up rags). It isn't enjoyable, not even in the "so bad it's good" way that RWS champions. It isn't even really a bad development problem, as it's completed in the Source engine. This is generally just a game with poorly implemented features.

The cycle of development was severely impacted by relying on programmers who weren't "in-house," especially since RWS wanted a game that could be ported to the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 (although that begs the question of why Postal 2 couldn't be played on those very systems). The game was anticipated to be a substantial improvement upon the Postal series, particularly over Postal 2 (which has since made a comeback); if the game was better developed it wouldn't have been so bad. Here's hoping that one day that maybe this game can be recreated.

As it stands, anyone looking at this game and wondering, I don't recommend it.

2025 Edit:

While Zoom attempting to polish the game helped some, and performance kicked up several notches, the game is fundamentally bad. Think a Mario Party of Postal games and that is prettymuch what this is.

column9: I'm Commander Shepard, and this is my favorite shop on the Citadel.

Remember the original developers' jokes about Postal 3 being crap, deleting it and waiting for Postal 4? We'll do it, we'll do it... And what did they actually release? Some hodgepodge of multicolored assets from the Unreal Engine store; there's no coherent image, just a circus and a riot of colors. Despite the game's obvious flaws, this Akella-made creation looks very cohesive and more iconic than Postal 4, which is its main advantage.

column8: DING DONG THE WICKED BITCH IS DEAD
column9: DING DONG THE WICKED BITCH IS DEAD

Well, another game has disappeared from the shelves of everyone's favorite store.
Personally, I have special feelings for the "Postal" series of games.
I grew up playing these games, learned many "interesting" words and phrases, learned how to meet people, and always appreciated them for their unafraid to push the boundaries of what was acceptable, allowing the player not only to witness but also to inflict such blatant violence. This game was a "salvation" from the daily grind, a wonderful way to relax and calm my nerves. Despite the failure of the game itself, which was allowed during its development, I enjoyed this installment of the series, not entirely, of course.
Many of the absurd situations will seem absurd and inappropriate to most players, but it was precisely this absurdity and inappropriateness that kept me entertained throughout the game.

As I said before, the technical characteristics of this game leave much to be desired, and at times they seriously broke the game.

The game's voice acting deserves special attention, as it evokes fond memories of childhood, watching some action movie from the 1970s or 1980s, and the very concept of the cutscenes clearly hints at this.

Even though "Postal 3" is the worst game in the series on many fronts, it gave me pleasant emotions playing it back then, back then, now, and will continue to do so in the future.

Goodbye, Dude from Part 3, it's a shame so many people didn't like you.

column9: Postal 3 The Hit Game From The Hit Developer AKELLA!!!! sold over 50 postillion copies and got 69420 postillion points on metacritic, game of the year,decade and game of all time. i cried when the dude say "is Postallin 3 time" and started postallin 3 everything üò≠üò≠üò≠üò≠im shaking and crying rn JUST BUY THE BEST GAME OF THE HUMAN HISTORY!!!!

Pros:
+ The graphics look good
+ The mission soundtrack is upbeat and pleasant to the ear (very rare)
+ Funny jokes (rare)
Controversial point: lots of dismemberment and blood‚Äîlike in Hotline Miami. Not everyone will like it.
Cons:
- You need to install a no-DRM patch to even launch the game. Otherwise, you're stuck with an activator limited to two activations.
- Inappropriate difficulty: either enemies stand still and don't attack, or the screen is hell and EVERYONE is trying to shoot you.
- None of the variety and fun features of the second game: just a bunch of corridor shooter levels.
- Instead of a plot, there are a bunch of random scenes with random characters. I want to ask: is this really a Postal game?
- The mission soundtrack is poor and boring.
Minor flaws compared to the previous ones: broken game scripts that will never be fixed, melee mechanics and 99% of the game's weapons are unusable, the camera shakes excessively when shooting and running, etc.

Verdict
Postal III could have been made into something fun and decent in quality, but it turned out differently: the game fell into production hell, and most of the planned content was simply not added to the final product, releasing what was already there.
Ultimately, Postal III is playable if you want, but there's no reason to, as there are plenty of more useful and fun activities. I don't recommend it to anyone.
Thanks for reading to the end!

Maybe I'm spoiled, but I don't regret the money I spent. This is the first Post-It title I've played from A to Z. It's a game from my childhood, and I had no complaints (except for the references and cameos that were unclear to me at the time). But after replaying it, I realized what a terrible game it is. So terrible that it's good (no fucking way). There are still some things that draw me in. For example, the OST. The soundtrack is simply amazing. The soundtrack is as good as the game is terrible. (If there are any errors in this (thesis), it's because my brain melted because of the game.)

Pros:
+ OST
+ Variety of weapons
+ The comic book cutscenes are very good and stylized like trashy B-movies
+ The art is very beautifully drawn, it wouldn't hurt to set at least one as your wallpaper

Cons:
- Plot
- Gameplay
- An unoptimized piece of crap, where in the files you can find phrases like "I don't know what this crap is, but it interferes with other crap, so let's disable it"
- Weapon balance ((it's just a mess) you can fix it in the game code, but that's too much)
- Bugs, bugs are never fixed (there are a TON of them, even Baggerpunk and Baggerfall suck in terms of the number of bugs per square meter combined)
- Segway
- BADGERSAW and CANISTER (you'll understand)

The game gets a bad rap from me 5 shit-stained napkins out of 10. (2 points for the OST)

column9: I'm going to play devil's advocate... Yes the game is buggy, crashes often, not translated, poorly optimized... But damn it's fun! We find the spirit of the franchise, it's stupid as hell, the winks to the film are cool and the atmosphere is there. I didn't sulk at my pleasure even if we go around it very quickly compared to its predecessor. (and again, almost 20 hours of play for my part doing most of the achievements and I get tired of it, it's still very decent) Postal 3, despite its technical flaws, is not so dishonorable and deserves its place in the franchise in my humble opinion.

column9:
Edit 2: The game has returned to Steam, this time releasing the Zoom version, which is DRM-free and has fixed some bugs. I'd say it's at least playable now.

Edit: Now that the game has been removed from the platform, it's LITERALLY unplayable, only pirated. What a shame because I was going to buy it again to give it a second chance. Now we just have to wait and see if RWS holds a giveaway or arranges for us to download this monstrosity.

OLD ANALYSIS:

There's no reason for the game to be sold to this day. Let me explain:

Besides the numerous bugs within the game, before you can run it, you need an activation key (basically, DRM). But that's fine. The only problem is that the website is down, it was removed, so there's no way to launch the game (unless you download a mod to remove the DRM and be able to play without a key code). The only problem with this mod is that it can crash your game; in short, it's unplayable. Furthermore, the game is poorly optimized, has horrible AI, and a poorly designed level system (yes, you read that right, this game is level-based). It's not worth 24 reais. I bought it just to complete my Postal collection, but the game is so horrible that I ended up refunding it.

column8: I would give this game a 4/10. It's ok, but I feel like there could be several things that would really improve this game. For instance, I feel like the kick and punch mechanic is broken and doesn't work very well in 3rd person. My biggest issue is that I had to download another file just to get this game to run, bc it wanted me to get an activation key from a website that doesn't exist anymore. Do I still find some entertainment value with this game, yes. Is it worth $12? Absolutely not. You're more likely to get your money's worth with any other Postal game aside from this one.

Akella, you're complete pigs, and the original developers are rightfully making fun of you :)

column8:
After the destruction of the city of Paradise - the dude goes deeper into America. And stuck in a small town near the border of Mexico - Catharsis.
It remains only to earn some money for gasoline and you can continue on your way! All you need to do is complete one small task, which can go wrong in this situation....

[list][b]Pros:[/b]
[*]+ Localization into third-party languages
[*]+ Achievements
[*]+ Voice acting of the Russian version from Courage-Bombay
[*]+ Modified Source engine
[*]+ Large selection of weapons
[*]+ Segway's! Now there are cars in Postal!
[*]+ Several options for passing the game
[*]+ Three finals!
[*]+ Great soundtrack

[b]Minuses:[/b]
[*]- Boring learning
[*]- Mediocre voice acting from Courage-Bombay
[*]- Part of the verbal puns - do not fit completely on the computer screen
[*]- Problematic melee controls
[*]- Problem aiming
[*]- Third person view
[*]- Voice acting / localization of only the main dialogues. And that is not completely.
[*]- Simple missions in which the player suffers due to terrible controls
[*]- Frequent freezes while loading levels
[*]- Small levels
[*]- Lack of free movement around the city
[*]- Lack of a map (or at least a mini-map)
[*]- Lack of task indicators (it‚Äôs not clear where to go at all!)
[*]- The choice of weapons (as long as you find the right one - you will die three times)
[*]- Terrible optimization
[*]- Enemies have infinite ammo and do not reload (especially painful from a couple of machine gunners)
[*]- Lack of stamina status bar (it just exists, but how much and when will it be restored? Nobody knows...)
[*]- Terrible character animation
[*]- Enemies spawn right behind the player
[*]- Terrible, stupid AI of game characters
[*]- Neutralizing a police officer with a shocker is equivalent to murder
[*]- Static cars and objects that block the player's map - hang in the air
[*]- When playing as a cop, pissing people are not troublemakers
[*]- Sound glitches that cause the Dude's voice to turn into a terrible rattle from the speakers (Cure with the help of a guide in the community)
[*]- Indistinct health bar
[*]- The damage caused by opponents and the player is not equivalent under the same conditions.
[*]- Boring and vague tasks
[*]- Lack of humor
[*]- Police killed by the Taliban at the Mexican border count as player kills
[*]- Bugs[/list]

[b]Total:[/b]
Since the release of the game, I knew that the game is considered a complete piece of crap. And buying it, I just wanted to collect a complete collection of games from the Postal series.
But the latest reviews, as well as the review of one of my comrades - that they advise you to reconsider your view of the game. Claiming that she's actually pretty good made me take my balls in my fist and go through her.
To my great regret - the game, as it was a piece of shit, so it remained.
I tried to ignore the toilet humor - not because it was nasty or I was embarrassed. No. I did not pay attention to him due to his absence. There is simply no humor in the game. And pathetic attempts to ridicule the most diverse situations only made them even more pathetic.
The game has moved from a first-person shooter to a third-person shooter. And of course, it played a terrible joke...  Because the controls are not optimized for this type. Get ready for the fact that you will not be able to hit the target with a pistol further than a few meters from the hero. Because the sight that is on the screen does not reflect the actual hit on the target. And this applies not only to ranged weapons - but also melee ones.
But you can get used to it. Even to the fact that a shot from a rifle tears the body in half, while from a machine gun you need to fire 200 bullets to put the enemy on the shoulder blades.
But you will have a great burn when you decide to choose a weapon - after all, the ammo in the game is not endless! And here we are met - a GREAT CHOICE OF WEAPONS! Yes, there are quite a lot of them in the game, but to streamline it - no one even thought about it. So spin the wheel! While you are being killed by a crowd of aggressive high school gamers with their mothers!
Remembering the absurd - but nevertheless funny tasks in Postal 2, I did not think that I would fall asleep from the most boring and monotonous tasks in Postal 3. Yes, there are a lot of them. And there are even several options for passing - both for "good" and "evil". Which has its own "exclusive" tasks. Therefore, in order to complete all the tasks - and get all the achievements, you will have to go through the game more than once - But how boring they are... And the constant deaths from the enemy with endless ammo - drive you into depression.

[b]In general, as a result[/b]: The game tried to continue the Postal series, but, like the film from Uwe Boll, it only profited from the loud title.
I do not recommend this product for passing if your time, money and nerves are valuable to you.

column9:
This is the surviving child of the POSTAL series. Honestly, it's not as bad as I imagined. I heard the quality was inconsistent due to repeated changes in development teams, and because the new developers didn't know how to use Unreal, they had to use the Source engine. The optimization is poor, the running screen is severely juddery, the key layout is inappropriate, and the third-person perspective and linear storyline prevent P3 from inheriting the first-person open-world style of P2. The style is more Western-style.

Vince and Krotchy from the second generation appear, but the weapon variety is a bit limited, and the ammunition capacity is too small.

Overall, it failed to live up to RWS's efforts. It's certainly not good, but there's no chance of improvement, and there will never be another.
[b]Because RWS has completely abandoned it[/b]

January 24th Addendum:
Postal 3, a grand resurrection!

After playing Postal 2, which was a great game in this third installment, I think RWS didn't get it right.

column8: If you're someone who plays all games in a series hoping for every game to look and be played the exact same, this certainly is NOT for you. I think this game is super fun and charming in it's own way as long as you're able to look past or even find amusement in bugs and kinda bad mechanics, at least that's how I am with Postal 3. It's even more fun when you're streaming and/or have friends watching all the chaos unfold! So happy this game has come back.

It's even more fun when you're streaming and/or have friends watching all the chaos unfold! So happy this game has come back.

column9: I know what you're thinkin', but the funny thing is, I don't even like video games.

[h2]The worst game in the series or a misunderstood genius?[/h2]

How many times in the second game was it hinted: "Don't buy Postal 3?" The situation here is actually twofold.

The Source engine is an excellent choice for a game engine. The arsenal, while not as extensive as in the second game, is still enjoyable. New weapons include a beehive, a badger, a machine gun, and so on. There are practically no zombies in the game. Health now regenerates automatically.
And, of course, there are buggy achievements; 90% can be achieved normally or in a non-standard way. If you want to play this, you probably won't want to play it more than once. Better yet, play Paradise Lost for the second game. It's an excellent replacement. Also, multiple crashes. 7 out of 10.

10/14/23. CARL THEY DID IT!!! POSTAL 3 BACK!!!

The game continues to be fixed further.

column9: The only good thing about this game is Corey Cruise's voice.

[code] Dear players,
This review expresses my purely personal opinion and is in no way intended to be offensive or controversial. I don't mean to offend anyone, nor do I have any complaints about people of a different race, skin color, and/or nationality. Love games, play games.[/code]

Playing the third game was incredibly painful, really. I started replaying it a second time and couldn't take it anymore. I'll play it again later. There are a lot of bugs and problems: with sound, textures, autosaving, achievements, and crashes. The game is very crude. But I can't help but notice Courage's excellent voice acting, the lackluster storyline, the cool jokes, and the Postal-style missions. The game is fun, I really enjoyed it, but it's quite difficult to play properly. So don't download it from Steam; download the pirated version. Overall, the game is great, but save yourself the hassle and play Dark Souls instead.

column8: LEER ANTES DE COMPRAR!!!si no tenes mucha paciencia y dedicacion te va costar un poco terminarlo ,en si el juego es medio aburrido y con una historia sin sentido y que no tiene esa escencia postal, basicamente este juego fue manoseado por mas de 3 estudios par desarrollarlo y esto se nota con el resultado final ,un juego incoherente que la verdad vale la pena comprarlo para reirse de el ,ADEMAS ESTA BUGEADO ,este tema abarca a los logros ya que sacar el final bueno de no matar a nadie es practicamente cuestion de suerte y obviamente no van a arreglar eso asi que si queres conseguir los logros te va a llevar un buen rato jugar repetidamente ,mejor ahorrarse plata y unos malos momentos que que estoy pasando al completarme el juego una y otra vez hasta sacar los ultimos logros que me faltan
column9: READ BEFORE BUYING!!! If you don't have a lot of patience and dedication it will cost you a bit to finish it, the game itself is kind of boring and with a meaningless story and that doesn't have that postal essence, basically this game was handled by more than 3 studios to develop it and this is noticeable in the final result, an incoherent game that is really worth buying to laugh at it, IT IS ALSO BUGGED, this issue covers the achievements since getting the good ending of not killing anyone is practically a matter of luck and obviously they are not going to fix that so if you want to get the achievements it will take you a while to play repeatedly, it is better to save money and some bad times that I am going through completing the game over and over again until I get the last achievements that I am missing

column9:
Before I bought this, I saw a lot of videos about how bad this game is, the whole story about how much Akella and Trashmasters screwed it up, how on the RWS website if you click on the Postal 3 options in the games section, they Rickroll you, and more.
I bought this just to see how bad it is, and if people aren't overreacting to the hate.
They're not exaggerating, the game is really unstable and bad.
The game crashes at almost every possible moment
The controls are buggy, so Dude only walks in one direction and you can't do anything about it except reload it
Killing with melee weapons or fists doesn't work at all
The enemy AI is broken (Especially the rhino)
There are cut scenes, etc.
The only things that are good are:
Corey Cruise - who voiced Postal Dude, Corey is really a perfect alternative
Music - A lot of the songs and soundtracks are amazing.

And that's all, I personally don't recommend this piece of enormous disappointment, you'd better buy the original Postal game and maybe even 4, which is broken, but at least RWS is working on it and it's not as terrible as 3.
But if you really want to know what the game is like, you'd better watch Youtube and don't waste 12 euros on this garbage.

column9:
It's so broken that it randomly crashes. RWS said: Don't buy Postal III. I don't regret the purchase, as I wanted to keep it on my account. This is the third time I've tried to play, this time on Linux, and even changing the Proton version doesn't fix it. I barely got past the first level due to an involuntary crash.

Do I recommend it? No. Neither Mike J, nor Vince Desi, nor anyone else would. But if you still want to play and try... It's at your own risk. Don't even ask for support, as Akella went bankrupt thanks to the game, and RWS has no control over the game (I don't know now, because even though they've fixed some things, I'm still seeing involuntary crashes).

Girlfriend and I are indeed Postal enthusiasts. 
We both knew to steer clear of postal 3 as we had listened to the warnings from the beloved RWS team for years...until the Steam Summer Sale of 2022 swung by, dropping delicious discounts all around.

So she bought me Postal 3 as a surprise with the full intent of making me suffer.

And boy did I suffer.

It wasn't all too bad though, as I made her watch me play the game in its entirety. 

Needless to say, I don't think she'll be doing that again. No regerts from me.

column8:
its terrible
littered with bugs and glitches, broken hitboxes likes it an ubisoft game, music loops way too soon and way too often, environments feel very empty, the morality system is bullshit (its a god damn postal game let us kill WHOEVER we want), VERY boring and tedious, theres this one sound effect of screaming that is played often for some reason, its very loud and very sudden and short

All in all, Postal 3 is an insult to Postal fans. RWS had nothing to do with this game, don't blame them. Blame Akella who wouldn't let go of the project during the 2008 crisis. Akella fired their best developers and playtesters first, then the went down the line, firing most of their employees. The final group, group D, was basically completely unskilled in game making, yet they borderline had to make half a game by themselves.

RESUMEN R√ÅPIDO: Una paja a medio d√≠a entretiene m√°s

--------------------------------------------------
Es sabido que la saga Postal es demasiada bruta pero la tercera parte es una exageraci√≥n.
Tiene algo similar a una historia que apenas se entiende, Los gr√°ficos son malos a pesar de usar el motor gr√°fico del HL2.
Si quieres una experiencia decente tienes que descargarte un mod aparte (hecho por la comunidad) para pasarlo medianamente bien. Eso si, tiene varias ideas que fueron usados para Postal 4 as√≠ que en algo aciertan con este juego.
Lo recomiendo siempre en una mega oferta y considerando los mods de otros para correrlo.
column9:
QUICK SUMMARY: A midday jerk-off is more entertaining.

--------------------------------------------------
It's well known that the Postal saga is too brutal, but the third installment is an exaggeration.
It has something similar to a story that's barely understandable. The graphics are poor despite using the HL2 engine.
If you want a decent experience, you have to download a separate mod (made by the community) to have a halfway fun time. That said, it has several ideas that were used for Postal 4, so they're right about something with this game.
I always recommend it when there's a big sale and considering other mods to run it.

column8: Shockingly not that bad. I went in with very low expectations, knowing how bad it was but I ended up having some fun in the short time I spent playing it. The shooting wasn't nearly as bad as I had heard, I had absolutely no trouble getting headshots and taking down enemies lethally and non-lethally. Although melee sucks, so there's that. I don't mind the more linear structure of this at all. I think it does that even better than Apocalypse Weekend did, which was kind of a slog to get through. Although that could be because I did Friday - Sunday in one sitting. I do not regret getting this for $2.39, and I'll probably finish it before playing 4. Definitely not worth $11.99, though. Do not pay more than at most $4 for this game, it still isn't anything special. Just exceeded my already low expectations.

Hi! My opinion on this game...
-
Yes, this game has a lot of flaws, but it could have been decent if they'd fixed them.
Nevertheless, I recommend this game.
-
Pros:
-Decent humor.
-Dismemberment.
-Good graphics.
-Achievements.
-Russian voice acting.
-Weapon selection.
-More than two possible outcomes.
-
Cons:
-Bugs.
-Terrible optimization.
-Stupid quests.
-Boring locations.
-
6/10.

column8:
Is it worse than postal 2? yes
Is the ai broken on multiple missions? yes
is the morality system a mechanic which should never be in a game about "going postal"? yes
But is it still fun? also yes
I honestly i was shocked I got a few fun hours out of this game after hearing about how terrible it is for all these years. Sad this game went through development hell cause the 2008 crash cause it had the potential to be a game which rivals postal 2 in quality.
Also this game fixes my biggest issue with postal 2 which is headshot damage feeling nonexistent. headshots in this game feel great and the sound design for guns is amazing even if most of them are just ripped from valve games which already have those respective weapons.
And one last thing, this game's soundtrack is incredible, honestly one of the best game OSTs I've ever heard, even if you don't play this game, PLEASE listen to the soundtrack cause it's part of the reason I think this game actually isn't that terrible.

column9: The game is the representation of when you go to take a shit but the shit is runny, making the situation worse

Just for fun, I decided to pick up this piece of crap and, so to speak, relive my 2011 days... I REALLY regretted the lag, crashes, stupid AI, and incredibly small locations where you can't do anything but shoot NPCs standing still. It was still a fucking piece of crap in 2011; it's amazing anyone can still run it on 4.

If you think you shouldn't listen to the majority and Postal 3 might actually be a good game, don't trust your gut instincts; they're deceiving you. I did just that, thinking I'd give the game a chance and see if it's as bad as everyone says. Unfortunately, I never really got that deep. I'm glad I didn't buy it at full price and that it at least has achievements; otherwise, I probably would have committed suicide. Let me start by saying that the game started lagging right from the start, even before I'd loaded the menu, even though my computer is pretty good. Luckily, I found a guide on how to fix the freezes and lags using AutoExec, and it ran even at Ultra settings. But that was just the calm before the storm; later, I encountered more than just awkward controls. It's just a complete piece of crap with the most atrocious controls, broken sound, gameplay that was probably made by the worst Dark Souls developers, and the most incomprehensible and boring plot with the most incomprehensible and unfunny humor. This fucking game should be tortured, no less. Instead, buy Postal 2, the Paradise Lost expansion, go to Dota, do whatever you want, just don't buy or run this piece of crap. When I was in a coma, a nurse installed this game, and I came out of the coma to uninstall it, and the nurse looked out the window...

Cara, eu sou f√£ da franquia Postal, e comprei o game j√° sabendo da fama dele, mas [b]MEU DEUS, QUE JOGO QUEBRADO[/b].

Simplesmente nenhuma mec√¢nica funciona corretamente, √© um sofrimento dar um soco ou chute em algu√©m.
O √∫nico ponto forte desse game √© o modelo do Postal Dude, que √© bem badass e mais bonito do que o do Postal 2 e 4, mas tirando isso, o jogo √© uma verdadeira l√°stima.

column9:
Man, I'm a fan of the Postal franchise, and I bought the game already knowing how popular it was, but [b]MY GOD, WHAT A BROKEN GAME[/b].

None of the mechanics work properly; it's a pain to punch or kick someone.
The only strong point of this game is the Postal Dude model, which is pretty badass and better looking than the one in Postal 2 and 4, but other than that, the game is a real shame.

I don't know what happened to the soundtrack, which right in the first part of the bridge, plays royalty-free music that's uglier than a homeless person's lunchbox. Terrible.

I bought the game precisely so I could play the long-awaited Catharsis Reborn mod, but I just found out it's going to be fully standalone, which is a stupid purchase.

I'm going to refund it and use my 4 bucks to support my sawdust inhaling habit.

ok, eu zerei o jogo e vou apontar alguns problemas desse jogo.

1. os controles s√£o horr√≠veis, a mec√¢nica de usar cover em paredes n√£o funciona pq os inimigos ainda conseguem atirar em vc na maioria das vezes, pra pular vc precisa pegar cover e apertar w... pq? era t√£o difiicl fazer o pulo ser √∫nico e ficar na barra de espa√ßo????

2. game design porco, os mapas s√£o podres e contra intuitivos, eu fiquei perdido algumas vezes, sem saber onde ir (talvez pq eu seja meio lerdo, mas tinha alguns lugares bem escondidos)

3. gameplay chata do caralho puta merda, a cada minuto tem uma cutscene, e quando ela acaba vc tem q fazer a MESMA COISA TODA FASE: atirar nos carinhas, as vezes escoltar algum npc BURRO PRA CARALHO e de vez em nunca tem uns negocios legais, tipo a "bossfight" com o rinoceronte e o helic√≥ptero no come√ßo do jogo

4. o jogo √© muito mal otimizado, os gr√°ficos nem s√£o l√° essas coisas mas mesmo assim o fps √© inst√°vel demais, qualquer fase com bastante npcs atirando j√° fica com fps baixo.

column9:
Okay, I finished the game and I'm going to point out some of its problems.

1. The controls are horrible. The wall-covering mechanic doesn't work because enemies can still shoot you most of the time. To jump, you have to take cover and press w... why? Was it so hard to do a single jump and hold the spacebar????

2. Poor game design, the maps are crappy and counterintuitive. I got lost a few times, not knowing where to go (maybe because I'm a bit slow, but there were some well-hidden places).

3. Boring gameplay, every minute there's a cutscene, and when it's over, you have to do the SAME THING EVERY STAGE: shoot the guys, sometimes escort some FUCKING DUMB NPC, and every now and then there's some cool stuff, like the boss fight with the rhino and the helicopter at the beginning of the game.

4. The game is very poorly optimized. The graphics aren't all that great, but even so, the FPS is incredibly unstable. Any level with a lot of NPCs shooting already has low FPS.

I didn't like the game... I'll try to get the platinum!

I'm a cheerful shit-eater,
And I don't need candy.
I don't need chocolate,
I dream of shit.

And dreaming their seventh dreams,
I dive into the toilet
And swim like a scuba diver.

I have a dustpan with me
And a big bag like this.
I'll scoop up some shit -
I won't die of hunger.
I wash my face with fecal water,
And sometimes,
When shit isn't a problem,
I take baths in it.

If someone lives in shit,
They don't sing about it.
Well, fate has given us
To each their own shit.
A world filled with shit,
It's littered all around.
I have a table here and there -
It's good that people shit!

I'm allergic to cleanliness
A mile away. I can't imagine,
What I see in shit.
I want to be normal
And live normally,
But I still crave
But stinking shit.

And I don't need candy.
I don't need chocolate,
I dream of shit.
At night, when people are sleeping
And dreaming their seventh dreams,
I secretly go
On a shit hunt.

column8:
It isn‚Äôt just the humor that totally fails in this sequel, it is the game as a whole.

As I started up this game and went through that horrible tutorial, I could immediately tell that this was gonna be fucking ass and that I would have to drag myself through it, which also is why I stopped playing shortly after that sex shop mission in the start of the game.

Like I said, this is probably the worst tutorial I have ever played. It teaches you a bunch of shit that doesn‚Äôt relate to the actual objective before telling you how to do what the arrow wants you to do. I also managed to break one of the triggers, softlocking myself 5 minutes into the game. This was also an issue I had a lot in Postal 4, constantly softlocking myself.

The visuals also suck and gameplay just feels ass, especially the movement which feels weird and cheap, if that makes any sense. It looks like they spent all their time on shitty unfunny jokes instead of on good gameplay and visuals, like they think dumb jokes is all that is needed for a good Postal game.

Also, what the fuck is up with those 8 bit background tracks, feels like I‚Äôm playing a handheld game from the 90s.

Even though I didn‚Äôt pay for this game, I feel like I deserve a refund for wasting time on it. Go buy literally anything else.

The visuals also suck and gameplay just feels ass, especially the movement which feels weird and cheap, if that makes any sense. It looks like they spent all their time on shitty unfunny jokes instead of on good gameplay and visuals, like they think dumb jokes is all that is needed for a good Postal game.

Also, what the fuck is up with those 8 bit background tracks, feels like I‚Äôm playing a handheld game from the 90s.

Even though I didn‚Äôt pay for this game, I feel like I deserve a refund for wasting time on it. Go buy literally anything else.

I Regret Everything


This game makes Duke Nukem Forever look like a good sequel. 

It feels nothing like Postal other than some of the humor and the Dude being the main character.

The game encourages non lethal gameplay while not having voice lines for it. (You will be saying guns don't kill people I do when your arresting someone by the book as a cop).

The game seems to lack any major game breaking bugs from what I played, but the games buggy. I passed the police tutorial stage but got the failed cutscene then continued down the police path for example, and a lot of the time sound effects and music don't stop during cutscenes when they are supposed to. 

The humor is there and alright I guess but not as funny as the rest of the series, and feels in many ways like a retread of the movie (The Dude wanders into the chaos, the Taliban, Uwe Boll being in a scene, etc.). 

The one redeeming factor is Corey Cruise as the Dude. He is a great Postal Dude and easily the next best thing to Rick Hunter, and honestly in some ways I may even prefer him to Rick Hunter. But now you can play as him in Postal 4 and Brain Damaged, or use the mod using his voice lines in Postal 2 so there is no reason to play this game to have his performance as the Dude, as great as it is. 

The game is also non canon in a way as it counts only as a dream sequence, so don't bother playing it for the Postal plot line. This isn't an issue though it's a good thing it got retconned out of existence. 

The level design is just all around poor, and boring.

The controls are awkward. 

The graphics use a lot of predefined Source Engine assets (Yes this runs on Source.) for example the Blood and much of the gunfire is straight from TF2. The white stuff in the Adult store section is the Scouts Mad Milk. I even think the Dude's piss might just be the Jarate sprayed in a different way. The audio is the same way, the gun fire and impact sounds are all from Half Life 2, making the game feel less than official. 

To be honest the way the in game voice lines were handled makes it feel like the Dude was just modded into the game, but that honestly is an insult to mods such as P3 Dude in Postal 2 and the Postal Dude Hatred mod that mod him into those games and do so great. 

Just a waste of money and more importantly time.

Akella's stupidity and Trashmaster's constant crashes. There are freezes that make the game unpleasant. The game's strengths are the story, the dude's new style, and the fact that it's better than Post 4, as well as Jennifer Walcott, the courageous voice acting, funny moments, and the soundtrack. Still, I don't recommend it. Akella, please don't make any more games or shut down your company. Don't disgrace yourself. Trashmasters, your name says it all. I'll give the game a 3/10.
This is one of RWS's biggest mistakes. If they hadn't outsourced the game's development to some unrelated studios, the game would have been good. I'd love to see a remake of this game, but alas, it might not happen.
Have they really released an update for this game?

Despite the negative reviews, I still think Postal 3 is an average game, but by no means the worst in the series or g.o.v.n.o., as the young fans of the new RWS lineup believe. You can certainly enjoy the game if you install a fix or disable PHYSX to reduce the lag, as I've heard from many in the Postal community about this issue. Okay, let's move on to the good and bad aspects of the game. Pros:
+Nonlinear plot with multiple endings (there are only three, and they depend on your playstyle)
+Decent gameplay (the shooting is decent, and the third-person view doesn't detract from the enjoyment)
+Decent graphics for its time
+Diverse city of Catharsis (this city is, of course, no different from Paradise, but they still tried to at least add some variety to the structure)
+Short playthrough time (I played through the game on the good side the first time, and it only took me 3 hours)
The pros have ended, and now the cons are in order. Cons:
-Optimization (it's great that they used the Source engine for this game, but due to the careless programmers at Trashmasters, it will significantly reduce FPS, but as I already said, this problem can be solved)
-Russian dubbing (you can say all you want, but let's be honest: the microphone the dubbing was recorded on is of the worst quality, even for 2011. The best solution would be to set the in-game voiceover to English, since you're allowed to do so)
Bottom Line: I understand that defenders of the new RWS roster will pounce, but let's be honest: the new Postal games they're making are already derivative and low-quality projects made with one goal in mind: to make money off of such fans. Postal 3, on the other hand, was originally a game with a good idea, something Steve Wick wanted even after the development of the second part, but RWS decided to turn to Akella, and so it all started to roll: some things had to be cut, some had to be left in, and it barely worked. It's still a work in progress, but it still turned out to be what it is. There's just one thing: there are Postal 3 mods like Catharsis Reborn or a mod made using the Postal 3 Unreal engine from the second game. We're unlikely to see anything Steve Wick came up with, alas, here. As for the new RWS team, they can go fuck themselves with their Paradise Lost, Postal Redux, and their crap Postal 4 No Regerts. I also recommend getting it on sale; I got it for 79 rubles during the New Year's sale and wasn't disappointed with that price. Plus, the game itself shouldn't cost as much as they're asking.
Rating: 5.5/10
P.S. Okay, Postal 3 is complete crap, but it's still better than the useless and shit-covered Postal 4 No Regerts.

column8: It's not as bad as everyone says (the devs just like to beat that dead horse so bad its glue).  Its a fairly fun over the shoulder shooter with the tonal stylings of the uwe boll postal movie. The pacifist vs postal ideas mechanic is expanded way more in this game with multiple paths and stories to take. Though some of the good endings can be a bit difficult to obtain. While I don't think this game deserves the unapologetic hate it gets it is still a bad game... But for a die hard postal fan who needs their curiosity satiated its well worth the money and very much fun for a playthrough or two.

I don't have many hours on this game, but I do 

Think this game as Postal 3 but with bigger maps, plays better too, and has more or so the same gameplay (fix equipment, gather ammunition heal units etc). You can play as either the Germans or the Russians, in a series of scripted reenactments of real battles that took place. The meat and potatoes for me, is the dynamic campaign that this game offers. You play on a map with random battles, and while you play, you get to unlock units according your score of your previous battles. The game's variety of military personnel and equipment is close to that of Postal 3. You can chose your difficulty along with the campaign's length. Yes, the game has time management. It does not offer a tactical pause, but it can become so slow (almost bullet time) that will definitely give you all the time you need.
The best of all, is the ability to directly command a unit (from a single soldier to a tank) and play in 3rd - 1st person with which I had a lot of fun.Do expect the best graphics in the world, they are definitive. Corpses stay on the battlefield. Highly immersive.


I've never played a WW2 game before in my life, but i've never had so much fun as I have with this one.
