*POSTAL 3* Para analisarmos este game , teremos que fazer por partes |an√°lise geral , gr√°ficos , hist√≥ria , protagonista , jogabilidade , f√≠sica e comparar com o anterior|.
GERAL---------------
Bem mediano e med√≠ocre a comparar com o segundo game da franquia , contudo tem seu lado bom , mas ele ainda deixa a desejar quando voc√™ nota o qu√£o o jogo vai ficando broxante e repetitivo . Apesar disso , eu tive momentos divertidos com o game, mas n√£o o suficiente pra achar ele INCRIVEL no maximo legalzinho , o maior motivo para n√£o recomendar , √© que o 2 √© melhor , mais barato , mais historia , mais DLC , mais divertido e a jogabilidade incr√≠vel , mas se fosse um jogo sem franquia , ou criado por f√£s amadores ( afinal empresas gigantes fazendo merda n√£o √© aceit√°vel n√£o ) ele teria uma nota maior pela criatividade , mas a RWS fez muita coisa melhor .
Gr√°ficos----------------------------------------------
sinceridade eu amei esses gr√°ficos cartunescos , achei bonito , o design do Dude ficou bom , o cabelo , as botas , as cal√ßas e a cor menos EDGY da jaqueta deixou mais bonito o personagem , e o jogo no gr√°fico geral √© bonito e teve um bom trabalhinho ali. Nota 7 (j√° vi melhores)
Hist√≥ria------------------------------------------------
Parece uma piada de mal gosto , cuspido na cara dos f√£s do P2 como se fosse merda , do nada o jogo te for√ßa a ser bonzinho ou a fazer boas a√ß√µes (????????????????) POSTAL desde o 1 √© pra matar e fazer merda , fazer final Jesus √© algo opcional (√© divertido) mas n√£o crucial , e esse jogo a hist√≥ria √© essa , dude tem que ser bonzinho para as coisas darem certo , eu fiz o final ruim porque por-favor Running With Scissors , ENFIE NA SUA BUNDA FINALZINHO BOM E VAI FAZER UM POSTAL DE VERDADE ( ja fez , pq postal 3 de verdade √© o PARADISE LOST , ISSO √â POSTAL 3 !!). enfim fiz o final ruim , resumo √© que o dude morre e vai pro inferno e fim , tudo que vc fez n teve um final legal como o 2 , vc s√≥ foi pro inferno e fim , ainda bem que segundo a RWS o jogo √© ruim mesmo e N√ÉO √â CAN√îNICO , pule direto do 1 , 2 , paradise , 4 e brain damaged para entender a saga postal completa , esse jogo no quesito historia √© uma PIADA na cara dos f√£s. Nota 0 (LIXO !).
Protagonista-----------------------------------------
aqui eu dou valor , eles ainda deixaram a  ess√™ncia do humor negro , das falar carism√°ticas , do humor POSTAL , o jogo continua engra√ßado apesar de ruim , isso eu devo valorizar , pois me tirou boas risadas , isso sim √© protagonista engra√ßado com falas fodas , meu √∫nico problema √© a voz , a do Rick Hunter √© melhor , achei uma bosta a voz , mas o protagonista √© perfeito , n√£o desisti de jogar por conta do personagem estar √çNCRIVEL igual nos outros games POSTAL , espero que nos pr√≥ximos ainda tenha essa ess√™ncia fudidamente engra√ßada . Nota  8 (engra√ßado pra porra)
Jogabilidade ---------------------------------------
bem , ai chegamos em um ponto que me pega de surpresa , pois a jogabilidade terceira pessoa √© um cu , o cara corre e a c√¢mera fica com parkinson , o xixi n √© mais bot√£o pr√≥prio , agora √© arma (????????) , mas a mec√¢nica de cover √© √≥tima , √© divertida e √∫til , mas ai o jogo n te deixa pular (?????????????) √© uma gameplay confusa perto do 2 , mas o tiroteio melhorou , diferente do 2 que o tiroteio √© mediano , o tiroteio neste jogo est√° envolvente , mas ai eles FODERAM com uma pica de ferro o combate corpo a corpo  QUE PORRA DE COMBATE √â ESSE CARALHO ???? 50 cacetetada no cara ele n morre , mas que porra , no dois era melhor . e o gore √© 10 !!! o gore desse jogo √© √≥timo , tu pode desmembrar algu√©m VIOLENTAMENTE e usar o bra√ßo como arma , isso √© √≥timo , mas ainda assim O COMBATE A CORPO A CORPO √â HORROROSO ! o tiroteio √© bom , mas o corpo a corpo √© uma vergonha comparado a do dois , puta que pariu. Nota 5 (√© boa... mas podia ser BEM melhor...)
F√≠sica---------------------
assim , f√≠sica de armas √© ok , e de ragdolls √© bem boa , nada de novo , mas de props.......... √© horrorosa , lembro-me de empurrar uma cadeira pra frente e eu ir pra frente tamb√©m , virou leis de newton 2? acho que essa parte eu pulei na escola , pq n me lembro de empurrar coisas e ser empurrado junto , achei horroroso , atirei um gal√£o de √°gua no ch√£o e ele ficou de p√© (LEIS DE NEWTON APROVAM ESTA PARTE DA AN√ÅLISE) , ou seja , f√≠sica de props horr√≠vel , f√≠sica do ragdoll normal e f√≠sica de armas normal tamb√©m. Nota 5 (podia ser melhor , vamos combinar , principalmente feito na Physx).
Comparativos ---------------------------------------
No 1 jogo tinhamos a vis√£o de cima , no 2 melhorou em FPS ai eles tentaram inovar no 3 com TPS , e foi horr√≠vel, o jogo 2 √© melhor em 8/10 aspectos do jogo , hist√≥ria , dublagem , atua√ß√£o , combate , jogabilidade , fases , aventura e liberdade , P3 s√≥ √© melhor que o 2 no aspecto gr√°fico e design , de resto n√£o , ou seja , compre direto o 4 e pule essa merda ( eu devia ter feito isso).
NOTA FINAL : 5/10 jogo podre perto do anterior , faltou coisas , esse papinho de fazer bondade n√£o cola em um jogo como postal , n√£o criem franquias fodas pra depois trocar o objetivo delas , ningu√©m √© idiota .
EXTRA : o jogo √© ruim , mas se voc√™ puxa saco de jogos ruins que vem de empresas grandes , vc √© um idolatra , seja justo , essa √© uma an√°lise imparcial e incorreta politicamente , a ideia √© expressar a opini√£o de um f√£ de postal que zerou todo P2 e joga os cl√°ssicos postal tamb√©m , se discorda , comente o por-qu√™ , obrigado pela sua aten√ß√£o e ignore a gram√°tica merda.
                                                       5/10
column9:
*POSTAL 3* To analyze this game, we'll have to do it in parts |general analysis, graphics, story, protagonist, gameplay, physics and compare it to the previous one|.
OVERALL---------------
Pretty average and mediocre compared to the second game in the franchise, however, it has its good sides, but it still leaves something to be desired when you notice how the game becomes boring and repetitive. Despite that, I had fun moments with the game, but not enough to find it AMAZING at best, pretty cool. The biggest reason I don't recommend it is that the second one is better, cheaper, has more story, more DLC, is more fun and the gameplay is incredible. But if it were a game without a franchise, or created by amateur fans (after all, giant companies doing shit is not acceptable) it would have a higher score for creativity, but RWS did a lot better. Graphics----------------------------------------------
honestly, I loved these cartoonish graphics, I thought they were beautiful, the Dude's design was good, the hair, the boots, the pants and the less EDGY color of the jacket made the character more beautiful, and the game's graphics in general are beautiful and there was a good job done there. Rating 7 (I've seen better)
Story------------------------------------------------
It seems like a bad joke, spat in the face of P2 fans as if it were shit, out of nowhere the game forces you to be good or do good deeds (????????????????) POSTAL since 1 is to kill and do shit, doing the Jesus ending is something optional (it's fun) but not crucial, and this game's the story, dude has to be good for things to work out, I made the bad ending because please Running With Scissors, STICK THE GOOD ENDING UP YOUR ASS AND GO MAKE A REAL POSTAL (you already did, because the real postal 3 is PARADISE LOST, THIS IS POSTAL 3!!). anyway, I did the bad ending, in short, the guy dies and goes to hell and that's it, everything you did didn't have a good ending like 2, you just went to hell and that's it, thank goodness according to RWS the game is really bad and NOT CANONICAL, skip straight from 1, 2, paradise, 4 and brain damaged to understand the complete postal saga, this game in terms of story is a JOKE in the face of the fans. Rating 0 (TRASH!). Protagonist-----------------------------------------
Here I give value, they still left the essence of dark humor, of charismatic speeches, of POSTAL humor, the game is still funny despite being bad, I must value that, because it made me laugh a lot, that is a funny protagonist with awesome lines, my only problem is the voice, Rick Hunter's is better, I thought the voice was shit, but the protagonist is perfect, I didn't give up playing because the character is AMAZING like in the other POSTAL games, I hope that in the next ones it still has this fucking funny essence. Rating 8 (funny as fuck)
Gameplay ---------------------------------------
Well, here we come to a point that catches me by surprise, because the third-person gameplay is a pain in the ass, the guy runs and the camera gets Parkinson's, peeing is no longer a button, now it's a weapon (????????)), but the cover mechanic is great, it's fun and useful, but then the game doesn't let you jump (?????????????) It's a confusing gameplay compared to 2, but the shooting has improved, unlike 2 where the shooting is average, the shooting in this game is engaging, but then they FUCKED UP the melee combat with an iron pickaxe WHAT THE FUCK IS THIS COMBAT???? 50 beats the guy up and he doesn't die, but what the fuck, in 2 it was better. And the gore is a 10!!! The gore in this game is great. You can VIOLENTLY dismember someone and use their arm as a weapon. That's great, but THE MELEE COMBAT IS STILL HORRIBLE! The shooting is good, but the melee is a disgrace compared to the second one. Holy shit. 5 out of 5 (it's good... but it could be MUCH better...)
Physics--------------------
So, weapon physics is okay, and ragdoll physics is pretty good, nothing new, but the props... it's horrible. I remember pushing a chair forward and myself moving forward too. Is it like Newton's Laws 2? I think I skipped this part in school, because I don't remember pushing things and being pushed along, I thought it was horrible, I threw a gallon of water on the floor and it stayed standing (NEWTON'S LAWS APPROVE THIS PART OF THE ANALYSIS), in other words, horrible prop physics, normal ragdoll physics and normal weapon physics too. Grade 5 (it could be better, let's face it, especially done in Physx). Comparisons ---------------------------------------
In the first game we had the top-down view, in the second they improved in FPS, then they tried to innovate in the third with TPS, and it was horrible. The second game is better in 8/10 aspects of the game: story, voice acting, acting, combat, gameplay, levels, adventure and freedom. P3 is only better than the second in the graphics and design, otherwise not, in other words, buy the fourth straight away and skip this shit (I should have done that).
FINAL GRADE: 5/10, a rotten game compared to the previous one, it was missing things, this talk of doing good doesn't fly in a game like Postal, don't create awesome franchises and then change their objective, nobody is an idiot. EXTRA: the game is bad, but if you suck up to bad games that come from big companies, you're an idolater, be fair, this is an impartial and politically incorrect analysis, the idea is to express the opinion of a Postal fan who finished all of P2 and plays the Postal classics too, if you disagree, comment why, thank you for your attention and ignore the shitty grammar. 5/10

Postal 3 is a game that was so unfairly trashed that even the developers are complaining about it. It's definitely worth a place in the series. It's all down to the critics, who constantly ruin everyone's impressions of the games. The game isn't as bad as you might think.
The story is okay, but it can feel boring at times.
The gameplay is fun, but not as much as Postal 2. Postal 2 has more options, but there aren't many weapons and not enough content. The open-world mode is quite interesting; it's the best thing about the game. There were almost no bugs in the game before, and now they're completely absent.
Otherwise, the game is excellent.
And especially if you get it on sale for 73 rubles, it's definitely worth it.
7/10

column9:
The missions are really funny and creative, and this game's soundtrack is the best of all the postcards.

But there's no point in having good ideas if you don't know how to execute them. The combat in this game is terrible, the enemies are bullet sponges.

And all that freedom you had in Postal 2 is gone here, lol. But there are two endings, good and bad, which depend on your karma level. Many items were also cut, like the crack pipe and vests.

Melee combat is also garbage, not to mention the countless crashes this game has, lol.

But if you go in with your mind off things, the game is actually quite interesting.

Rating: 6/10

I honestly don't understand the hate towards this game. Seriously, the game is only bad technically; it lags on some missions and crashes occasionally, but it still has most of what we loved about the series.

It has solid dismemberment, a variety of weapons, and a variety of playthroughs. You can also complete the game without killing anyone, and the open world, while unlocked only after completing the storyline, is still fun to play. The satire, while not as intense as in the second game, is still there, and there are even moments that make you laugh.

The graphics still look pleasing to the eye (thanks to the Source engine), and the level design is good. And I still find details in this game that you might not notice the first time you play (for example, did you know that dogs can defecate in it?).

In short, it's an okay game. Not the best in the series, but not the worst it's been acclaimed for.

column8:
Game isn't as bad as they make it out to be. It's mostly the fact they often put you directly into the jobs/missions as opposed to Postal 2 where you roam free before going to your objectives that is lame.

And the fact the engine is very poorly optimised on top of it probably makes people quit fast (and the devs had the genius idea of bombarding the game with NPCs spawning everywhere).

Make the changes to the autoexec.cfg file recommended on this website https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Postal_III, and it'll help a lot with performances. Not perfect, but way better.

And it's maybe the only game I would recommend not buying on Steam, as it never goes on sale. I got it for like 1-2$ elsewhere, and I'm not too worried about the key being revoked. This game is Abandonware anyways. But worth it at this price.

(edit): It's pretty solid with mods, but without them this dumpster fire is nearly unplayable. If you wanna play this game for some reason, you're gonna have to pirate it since it's been removed from Steam (thank god). Next, download the beta mod, improved Postal 3 mod, gore mod, unofficial patch, and DRM-free fix. After that, you're all set to play Postal 3 the way it was meant to be played. Or you can just go on RWS' website and pick up a DRM free copy of Postal 2 and Paradise Lost for 2 bucks a pop and skip this trash. And while you're at it, support Hyperstrange by buying Postal: Brain Damaged. And remember, if you wanna regret nothing, don't buy Postal 3.

(2nd edit): Postal III doesn't launch on my computer anymore as of 12/30/22. Rest in piss, sweet prince.

column8:
I really thought "it can't be THAT bad, right?"
Well, I was wrong.
Apart from some satisfying dismemberment and some occasionally good music, this game really has no redeeming features and is just an unstable pile of crap.

Expect the following:
-Inconsistent audio volumes, where some moments bleed your ears out, and other you won't hear what the crap anyone is saying.
-The tutorial is obnoxious with way too many popups.
-Prone to crashing, especially whenever you throw an item or throwable weapon.
-Boring and linear mission design, with a lot of escort missions. Thankfully the NPC you need to protect has never died on me, but their AI is just annoying and crap to deal with, takes forever to walk to their destination.
-Constant softlocking, especially in the Police building levels. Doors that are supposed to open up will just stay closed, and you are forced to restart the mission over and over if you haven't quicksaved ever minute.
-Horrible melee combat. Don't even bother using it, as it is extremely tedious to even hit anyone.
-Rocket launcher has caused me to kill myself in the majority of times that I attempted to use it. Don't bother with any other weapons that aren't machine guns, honestly.
-Extremely long loading times. No idea why.
-Constant interruptions from cutscenes. Don't get me wrong. I don't mind cutscenes in videogames. And they aren't the worst in this game. It's just that there are plenty of moments where 20 seconds of gameplay gets interrupted over and over with another cutscene.
-The game features a lot of optional side objectives that you need to furfill if you want the "good ending" of the game. Which 90% of the case revolves around NOT killing people. Imagine that. The objective to NOT KILL PEOPLE in a POSTAL GAME.
-The improvised pepper spray flamethrower flame effects look absolutely pathetic.
-Horrible framerate UP THE ASS.
-Some occasional tasteless homophobic jabs. I get that Postal is very silly and often makes tasteless jokes aimed at plenty of different stereotypes and whatnot, I get it, I am fine with jokes. But the homophobic jabs I am talking about are no "jokes" that the game is making. Just tasteless insults.

Generally speaking, just don't bother with this game and wait for Postal 4 to get out of Early Access.

column8:
This game is so bad that it is funny beyond believe .
Graphics are mediocre, the game when it was released was one big glitch but this issues have been fixed mostly.
Now what is left is a truly hilarious bad videogame that tries not to take anything (including theirself) serious.
Gameplay is also a mediocre thing, The story? It is doing  the name "postal" proud.
Now you would thing i could not recommend such a crappy cult game.
Well i can. The short while i have been rampaging has been quite a good time and i more than once had a huge smile on my face.
My advice is if you love bad cult games the try this game when it is cheap.
For all you GTA purists and fans of more serious games, you better stay away from this one.
Still.... Recommended

column9: i took one step and it crashed lol

I think a lot of people are deliberately underrating it without even playing it properly. The game has a lot of technical issues, like distorted sound, enemies falling through the floor, or the final boss getting stuck in the pavement... Lots of problems. I'd especially like to touch on the humor. What is it like? Well, let's say not everyone gets it. The only truly funny and noticeable reference is Mavrodi, who for some reason hangs out in Catharsis. 
This game is full of bugs, optimization issues, and questionable decisions, but I'd be embarrassed to call it crap. Oddly enough, in both technical and graphical terms, it's a cut above the 2. The graphics are nicer, the mapping isn't eye-watering, there's at least some variety, and most importantly, there are now cassettes. They're not exactly the best quality either, but it's not as bad as Serious Sam, and the monotonous, clunky voiceover creates the feeling of a lousy, cheap movie bought in an alley from Uncle Vasya. I don't know if that was their original idea, but the effect is pretty good.

So... What can I say in the end? Is it trash? Yeah, but it's enough for a one-time watch. I think a 6/10 is the maximum it deserves. Whether you play this piece of crap or not is up to you; everything I've said above is just my personal opinion.

I liked it...
Well, the game is better than the second game in some places ‚Äì it's less drawn-out, and the gameplay does its best to keep you entertained... well, it tries. Some missions are truly boring, but there are also plenty where you naturally rush into a rush with a bang, accompanied by cool music.

A few things about the game disappointed me:

1. No proper kicks or jumps.
2. Optimization... It's crap ‚Äì if you don't clear your saves, the game will crash like hell.
3. The humor ‚Äì it's noticeably worse than the second game.

And that's about it. As a sequel to the second game, the game raises a lot of questions, but as a 4-6 hour trasher, it's perfect. Ultimately, it's not as bad as many say.

column8:
A ver...
Si bien este juego posee muchos bugs, crasheos y mala optimizaci√≥n (no es como que el dos no tenga, tiene como para hacer un pastel) Considero que esta entrega respeto muy bien el universo de postal en lo que es su violencia,  humor negro y satira hacia ciertos grupos que los fans de este mundillo ya se saben. adem√°s de inclusi√≥n de personajes famosos y previos de la franquicia. 
No considero que el pase de escenarios haya estado tan mal pero esto ciertamente daba para un mundo abierto de verdad (no pura carga entre pantallas) lastima que los desarrolladores no lograron aprovechar el motor para eso.

En fin, lo considero un experimento el cual mato la critica y el abandono de akella al no ponerse a arreglar lo que correspond√≠a.
Comprenlo si sale en oferta por si les da morbo probarlo aunque sea un rato.
column9:
Let's see...
While this game has many bugs, crashes, and poor optimization (it's not like the second one doesn't have any, it has enough to make a cake), I think this installment respects the postcard universe very well, with its violence, dark humor, and satire toward certain groups that fans of this world already know. It also includes famous and previous characters from the franchise.

I don't think the stage transition was that bad, but this certainly had the potential for a real open world (not just loading between screens). It's a shame the developers didn't take advantage of the engine for that.

Anyway, I consider it an experiment that killed the critics and the abandonment of Akella by not fixing what was needed.
Buy it if it comes on sale in case you're curious to try it, even for a while.

column8:
Wow, I was so excited to play this back in the day, but, then I somehow thought it had been cancelled. A couple of years ago I found out, very late, that it finally had come out, but it was supposed to be horrible and unplayable. I was convinced by so many that it was legit unplayable, and that is a dang gong lie! 
Now, I have no idea why Running With Scissors hates this game... 

The story is so darn funny, and it really is a time capsule of history viewed through a satirical bong filter. IS the gameplay perfect? No, no, no... But it does something really different in my opinion, the game has a very old-school arcade-style to it, where you get these little missions, which either have inventive story design, or offer a new kind of take on the same old shoot this and that formula. 

The objectives are interesting, varied, and hysterical. I really do not get the massive hate, maybe I am stroking the game a little too much, but how else are you gonna climax? The shooting and combat are fun simply due to the strange arcade vibe the game has, things are a bit off here and there, the A.I and some areas needed more work, but it's just so much fun.

What is wrong with a game that is just enjoyable? It's fun, brutal, mayhem and I love every second of it, not to mention the branching paths and choices offer massive replay value. This game really does deserve a second chance, it has some issues but they are few and far in between and never stop the game from progressing or cause any real agony. 

I just cannot understand why people lied about this game, I get not liking it, but you all made me think it was unplayable, and yet, three hours of game time later, I had not one issue. I have to say the game has some because some people report them, but the game did not even lag, and also looked damn sexy. Postal 3 may very well be the most underrated and unjustly tarnished game in history.

column9:
Games are beyond politics, and that's fine, and developers can be too. Unfortunately, however, I believe that if a psychopathic Dobby can invade a neighboring country with impunity, simply because he wants to, and on top of that, threatens any countries that might prevent him with nuclear weapons, then, with all due respect and no offense to game developers, it should be boycotted. It took decades for the world to once again look at Russians as civilized people after the end of the Cold War, and yet here's one Dobby-looking brat with an ego the size of a galaxy, whose stupid actions ensure that for another decade, such a noble nation will be perceived as mindless scum, doing dirty work in the hands of a mindless KGB colonel with dictatorial aspirations.

It's not your fault, developers, whoever you think is your dictator in Moscow, but unfortunately, you, along with all this Russian madness, should be isolated from the civilized world, both politically and economically. Before a global tragedy occurs and your government (in the person of a possessed idiot) begins to function stably in modern civilization. Until then, you should be boycotted in every sphere of economics and politics, barred from external influence, and without foreign sales. Perhaps a lack of financial resources will finally force your oligarchs to think twice and eliminate from the system this cancerous tumor gnawing at your country: the dwarf psychopath from the KGB.

While its clearly visible that reviews says something else and those who played are pulled off, BUT few bugs and script errors that can land you out of the game sometimes which is completely Redacolous, these glitches appear at minor scale and not something that can make your gameplay experience agonizing. I myself experienced 4 or 5 such times , all the time I played it. BUT , are you gonna give away the chance of Uncontrollable laughter moments that this game has to offer. What's better than 1st person postal 2, A 3rd-person Rootin-tootin postal 3 where you can either follow a good path and become a law enforcer peeing the scum and maniacs and havoc causing Al-qaeda out of your area or just be a mamma's bad boy and kill anyone and everyone you see because you like spilling blood, Its fun and no one actually punishes when you slice and dice innocents in the game. I followed both playthroughs and the fact of having boss fight with Dhoti and lehenga wearing clown looking al-qaeda ring leader Osama Bin Laden and his funny arabic accent can make you fart out of unstoppable laughing. Every element of the game comes with humor. If you want to seek revenge and actually bring osama bin laden and Al-Qaeda to grounds, yeah the same laden that everyone knows (which is a main boss in the game), Postal III is your surefire destination. 

Now , excuse me, but I can't stop so here I go :-

Hahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahah!!!!

What's better than 1st person postal 2, A 3rd-person Rootin-tootin postal 3 where you can either follow a good path and become a law enforcer peeing the scum and maniacs and havoc causing Al-qaeda out of your area or just be a mamma's bad boy and kill anyone and everyone you see because you like spilling blood, Its fun and no one actually punishes when you slice and dice innocents in the game. I followed both playthroughs and the fact of having boss fight with Dhoti and lehenga wearing clown looking al-qaeda ring leader Osama Bin Laden and his funny arabic accent can make you fart out of unstoppable laughing. Every element of the game comes with humor. If you want to seek revenge and actually bring osama bin laden and Al-Qaeda to grounds, yeah the same laden that everyone knows (which is a main boss in the game), Postal III is your surefire destination. 

Now , excuse me, but I can't stop so here I go :-

Hahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahah!!!!

column9:
Postal 3 is the black sheep of the whole series. 

Every time I turned on Steam and tried to find the forgotten third part (it's no coincidence that the search engine doesn't offer you the game even after entering the exact name) I was left wondering about the rating of this game. 
I always told myself that it couldn't be that terrible, and if it was, at least I'd laugh about it. 

After all, the original Postal games were no gems, they were mainly very subpar games (in terms of technical condition and design), but what they managed to capture the player was their controversies and relatively fun gameplay. That's why I expected similarly simple entertainment from this part as well. From the beginning, it seemed that it would come true, when the initial cutscenes did not seem to be thrown away at all, I was able to overlook the bad control in the first two missions, but then the sobering came as soon as the whole map opens up to you and you have to catch HIV-cats in the first mission. 

The whole city is boring, flat, the controls are as if the Postal Dude got drunk and decided to pilot (not drive) a tank connected to a bus, the weapons don't work as they should, the inventory is unsystematic and even chaotic, and the annoyingness of the enemies, horror and horror. On the critical side, I more or less described the previous two Postals, but what this game was able to screw up the most is the humor, which over time begins to sound incredibly cringe, as if the script was written by Tro≈°ka himself, the fact that the Source Engine (my precious) is programmed with fool-proof codes, where, like cooking rice, it is impossible for anyone to screw it up, but also the optimization, which even on my system (i7-3770 3.4 GHz, 12 GB RAM, GTX 1050TI) on the lowest settings and when playing in a window, is still well below the level of bearable framerate. 

Just to summarize. If you want to play Postal 3, consider an alternative way to get the product rather than the direct route, or wait for the fan mod Catharsis reborn, which promises to fix the entire game along with the story, or in short, play Postal 2 along with the Paradise Lost dater, which denies the entire existence of the third part. In the state in which the game is (when the game forces you to turn it off four times in a row, because it is not able to recalculate, or remember, a single setting change) it is a damnable act, in which I am really glad that Running With Scissors itself has distanced itself from the product. 

2/10 - And for what? Probably out of grace. It doesn't deserve two points even for a successful launch.

The first thing you notice is the third-person controls, but you get used to it. Then comes the disappointment that the game isn't open-world. There's a free-roam mode, but it only has four maps. It's also unclear why, when you lose about 50% of your health, the Dude mentions magic health pills when there are simply no health-restoring items in the game. That's about it.
The game has some pretty good humor, especially in the Dude's cutscene monologues, and the game could have been quite good if not for...
BUGS.

Yes, this game has a ton of bugs, and some are pretty serious. Get stuck on the floor? Okay! Break your inventory? Yeah, right! Spin Champa around the enemy instead of attacking them? You're welcome! Crash the game at any time? No problem! At least it doesn't crash often.
The achievements are just puzzles like "Cicada 3301." Nobody really knows how they work.
Who are the terrorists, according to the achievement? Al-Qaeda? No way! The terrorist turned out to be a rhinoceros, encountered once per game. Now go and kill it 200 fucking times.

Oh yeah, you won't need melee weapons here. They've been reduced to the level of a silicone baton. Even the divine machete, which cuts an entire crowd to pieces in the second game, is just garbage.

Overall, the game is a complete failure, since no one is going to fix the bugs. And it's not worth the money. Or any money at all.
And it could have been quite good.

The game is good, the optimization is good, but there's one thing: the game's author is a complete idiot! So, the author didn't bother fixing the game, didn't test it, and instead let Akella test it. The author just made a mess of things and this game came out, and you're seriously hating on it? So, when Half-Life Source broke, you didn't care, but when Half-Life 3 broke, you care. I don't understand why you're attacking P3? Even if the game is buggy, with freezes, with crashes, it doesn't make it bad. It has a good engine and maps, but the hardest mission in the game is with the feminists. It was the hardest mission, so I was too lazy and switched to a different map through the console and that's it. So, what can I say? The game could be buggy because of a shitty PC or something like that, so I advise installing the game on a clean Windows rig and the problem will go away (maybe). And the worst thing is that there are no patches to fix the game! What a disgusting act on RWS's part, handing over the game to others! Like, by RWS's logic, they're doing this: hmmm, we're too lazy to make the game and should hand it over to some crappy developers. I understand that maybe RWS lost its budget or something, but why the hell are you bullshitting P3? After all, if the game is buggy, it's the developers' fault, not the game's...

column8: This is the biggest sh-t what I've ever played. I like Postal 2, great story, open world but here I am  completely dissapointed

wow. if you're here, you either know this game sucks, or want to complete your postal collection. well, this game IS as bad as they say. it is ACTUALLY broken. the fact that this game never sees a steam sale and sits here for full price, or even sits here at ALL is a shame. don't play this game. the original developers of postal disowned it themselves. it came included with some box set, that's the only reason i tried it in the first place. a KARMA system in a postal game. what the fuck? good and bad endings?

i could tell there was a vision here. the art style is honestly top notch for postal. if you look at screenshots of the game, it LOOKS like it would be awesome! unfortunately, looks aren't everything, as it plays like the biggest piece of garbage ever. constant crashing and frame rate lagging. there are funny IDEAS that are executed horribly, and the writing is cheesy and low-brow, even for postal standards. it's honestly a shame that this game is called Postal III and not some terrible spinoff. this is simply a stain on the postal legacy. don't even play it for free like i did. it wasn't worth the 40 minutes i wasted. 40 MINUTES IS ALL IT TOOK FOR ME TO GIVE UP. don't give these motherfuckers your money, buy postal 2 instead. wait for postal 4 to be more playable.

This isn't Postal, it's not even a game...
It's a piece of crap designed to torture innocent people.
If I could post a picture, I'd include the one where the devil says to the guy, "You know, I have to admit, I've been a longtime fan of yours."
Well, let me elaborate. When I was younger, about 14, I played this game on a pirated copy and liked it. I even finished a bit. Now, 6 years later,
I decided to play it again, and... I couldn't even get through the tutorial.
1) Camera. It's so awkward and constantly shaking, it feels like I've signed up for astronaut training.
So why does Postal need a third-person camera??
2) Physics. Well, I don't remember exactly how it is with shooting, but I do remember that close combat is a real challenge. Well, that's because of the camera again.
3) Missions. Collecting apples, shit, soiled napkins, and so on, like some kind of escapade, isn't very appealing. And why even bother?
Basically, the game is garbage. The only positives are decent graphics and dismemberment, and that's it.

column9:
I'm going to rethink this game. The fact is, it's terrible, and whether I give it a thumbs-up or thumbs-down review won't change that. Let me start with the good points. First, I think Dude's voice acting is pretty good (though my favorite is the Chinese voice acting in POSTAL2). Just because I say this game is good doesn't mean other games are inferior. Secondly, even bad games have their own fun. With such an obviously awkward plot, forget playing it with your intelligence. Just watching for fun? I can't think of any other way. And then, my personal advice: if you're not like me, knowing this game is terrible and not a collector, then I suggest just playing the free version for fun (I'm being a bit of a jerk here). Honestly, if you have the money, why not buy POSTAL2 or POSTAL Redux? RWS has a new game coming out in May, so why buy this?

I bought it purely for fun, and it's about as bad as I expected.

Postal - translated from English as "to go nuts" - is a game about madness in a mental hospital and manic hallucinations, a distorted, vile essay on the sweet devastation of the flesh.

Postal 2 is a satire on American life (and any life, really), with a collection of phenomena exaggerated to the extreme, proving that animal behavior speaks within a person (the game itself is fine; it's basically you going Postal at this point).

Postal 3 - ... well... Postal 3 is a game about nothing.

Literally. The game looks good and attractive, but in reality, it only lasts a few levels. Apparently, the developers liked the "Saturday" and "Sunday" concept from Postal 2, where the world is a comically staged linear shooter, periodically offering certain tasks (like killing 20 zombies or slaughtering 10 elephants), so Postal 3 is completely made up of such levels. Unfortunately, you won't be able to explore the new city and its surroundings, only in Free Roam mode after completing the game (that is, when it's no longer worth fucking doing). I gave up). The missions themselves are incredibly boring. Vacuuming up shit-stained napkins, vacuuming up apples, vacuuming up balls, vacuuming up manure‚Äîeither they were too lazy to code anything else, or someone had a fetish. It sounds funny, but in reality, it's complete crap: the vacuum cleaner doesn't work properly, and shooting shit and cum out of it is not funny at all (we're getting fatally close to violence here).

And the violence in the game has been toned down significantly: while in the previous game you could pee on a homeless person until he vomits, then cut off his head and watch the bloody, vomit-filled stream of blood pour out of his neck, here you can't pee properly or dismember anyone, all thanks to the Source engine, which came from who knows where. Since they stuck a third-person view here (apparently to avoid using first-person models), Any non-firearm weapon is completely unusable because the aiming reticle simply doesn't correspond to reality. In any Source game, melee weapons (and similar ones) in third-person view are completely flawed and require some sort of fix, otherwise the creators of Postal 3 couldn't care less. I spent the entire game with a pistol, a submachine gun, and a machine gun, not with beehives, gasoline canisters, a cheerful vacuum cleaner filled with shit, a machete, a shovel, a sledgehammer, a fucking monkey, and so on.

And speaking of the game's Source base being wildly unpolished in third-person view, it's worth saying that it's not polished at all. Throughout the game, you'll encounter countless references to Half-Life 2: the plastic sounds of severed limbs, the familiar sounds of Garry's Mod. Ragdolls, bullet hole textures, flat brush textures, and a ton of other little things create the indelible feeling of playing a Source mod for Half-Life 2, downloaded in an archive from Yandex.Disk. This flaw could be overlooked if the game were generally playable, but it leads to astronomically increasing indignation and hate.

The music is good, but it plays completely out of place, and on a loop, which is FUCKING worse than the ongoing music in the pause menu.

Optimization is zero. Imagine spawning thousands of entities in Garry's Mod and trying to have fun‚Äîthat's what Postal 3 is, since Source was completely unpolished. The only thing is, in Garry's Mod, there are no optimization limits, simply because the player isn't limited in engine load (and, in fact, it depends on the engine itself), and Here, the game itself generates NPCs and suffers because of it.

Speaking of NPCs, the lag is incredible. I wouldn't say they were smart in Postal 2, but at least they could shoot normally, whereas here, it's a complete mess.

So, it turns out that Postal 3 is a Source engine unprepared for use in a semi-open-world game, a wholesale redesign of menus, sounds, textures, and models, with glitchy AI and clunky weapons, zero game design and sound design, a crap boss, and a complete lack of concept, which was the case from the very beginning. It's still playable, but it's just boring, incredibly boring.

While this game is considered the worst Postal game, it's not. It's a typical bloody shooter for a one-time playthrough. In short, it's the perfect stress reliever. It's certainly no match for the first and second Postal games, but it's certainly better than the schizoid Paradise Lost and the laggy Postal 4, which merely capitalizes on the original's accomplishments.

A 6.5/10 is well-deserved.

column9:
[h1] It was under ¬•300, so "I regret nothing"[/h1]
The apocalyptic controls, the task missions, and the forced crashes ruin every point of praise, but the 200 million POSTAL 2 fandom, along with the official RWS, have already trashed the game's flaws, so I'll go ahead and write my points.

-Graphics
Good. While the TPS perspective makes it hard to read corpses and small notices, you can smear blood, vomit, and milky liquid on NPCs, and the Postal (name) animations [b] look good and meet the standards of the time. Well, the hit detection is a bit weird, though.
The frequently used comic-style art style is quite appealing. This is carried over to 4.

-Music
The "Showbiz Crisis" song that plays during the tutorial is truly amazing. Many players are captivated by the melancholy yet exciting music, only to be shocked by the grenades, gas cans, and inability to jump Postale, which completely erase any sense of exhilaration.

„ÉªStory
It's just plain vulgar. This is the only game where you can squeeze out man juice from a tissue and spray it on random old men and pole dancers. Let's just accept its dated nature as a historical document.

So, while there are some positive aspects to this game, it's a piece of crap no matter how you look at it. It's so bad that it's barely even talked about outside of RWS's self-deprecating comments. The anger of users who waited so long and then ended up buying this [b] crap [/b] at full price is understandable, and there's no need to buy another crap game of the same caliber now, even without a paid beta that will see improvements.

Her ne i√ßil yapƒ±lmƒ±≈üsa sa√ßma olmu≈ü, bu tarz grafiklere sahip ve bol bol ara sahne aksiyonu i√ßeren bir postal oyunu oynamak isterdim. B√∂yle olmasƒ± √ºzd√º birazcƒ±k beni. :/

-Kontroller √ßƒ±ktƒ±ƒüƒ± yƒ±l i√ßin olduk√ßa hantal. Optimizasyon sƒ±kƒ±ntƒ±sƒ± mƒ± dersin, yoksa g√∂revlerin bir anda Bug a girmesi mi. Misal kopan kol, bacak, kafa gibi uzuvlarƒ±, hatƒ±rladƒ±ƒüƒ±m kadarƒ±yla postal iki de kar≈üƒ±mƒ±zdaki insanlara fƒ±rlattƒ±ƒüƒ±mƒ±zda kusmalarƒ±na sebep veriyordu lakin bu oyunda polisin √∂n√ºne fƒ±rlattƒ±ƒüƒ±m kafa sayesinde i≈ülerin √∂yle olmadƒ±ƒüƒ±nƒ± anladƒ±m. Normalde benim bildiƒüim o kafa polisi kustururdu ve bende oradan rahatlƒ±kla ka√ßar, mal gibi √∂lmezdim. 

-Grafikler g√ºzel, riske girmeyip Source motoru kullanmak iyi bir tercih olmu≈ü. Tabi birde optimize etselerdi oyunu daha da √∂v√ºp g√∂klere √ßƒ±karabilirdik lakin g√∂r√ºnen k√∂y kƒ±lavuz istemez. Kasmalar can sƒ±kƒ±cƒ± d√ºzeyde. GTA 5 de 1080p normal ayarlarda, 60 FPS nin altƒ±na normal d√º≈ümeyen bir sistemin, POSTAL 3 gibi 2011 √ßƒ±kƒ±≈ülƒ± bir oyunda aƒülamasƒ±, insana garip geliyor.

-Bazƒ± g√∂revlerin opsiyonel olarak taraf se√ßme imkanƒ± tanƒ±masƒ± beni olduk√ßa mutlu etti. Spoiler vermek gibi olmasƒ±n da 3 g√∂revdeki polis ve ekonomistler arasƒ±nda ki sava≈üta tarafƒ±mƒ± kendim se√ßmekten ve devamƒ±nda polis memuru olarak hizmetime devam etmekten dolayƒ± fazlasƒ±yla tatmin oldum, mekaniƒüi de olduk√ßa iyi ve g√ºzel buldum. 

-Segway ara√ßlarƒ±nƒ±n oyunda sadece s√ºs deƒüil de kullanƒ±labilir olmasƒ± ger√ßekten iyi olmu≈ü. Bir yerden bir yere amele gibi ko≈ümaktan bizi bir nebze de olsa kurtarƒ±yor.

-Yakƒ±n d√∂v√º≈ü berbat. adama √∂ld√ºresiye yumruk atƒ±yorum ama tepki yok. Sadece pala ile saldƒ±rdƒ±ƒüƒ±mda tatmin oldum. Onun dƒ±≈üƒ±nda √ß√∂p bir yakƒ±n d√∂v√º≈ü mekaniƒüi s√∂z konusu diyebilirim. Havayƒ± d√∂vme konusunda Skyrim ile yarƒ±≈üƒ±r.

column9:
I was a fan of Postal 2 because of the freedom it gave me to complete missions. When I bought Postal 3, I thought it would follow the same choice-based gameplay pattern, but I ended up seeing that it's completely the opposite. The game became a level-based game, where each level has an obvious objective that can only be solved in the same way. The only positive aspect of the game is that the character models are interesting.

This game really disappointed me.

I don't know why people hate this game. I started playing the second and Apocalypse years ago and have replayed them a hundred times. When I found out there was a third one out, I was overjoyed. I installed it and played it. Well, it wasn't without its flaws, but I enjoyed it.

I started playing with very low expectations. I'd already tried a pirated version, and to put it mildly, it wasn't the best experience. The game constantly lagged, and eventually, on the third level, it simply crashed, after which I lost all desire to play. But about a year later, I picked up Postal 3 on sale and decided to give it a second chance. And you know, the game took advantage of that chance. I don't know what patches are on the Steam version, but unlike most "torrent editions," this one is playable without any issues, and even enjoyable. Yes, enjoyable. Taking a sober look at Postal 3, after everything the gaming industry has been giving us lately (particularly the technical underperformance of Postal 3 at release, and sometimes even worse), and especially after the completely lackluster Postal 4, Postal 3 already seems like a decent game, with some funny moments, enjoyable gameplay (especially in terms of impact), a cool soundtrack, nice graphics, and even the variability that ultimately allows us to reach one of two endings. A big problem with Postal 3, in my opinion, is its incompleteness; various glitches pop up here and there, and the overall game lacks... cohesion. The game's plot gallops across Europe, and even this is uneven: at the beginning, the game greets you with a simple tutorial, then bam, bam, various loosely connected quests. Then come the routine, monotonous quests (if you're playing as the good guy, which is exactly how I played the game). And then, after a couple of hours, bam, there's the final boss battle. Yes, the game is very short; I finished it in four hours. Of course, I plan to replay it to get the bad ending, but that's for later.
Overall, this game can brighten up your evening if you're tired of modern, identical, completely sterile games. It's enjoyable, although the gameplay can be annoying in places, which is a given in a Russian game. Technically, everything is fine: the FPS never dropped to unplayable levels, saves didn't break, the controls worked perfectly (unlike the pirated version), and there were only two crashes in four hours, and my saves were still intact. Whether you decide to play it or not is entirely up to you, but I give it a well-deserved 5.5/10.

column8: Look honestly in this day and age with the current gaming industry, This is why I decided to write this review coming up to 11 years after Postal 3's initial release. (It's not really as bad as people make it out to be). Let's say you make some random "normal person" play this game without being a postal fan or playing the other entries in the series. I'm sure they would have an absolute blast with this game, assuming with what freedoms you can do, who you can kill/side with; the different and unique story lines, characters and mission objectives. Yes, it may not be the most polished or beautiful looking game, and maybe some of the controls don't make sense, (like having to take cover and then vaulting over something instead of being able to jump over objects and obstacles). And one of the reasons this game gets so much hate, is because it was largely looked through past postal fans "goggles" so to say. That meaning, there is no large town like in postal 2 or in postal 4. The levels in this game are pretty linear with some having you released in a section of the town and you can run around and do what you want there but it is nowhere near the scale of four or two. Which is where I can see past fans having a problem. And another problem with this game is that they decided to put in some good and bad story line you can follow. Which is pretty stupid... Why add morals to a postal game? ( even if it is mocking them, its still stupid because it can effect the story line. Anyways, all in all just remember that releasing an unfinished game in 2011 was a lot different then developers releasing unfinished games today. Hell today we have AAA developers releasing unfinished games that are way worse and I mean far worse than postal 3. Postal three looks like a masterpiece compared to some of the games being released especially in 2021 and the past few years. The one thing to remember about purchasing this game. Is yes it's not as good as the other postal games, i'm not trying to defend it or anything. I'm just here to say that it's playable, it's a crude humor game just 2 and 4, and it's not AS bad as people say it is. You can still have some fun with this, whether you're an intense postal fan or not. Honestly I just got this because it was on sale and I wanted to complete my collection and own every postal game period. However, I ended up liking it a little more than I thought I would. Maybe it's because I came in with rock bottom expectations, and that's why I ended up liking it more then I thought I would. Anyways who knows, the only thing that does suck about purchasing this game. Is that none of the profits go to Running With Scissors, it all goes to some ****** Russian developer that really screwed them over in the making of this game.

column8:
Friendly post-review edit: I am sat here in stunned silence unable to comprehend what I just experienced. This isn't a game - it's a torture device.

Holy **** I knew I was buying a bad game but I didn't realise I was buying one of, if not the worst game I've ever played in my life. Motion sickness just from running because the screen shakes way too much. Dumb tutorial. Crap humour. Third person but the game engine still obviously thinks it's an FPS so the crosshair doesn't line up with anything. I was looking forward to academically playing this but even that I wouldn't wish on my worst freaking enemy.

Seriously, RWS meant it when they disowned this game literally made by a company called Trashmasters. Thank goodness I got it for next to nothing. Do not buy, unless you have a stupid need to find out for yourself how truly awful it is, like I did.

column8:
Let‚Äôs not beat around the bush: Postal 3 sucks. 

The game had a morality system featuring two sides; good and evil. Good starts you off playing as a police officer, while evil starts off as you playing as a member of an extremist animal rights faction. Each faction has their own missions.

It sounds simple enough, but the problem is how the system is handled. You see, you can gain good points while evil by taking enemies down non-lethally or continue to get evil points by massacring civilians, but you can only gain evil points by taking down civilians and certain types of hostiles lethally while you‚Äôre on the good side. Your character acts like a total saint in the missions, but no matter what you do, you can only go down. Lovely.

This game is also pretty liberal about what it considers ‚Äúevil‚Äù actions. Some of the heinous crimes I‚Äôve committed were
[list]
[*]Going from good to pure evil for accidentally charging into two police officers while sprinting during a mission.
[*]Arresting a man for public urination simply because it wasn‚Äôt a mission objective, despite being a crime.
[*]Shooting protesters armed with melee weapons that are actively trying to kill Uwe Boll.
[*]Somehow losing points when fellow police officers were killed by enemies while trying to defend the US-Mexico border.
[/list]
You can use lethal force without being penalized, but only when enemies have firearms themselves. Of course, the game occasionally scatters civilians with dumb AI to make things more ‚Äúchallenging‚Äù. Essentially, playing through the ‚Äúgood‚Äù route forces you to be careful about your shots and avoid collateral damage.

The question is, why bother adding a ‚Äúgood route‚Äù when it forces you to play completely against how the series is usually played? Sure, that could be a fun challenge for an errand or two, but building an entire route around it is dumb. Did the people that make this even fully understand what the series was about?

Unlike Postal 2, the game is linear. While there is a large city that could be used to link missions from one to another, it‚Äôs only used in patrol missions on the good side, where you‚Äôre confined to one part of the city and have to stop criminals. Otherwise, you‚Äôre teleported from one area to another without being able to explore the city or cause mayhem between missions, which is one of the things that made Postal 2 so good. 

The strange thing is that beating the game once opens up a freeplay mode in the city, letting you do whatever you want in it and go into several buildings featured in missions (but without any meaningful law enforcement or things to find), so they clearly were able to do a Postal 2-style world at one point. What happened? No time or money? Developer incompetence?

The missions themselves range from ‚Äúgeneric third person shooting sequences‚Äù to ‚Äústop criminals in the city‚Äù. 

As odd as it sounds, the generic shooter sequences are the best part of the game; there‚Äôs no annoying objectives, no unfun bosses, and little ways for it to glitch out. It still finds a way to piss you off, though; some missions force you to kill everyone before proceeding, but doesn‚Äôt tell you how many enemies are left. Over missions have infinitely respawning enemies, but you have no idea about this until you notice they keep coming after killing them a few times.

The worst is the ‚Äúpatrol‚Äù missions that appear in the good path. In these, you‚Äôre given a section of the city to roam around in and stop crime. It sounds like it‚Äôs a return to how Postal 2 did things, but it completely drops the ball because there‚Äôs no indication of where to go. All you do is mindlessly run around until a cutscene appears, taze and arrest the character(s) shown in it, then continue on. You can shoot enemies if they have guns and fire back, which doesn‚Äôt do a lot to change things up. There‚Äôs no hint about how many crimes you need to stop until the mission ends, and you must stop certain crimes before others will appear, so the whole thing is essentially a linear romp, but you have no damn idea where to go. It‚Äôs as dreadful as it sounds.

Making things worse is how buggy the game is. From crashes to pisspoor AI, Postal 3 knows how to be a mess. Some fun examples include
[list]
[*]Allowing the game to restart from a game over instead of loading a save the moment the Postal Dude dies can cause the game to break in various ways. This includes as a vital NPC deciding to stay where he is instead of moving to his destination, the game becoming unstable, and, somehow, the controls completely messing up, making the Postal Dude uncontrollable. If any of these happen, you‚Äôll have to reload from an earlier save and hope that fixed it. If it doesn‚Äôt, you‚Äôll have to close out of the program (if it didn‚Äôt crash already) and hope the problem is fixed when you reload the save.
[*]Godawful AI pathing. This isn‚Äôt much of a problem with enemies (in fact, it can be a big help when it does happen), but your allies are brain-dead dumb. This is especially bad in the game‚Äôs token escort mission, as the AI has genuine trouble trying to follow the path laid out for it. I saw the NPC I had to protect ram into a wall, do random U-turns, spend several minutes driving into a fire hydrant, and somehow get stuck hitting the very edge of a ruined car, which forced me to free him by running into him just when he was on the very edge of the car‚Äôs collision box. 
[*]An NPC that you must kill to proceed somehow disappearing. After some testing, I discovered that if the NPC (or any, for that matter) entered ragdoll mode for any reason in the level, he would fall through the floor and never return as part of a performance saving measure. This forced me to kill him ASAP, causing me to take a ridiculous amount of damage in the process and making things much harder than it should be.
[*]Multiple crashes when trying to protect Uwe Boll from a wave of hostile NPCs. 
[*]Not really a bug, but since it‚Äôs related to shitty design and programming, it goes here. One area featuring a gigantic firefight between three factions and random civilians running around. The issue is that the level is absolutely flooded with NPCs, which the poor engine can‚Äôt handle. Seriously, it has like 20 to 30+ characters doing their own things at once. Even people with strong CPUs will probably have trouble with this section.
[/list]
The cherry on top of this shit Sundae is poor sound mixing. Music and sound levels are inconsistent, leading to situations such as music that‚Äôs ridiculously loud while NPC chatter can barely be heard, despite having the same volume for sounds and music in the game‚Äôs options. At one point, I had to mute music entirely because it was close to blowing my eardrums out when it didn‚Äôt in previous levels. I never turned it on afterwards.

It‚Äôs not just music that has mixing problems either. Most weapons have sounds that aren‚Äôt too loud, but the M16 is ridiculously loud. While this is fine when only one person is using it, multiple characters using it feels like an assault on your eardrums. This makes enemies wielding the M16 the most dangerous enemy in the game; not because of the damage they do (which is sort of piddling), but for the fact they‚Äôre effective at directly attacking your IRL hearing abilities. I‚Äôve never heard of a game where enemies are more effective hurting you IRL than in game, but Postal 3 manages to surprise and amaze.

As for good things, there are some fun weapons, such as the Machine Gun, and the graphics are pretty good for the time they were made in. The generic shooting segments are fun when there isn‚Äôt any BS in them. It‚Äôs not much, but it is something.

Overall, Postal 3 is a tremendous turd of a game and should be avoided. It fails at nearly everything it sets out to do. There are many reasons why the people that own the Postal IP, RWS, has disowned this game, despite their involvent in the game while it was being developed.
column9:
Let‚Äôs not beat around the bush: Postal 3 sucks. 

The game had a morality system featuring two sides; good and evil. Good starts you off playing as a police officer, while evil starts off as you playing as a member of an extremist animal rights faction. Each faction has their own missions.

It sounds simple enough, but the problem is how the system is handled. You see, you can gain good points while evil by taking enemies down non-lethally or continue to get evil points by massacring civilians, but you can only gain evil points by taking down civilians and certain types of hostiles lethally while you‚Äôre on the good side. Your character acts like a total saint in the missions, but no matter what you do, you can only go down. Lovely.

This game is also pretty liberal about what it considers ‚Äúevil‚Äù actions. Some of the heinous crimes I‚Äôve committed were
[list]
[*]Going from good to pure evil for accidentally charging into two police officers while sprinting during a mission.
[*]Arresting a man for public urination simply because it wasn‚Äôt a mission objective, despite being a crime.
[*]Shooting protesters armed with melee weapons that are actively trying to kill Uwe Boll.
[*]Somehow losing points when fellow police officers were killed by enemies while trying to defend the US-Mexico border.
[/list]
You can use lethal force without being penalized, but only when enemies have firearms themselves. Of course, the game occasionally scatters civilians with dumb AI to make things more ‚Äúchallenging‚Äù. Essentially, playing through the ‚Äúgood‚Äù route forces you to be careful about your shots and avoid collateral damage.

The question is, why bother adding a ‚Äúgood route‚Äù when it forces you to play completely against how the series is usually played? Sure, that could be a fun challenge for an errand or two, but building an entire route around it is dumb. Did the people that make this even fully understand what the series was about?

Unlike Postal 2, the game is linear. While there is a large city that could be used to link missions from one to another, it‚Äôs only used in patrol missions on the good side, where you‚Äôre confined to one part of the city and have to stop criminals. Otherwise, you‚Äôre teleported from one area to another without being able to explore the city or cause mayhem between missions, which is one of the things that made Postal 2 so good. 

The strange thing is that beating the game once opens up a freeplay mode in the city, letting you do whatever you want in it and go into several buildings featured in missions (but without any meaningful law enforcement or things to find), so they clearly were able to do a Postal 2-style world at one point. What happened? No time or money? Developer incompetence?

The missions themselves range from ‚Äúgeneric third person shooting sequences‚Äù to ‚Äústop criminals in the city‚Äù. 

As odd as it sounds, the generic shooter sequences are the best part of the game; there‚Äôs no annoying objectives, no unfun bosses, and little ways for it to glitch out. It still finds a way to piss you off, though; some missions force you to kill everyone before proceeding, but doesn‚Äôt tell you how many enemies are left. Over missions have infinitely respawning enemies, but you have no idea about this until you notice they keep coming after killing them a few times.

The worst is the ‚Äúpatrol‚Äù missions that appear in the good path. In these, you‚Äôre given a section of the city to roam around in and stop crime. It sounds like it‚Äôs a return to how Postal 2 did things, but it completely drops the ball because there‚Äôs no indication of where to go. All you do is mindlessly run around until a cutscene appears, taze and arrest the character(s) shown in it, then continue on. You can shoot enemies if they have guns and fire back, which doesn‚Äôt do a lot to change things up. There‚Äôs no hint about how many crimes you need to stop until the mission ends, and you must stop certain crimes before others will appear, so the whole thing is essentially a linear romp, but you have no damn idea where to go. It‚Äôs as dreadful as it sounds.

Making things worse is how buggy the game is. From crashes to pisspoor AI, Postal 3 knows how to be a mess. Some fun examples include
[list]
[*]Allowing the game to restart from a game over instead of loading a save the moment the Postal Dude dies can cause the game to break in various ways. This includes as a vital NPC deciding to stay where he is instead of moving to his destination, the game becoming unstable, and, somehow, the controls completely messing up, making the Postal Dude uncontrollable. If any of these happen, you‚Äôll have to reload from an earlier save and hope that fixed it. If it doesn‚Äôt, you‚Äôll have to close out of the program (if it didn‚Äôt crash already) and hope the problem is fixed when you reload the save.
[*]Godawful AI pathing. This isn‚Äôt much of a problem with enemies (in fact, it can be a big help when it does happen), but your allies are brain-dead dumb. This is especially bad in the game‚Äôs token escort mission, as the AI has genuine trouble trying to follow the path laid out for it. I saw the NPC I had to protect ram into a wall, do random U-turns, spend several minutes driving into a fire hydrant, and somehow get stuck hitting the very edge of a ruined car, which forced me to free him by running into him just when he was on the very edge of the car‚Äôs collision box. 
[*]An NPC that you must kill to proceed somehow disappearing. After some testing, I discovered that if the NPC (or any, for that matter) entered ragdoll mode for any reason in the level, he would fall through the floor and never return as part of a performance saving measure. This forced me to kill him ASAP, causing me to take a ridiculous amount of damage in the process and making things much harder than it should be.
[*]Multiple crashes when trying to protect Uwe Boll from a wave of hostile NPCs. 
[*]Not really a bug, but since it‚Äôs related to shitty design and programming, it goes here. One area featuring a gigantic firefight between three factions and random civilians running around. The issue is that the level is absolutely flooded with NPCs, which the poor engine can‚Äôt handle. Seriously, it has like 20 to 30+ characters doing their own things at once. Even people with strong CPUs will probably have trouble with this section.
[/list]
The cherry on top of this shit Sundae is poor sound mixing. Music and sound levels are inconsistent, leading to situations such as music that‚Äôs ridiculously loud while NPC chatter can barely be heard, despite having the same volume for sounds and music in the game‚Äôs options. At one point, I had to mute music entirely because it was close to blowing my eardrums out when it didn‚Äôt in previous levels. I never turned it on afterwards.

It‚Äôs not just music that has mixing problems either. Most weapons have sounds that aren‚Äôt too loud, but the M16 is ridiculously loud. While this is fine when only one person is using it, multiple characters using it feels like an assault on your eardrums. This makes enemies wielding the M16 the most dangerous enemy in the game; not because of the damage they do (which is sort of piddling), but for the fact they‚Äôre effective at directly attacking your IRL hearing abilities. I‚Äôve never heard of a game where enemies are more effective hurting you IRL than in game, but Postal 3 manages to surprise and amaze.

As for good things, there are some fun weapons, such as the Machine Gun, and the graphics are pretty good for the time they were made in. The generic shooting segments are fun when there isn‚Äôt any BS in them. It‚Äôs not much, but it is something.

Overall, Postal 3 is a tremendous turd of a game and should be avoided. It fails at nearly everything it sets out to do. There are many reasons why the people that own the Postal IP, RWS, has disowned this game, despite their involvent in the game while it was being developed.

column8:
this is just bad, its a sad parody of a once great and relevant series. I had been waiting so long for a new postal game that i failed to even notice that it wasn't even made by running with scissors. that would have been the first red flag. its linear but not in a good way. its basically copycat missions no matter what choices you make. worse still every mission is exactly the same. go here kill this number of whatever. go there collect this number of that. oh your morality system isn't working get bad ending. 
I would recommend you avoid this harder than my dad avoids regular check ups. its very clear these people didn't so much as skim the wiki on postal let alone play it before shoving this broken abortion of a game out the door. they had no respect for the source material or any understanding of american politics. the old games had nuance like the first being the anatomy of a mental breakdown in a violent psychopath. the second being a satire of america's rapidly degrading culture as well as a social experiment in how far one can go with creative solutions before resorting to violence and it's unique self aware humor had charm. postal 3 has... the source engine.... and even that wasn't implemented well. 
this game is nothing more than a tasteless dollar store knockoff of the franchise.

Si pensabas comprarlo porque:
_Te odias a ti mismo.
_Est√°s esperando el mod de Catharsis Reborn.
_Lo encuentras en descuento a 2 dolares o menos.
_No eres fan de hacer el Jack Sparrow.
_Est√°s al tanto de que el juego est√° roto.

Solo entonces, es m√°s o menos decente para lo que cuesta, de no ser el caso ni te molestes.

Aqu√≠ dejo los mods que us√© por si a alguien le interesa, los puedes encontrar en ModDB:
_Improvement Mod (Arregla gran parte del juego y lo hace menos tedioso).
_Gore Mod (A√±ade efectos y particulas a las kills).
_Overhaul of the sound of weapons (Hace que las armas no suenen horrible).
_Karma Fix (Arregla la habilidad rota de deshacer el mal karma con buenas acciones, si quieres quitarlo del todo solo instala el improvement mod que lo quita por defecto, de no ser el caso instala este a lo √∫ltimo).

column9:
If you were thinking of buying it because:
_You hate yourself.
_You're waiting for the Catharsis Reborn mod.
_You find it on sale for $2 or less.
_You're not a fan of playing Jack Sparrow.
_You're aware the game is broken.
_You're going to use mods.
_You understand RWS isn't going to get a cent.

Only then, is it more or less decent for the price. If not, don't bother.

Here are the mods I used in case anyone's interested; you can find them on ModDB:
_Improvement Mod (Fixes a lot of the game and makes it less tedious).
_Gore Mod (Adds effects and particles to kills).
_Overhaul of the sound of weapons (Makes weapons sound less horrible).
_Karma Fix (Fixes the broken ability to undo bad karma with good deeds. If you want to remove it completely, just install the improvement mod that removes it by default. If not, install this one last.)

If you'll excuse me, I'm going to jump off a tenth floor.

column8: I do not wish this upon anyone. I bought it as a joke and to spite my roommate but it's still a fucking terrible piece of shit.
column9: I do not wish this upon anyone. I bought it as a joke and to spite my roommate but it's still a fucking terrible piece of shit.

The game exceeded all my expectations. I was pleased that you can kill people with a badger, have different storylines just like in Detroit, kill people with monkeys, run people over with Segways, kill people with a machine gun, kill someone's penis, arrest people, be a normal citizen or a bastard who kills people, have a wide variety of weapons, and so on.
Yes, the game has its drawbacks ‚Äì poor Russian voice acting (it doesn't immerse you in the game's atmosphere like Postal 2 does) and bugs that you might encounter along the way. There are quite a few of them, but they're not serious.

column9:
The game has a lot of flaws... but it also has its pros! I'll be honest with you, I had a pretty good time with this game. It wasn't the worst, but it wasn't the best either. I don't feel like writing all these sentences and my feelings, so I'll just list the game's features (I bought it for 11.76 PLN):
+ The Dude's model, which I absolutely love
+ The Dude's voice, which I absolutely love
+ Blood and brutality
+ The arsenal
+ The filthy, disgusting, and pathetic humor
+ The soundtrack is pleasant to the ear
- Disgusting animations (e.g., in cutscenes)
- The effectiveness and accuracy of melee weapons (which are fucking nonexistent)
- Awkward controls that take a while to get used to
- Crappy optimization
- Damn-long loading times

In short, 6/10

column8:
[h1]POSTAL III[/h1]

[b]Postal III[/b] √® il terzo capitolo della saga umoristica [i]Postal[/i] sviluppato dalla Akella (–ê–∫–µ–ª–ª–∞) in collaborazione con Trashmasters nel [b]2011[/b], non pi√π ufficiale dopo il rilascio del quarto capitolo da parte della RWS.
-
Il gioco riscrive la parte finale di "A Week in Paradise", invece di scontrarsi contro il temibile Demone-Mucca, il [b]Postal Dude[/b], ora interpretato da Corey Cruise, si trova sul ponte che separa Paradise City dal resto dell'America, presidiato da forze militari che tentano di contenere l'epidemia zombie causata proprio dal protagonista. Fuggito dalla corruzione e dalla trasgressivit√† del suo passato, trover√† nuove possibilit√† nella tranquilla cittadina di "Catharsis", ma la sua natura malvagia e distruttiva √® sempre in agguato, pronta ad uscire fuori ad ogni occasione.
-
[h1]PRO:[/h1]
‚úÖ Divertente da giocare... quando parte.
‚úÖ Trama, anche se scarna, pi√π tridimensionale rispetto ai titoli precedenti.
‚úÖ Arsenale ricco e variegato.
‚úÖ Tenta di seguire l'onda di cambiamenti dei predecessori.

[h1]CONTRO:[/h1]
‚ùå Bug e Crash continui.
‚ùå Missioni ripetitive e banali.
‚ùå Sistema Karma imbarazzante e fallato.
‚ùå Nessun free-roaming in modalit√† storia.
‚ùå Humor di scarso livello.

[h1]FINALE:[/h1]
2011, lo sviluppo per il terzo capitolo di [b]Postal[/b] viene affidato alle due aziende Russe che riadattarono e censurarono i primi giochi originali della RWS per il mercato nazionale. In superficie possiamo dire che POSTAL III non √® niente di meno che quello che ci si aspetterebbe: sboccato, pieno di humor nero, battute scarne, violenza gratuita e riferimenti sessuali di ogni tipo. La modalit√† di gioco segue la corrente del predecessore, ovvero cambia totalmente rispetto al capitolo precedente: nel primo caso (Postal / Postal: Redux) avevamo uno sparatutto a visuale isometrica, nel secondo un FPS stile Half-Life e con questo un TPS ad ondate, un genere che per via della sua natura ARENA richiede un sacrificio da parte della componentistica free-roaming. Ma quindi, qual'√® il problema? Il problema di questo gioco √®... il gioco:
Cali di frame-rate impressionanti, bug come se piovessero, armi inutili o mal funzionanti, missioni banali e ripetitive, humor di scarso livello e scelte Karma imbarazzanti.
Non c'√® niente da fare, Postal pu√≤ essere sviluppato da pochissime persone, Akella e Trashmasters non sono fra queste. La RWS ha deciso di rilasciare da poco [b]Postal 4: No Regerts[/b], non un grande titolo, pieno di problemi e poca originalit√†, ma sicuramente... non √® [b]POSTAL III[/b].
column9:
[h1]POSTAL III[/h1]

[b]Postal III[/b] is the third installment in the humorous [i]Postal[/i] saga, developed by Akella (–ê–∫–µ–ª–ª–∞) in collaboration with Trashmasters in [b]2011[/b], no longer official after the release of the fourth installment by RWS.
-
The game rewrites the final part of "A Week in Paradise": instead of fighting the fearsome Cow Demon, the [b]Postal Dude[/b], now played by Corey Cruise, finds himself on the bridge separating Paradise City from the rest of America, guarded by military forces attempting to contain the zombie outbreak caused by the protagonist himself. Having escaped the corruption and transgression of his past, he will find new opportunities in the quiet town of "Catharsis", but his evil and destructive nature is always lurking, ready to emerge at any opportunity.
-
[h1]PROS:[/h1]
‚úÖ Fun to play... when it gets going.
‚úÖ Plot, though sparse, more three-dimensional than previous titles.
‚úÖ Rich and varied arsenal.
‚úÖ Attempts to follow the wave of changes from its predecessors.

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
‚ùå Constant bugs and crashes.
‚ùå Repetitive and banal missions.
‚ùå Embarrassing and flawed Karma system.
‚ùå No free-roaming in story mode.
‚ùå Poor humor.

[h1]FINAL:[/h1]
2011, development for the third installment of [b]Postal[/b] was entrusted to the two Russian companies that adapted and censored the first original RWS games for the domestic market. On the surface, we can say that POSTAL III is nothing less than what you'd expect: foul-mouthed, full of dark humor, lame jokes, gratuitous violence, and sexual references of all kinds. The gameplay follows the same trend as its predecessor, meaning it's completely different from the previous installment: in the first installment (Postal / Postal: Redux), we had an isometric shooter; in the second, a Half-Life-style FPS; and with this, a wave-based TPS, a genre that, due to its arena nature, requires a sacrifice in free-roaming components. So, what's the problem? The problem with this game is... the game:
Disturbing frame rate drops, profuse bugs, useless or malfunctioning weapons, banal and repetitive missions, low-quality humor, and awkward Karma choices.
There's nothing you can do about it; Postal could be developed by very few people; Akella and Trashmasters are not among them. RWS has recently decided to release [b]Postal 4: No Regerts[/b], not a great title, full of problems and little originality, but it's definitely... not [b]POSTAL III[/b].

column9: So, where to begin? Terrible optimization, the controls are passable, but they still leave much to be desired. The plot is terrible. After a while, I lost track of what was happening. I simply stopped paying attention to the plot halfway through and pressed on. The advantage is that you can complete the game in two ways, although the "kindness" system completely ruined the game. Postal 2 portrayed the guy as a psychopathic, insane, and sociopathic individual, while Postal 3 made it possible to turn the guy into a law-abiding citizen. It completely ruins the series' atmosphere. I'm glad that Postal 2: Paradise Lost cleans up this mess. I definitely recommend buying a key at a discounted price, because the game isn't worth the 400 z≈Çoty.
