[h1][b][u]Characters[/u]‚Äî[/b]Boring[/h1]
‚ÄîPostal guy is boring; all the characters are dull, forgettable, and not interesting. To this day I cannot remember any memorable characters except Ron Jeremy, Osama Bin Laden, Uwe Boll, and that's it.

[h1][b][u]Atmosphere[/u][/b]‚ÄîLackluster[/h1]
‚ÄîEnvironments differ for each encounter, but some areas recycle the same map over and over again but with different scripted events. It doesn't feel lively at all; just dull.

[h1][b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]‚ÄîBelow Average[/h1]
‚ÄîThe core of any game is being able to play it, and in this category it's awful: the performance and graphics are really bad, aggravating, frustrating, and time consuming. Constant hitches with sound files, random crashing for no reason, the navigation of AI characters (jeez), and has one of the worst aiming mechanics for a rocket launcher that I have ever experienced in a game.
‚ÄîThe developers added multiple endings, pathways, and even a moral compass because THAT'S what we need in a Postal game; the more evil you do, the more evil you become. But that's not all, there's one level where if you let any terrorists across the border your meter starts filling up the evil path, so good luck there.
‚ÄîThere are also too many guns and they are not as fun to use as they should be despite the customization for all of them.
‚ÄîArresting people in the middle of combat is awkward.
‚ÄîSometimes when you want to join a side it's very difficult at first to tell who to shoot if you want to be a good or bad; an indicator would have been nice.
‚ÄîAllies can get stuck in doors or hallways that prevent your character from advancing in the game which is bad. There are some vehicles that you can ride, but you need them to protect VIP's in escort missions.
‚ÄîTrying to pour gasoline on someone and then set them on fire leads to teeth-grinding frustration

[h1][b][u]Enemies/Allies[/u]‚Äî[/b]Mediocre[/h1]
‚ÄîAllies tend to rush into battle and not use cover
‚ÄîEnemies say the same dialog over and over again and they overlap their voices. May want to turn the sound down.
‚ÄîEnemies that are mandatory to kill move all around the place, and the monkey experiments and ones that throw beehives at you? Trying to shoot them is like playing spin the bottle on top of a rotating rotary fan inside of a spinning circus top.

[h1][b][u]Story[/u]‚Äî[/b]Snooze fest[/h1]
What story? Postal dude solves stuff with his own logic, helps some people, and either becomes bad or good. That's it. He just had to press that button...

[h1][b][u]Bosses[/u]‚Äî[/b]Monotonous[/h1]
‚ÄîThree boss battles in one? Thankfully it's the easiest, but good lord they are bullet sponges worse than The Division.
‚ÄîCharging bosses? Forget this. Wander around and let them chase you until they happen to fall over randomly while they pretend to hit a wall. Works 1/4 of the time.
‚ÄîThe TANK BOSS? Don't get me started. Worst boss ever. Side-stepping around the corner to fire felt like doing the cha-cha slide to "What Is Love?" on thin ice. Have fun shooting the ROCKET LAUNCHER!

[h1][b][u]Graphics[/u][/b]‚ÄîUnderused[/h1]
‚ÄîThe Source engine is utilized to the lowest common denominator; the lip movements are worse than Half-Life 2, and why make the screen so small in the main menu? To show off Postal Dude's ego?

[h1][b][u]Music[/u][/b]‚ÄîReplace it[/h1]
‚ÄîBoring, repetitive, yawn, dull. Might as well put the music from Postal 2 on as a replacement. eve the music cannot save this game.

[h1][b][i][u]Conclusion[/u][/i][/b][/h1]
This may be the worst Postal game ever created by an outsourced developer on the Source engine. Suspending your disbelief is paramount within the first 30 minutes or so; the absurdity of events that happen one after another during the tutorial sections are rather less fun than enjoyable. Running With Scissors should have nothing to do with this, and same goes for anyone who is looking to buy this game. Stay away from it. go buy Postal and/or Postal 4 to support RWS.
column9:
Where do I start?

[h1][b][u]Characters[/u]‚Äî[/b]Boring[/h1]
‚ÄîPostal guy is boring; all the characters are dull, forgettable, and not interesting. To this day I cannot remember any memorable characters except Ron Jeremy, Osama Bin Laden, Uwe Boll, and that's it.

[h1][b][u]Atmosphere[/u][/b]‚ÄîLackluster[/h1]
‚ÄîEnvironments differ for each encounter, but some areas recycle the same map over and over again but with different scripted events. It doesn't feel lively at all; just dull.

[h1][b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]‚ÄîBelow Average[/h1]
‚ÄîThe core of any game is being able to play it, and in this category it's awful: the performance and graphics are really bad, aggravating, frustrating, and time consuming. Constant hitches with sound files, random crashing for no reason, the navigation of AI characters (jeez), and has one of the worst aiming mechanics for a rocket launcher that I have ever experienced in a game.
‚ÄîThe developers added multiple endings, pathways, and even a moral compass because THAT'S what we need in a Postal game; the more evil you do, the more evil you become. But that's not all, there's one level where if you let any terrorists across the border your meter starts filling up the evil path, so good luck there.
‚ÄîThere are also too many guns and they are not as fun to use as they should be despite the customization for all of them.
‚ÄîArresting people in the middle of combat is awkward.
‚ÄîSometimes when you want to join a side it's very difficult at first to tell who to shoot if you want to be a good or bad; an indicator would have been nice.
‚ÄîAllies can get stuck in doors or hallways that prevent your character from advancing in the game which is bad. There are some vehicles that you can ride, but you need them to protect VIP's in escort missions.
‚ÄîTrying to pour gasoline on someone and then set them on fire leads to teeth-grinding frustration

[h1][b][u]Enemies/Allies[/u]‚Äî[/b]Mediocre[/h1]
‚ÄîAllies tend to rush into battle and not use cover
‚ÄîEnemies say the same dialog over and over again and they overlap their voices. May want to turn the sound down.
‚ÄîEnemies that are mandatory to kill move all around the place, and the monkey experiments and ones that throw beehives at you? Trying to shoot them is like playing spin the bottle on top of a rotating rotary fan inside of a spinning circus top.

[h1][b][u]Story[/u]‚Äî[/b]Snooze fest[/h1]
What story? Postal dude solves stuff with his own logic, helps some people, and either becomes bad or good. That's it. He just had to press that button...

[h1][b][u]Bosses[/u]‚Äî[/b]Monotonous[/h1]
‚ÄîThree boss battles in one? Thankfully it's the easiest, but good lord they are bullet sponges worse than The Division.
‚ÄîCharging bosses? Forget this. Wander around and let them chase you until they happen to fall over randomly while they pretend to hit a wall. Works 1/4 of the time.
‚ÄîThe TANK BOSS? Don't get me started. Worst boss ever. Side-stepping around the corner to fire felt like doing the cha-cha slide to "What Is Love?" on thin ice. Have fun shooting the ROCKET LAUNCHER!

[h1][b][u]Graphics[/u][/b]‚ÄîUnderused[/h1]
‚ÄîThe Source engine is utilized to the lowest common denominator; the lip movements are worse than Half-Life 2, and why make the screen so small in the main menu? To show off Postal Dude's ego?

[h1][b][u]Music[/u][/b]‚ÄîReplace it[/h1]
‚ÄîBoring, repetitive, yawn, dull. Might as well put the music from Postal 2 on as a replacement. eve the music cannot save this game.

[h1][b][i][u]Conclusion[/u][/i][/b][/h1]
This may be the worst Postal game ever created by an outsourced developer on the Source engine. Suspending your disbelief is paramount within the first 30 minutes or so; the absurdity of events that happen one after another during the tutorial sections are rather less fun than enjoyable. Running With Scissors should have nothing to do with this, and same goes for anyone who is looking to buy this game. Stay away from it. go buy Postal and/or Postal 4 to support RWS.

[h1][b]"[i]Akela missed![/i]"[/b][/h1]
This game is the swan song of the publisher Akella and everything they did in the gaming industry in the mid- and late 2000s. The systematic pumping of bad games onto the population by publishing and developing a variety of trash ended in its demise. This approach from the 90s didn't work in the internet era, when people stopped trusting corrupt game journalists and turned their attention to online reviews from ordinary users.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sometimes you can see nostalgic comments from players about various old publishers that went bankrupt for one reason or another. The old TNQ, Sierra, Midway Games, and many others are remembered by players for their good games. The defunct Akella was only remembered in the context of the mini-scandal surrounding the development of the new Corsairs game. It's hard to believe now that in the 2000s, players consciously bought games from Russian developers. It's hard to believe that Russia had a gaming industry that produced both complete trash and games superior to foreign ones. Now it's easy to see news stories like "Russian game developer [insert developer name] will soon release their game [insert game name]." These events are already making headlines, claiming that we can make games too, and users react with phrases like "we need to buy and support a domestic developer." 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The major Russian companies that are still active are primarily developing a variety of online games. Riding a tank, shooting terrorists as [i]SPETSNAZ[/i], and buying free items. What else does a modern Russian gamer need? Of course, Akella isn't alone in this. The Russian gaming industry was a huge market for many publishers. Postal 3 and the publisher's story itself are a clear example of how the Russian gaming industry has come to what it is today.

‚ñ≤Con menos Bugs que Cyberpunk 2077 y mas entretenido que Twelve Minutes.‚ñ≤

‚ñºACTUALIZACION DE RESE√ëA:

‚ñ∫Introduccion:El juego es entretenido. Cumple completamente con su funci√≥n. Lo que no cumple es con la calidad pero el juego es pasable. De todo lo que he jugado, he sufrido 3 crashes y luego funciono de maravilla.
‚ñ∫Historia: No es para darle mucha importancia, ya que podes pasar de estado Pasivo a Agresivo y viceversa.
‚ñ∫Jugabilidad: Al principio es torpe pero luego te terminas acostumbrando. Nada grave.
Como anteriormente lo habia mencionado, el motor que utiliza de Valve es una cagada, ya que al acumular muchos ragdolls esto causa un drop de frames pero no es tan grave.
‚ñ∫General: No hay una gran cantidad de armas como lo habia en la entrega anterior. La musica no ambienta. Yo recomiendo bajarla y poner tu propia musica de fondo en un volumen intermedio. 

CONCLUSION: ¬øPorque pudo haber fallado? Lo que fallo es que RWS no fue el desarrollador principal. No eligieron un buen motor. Los desarrolladores principales no usaron correctamente los audios (no estan balanceados). La historia no era tan atrapante, basicamente cumplias ordenes y nada mas. No habia una gran cantidad de armas. En resumen, lo que intentaron hacer es dejarle a otros desarrolladores que se renueven como lo hicieron con POSTAL 1 a 2. Cambiaron la jugabilidad, la historia, el motor grafico, todo. Y eso es lo que a la gente le molesto, que no hayan conservado lo que fue POSTAL 2.

Antigua Rese√±a:

POSTAL III, el juego que recibio tanto HATE. ¬øPorque fracas√≥? ¬øSer√° por intentar renovarse? ¬øPor utilizar el pesimo motor de Valve (Al tener una gran cantidad de NPC el juego tiene altos FPS drops) ? ¬øPorque no entienden la historia del juego? ¬øO porque sus objetivos no son precisos? No lo s√©. Yo compre el POSTAL 4: No Regerts sin siquiera haber jugado a este. Yo sabia que le iba a darle la oportunidad a RWS y que iba a comprarme a este juego para demostrar mi apoyo. Me gustar√≠a que las rese√±as pasen a variadas. Hayan o no reembolsado el juego. Me voy a pasar este juego y les aseguro que pronto les traere una actualizacion de esta rese√±a.

column9:
I first played Postal 3 at a computer club some year ago... Back then, I basically didn't understand what was going on; I was a kid.
I bought Postal 3 a while back, played it for a bit, and then abandoned it.
Now I'm playing, watching the credits, listening to the voice acting, squeezing every last drop out of the game, and I realize it's the best Postal game ever. For the record, I've played every possible way, but this game can only drag on for two days of nonstop gaming (48 hours).

I watched Postal 4 and I realize that the fourth part is completely different from the third. It's not interesting at all. It's a shame that everything has changed so dramatically.

column8:
This game isn't even comparable to the Postal games that Running With Scissors have made. The missions are quiet boring. So many cut scenes to load next mission instead of letting us free roam around to learn the map. there's not many building you can actually access, no collectables or any reason to explore when you actually can. 

Two achievements are completely bugged and not even possible to get and that's messing with my OCD. Melee weapons are completely trash and the m16 is really the only decent gun that can hit a target. Game crashes occasionally , so you best save your progress every so often. Should you buy this game? my answer only if you are a die hard fan of the postal franchise and its on sale. But keep in mind Postal 4 is in early access and they can probably do with your money instead to help finish the game.

I regret nothing...

column8:
After finishing both Postal Redux and Postal 2, I was excited to jump into the third title, however I was very aware of the reception it received. Jumping into the game, I was prepared for a broken, unplayable mess. 3hrs later the credits rolled and I had a blast!

Throughout my whole gameplay experience, I never came across anything that made me think that the game was "bad", especially not to the extent people were describing it. The gameplay was fun, the controls were responsive, visually it has aged quite well and I genuinely thought it was quite funny. 

I enjoyed the linear style mission structure as well, blending both gameplay styles from Postal 1 and 2 into one. Because of this, the game never let up, with constant progression and action sequences that you would usually have to search for in Postal 2.

Honestly, If you are a fan of the type of comedy you see in the Postal series and you aren't too strict on games being "perfect", i think you'll have a really good time. Granted I went down the Evil route, so I can't advise you if the Good path is any fun, because I enjoyed just mowing everyone down.

Overall, I think I actually enjoyed this more than both of Postal 2's expansions if that says anything; Definitely give this one a go if you can get it cheap!

column8: What the hell is this Running with Scissors???? I actually enjoyed playing Postal 2, even if it wasn't really finished. I thought people were joking when they said don't bother - and they were right. This game is so badly put together, there's no enjoyment what so ever. it's just one infuriating blunder after another. I can't think of anything positive to say about this game, which is a shame - Postal 2, while not the best looking game was funny, in it's own way. That hasn't been captured here. Holding the players hand every 5 seconds with a cut scene video doesn't work, and never ending sporning of bad guys is just so 90's

column8:
While I realize its odd to do so, I am going to have to recommend you complete this game. Because of the great story? No. Because of the bug-free smooth running gameplay? Nope. Because you are a true fan of anything Postal and want to say you've completed them all? There ya go...
Its nigh the only reason to put yourself through this trainwreck. Just make sure you pay next to nothing for it. You'll almost feel its worth that.

Pros: 
Wanton destruction and blatent murder of innocent and guilty bystanders.
Weapons that work most of the time.
Colors.
Things to look at. ie. Walls, Ron Jeremy, Apple Trees, among other things you didn't know you needed.
The ability to SaveGame at nearly any moment in Time.

Cons:
They still want money for this.
Crashes at complete random.
Inability to attack anything without the entire World coming down on you like a tracking missile.
Some of the flakiest Controller support that is actually in a game, but should never be used.
The AI of Friendlies seems to be constantly set to suicidal.
Thats ok, if THEY jump in front of you, they will then get PO'ed, turn around and start smacking you around.
The AI on both sides, seem to have sniper like accuracy at any range. But neither of them can kill each other, only You.

Piledriver 8350 4.0Ghz 8-core
32gb DDR3
WD 3D NAND SSD
and an AMD R9 290 4gb, combine powers to run it well enough to barely function.
(Fortunately the 2016 DOOM, Black Ops 4, and Prey reboot all run exquisitely)

Would give them a 1$ to play it through once and uninstall it again.

column9:
The Postman 2 is a classic, and The Postman 3 is the worst. Here are my thoughts.
First, the game went from being an FPS to a TPS, which is incredibly jarring.
Second, the melee combat feels terrible. My fists feel like spraying white mist into someone's face (not to mention they never kill them). Machetes and shovels are okay, but batons and maces feel like hitting steel. Some melee weapons don't even have hit registration, like hammers and axes. If your only weapons are a hammer and a fire axe, congratulations! You'll never kill anyone (I used those two to send a windmill through a passerby without killing anyone).
Also, The Postman 3's maps look huge, but the level of freedom is awful. In The Postman 2, you could enter any house, but in The Postman 3, you can only enter a few (and that's for plot reasons). There's absolutely no freedom.
The camera shake when Dude starts running made me dizzy after half a minute. (Kane & Lynch 2 is awesome!)
Can anyone tell me how to use the monkey? The laser pointer is almost sticking in my eyes, but it won't move. DUDE's kicking style is like a strutting old man, and it's practically useless in this game. Even grenades can't be kicked back, while in 2, even rockets can be kicked back.

The shooting feels more fake than BBs, and even machine gun fire can't suppress it (the 5.56 M249 somehow manages to sound like the M2 Lao Gan Ma). The M16's gunfire is louder than anti-aircraft guns.

Another one: antisocial. I know the Postman is known for his antisocial nature, but what's the point of having me fight UN troops right off the bat? (The soldier guarding the bridge in the tutorial has the UN logo on his shirt.)

And 2 was released in 2003, and 3 was released in 2011 (damn, you came out eight years later and still make such a mess).

Also, development team, would you be killed if you made a health-replenishing item? Every time I'm in a firefight, I have to hide in cover to automatically regenerate my health (and it regenerates so damn slowly). Even DUDE has voiceovers asking for health-replenishing items, so would you be killed if you made a medkit? In short, Postal 3 is a pile of vodka vomit mixed in with the game's turds.
If you're buying this game for your collection, fine.
But if you're just playing it, absolutely don't buy it.
Postal 3: 13GB
Postal 2: 7GB
What's with the extra 6GB?
Added in February 2024:
Wow, it's actually getting an update, and a substantial one at that.

column8: One of the worst games i have ever played DONT BUY IT
column9: One of the worst games i have ever played DONT BUY IT

100 crashes out of 10. This game isn't worth the money, nor is it worth the free version. Even the pirated version is more playable and more playable than the Steam version. The game is nonlinear: you can choose the good path, or the evil one. Well, screw it, the game will crash after the very first "bad" path, and it'll do so constantly, a strange pattern. Most likely, some missions are so broken that it starts crashing right away. I understand Postal is trash, but it's not even trash, it's crap. Two positives I can point out are the Dude's Russian voiceover and the soundtrack in some places.

column8:
The Postal series has never been the highest quality series, in either taste or presentation, but they were at least completed games that were fun. This game not only has none of what makes Postal the cult followed series what it is, it's tied with Hunt Down the Freeman as the worst, most ill-prepared for commercial release game to ever use Valve's Source Engine. Running With Scissors was barely involved with its development, and stopped sell hard copies on their site less than a year after its release because of issues they had with the publisher, Akella, who was trying to leverage the game's source code against the series' rights in a last ditch attempt to avoid bankruptcy.

If none of that is enough to turn you away, and you think that purchasing this game will at least help give RWS a few bucks in royalties, think again. They got screwed out of any and all royalties of this game thanks to Akella's BS contractual agreement and could only get kickbacks from direct sales on their site (which again they stopped doing long ago). Since they aren't credited as one of the developers of this game, they legally cannot make any patches or updates that get delivered through Steam, and since they aren't the publisher they cannot take this page down. If you spend any cash on this, you are giving money to whatever anonymous Russian investor that owns the hollowed out husk that was once Akella.

RWS' own Vince Desi has since called this game, "Akella's Non-Canon Postal Spinoff", and he and the rest of the studio have completely disowned this game. Again, Running With Scissors doesn't see a cent of this game's purchase, and would take down this page if they could; besides that, this game has none of the charm or fun of the other Postal games. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR ANY REASON.

EDIT 10/14/23: So since this review originally came out, Akella removed the game due to issues with the DRM Postal III originally shipped with not working on modern Windows. Not long after, Jordan Freeman Group got a license to sell the game DRM free on Zoom-Platform. In September 2023, the Zoom version received an update to fix up most of the major bugs and issues with the game, especially those that caused consistent crashing, alongside adding the illusive preorder DLC weapon, the fart gun.

I gave this update a quick spin with the first few missions, and while the experience is more playable and stable, it is still not great to play. The aiming is still borked as it still relies on aiming where the weapon is pointing and not the center reticle, combat is still unintuitive, weapons still feel unsatisfying to use, the audio mixing is still subpar; all in all it's a polished turd gameplay-wise. I haven't tried the fart gun, but I cannot imagine it salvaging the experience since the base experience of the game is still bad.

I give all the credit in the world to the folks at Jordan Freeman Group and Zoom-Platform for at least fixing the technical issues, giving all players access to the preorder bonus weapon, updating the Steam version and removing the three achievements that could not be gained legitimately. However, the underlying game is still garbage, and as afaik RWS still doesn't see a cent from any sales of this game through Steam or Zoom. The only solace is that the game's price has permanently dropped to $6 USD as of the time of this revised review, but you can still find cheap games on Steam for that price, MSRP or on sale, that would give you far better experiences than Postal III.

About the only reason you'd want to pick this game up at this point is because it's on sale for dirt cheap and you plan on playing the game modded. Otherwise, see the original conclusion to this review above: don't buy it.

This game not only has none of what makes Postal the cult followed series what it is, it's tied with Hunt Down the Freeman as the worst, most ill-prepared for commercial release game to ever use Valve's Source Engine. Running With Scissors was barely involved with its development, and stopped sell hard copies on their site less than a year after its release because of issues they had with the publisher, Akella, who was trying to leverage the game's source code against the series' rights in a last ditch attempt to avoid bankruptcy.

If none of that is enough to turn you away, and you think that purchasing this game will at least help give RWS a few bucks in royalties, think again. They got screwed out of any and all royalties of this game thanks to Akella's BS contractual agreement and could only get kickbacks from direct sales on their site (which again they stopped doing long ago). Since they aren't credited as one of the developers of this game, they legally cannot make any patches or updates that get delivered through Steam, and since they aren't the publisher they cannot take this page down. If you spend any cash on this, you are giving money to whatever anonymous Russian investor that owns the hollowed out husk that was once Akella.

RWS' own Vince Desi has since called this game, "Akella's Non-Canon Postal Spinoff", and he and the rest of the studio have completely disowned this game. Again, Running With Scissors doesn't see a cent of this game's purchase, and would take down this page if they could; besides that, this game has none of the charm or fun of the other Postal games. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR ANY REASON.

EDIT 10/14/23: So since this review originally came out, Akella removed the game due to issues with the DRM Postal III originally shipped with not working on modern Windows. Not long after, Jordan Freeman Group got a license to sell the game DRM free on Zoom-Platform. In September 2023, the Zoom version received an update to fix up most of the major bugs and issues with the game, especially those that caused consistent crashing, alongside adding the illusive preorder DLC weapon, the fart gun.

I gave this update a quick spin with the first few missions, and while the experience is more playable and stable, it is still not great to play. The aiming is still borked as it still relies on aiming where the weapon is pointing and not the center reticle, combat is still unintuitive, weapons still feel unsatisfying to use, the audio mixing is still subpar; all in all it's a polished turd gameplay-wise. I haven't tried the fart gun, but I cannot imagine it salvaging the experience since the base experience of the game is still bad.

I give all the credit in the world to the folks at Jordan Freeman Group and Zoom-Platform for at least fixing the technical issues, giving all players access to the preorder bonus weapon, updating the Steam version and removing the three achievements that could not be gained legitimately. However, the underlying game is still garbage, and as afaik RWS still doesn't see a cent from any sales of this game through Steam or Zoom. The only solace is that the game's price has permanently dropped to $6 USD as of the time of this revised review, but you can still find cheap games on Steam for that price, MSRP or on sale, that would give you far better experiences than Postal III.

About the only reason you'd want to pick this game up at this point is because it's on sale for dirt cheap and you plan on playing the game modded. Otherwise, see the original conclusion to this review above: don't buy it.

column8:
I'm going to write a completely objective review here from my experience playing Postal 3. At present only 14.7% of people who own this game have actually beaten it and I'm among them so you know I wont just be parroting the near universal hate for P3.

This is called an incomplete game riddled with bugs but frankly I don't understand why. Let's be honest, this is the worst game in the Postal series but that doesn't mean it's garbage. I went through the entire thing and the only issues I had were some crashes on loading, 3 times when an arrested NPC's body blocked a doorway and of course the bugged and in some cases literally uncompletable achievements. I had no lag whatsoever and performance was fine. The achievements are pretty f'ing messed up though. One for killing 235 terrorists will only increase, 1 kill at a time, when a meth crazed rhino boss is defeated. I mean how the hell does that even happen?

The humor and absurdity in this game is the same as the others in the series and it's the same old Postal Dude making the same old types of comments while mowing people down. Everything feels the same, there's just less of it. The game is short, the missions aren't super in depth and there's just not as much going on as in Postal 2. It's also much more linear. Does that all mean this game sucks? Absolutely not. The music is also fantastic, especially the theme from the very first bridge level.

The only issue for me is that RWS doesn't get any money when you buy Postal 3. Because of that (and because it's admittedly not a top shelf title) you should either buy it during one of the many dirt cheap sales or try something I read people talking about on Reddit. Supposedly if you email one of the RWS devs and just ask for a Postal 3 game key they'll give you one for free. No clue if that's still true but it's worth a shot.

column9: Recommended only if you really liked the second game. It's clearly a bad game, despite having positive aspects. Mainly, the novelty of the third-person perspective, the graphics, and the artistic section, along with its cinematics, which I personally like, despite being tacky. On the negative side, we have the repetitive mission style, something that happens in many games but here it really burns. The controls themselves are horrible, and the game optimization even more so. It also doesn't have Spanish subtitles, so you either understand what they're saying or even get all the humor of the game. It's still understandable, but there were some things I missed (sorry, I don't own a C2, haha). In conclusion, for a general audience, this game is quite deficient, but for fans who overlook all the flaws and want to continue Postal Dude's story, even if it's in a less rewarding way than the second installment, it's recommended to buy it on sale. Score: 6

Yeah, I expected something worse from this game.
But it's still a piece of crap from Akella, which caused quite a stir back then.
Besides, the game is painfully short, but that's actually for the better.

column8: The most beautiful game I have ever played. The story was extremely well written, dramatic, and heartwrenching. The characters felt like they were real. The gameplay was smooth, with glitches being non-existent and every segment feeling unique and fun. The ending made me cry, being the most beautiful work of art I have ever seen. POSTAL III manages to beat Devil Survivor 2, Yakuza 0, Persona 5, Metal Gear Solid 3, Fallout: New Vegas, Super Paper Mario, Mystic Messenger, and, of course, POSTAL 2. I will cherish this game with my heart for the rest of my life.

column8:
The worst Postal game by far but a decent game in general.

I love the soundtrack.
The graphics, dialogue and general sound effects are decent.
The humor is okay.

The game offers some pretty interesting concepts when it comes to weapons and its still very very (very!) satisfying to decapitate people with the machete and rounding up headshots with the pistol.

However, the story feels a bit so-so all over and gets repetitive, its more like chores you need to do from time to time.
(the segway is just a really bad joke)

Will i play it again? Maybe.

What's important to note is that this game wasn't developed by RWS, but by Trashmasters in Russia.
It's such a bad game that even the official RWS team was pissed off.
It's plagued by horrible bugs and freezes all the time. The AI ‚Äã‚Äãalso behaves in strange ways. If you've beaten it, you'll want to brag about it.

It's so good that a DLC for POSTAL 2 was released after this one, and it makes full use of POSTAL 3.
By the way, POSTAL 4 has been announced, and it's being made by RWS, so you can rest assured.
In fact, you should buy that one. Really.

PS: For some reason, Japanese was added on January 30th, 2024, 13 years after its release.
But that doesn't change the fact that I can't recommend it as a game.

column8: Good concept, good artwork, good music, absolutely dogshit everything else
column9: Good concept, good artwork, good music, absolutely dogshit everything else

Moving on, we have a review of the third installment of Postal. This game's voice acting was done by Courage Bombay himself (anyone who's seen The Big Bang Theory in this translation will understand what I'm talking about, and it's quite funny). I'll say the same thing as in the second installment: the game is the same, let's call it informal, as it always was. The music is amazing, and there were some bugs, by the way. I remember the moment when I was supposed to set a zombie on fire at the beginning of the tutorial, but it wouldn't. That's basically it. I give this game a 10 out of 10, according to Senpai Bernix.

Before you call me a mentally retarded drug addict, throw Molotov cocktails at me while screaming "monster," and sharpen aspen stakes and machetes, first read what I wrote and don't judge me by just a thumbs-up.
I'm not denying that this is a bad game. In fact, in some respects, it's worse than just bad; it's fucking awful... just incredibly broken, broken in the most unimaginable places, with a ton of bugs and such.
BUT! Let's say... so, you! Put down the pitchfork and torch, and give me a couple more minutes!... So what was I talking about?
Oh yeah. Let's take a realistic look at the situation. 2003, Postal 2 comes out. It gathers a bunch of fans who are pissing themselves over the game (I'm retelling it from what I remember), and they attack the developer studio with the demand, "We need more!" And they're asking this of people who previously made a game that thrives solely on violence and gore (just like Hatred, only more graphic). I'm talking about the first one. And considering the studio isn't exactly a big name, they're handing over the rights to third parties. So now, just imagine and put two and two together.
A game that thrives on gore and gore, which is a sequel to a game that thrives on gore and gore, and which has a ton of technical problems. It's flawed in many ways. And now they're handing this series over to random people who have to slap together something on the cheap (they claim). Now let's take a deep breath and ask ourselves, "What the f*ck could have gone wrong?"
And it seems to have everything that came before. Gory, sleazy humor with a twist (though sometimes more specific), gore and gore. A ton of technical problems. Only this time, people didn't like it.

And I want to ask those people who demanded a sequel to Postal 2 and trashed Postal 3: "What did you expect from this game, you sick fuck? Did you really expect a AAA game with RPG elements, an open world, and blah-blah-blah from a lousy studio on a shoestring budget? Are you completely out of your mind?"
*BANG*
-Okay, okay. Don't aim that thing at me! No, seriously. Did you expect anything halfway good?

Alright. Let's skip the technical part. And focus on the reason I'm still willing to risk recommending this game.
Darkness and filth. It's all about ridiculing stereotypes, too. For example, Asians trying to eat any animal and speaking with a specific accent. (Muslims were mocked at the same level in Postal 2.) Ridicule of nerds and I'M-A-MOTHERs. I personally laughed out loud at some of the situations, because it's so reminiscent of our reality (a bunch of ugly women trying to eradicate porn and beat up beautiful women because their husbands can't get it up. Doesn't that ring a bell?)
Yes, some of the jokes are really for an acquired taste, or they're too over the top. But damn, there were a lot of over the top moments in Part 2, too.
Although it's still a shame there's no semi-open town like Part 2. After all, it's been replaced by corridor-like locations and very small patches of 2-4 streets per mission.
Yes, I'll say it again, the game has a ton of flaws. Lousy aiming. Poor level design. Some jokes might not land. Odd animations. But this game is one of those things: - so bad you have to fucking try it! Because you have to experience it for yourself.

So? Have I convinced you not to hit me in the head with that beautiful axe...

A lot of crap has been poured out on this game, and I can support this opinion. The game lags, has bugs, and can simply crash at a crucial moment and you will have to replay the level, there are glitches with the sound, useless melee weapons, and the shooting is strange and the voice acting is let down (THANKS FUCKING KURAZH BAMBAY FOR THAT). But even this game has at least some positives: The music in this game, to be honest, didn‚Äôt annoy me and, on the contrary, I liked it (I even recommend it), some jokes were funny and I liked them, the visual style (it‚Äôs good), the story (it tells the story of the same dude who lives in this fucked up world and tries to live a normal life). And seeing all this, I can say that you can play it, of course, wasting your nerves and time, but still, you can, and I don‚Äôt think this project is terrible, that it should be abandoned, despised, and spat on, like they do RWS. Is the game bad? In technical terms It's just bad and unplayable, which can cause a nervous breakdown and diarrhea, but is it terrible, as people and RWS themselves say? Of course not. The story, music, and characters can evoke positive emotions, and I'm very sad that no one needs it, just lying dead on the sidewalk with a sign that says, "Buy me and play."

column9: Champ didn't die for this

This game is so fucking crazy that it even crashed on a pretty powerful PC! But seriously, I liked the game. The only downside is the technical part: I crashed four times throughout the entire game. I won't even mention the FPS drops, but it's still playable. I finished it completely and, in my opinion, it's even more fucked up than Postal 2, but it's linear and because of that, the story is short (if you can even call it a story, because it's complete nonsense and trash).

I've completed this game, and it's not as bad as everyone said. First, I want to express my opinion on the entire series.
I tried to play the first Postal several times, but it was so boring that I turned it off after 10 minutes.
The second part, however, is an example of how a bad game in every sense of the word can be turned into an interesting and memorable project.
Everyone called the third part crap, and I thought so until I finished it. The game is designed in the same style as the previous part. It's just as crazy, and it also has a turning point where everything goes wrong.
There's also more variety: you can work for the police or be a psychopath; the game has three endings.
Many people didn't like the game because the developers promised so much but delivered so little.
I'd recommend this game to anyone who liked the previous parts.

Did you know... You won't be able to get all the achievements due to bugs. Some simply don't unlock, even story-related ones.

Overall, if you don't dwell on it, the game isn't as terrible as the reviews suggest. The graphics are decent, it runs smoothly on modern hardware, and while there are a lot of bugs (which are the main source of negativity), you get used to the game's dynamics, and over time, it even starts to seem fun. However, the game is significantly limited compared to the second game. To get some achievements, you have to spend hours saving and loading. I don't recommend this game to anyone with weak nerves.

The game is patched! They fixed almost all the bugs and fixed the characters' minds, the physics are excellent, and there's corpse dismemberment after death!!! Corpses don't disappear at all! My verdict IMHO.
Graphics - 8/10. The characters and environments are well-drawn, the source engine is barely noticeable, but otherwise, everything is OK.
Sound - 7/10. The soundtrack is good during missions, BUT! The only downside is the mediocre voice acting and repetitions of the same old Dude post - the same old lines (((
Controls - 8/10 good, I don't know about you clumsy monkeys, but the only downside is the weapon selection - there are too many!!
Gameplay - 8/10 The game has very fun missions))) Everyone makes you smile, you can even compare it to Saints Row 3. There are some very difficult moments in the game, for example, the 2nd mission where you have to collect cats)) The Chinese are everywhere)
Conclusion - This game is for fun and relaxation, don't expect anything serious, just collect apples, collect cats, kill homeless people. In short, if you haven't installed the patch, there's no point in playing this game. Install the patch and enjoy. Overall rating: 8/10
I played for a while... and then my opinion changed dramatically. It's a very monotonous game: go clear a building, go kill all the Taliban, etc. The plot is only held together by short cutscenes, the characters are all the same. The game only becomes fun when you play as a psychopath. But it still deserves a 7/10.

It even is replayable, thanks to good/bad meter.
I can see why RWS doesn't want anything to do with it however.
It's most reminiscent of P1 overall, only with toilet humor in place of P1's psychotic breakdown.

column9: Hot Garbage

I don't know why this game exists because it's a complete nightmare. Even Running with Scissors themselves completely abandoned this game. I thought it wasn't that bad, but I was sorely mistaken. On the other hand, fans of the second game are to blame for what happened with the sequel. Like the toilet humor, the complete nonsense, the terrible gameplay? Well, here you go, that's why you loved the second game, right? Well, I still think the first Postal was the best.

The gameplay has migrated from the second game, only now with a third-person view, everything has become even worse. The horror started with the choice of engine. Source is disgusting, the optimization is terrible, and the scripts are flawed. They took away the open world, added nonlinearity, which at the very end is flushed down the toilet and serves no purpose. The recoil of each weapon is like a one-year-old holding it, and even when aiming, it spins in all directions. The only good thing is the decent dismemberment, but that's where the positives end. The AI ‚Äã‚Äãis absolutely terrible, like it doesn't exist at all. I burned out on the police station level when, to finish the level, I had to run back for the mustachioed guy, who ended up stuck. By the way, the game was developed by the Russian studio TrashMasters; the name says it all. It's simply disgusting, pure crap.

The plot? A guy ends up in another city and runs out of gas. He needs to find money for it, because it's incredibly expensive. Spoiler alert: he won't get paid for the entire game. Basically, fans of the second game should be accustomed to all this nonsense.

The graphics are also shitty for its time.

The music seems okay at first, but then it turns out to be sooooo loopy. It would be easier without it.

The atmosphere? Well, I don't know, it's just some kind of fucked-up mess. And then there's the crappy voice acting by Kurazh-Bambey, which sounds like a pirated version of the game.

Running with Scissors apparently shelled out a ton of money to these developers and took them at their word that they'd make a gem, not a game. The biggest failure I can remember. A piece of stinking crap. I played through this game through pain, but I don't recommend you do so. It's ridiculous that the game hoped for replayability with its plot twists. No, I'll never replay such a "masterpiece"; I'd rather check it out on YouTube. My condolences to the publisher; this is an irreparable blow for them. However, Postal 4: No Regerts recently released in early access, which completely ignores the third game. Maybe it will fix the mistakes? Paradise Lost also treated the third game with disdain, treating everything as if the main character in that game was a figment of the real Dude's imagination. I wish you patience and success in Running with Scissors, and I hope the third part disappears from everywhere. So, we have: the first part is the best, the second part is okay, the third part is without comment, and the fourth part is still unknown.

Earth to you with unwashed dicks - 0/10

THIS ISNT A RECOMMENDATION PER SE: ONLY FOR VERY SPECIFIC PEOPLE!

The ONLY reasons you should buy this game if at least five or so of these things apply to you:
- you pathologically need to own every postal game
- you are aware of how broken and frustrating it is and still want to own it
- you plan to mod the game hard enough that it is playable
- you heard about the fan project "catharsis reborn" that sets out to actually make the game playable
- you really can let go of 12 dollars for a game worth a 5th of the price, at best
- you already own every other postal game out there
- you're fine with none of this money going to RWS (the developers of the other Postal games)

if this criterium isn't met: DONT BUY IT! IT IS BROKEN, UNFINISHED, FRUSTRATING AND REALLY SHOULD NOT HAVE TURNED OUT THE WAY IT DID!

column8:
Horrible game. I knew it was going to be awful, but somewhere I was hoping it would be laughably bad, rather than frustratingly shit. Having removed things like the open-world gameplay and even your ability to jump, I'm 100% convinced that the developers took everything that made previous Postal games good and then flushed it down the toilet. You basically just end up fighting incessant waves of generic, overly-present enemies. This would be bearable for a while were it not for the fact that the devs completely ruined the combat system as well, making it almost impossible to aim with most weapons, let alone enjoy using them. 

If you're looking for a sequel to Postal¬≤, go buy Postal 4 instead of this one. You won't be missing out on any important story elements. And even if your computer can't run Postal 4 (as is the case with mine), I can guarantee you will have more fun going through the menu of Postal 4 than you would playing through the entirety of Postal III.

column9:
I love Postal 2. I forced myself to finish Part 3 so I could finally form an opinion on the game.

At first, I was put off by:
- the tutorial music was torture, I immediately turned it down,
- pouring gasoline on the target - very uncomfortable and ineffective, throwing grenades was the same,
- shooting with the vacuum cleaner - to hit a headshot, you have to aim above the character. WTF!?

After that, I said, I've had enough, but I didn't give up.

Then it got worse - the mission with the cats, a cool idea with the killer cats, I liked it, but... the attacks by the Chinese were a joke! They kept respawning ENDLESSLY, hitting me endlessly. But I still managed (not that it was that difficult, I just got tired of it).

After getting used to the aforementioned. I had a lot of fun with the elements, but other drawbacks include:
- short episodes instead of even a pseudo-open world,
- completely nonexistent enemy AI, including pedestrians; they run out in front of the gun, and if you're playing the "good" path, it's really annoying,
- melee combat is idiotic. You can still fight with the machete and badger, but hitting anyone with the other weapons, let alone killing them, is impossible,
- optimization - sometimes FPS drops regardless of the graphics settings,
- short, it took me 9 hours to complete both paths + some fun,
- small number of firearms,
- monotonous combat, just mindless slashing,
- health regeneration,
- no fun with fire and setting fires - terribly inconvenient and impractical,
- taking cover - generally useless, because enemies run blindly at you, and then someone runs up to you and puts a magazine in your face, so it's more worthwhile. Run and shoot,

These are the ones that quickly came to mind.

But overall, I gave the game a thumbs up. Why?
Because I had fun with it. The pros:

- the graphics are quite passable, the carnage scene looks nice ‚Äì blood splatters, body parts, etc.,
- the shooting feel, it's fun to blow up enemies, shooting with firearms is quite satisfying,
- even some funny humor (the aforementioned killer cats, the rhino rodeo),
- new weapons, like the badger (a great idea), bees, and throwing a cat on your head.

In summary, the game is bad, that's true, but it's not a complete mess that's unplayable. It's completely different from the previous Postal, more of a spin-off, and treated as such, it can be enjoyable.

Holy fucking shit.
I tried to enjoy it, but it is a buggy hellscape. I couldn't care less that it tossed away the whole postal meaning with the karma system or the crazy-ass story (actually seemed somewhat fitting for the most part), and I actually liked Corey Cruise's work in this; maybe not as much as the OG Rick Hunter, but certainly better that Jon St. John [spoiler]fite me[/spoiler]. What makes this game beyond redeemable is because Trashmasters/Akella refuse to fix this game or even give the original developers, Running With Scissors, access to fix this. NINE YEARS it has stayed this way, and it looks like it'll never get into a proper state. That is the true nail in the coffin for this to never be recommended.

column8:
3/18/24

Postal III is a weird game. It's one of the worst in the series and had a extremely awful development.

Postal III was ment to be big. It was being developed for source way back in 2007 when Valve handed out the Engine and was sadly a disaster. RWS outsourced this, and that resulted from Akella, known as "Russian EA" taking a hit from the russian economy and had to fire their A Team and shove this over to their B-Team to finish the game, resulting in almost 100s of things cut and rushed out. RWS caught wind of this in the final months of development after hearing nothing for almost a year and was hesistant to cancel the project cause they knew it's going to be screwed up. And it released. And it was really bad, and taught themselves to never outsource again. RWS then denied all payment for sales and take this game as a meme in their series, even making it Non-canon in Paradise Lost. 
Funniest part is that Akella also wanted to make this game not rated by the ESRB, which would result in the game BEING SOLD ONLY IN RUSSIA. RWS had to quickly hand out steam keys to people who pre-ordered or bought the game and tried to avoid that.

Story :
Postal III follows after Apocolypse weekend directly after the bridge ending. Postal Dude is back, now in Catharsis, a sister-city to Paradise and has to get gas to get out of town. Sadly, Gas is rediculously expensive so Dude has to do some errands around town.
Although, that's forgotten in less then 10 minutes and it's just about dude's adventures in Catharsis and really awful jokes, trying too hard to make it funny and edgy. The plot is non-sense and is terrible, and I was literally cringing at the plot half the time, and mostly it's references to better games, like Dude making idle comments about playing GTA IV or something of the sort or really dated jokes.

The plot mainly follows Dude's morality and choices you make, which all make no sense most of the time. You got choices through the story that will change the outcome of the plot, such as in one part, you gotta protect the chief of police, you can gun through everything which will result in you not getting hired or just shoot the bad guys and get to have storyline where you work for the Police. Also, the concept is broken because if you do the good run, you get the bad outcome and won't be a cop, but bad outcome, you become a cop because of a bug. It's a interesting concept, but the morality system hurts gameplay cause it affects the main ending aswell, and will literally cuck you on the final level if you don't have high or low morality and it's not polished at all. 
But, the systems are confusing really. And you'll end up scratching your head cause you made a single mistake, and it ruined the concept of Postal 2. Postal 2, you were dude. You made your own choices cause you were in this world, you got choices but you were still able to finish or play the game, mostly just a "What would you do" sorta thing. 3 throws that away completely.
3/10.

Gameplay :
It's bad. 
Gunplay is weak, melee combat barley functions and game is a chore to play. The game's guns barley pack a punch.
Only powerful and working weapon is the M16. Other then that, all the other weapons are awful.
And the AI is terrible. No Police systems either, so cops just shoot you and forget about you later on. No money systems either, no shops, no inventory, and no map. The game is painfully linear and has nothing left of Postal 2's identity.

There is a sandbox mode which connects most of the city maps into load zones but it's kinda weak. Just run about and shoot people is what it is, or explore the city. Other then that, the gameplay is a slog.
2/10.

Visuals : I like the style of this game though.
They did a really good job on the art design and look of the game. It's a crap game but looks nice. 
Models look decent, and it has this mix of a comic and real life. 

Visually, the game does have some good lighting and nice looking levels. So, that's a good point.
6/10.

Verdict :
This game sucks. Go buy Postal 2 or 4. It's better. 

This game is a trainwreak. The story is bad, gameplay sucks, and the rest of the game is no better or mediocre. 

1/10

HOWEVER, a random community update dropped which removed the DRM they had which made it unplayable, and they did add Mod support and some other additions such as pre-order Fart Gun and lots of minor fixes! So, the game has full mod support and is more stable then in the past. They also changed the price from $9 to $5 and readded the game onto Steam with an Official Soundtrack for free. So, if your a source nut or into modding shit, feel free to try it. But if you want an fun game, avoid this at all cost.
column9:
3/18/24

Postal III is a weird game. It's one of the worst in the series and had a extremely awful development.

Postal III was ment to be big. It was being developed for source way back in 2007 when Valve handed out the Engine and was sadly a disaster. RWS outsourced this, and that resulted from Akella, known as "Russian EA" taking a hit from the russian economy and had to fire their A Team and shove this over to their B-Team to finish the game, resulting in almost 100s of things cut and rushed out. RWS caught wind of this in the final months of development after hearing nothing for almost a year and was hesistant to cancel the project cause they knew it's going to be screwed up. And it released. And it was really bad, and taught themselves to never outsource again. RWS then denied all payment for sales and take this game as a meme in their series, even making it Non-canon in Paradise Lost. 
Funniest part is that Akella also wanted to make this game not rated by the ESRB, which would result in the game BEING SOLD ONLY IN RUSSIA. RWS had to quickly hand out steam keys to people who pre-ordered or bought the game and tried to avoid that.

Postal III follows after Apocolypse weekend directly after the bridge ending. Postal Dude is back, now in Catharsis, a sister-city to Paradise and has to get gas to get out of town. Sadly, Gas is rediculously expensive so Dude has to do some errands around town.

It's a interesting concept, but the morality system hurts gameplay cause it affects the main ending aswell, and will literally cuck you on the final level if you don't have high or low morality and it's not polished at all. 
But, the systems are confusing really. And you'll end up scratching your head cause you made a single mistake, and it ruined the concept of Postal 2. Postal 2, you were dude. You made your own choices cause you were in this world, you got choices but you were still able to finish or play the game, mostly just a "What would you do" sorta thing. 3 throws that away completely.
3/10.

Gameplay :
It's bad. 
Gunplay is weak, melee combat barley functions and game is a chore to play. The game's guns barley pack a punch.
Only powerful and working weapon is the M16. Other then that, all the other weapons are awful.
And the AI is terrible. No Police systems either, so cops just shoot you and forget about you later on. No money systems either, no shops, no inventory, and no map. The game is painfully linear and has nothing left of Postal 2's identity.

There is a sandbox mode which connects most of the city maps into load zones but it's kinda weak. Just run about and shoot people is what it is, or explore the city. Other then that, the gameplay is a slog.
2/10.

Visuals : I like the style of this game though.
They did a really good job on the art design and look of the game. It's a crap game but looks nice. 
Models look decent, and it has this mix of a comic and real life. 

Visually, the game does have some good lighting and nice looking levels. So, that's a good point.
6/10.

Verdict :
This game sucks. Go buy Postal 2 or 4. It's better.

HOWEVER, a random community update dropped which removed the DRM they had which made it unplayable, and they did add Mod support and some other additions such as pre-order Fart Gun and lots of minor fixes! So, the game has full mod support and is more stable then in the past. They also changed the price from $9 to $5 and readded the game onto Steam with an Official Soundtrack for free. So, if your a source nut or into modding shit, feel free to try it. But if you want an fun game, avoid this at all cost.

Yeah, it'll do.
I like the visuals of Postal 3; it's clear they tried their best (during breaks, when the booze ran out). The music is good, the jokes... sometimes funny, at least they're not annoying. Technically, of course, this game is a complete failure in a ton of ways, but that's partially fixed by fan patches. Skyrim fans also patched and tweaked it here and there :D Many criticize the game for being too linear compared to the second game. It doesn't really matter, Apocalypse Weekend was also linear and didn't seem to be that bad (not the best example, of course; that expansion was a piece of crap). But still, the game is entertaining! It limps, stumbles, and falls, but it's entertaining.
I'd give it a 50/100.

column8:
It's not the worst game I've ever played.
Being a huge fan of the POSTAL games and hearing how "bad" POSTAL III was, I had to check it out.
Gameplay-wise, it's okay. It follows the same linear style as Apocalypse Weekend, which I didn't really mind all that much.
Technically, its a janky piece of shit due to its poor implementation of the Source Engine.
There are various bugs, one of the most irritating in particular being that the game has an 80% chance of crashing every time you use a fucking grenade, but other than that, they aren't THAT annoying.
The humor is juvenile as all hell but the design is overall appealing and I like Corey Cruise's voice work, but he's still not MY dude.
However, before going in, it is absolutely critical that you apply some tweaks and mod the game (particularly using any scripts that alter the morality system). This will make the game much more enjoyable, but you can forego them if you want.

Overall, it's not THAT bad. Sure, it's dogshit compared to POSTAL 2, but it's not that bad of a game.
If you're a fan of the POSTAL games and are either a completionist and/or bored as hell, then give it a shot.

column9:
I don't think there's anything wrong with Postal III.
Overall, it lives up to the standards of previous Postal games, but with a few flaws...
The game is buggy and poorly optimized; that is, they managed to make the Source Engine lag! No fluff!

Many players don't recommend it, but in my opinion, this game is capable of providing a gaming experience almost as crazy as Postal II... it's a shame it's not as free-roaming as the previous game...

Despite this, I still recommend the game, as long as you pay under ‚Ç¨5, like I did!

Points n√©gatifs : tout le reste....
Le jeux est creux sans substance; les missions laissent un go√ªt d'inachev√©es l√† ou sur postal 2 il y avait toujours des p√©rip√©ties, un aboutissement.

column9:
Good to buy on sale for less than ‚Ç¨5, but no more; passable.
The storyline reflects the Postal spirit.

Positive: the graphics, obviously.
Cons: everything else...
The game is hollow and lacking substance; the missions leave a feeling of incompleteness, whereas in Postal 2 there were always twists and turns, a conclusion.
The game mechanics are radically different from Postal 2, whether in the interaction with other characters or the management of the health bar.

Let's be clear: Postal 2 was released over 12 years ago, and aside from the graphics, Postal 2, with its Apocalypse Weekend and AWP expansions, is so much better than Postal 3. A waste...

column9: Garbage and a waste of money, I asked for a refund.

"Video games never taught them anything."

Time to write a review. "Well, now I'll go wild."

Playing Postal 3 is like fucking, but only half-baked.

The game is bad because "It's all MTV's fault."

It seems okay: there's a plot, there's humor, there's moderate trash (less than in Apocalypse Weekend, but a little more than in the original 2), plenty of weapons, Champ, they even brought in some graphics, but it's just not quite right.

"It's all SpongeBob's fault."

The game is boring, half the music is terrible, and it only starts playing when the action starts. And one song plays per level. On a loop. If for some reason it takes you an hour to complete a level, you'll be listening to the same song on repeat for an hour (I'm exaggerating about the hour, of course; the entire game takes four). "GTA has better physics!" The third-person view is terrible because it's inconvenient. Tons of bugs and crashes, terrible optimization. They promised an open world, but it doesn't exist. It's like the Apocalypse Weekend mission/location. The AI ‚Äã‚Äãis like real-life humans, and Akella is fucking stupid.

"How many cats can fit under that cloak!" But overall, the plot isn't bad, and although I mentioned it's boring, it can sometimes be engaging. Just look at the forty-year-old slave boy. There are also three paths to play: good, saint, and psychopath. Consequently, there are three endings. "This never happened even when I was smoking weed."

I think I should recommend the game, but there's a red button nearby. "What a cool button. Not a button, but a candy. What happens if I press it? No one's looking, maybe I should press it a tad lighter? Okay, I press it. No, I probably shouldn't. Okay, I pressed it."

"This is brutal. I'm almost ashamed. Is this my job?" "I hope this doesn't end up in my personal file."

And "you will burn in hell. Amen."
No Comments..

column8:
[i]Where do I start...[/i]

I grew up with [b]POSTAL[/b] and [b]POSTAL 2[/b] so a while ago I was naturally excited for Postal 3, but after it got pushed back I had a feeling something is going wrong.

And holy shit I was right.

Let's start with the engine itself, the source engine might be the worst possible choice for a game like Postal in my opinion, it was never meant to be used for a 3rd person game, and it shows. Textures are ugly, sounds are straight up missing, and half of the game just feels like an early access game that a single guy made, the game crashes VERY often for really no reason what so ever, guns feel awful along with the aiming (Again, source engine is not good for 3rd person games), and the animations are absolutely terrible, sprinting will likely give you motion sickness after you do it too much.

The """story""" is pure cringe. While POSTAL 2 had the more "subtle" approach to things, while still being funny and offensive, here it feels like a 10 years old kid came up with half of the scenes / dialogues and missions. It just doesn't work, they even pulled the "don't do this thing even though you are supposed to do it" after just 10 minutes.

And of course, the bugs. Oh good lord the bugs. I barely played half an hour of this game and I found the following bugs:
[list]
[*]Subtitles are invisible if you change resolution and don't restart your game
[*]Gun sounds are sometimes completely silent
[*]Switching weapons won't always "flip" the gun UI in order, making it look very confusing
[*]The catnip doesn't always work with cats, and even after they're seemingly stunned, the game won't let you pick them up
[*]No sounds what so ever for picking up guns
[*]No sounds when hitting someone with fists / melee
[*]Stunning enemies with a tazer (Which is what you're supposed to do) will make your friendly NPC NOT attack them, hence you'll be stuck, since in order to progress she needs to kill them, not you.
[*]Guns don't always fire if you press the left mouse button, sometimes they fire if you LET GO of the left mouse button.
[*]You can actually fall under the map if you ragdoll in certain places after getting hit by enemies.
[*]Music will randomly cut out and restart during a mission
[*]Physic objects can, and will get in your way sometimes, and they'll rarely go in the direction you're trying to push them in.
[*]Changing volume in the options menu during gameplay crashed my game once. It didn't do it again but I'll include it here.
[/list]

If you STILL want to get this game for.. some.. reason, just get the 20th anniversary collectors edition, it'll get you all the GOOD postal games, and this one, along with some cool merch, and you'll be supporting RWS directly, not these... people.

column8: gg bet
column9: gg bet

I bought the game back when it first launched, as a disc edition. I never saw the developers' promise of a Steam bundle, so I bought it here on sale.
What can I say? I played it back then, maybe even more than once. It has some elements, but... it's weak, frankly weak. The art and maps are clearly well-designed (Source is a pretty good engine and can produce beautiful art), but everything else is lacking. Balance, gameplay, story, jokes, optimization‚Äîthese are essentially the core of the game, and they're all pretty poorly executed. Furthermore, some features have been removed, which is also disappointing. For example, Postal 2 had some freeplay as part of the story, but here it's essentially a very linear game with repetitive and uninteresting missions. Freeplay was added as a separate mode, and even then, only after several patches, and it's quite uninteresting and pointless. While in Postal 2 you could grind money for fun, buy some pipes, feed donuts to dogs and meth heads, and then return to the story missions, there's no such thing here. On top of all that, they've for some reason implemented health regeneration like in Gear of War, removed jumping, and added cover. And then again, the game is pointless. Yes, it's trash, and yes, Postal 2 is even more so, but there was some sense to it, and each mission was good because it represented some everyday routine of the average person that turned into a complete disaster. Here, if it's not absurd, it's a clumsy reference to the previous game... In short, you have to play it, but it's better not to. Again, I repeat, the game has a decent core, but it's surrounded by "crappy Russian meat," which could have worked, but doesn't.

column8:
I played this game twice. One on the good path, one on evil.

Honestly, I gotta admit, when I started playing this game, I kind of [i]liked[/i] it... Then I played the final boss of the hero path. And then the game crashed. And every time I tried to access my quick save or manual save, the game crashed, forcing me to restart the entire battle. And it all went downhill from there.

When this game [i]Isn't[/i] bugging out, it's a mediocre game that doesn't really [i]do[/i] anything it's contemporaries haven't done, or done better.

Don't pirate this game, don't bug a Running With Scissors employee for a steam key, and [i]especially[/i] don't buy it. There are better things you can do with your time.

column9:
It's hard to say for sure about this game.
Pros:
1-RWS unfairly drowned the game in crap, as the game had enough content for two (almost) full games.
2-There's more trash.
3-A very convoluted plot with two paths‚Äîgood and bad (I just like that).
4-The game is made on the Source engine, so the graphics look solid.
Cons
1-Lack of any optimization, causing the game to run at 40-50 fps, or even 20.
2-Linearity
3-Third-person view (why they couldn't combine TP and FP is unclear)
Overall:
4.8 out of 10, and the game is partially saved by the fact that the voice of Courage-Bombay (Denis Kolesnikov)
is similar to the voice acting of almost every TV series from the 2000s, although it's unclear why they couldn't have invited Alexander Gruzdev.

column8:
This game is like accidentally ripping your nail so you try to pull it off and end up bleeding everywhere and on everything. 
So you're covered in botched toe-blood. 
You try to clean it up with soap & towels and then end up getting lemon-scented soap into the wound. 
Causing painful acidic burns that cause agonizing pain like battery acid for the rest of the day.

This game is actually nothing like that. I just wanted to give you a less painful experience to think about in case you actually buy Postal 3.

column9: Well, despite the bad reviews for performance and such, I liked it, but I highly recommend Postal 2.

A terrible game. Unfinished, glitchy, and repetitive. While the second game offered several playthrough options, here, while there's a semblance of choice, it's really all about gunplay, with the exception of the no-kill mode, which requires using a taser. The developers completely ignored this mode‚Äîwhen using the taser, the Dude says the same lines as when he kills, and they don't tie in with what's happening on screen. There are a huge number of bugs, glitches, and frequent crashes. The fact that it's in third-person rather than first-person isn't a problem. If they'd worked on it more carefully, it could have been a decent game.

column8:
When Postal 2 was released I was one of the initial wave of people who foolishly purchased and installed at launch, and I was treated to shit graphics, buggy "A.I.", massive loading times, and more. But It was at its base a great game with technical flaws and many of those flaws were fixed, leading to Postal 2 being a pretty good game. Yeah, the graphics were dated even when it was released and it still had a bunch of stuff wrong but the game was still great for what it was.

Postal 3 Is just terrible. Its technical superiority (only compared to Postal and Postal 2) means little because the game just sucks. Postal 1 was original, Postal 2 was original in its own way as well, but Postal 3 isn't original - its just trying too hard and not pulling it off. Maybe if Postal 2 never existed then a game like Postal 3 would work, but it does so all of the stuff in the game which is supposed to be edgy or whatever is just dumb and lacking and falling short. 

I have purchased all 3 of the Postal games and I recommend the 1st two to others, but I wouldn't recommend Postal 3 to anyone - even if they were to get it free.

Pros
The graphics have finally improved.
No more running back and forth across the map, a boon for those with poor navigation.

Cons
The third-person perspective isn't as convenient as the previous first-person perspective.
The crosshairs on cold weapon attacks are inaccurate.
The cheat mode has too few bullets.

column8:
Postal 3 is an exercise in freedom of expression, and if you want- an exercise in patience. I'm a big fan of both, so I found this game to be particularly enjoyable. The crude, tasteless and intentionally offensive storytelling is easily the highlight, and it all reeks of smug self-satisfaction. The game insults everyone, especially the player, and your reward for perseverance is to endure more merciless mocking and aimless social commentary. I wish more games had the balls to be so shameless.

The game carries on the themes of its predecessor, Postal 2, but it's a lot less artistic about it. Postal 2 was ‚Äúonly as violent as you are‚Äù, and the same can be said of Postal 3, but Postal 3 is less interested in gray morality or nuances. There are two black and white paths to choose: Good or Insane. Being insane is easier, more fun, and allows you to use the crazy variety of messed up weaponry to your enjoyment. Being good is... boring, and difficult. It's similar to Postal 2's thematic take on morality, though it lacks the depth. Being good is hard and boring, being bad is easy and fun. The message hasn't changed much.

I think the thing that sold me on Postal 3 in the end was its hidden third ending, which you receive only if you complete the entire game without killing someone. It's a monumental task and your only reward is a cutscene, but it's physically possible to play this entire game non-lethally. Again, being good is hard. Being a pacifist in a world of murderers is even harder.

The core gameplay is probably what disappointed people the most. It's comprised of largely linear objective-focused traditional videogame levels. You shoot men or collect things or guard someone, then you move onto the next level and do it again. I think the shooting feels fine, and I appreciate the wide variety in locations and the odd attempt at enemy variety. That being said, the sheer repetition of things could easily get to a lot of people.

There is one particular mission that was bugged beyond all reason, but aside from that, most of them seemed to function as intended. There were the occasional freezes, but that's what the quicksave is for, surely.

column9: The game's visuals were cool, but that's all. Otherwise, the game was horrible. It constantly crashes and you have to turn off your PC or the game will close by itself. The gameplay is very boring and difficult when you want to follow the "good" side, and the map is very limited compared to Postal 2. Melee weapons are terrible to hit the opponent, which is very annoying. In Postal 2, it was a lot of fun to play, but this Postal 3 I lose my patience. I can't even get halfway through the game because every time I have to start the level all over again. Sorry, but I will uninstall this game and get a refund. I DO NOT RECOMMEND IT.

column9: While I've seen many reviews criticizing this game, it does satirize many aspects of life, highlighting the needless gun bans in Europe and the United States. (A line from Dude in the second game hints at this: "I enjoy the legal right to use a gun, and yet you're so afraid?") Anyone could become the trigger-puller, and in the end, only humanity's most powerful weapon, the nuclear bomb, can quell all violence. Aren't the protagonist Dude's circumstances and actions similar to many of the current problems in Europe and the United States? I've heard that countries are constantly opposing this game, but don't they realize that what they should be opposing is their own greed? Isn't opposing guns and violence what they should truly be resisting?

column9: I'll be brief, the game is extremely poorly optimized, it crashes all the time, it freezes a lot on a current PC that is running Far Cry 5 and Resident Evil 2 very well, it is buggy and has bugs that force you to reset the save, you need to save constantly to not lose your progress because if you fail, it doesn't matter if it's your mistake, a bug or a crash, you return from the beginning of the mission, as there are no checkpoints, you must always save, it doesn't have subtitles not even in English, very poorly programmed, AI dumber than anything you can imagine among other things. But despite all this, the game was a lot of fun for me. It made me laugh, and the game itself knows it's bad and makes fun of itself. It's cool to try to choose the side of good, like in Postal 2. The difference is that this one is official and really differentiates the missions. There are a huge amount of bugs and the optimization is terrible. Seriously, the game crashes all the time. It seems like not even the PC wants to run this game. The missions are repetitive and give the impression of the game being much longer than it actually is. I myself thought I had played for more than 10 hours when it was only 6. After reading all this, you think, "Man, only a lunatic would buy this game." Indeed, but I personally like it and have a lot of fun playing it. Seriously, I even have fun using the taser to stop people on the path of good. So, yes, I recommend buying this game on sale. It may be terrible, but it's a lot of fun, at least for me.

column9:
8 software titles have arrived for the 2019 New Year's Special Offer. They're using the IP as a front for a ridiculous sale, but what they're really selling is bullshit. No, bullshit.
It crashed six times in less than an hour. The optimization is questionable. Even with the standard Lenovo Legion running at the highest settings, it was terribly laggy... This 2011 game is quite something.
The movements are stiff, the hits feel weird, and peeing is even weirder. After getting hit, the screen vibrates violently and turns red. I couldn't even see the road when I was being chased and shot at.
The game's navigation system is extremely uncomfortable: [b]I don't want to press the red button, why do you make me do it? I want to kill the invaders with my fists and guns, why do you only let me use a vacuum cleaner to dissuade them? [/b]
The world of Postal 2 was free. You could express yourself freely, or be utterly utterly uttered to death. But this game is different. Everything is confined to a narrow storyline. The banter is all vulgar and deliberate. There's no freedom at all. [strike]Only my Origin engine-powered breasts are still fluctuating and showing a bit of warmth[/strike].

PS: All Chinese patches cannot be applied, so I am going to play the "Three Aunts" version.

column9:
I don't know why this game is so badly criticized. A game about trash, and it's trash! Excellent. Maybe everyone forgot, but Postal 2 was also pretty glitchy, with long loading times, poor ballistics, and FPS drops. But this one isn't that difficult; the game is entertaining. There are lots of references for CIS players. The dark side playthrough even has an unexpected twist. Otherwise, I finished it in two evenings and thoroughly enjoyed it. The music is cool, and killing is satisfying.

The downside is the poor game design. There are a lot of weapons, but you only use them for health. The game doesn't give you any rewarding moments, and there's no ammo for all of them.

column9:
I bought this game and upon launching it, a Windows pop-up alerted me that a Trojan had been discovered on my PC. When I uninstalled the game the same day, within 5 minutes of launching it for the first time on January 23, 2019, I discovered that the game had changed the dates and indicated that I had launched it in 2017 (but purchased it in 2019) and also indicated a playtime of 1 hour.
So I'm warning players that this game has illegal and malicious intentions from the moment it launches, so imagine how long the game lasts.
