[h1] One of the most interesting games in history...[/h1]

POSTAL is perhaps one of the most interesting games in the history of computer gaming. To this day, the entire POSTAL series remains one of my favorite games. But it's no secret to any of the fans what's happening with this title. Postal 3 came out at the wrong time. The game itself isn't bad, it's still the same satire and irony about humanity and society. But what's the problem!? It's all very complicated... The developers and the publisher took everything and, to put it mildly, ruined it. Postal 3 didn't have anything they promised us, but instead, it was riddled with bugs and crashes. They really trashed the game. We would have tried to finish it together, as a team; what else could we do if we loved this game? They improved, expanded, changed everything for the better... And the fans are partly to blame too; if they hadn't been so spitting and had worked together, it would have been awesome. There are actually a lot of modding teams and the like who create great mods and post them on websites and in the Postal workshop. But each team has their own problems...
Some time passes, about four years, and it turns out that Postal 3 is suddenly no longer canon, but simply an unofficial spin-off. Then comes Paradise Lost, an expansion about the Dude's continued travels (it also has its flaws, like Postal 3, but is most notable for its incredibly interesting and trashy, yet untrue, drug-fueled plot). Postal Redux comes out, which is well-made in its own right, but its biggest drawback is the gameplay, which is completely unrelated to the first Postal (it doesn't match the gameplay in the first game, which was individual and challenging, which complemented the game). I won't go into details; there are many people (like me, POSTAL fans) who have put everything they could on the shelves.
I'm sorry about what happened to POSTAL. The game is going through a major downturn...

column8:
I almost forgot how bad this game was.

Postal 3 is the reason I don't pre-order (most) sequels anymore. I've had this game since it first released. It was garbage back then, and it's stillg garbage now. There has been 0 updates to the game, and for a game that's running in the source engine, one is confused why it's optimized so poorly (framerate drops, constant crashes, constant pauses, etc.)

The game still follows the postal dude, but it's now in a third-person aspect. The game feels like it wasn't even properly finished before release, tutorials and mission objectives are just a black screen with words to tell you what to do, there's plenty of typos in the words used to describe missions, and different items.

Do yourself a favor and avoid this game at ALL costs. The previous game, (Postal 2) is a fantastic game, and is well worth the money.

column8:
*EDIT*
*
Many people don't seem to understand RWS's update to the game. This game was made by a third party with licenses from RWS to make it. The third party abandoned the dumpster fire of a game shortly after and it was unplayable due to their DRM software. The game was infamous for being unplayable and broken when playable. Years later RWS removed the DRM and applied some quality of life fixes but didn't make it any better of a game. They only did this to make the game playable again, not improve it's gameplay.

So TL;DR: RWS and every Postal fan knows this game is garbage and a joke, so if you bought it expecting anything else then you're part of the joke now
*

This is simply a meme, don't consider this part of the Postal story/lore.

If anything the DLC to Postal II is better than this

column8: Now, I know what everyone means, and I get exactly why this game is so negatively graded, and perhaps I'm blinded by the vanity that i've been with the POSTAL series for years, but I honestly quite enjoyed this game. There are a lot of bugs, no doubt, such as mapping problems where you'll spawn in from a cutscene and the map doesn't exist anymore, or AI bugging out and getting stuck between props or other AI, and not to mention the often crashing; these are all problems, but you can easily look past them, in my opinion. Take into consideration all the problems this game has is the same problems that are often found in Valve games, speaking of which they both use the Source Engine, which isn't perfect by any means. It's kind of a shame that the levels are very simplistic and unclear to the storyline oftentimes, but it's worth the value of doing it most of the time, as it does lead up to something in the least. The factor of having two different game-styles based on your choice of Good or Bad is a nice touch, and alternate endings based on what you do throughout the game is a fun factor to work towards. Additionally, I will mention that the game is not really lengthy, unlike POSTAL or POSTAL 2, where you can make the game pretty much as long as you'd like. But on a positive side, after you've beaten the story once, you do unlock a free-roam mode, which is much like POSTAL 2, but in Catharsis, not Paradise. Bottomline, there are a lot of features in the game that are good, and it's a solid Third-Person Shooter in the least, but yes, there are gamebreaking and annoying bugs. In the sense that the game itself is disowned by Running With Scissors themselves, as it was mostly developed by Akella and Trashmasters, I understand why, But, despite it all, if you are a [b] Big Fanatic [/b] of the POSTAL series, like myself, do give it a try, but I do feel like the only ones that are able to stick with the game are the super-fans, and I totally understand why anyone would overlook this game and play POSTAL 2 instead, because it is a lot more fun, and cheaper. Conclusively, I recommend this game to primarily huge fans of the POSTAL series, but for those that aren't and are looking for a better game, I would recommend getting POSTAL 2 and overlooking Postal 3 here for now.

column8:
The (actual) bad side of the Postal franchise. Postal III is too glitchy, too prone to crashes, and too unfinished to recommend.

I do like the ultra violence, the humor, and the voice acting, though. The Postal Dude is voiced by Corey Cruise rather than Rick Hunter, and while some people aren't happy about that, I personally love Corey Cruise's work. He makes the Dude seem more relaxed and chill, and it's an interesting take on the character.

But that won't save the game. The game's got performance issues, often severely dropping in framerate, even if you have a powerful PC. This makes the already difficult aiming worse, where sometimes bullets seem to pass right through enemies; you have to be really accurate when you aim, but sometimes that doesn't help anyway.

If there's too much going on in the level, the game may crash. If you have a save file where there's a lot of stuff going on, it may become unusable and you'll have to revert to an older save. Even if it's not that far back, it can undo a short but difficult part (which wouldn't have been difficult if the game was done better).

Postal III uses a sticky cover system, where unless you're close enough to a cover object, you may find yourself getting shot by hordes of enemies because you can't crouch. Sometimes the cover is too sticky and you can't escape fast enough. Or you can't find a good position or angle to use it. I'm sure this system was implemented to capitalize on the whole "realistic", "tactical" cover shooter craze; thanks, Gears of War. Okay, I do like Gears of War, but that game did its cover system better.

Unless you're a die-hard Postal fan, skip Postal III. Or even if you are, you'd probably be better off skipping it anyway.

A Truthful Review of POSTAL III

You know, I'm amazed how, in the last seven years since POSTAL III's release, there have been so many idiots in the community who, without even playing it, are constantly blaming it for being the worst game in the series, while praising Parasite Lost and the first game's redux, which is barely above ground. Let's figure out what's so bad about Postal III.

Back when the game first came out, I surprisingly don't remember any dissatisfied fans of the series, and all the complaints were often about the technical aspects of the game, which are truly terrible because they simply needed at least a year and a half of polish. The game had a lot of problems, so many that most of the bugs were never fixed because few in the community had experience writing source code. So, for the entire time, no one was found to fix the shortcomings, except for a couple of patches from my comrade who, through trial and error, was able to enable non-working or partially disabled code that had been disabled a couple of months before the game's release due to it simply being unfinished, malfunctioning, or even outdated code from the 2008 alpha. However, there was still some useful code there, including disabled phrases, loading screens, etc. Also, the game lagged terribly after release because the engine was simply overloaded with all sorts of junk and threw errors every few minutes as a reminder that the trash master either doesn't know how or doesn't want to write coherent code, because in some places it feels like the code was written by captive Indian child programmers. And in my opinion, this is practically the only downside to this game. It's also a bit annoying that the developers couldn't get the music right, causing it to cut out occasionally. But overall, the music is very interesting and doesn't make you vomit after several hours of play. Some people also complain that melee weapons are unusable due to animation and low damage, but as for me, these people either haven't played P3 at all or don't have an opinion at all. As someone who spent half the game using a machete and a shovel, I can say that almost every weapon in P3 is usable and useful. The only useless weapon is the Motorhead monkey, which has no clear purpose and doesn't do anything useful, and often stalls due to the buggy AI. Of course, there's also the malfunctioning axe, which deals far too little damage, but I think this issue could be addressed with a patch by increasing the damage per hit. (By the way, try pressing the second mouse button while holding an axe; I assure you, you've never seen a death run like this.) My comrade's video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uNQlPLDOg2I

It's also unclear now why so many people are complaining about P3's plot, saying it's trashy and completely different from P2. But isn't each Postal game unique? Right? The only drawbacks to the plot, in my opinion, are the inadequate karma meter, which simply doesn't work properly, and some unnecessary or logically flawed missions, like the police academy level, which could have been much more varied. But these drawbacks are essentially due to the game's weak technical aspects. That's where the serious downsides end for me, because P3 continues to feature a ton of interesting missions and locations. For example, the patrol, in my opinion, is a very interesting concept, and it truly feels like Postal at its core, with its dark humor and satire, and a truly open world. So I don't understand those who say the game's plot and quests are lacking.

Also, many particularly smart people complain that P3 doesn't have an open world, but why would the game need one in the story anyway? P3 itself consists of large open locations that essentially replace the open world, making it completely unnecessary. And for those who wanted a sandbox in the style of Part 2, I encourage you to try the free roam mode. Although I must admit, the intelligence compared to Part 2 is significantly dumber and more cardboard-like due to the fact that most of the AI-related code was simply cut out... Perhaps the new and only mod for Catharsis Reborn will give us the completed AI code that can later be used in the regular P3.

And where are all those negatives that schoolchildren are foaming at the mouth? Is the fact that the game is different from P2 a bad thing? I don't think so, because that's what gives it uniqueness compared to the original game and Postal 2.

A game with poor technical features and broken code that is still better than Postal Paradise Lost.

7.5 / 10

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1332310949
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1137210474

I've been a longtime fan of the Postal series, but even I can't recommend this game. It's unoptimized, lags, and is simply a buggy creation from Trashmasters. I spent 40 minutes playing; I should have read the newspaper, it would have been more useful. The plot is like trying to kill as many dumb mobs as possible, accompanied by the protagonist's third-rate humor. The controls are clunky, the enemy AI is floor-level, and I definitely want my money back. Don't buy it, you fools.

column8:
Honestly, It's an ok game, but it's older brother Postal 2 is a more enjoyable video game. 5/10  

(Quick disclaimer, this review may contain bad spellings and/or bad grammer) 

Pros 

I love the story, it's amazing how Postal dude casually massacures a certain area / building and casually leaves, only concerned about his money. Although the whole game is based on an idea, the fact that he needs gas money for his car so he tries to earn money in order to purchase gas, that could've been thought up by a five year old all the missions are rather create and fun, and include a large amount of death, which us postal players love! The graphics are a big improvement from Postal 2. Another thing I love is the city design, the layouts and levels are way more better designed that postal 2, and all the objects, vechicals people and weapons look very nice. Also, and argueably the most inportant feature, the gore! The gore in Postal 3 is amazing, the whole mutilation and blood is very realistic, and makes the game a whole lot fun as during the carnige, watching all the guts and limbs as well as heads fly around, we just forget we're in a game, forget about all our worldy problems and the fact that we have to go to work soon as the weekend flys by, and just enjoy the moment! Oh and also their is an ingame console, which can easily be activated, that has some cheats to help bad players beat the game or ordinary players to mess around with. Their are a few cheats including godmode, noclip and give all weapons! There are quite a few cool weapons too, including a shotgun, machine gun and a few creative ones like a controllable mad af badger!

Cons. 

The melee is awful. The axe and other weapons barley even actually hit anything, and when they do zero gore any barley any damage happens the first few times, and, from what I've seen during my gameplay, only after your victims drop to the floor, after you beat them with a melee weapon, can you sever their limbs, what is this? Batman? We're just going to knock them out with an axe or a mathete and leave them? No, this is Postal, and in Postal we have to kill everything in sight, which is practically impossible using any meele weapon. The best way to kill npcs and get gore, just as sevred heads or limbs, is too shoot them. Also another bad thing, health! Even with godmode, it's still a challenge to masacure large areas. Wanna know why? Because the Npc's have so much health. It takes atleats four shotgun shells to kill a civilian! I shot an unarmed running civilain, at close range, about 7 times before they finally died. After I played a bunch of missions and decided to mess around I enabled godmode and just stood their, getting shot at, reloading constatnly as I struggle, yes struggle, to kill civilans with my guns. Guns! Seriously??? I hope that their is some unfound cheat to alter the health of ncps or damage from weapons, because it's so hard to go on a massacure witthout realoading due to the fact you just used half a magazine to kill a pathetic civilain..... that negative aspect really ruins the fun and is the most popular reason why I get bored and stop playing for a bit. Seriously, you'd think the civilains had godmode themselfs or somthing...... Also the game is a bit glitchy, with some animations not working and sometimes corpse not dropping to the ground after dying. Also, no steam workshop??? Why??? Now I know video game cheats aren't nessacery, but they're hella fun, but if you're going to add cheats please add more than a few. There's only a few cheats, but luckily their really fun. Although the current weapons are fun, there isn't really many weapons. I would have loved to see more or atleast a steam workshop page with more weapons availabe, but that's not going to happen....

Conclusion 

I think this game is worth a try, but if you plan of killing civilain npcs I wish you goodluck as it's a pain in the arse. There are cheats, which include godmode, noclip and allweapons plus a few more, but not many. The graphics are pretty decent and an inprovement from Postal 2. The story is ok, but how the levels play out is really creative, sometimes challenging and enjoyable. The npcs have a lot of health and the orginal power and easy kills on the weaker unarmed npcs that postal 2 brought apon the player are gone, and now it's actually quite hard to go on a rampage and kill everyone. It's a shame that their isn't a steam workshop page as Postal 2 had one. Their are some cool weapons, but not many. Overall this game is actually ok, but it definaly is disapointing to what I expected. I don't think ¬£9.99 is acceptable for this game, I'd pay about ¬£4 for it.....

column8:
Just don't. Every single game mechanic it employs is clumsy and clunky, the running creates a ridiculous screen-shake, the aiming is wonky and random, you can't jump over objects: you actually have to snap to cover and then vault over them, the melee is literally luck of the draw as to making contact and both forms of attacking have a seemingly random damage/location result. 

The visuals and the audio are both lazy and repetitive; the voice and sound samples used quickly become annoying. Five and a half years later the performance is still bad, you still can't alt-tab it without it hanging or crashing, and in-game bugs will either make you get stuck or just halt your progress arbitrarily. 

On top of all that, it's a Postal game in name only; it has no concept of "going postal". Every level simply contrives enemies to attack you and the only thing of any entertainment value whatsoever is that, ironically, in a Postal game, you're actually acting in self-defence all the time. 

If you want a Postal game just replay Postal 2, it's a classic game; if you want a third person shooter just pick another one at random, it's highly unlikely you'll end up with something worse than this.

column9: Cool game! Buy, will not regret!

The style is fine, but the gameplay is an acquired taste. It's not bad, but it's nowhere near the level of the second game. And yet, back in 2008, Igromania reported that 80% of the game was ready, along with first-person screenshots. I wish I could find that beta and play it. This version of the game was already being thrashed around October 2008. It was even mentioned somewhere. For this very reason, the game turned out to be a glitchy piece of crap at launch. In short, it was a shame they let our guys remake Postal 3. I have nothing against Akella itself, but I do have a problem with their TrashMasters division... That division only made low-quality games and games licensed for film. That fact alone reeks of a rural outhouse. At least they patched it.

Verdict: Playable, but not a masterpiece.

column8:
Bought it for a few bucks, thought I'd check for myself what all the hatered is for.

Is this a good game? No, not at all. It's unfinished, it crashed several times while playing through the story, melee doesn't really seem to work all that well, pee doesn't collide with the characters in the world like it did in postal II, the rpg blows up in your face unless you charge it, the game uses assets from half-life 2 because they couldn't be bothered to replace them and the missions are monotonous and repetitive.

The game is now in a forced third person pespective and they replaced jumping with some crappy cover system I never found any use for, atleast the movement animations are nice.

On the plus side gunfights are actually quite enjoyable in this game, good sound effects, nice visuals and very gory, fps drops a little sometimes because the source engine just can't handle lots of npc's in combat, the story did give me a good laugh every now and then and the new Dude voice does an okay job aswell.

Still can't recommend it though, it feels more like a postal themed half-life 2 mod than a worthy sequel.
column9:
Bought it for a few bucks, thought I'd check for myself what all the hatered is for.

Is this a good game? No, not at all. It's unfinished, it crashed several times while playing through the story, melee doesn't really seem to work all that well, pee doesn't collide with the characters in the world like it did in postal II, the rpg blows up in your face unless you charge it, the game uses assets from half-life 2 because they couldn't be bothered to replace them and the missions are monotonous and repetitive.

The game is now in a forced third person pespective and they replaced jumping with some crappy cover system I never found any use for, atleast the movement animations are nice.

On the plus side gunfights are actually quite enjoyable in this game, good sound effects, nice visuals and very gory, fps drops a little sometimes because the source engine just can't handle lots of npc's in combat, the story did give me a good laugh every now and then and the new Dude voice does an okay job aswell.

Still can't recommend it though, it feels more like a postal themed half-life 2 mod than a worthy sequel.

Developer: Trashmasters
Publisher: Akella
Localizer:
Running With Scissors
Akella
Steam
Localizer:
In Russia: Akella
Release Date:
December 21, 2011
Genre: Action

Postal III is a third-person shooter video game developed by TrashMasters Studios and published in Russia by Akella. It is the third game in the Postal series[1] for Microsoft Windows[4]. Postal III was originally planned for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 consoles, but was cancelled due to lack of funding.

column8:
Che disastro questo gioco...
Postal 3 tiene come il predecessore violenza gratuita e anche tante situazioni demenziali.
Il problema principale del gioco √® il fatto di essere rotto. Tiene tantissimi problemi, cos√¨ tanti da sembrarlo come quelli mal fatti dello "Steam Greenlight".


Non √® per cattiveria, la trama segue esattamente come finisce il dlc "Apocalypse Weekend" del postal dude, andr√† in nuove citt√† a fare lavori di tutti i generi, fine.
La narrativa non √® mai stato una priorit√† per la serie, era sempre povera quindi in questo caso ci st√†, il problema √® tutto il resto.

Il gameplay √® in terza persona, e gi√† qua potrebbe far storcere il naso a parecchi fan della saga, ma alla fine riusciamo ad abituarci.
Non dovremo pi√π fare semplici commissioni come facevano il capitolo precedente, ma per ogni livello avremo un lavoro diverso, alcuni normali e altri bizzarri.
Un grosso punto a sfavore del gioco √® il fatto che non sia pi√π free roaming. I livelli sono abbastanza piccoli, e le missioni che dovremmo fare tengono tanta ripetitivit√† come raccogliere oggetti con "l'aspirapolvere" o proteggere delle persone.
L'arsenale √® ben vasto e ci sono delle armi originali che mi hanno fatto divertire, come la motosega-tasso. Avremo a disposizione nuovamente il gatto che oltre a usarlo come silenziatore sul fucile d'assalto lo potremmo lanciare addosso ai nemici.... avr√† lo stesso effetto del DLC "Weekend Apocalypse". Ruoteranno su loro stessi alla taz-mania danneggiando parecchio il nemico.

Nel quarto livello bisogna decidere una fazione, se stare dalla parte buona o quella cattiva. Dalla decisione che prenderemo ci verranno proposte missioni completamente diverse.
Fin qua sembrerebbe un bel gioco anche, ma adesso arriviamo alle parti negative le elenco:

LA IA DEL GIOCO E INESISTENTE!
Ok anche quella di postal 2 non era il massimo, ma alla fine faceva il suo lavoro. Qua perch√© dico che √® inesistente?
Vedo persone che sparano AI MURI, TANTE PERSONE. Persone che ti dovrebbero sparare e se ne stanno fermi senza far nulla, e persone che non reagiscono (qua un 50%) neanche se gli pisci addosso...

MUSICA
La musica di questo gioco ha principalmente 3 lati negativi:
-la prima √® il tipo di musica non azzeccata bene, anche banale con pochi strumenti musicali, solo quella della missione "gay" l'ho trovata abbinata.
-la seconda √® il volume della musica, che √® nettamente pi√π alto ai rumori e voci del gioco. Molte volte non riuscivo a capire cosa diceva il Postal Dude
-la terza √® fatto in un loop orrendo, la musica finisce con tanto di effetto dissolvenza... e poi riprende come niente fosse (sar√† orribile da sentire, sopratutto nelle canzoni "cantate").

OTTIMIZZATO MALE
Ci sono molte sezioni nel gioco dove andr√† a scatti pure sotto i 30 frame quando.

MISSIONI RIPETITIVE FINO ALL'ESTREMO
Come avevo accennato pure prima, le missioni sono veramente troppo simili fra di loro. Anche Postal 2 lo era per carit√†, ma riusciva a coglierti di sorpresa dagli eventi che ti capitavano quando facevi delle commissioni normali.
Senza parlare della fazione "buona", tiene lo stesso problema della ripetitivit√† ma √®  "Fuori luogo" visto che sarai letalmente un poliziotto.
Cavolo il postal dude un poliziotto... per carit√† ha i suoi momenti comici per√≤ non √® cos√¨ divertente come la fazione opposta.
La longevit√† invece √® sulla norma... sulle 4 ore e mezza/5, fidatevi che son pi√π che sufficienti.

PRO
-Humor seppur non divertente come il predecessore, riuscir√† a strapparvi qualche sorriso
-Arsenale di armi ben ricco e contiene altre armi originali
-Due fazioni di gioco da scegliere ti d√† la possibilit√† di rigiocare il gioco

CONTRO
-Esplorazione nei livelli singoli quasi nulla
-Missioni troppo ripetitive
-Difficolt√† facile (non sar√† possibile selezionare il livello di difficolt√†)
-La musica non √® niente di ch√®, ogni tanto non c'entra con gli eventi che stanno succedendo, e in pi√π tiene un volume troppo alto non facendo sentire i dialoghi
-Ottimizzatto molto male con cali di frame rate abbastanza gravi
-Ci sono tantissimi suoni che mancano tipo quando ricarichi le armi o quando prendi a pugni qualcuno
-I pugni sembrano che non facciano danno
-Modelli dei personaggi che non funzionano a dovere (spesso si muovevano senza l'animazione dei passi).
-Grafica datata
-La fazione buona l'ho trovata "fuori luogo" (per via delle missioni poliziesche, parere personale).

Voto: 4.5/10
column9:
What a disaster this game is...
Postal 3 lives up to its predecessor's gratuitous violence and even a lot of silly situations.
The game's main problem is that it's broken. It has so many problems, so many that it feels like the poorly made "Steam Greenlight" ones.

This isn't meant to be mean; the plot follows exactly how Postal Dude's "Apocalypse Weekend" DLC ends: he goes to new cities to do all sorts of jobs, and that's it.
Narrative has never been a priority for the series; it was always poor, so in this case it's fine; the problem is everything else.

The gameplay is in third-person, and that might already turn off many fans of the series, but we eventually get used to it.
We'll no longer have to run simple errands like the previous game, but for each level we'll have a different job, some normal and some bizarre.
A major downside to the game is the fact that it's no longer free-roaming. The levels are quite small, and the missions we have to complete are quite repetitive, like collecting objects with the vacuum cleaner or protecting people.
The arsenal is vast, and there are some original weapons that I enjoyed, like the badger chainsaw. We'll once again have the cat, which, in addition to being used as a silencer on the assault rifle, we can throw it at enemies... it will have the same effect as the "Weekend Apocalypse" DLC. They'll spin around like a taz-maniac, damaging the enemy quite a bit.

In the fourth level, you have to decide on a side, whether to be on the good side or the bad side. Depending on your decision, completely different missions will be offered.
So far, it seems like a good game, but now let's get to the negatives. I'll list them:

THE GAME'S AI IS NON-EXISTENT!
Okay, even the one in Postal 2 wasn't the best, but in the end, it did its job. Why do I say it's non-existent?
I see people shooting at walls, LOTS of them. People who should be shooting you and just stand there doing nothing, and people who don't react (50% of them here) even if you piss on them...

MUSIC
This game's music has three main downsides:
- the first is the kind of music that's not well-chosen, even banal with few musical instruments; only the one in the "gay" mission matched it.
- the second is the volume of the music, which is significantly louder than the in-game noises and voices. Many times I couldn't understand what the Postal Dude was saying.
- the third is that it's on a horrible loop; the music ends with a fade-out effect... and then resumes as if nothing had happened (it's horrible to listen to, especially in the "sung" songs).

POORLY OPTIMIZED
There are many sections in the game where it will stutter even under 30 frames per second.

EXTREMELY REPETITIVE MISSIONS
As I mentioned before, the missions are truly too similar to each other. Postal 2 was similar, for goodness sake, but it managed to catch you off guard with the events that happened when you were doing normal errands.
Not to mention the "good" faction, which suffers from the same repetitiveness problem, but it's "out of place" considering you're a lethal cop.
Damn, Postal Dude, a cop... he has his comical moments, but he's not as funny as the opposing faction.
The length, on the other hand, is average... about 4.5 to 5 hours, trust me, that's more than enough.

PROS
- Humor, while not as funny as its predecessor, will still make you smile.
- Extensive arsenal of weapons, including other original weapons.
- Two factions to choose from gives you the opportunity to replay the game.

CONS
- Almost no exploration in individual levels.
- Missions are too repetitive.
- Easy difficulty (you can't select the difficulty level).
- The music isn't anything special; sometimes it doesn't fit with the events, and it's too loud, making it hard to hear the dialogue.
- Very poorly optimized, with some pretty severe frame rate drops.
- There are tons of sounds missing, like when you reload weapons or when you punch someone.
- Punches feel like they don't do any damage.
- Character models don't work properly (they often moved without footstep animations).
- Dated graphics.
- I found the good faction "out of place" (due to the police missions, personal opinion).

Rating: 4.5/10

column8:
This game isn't as bad as people say it is. Sure, it can be buggy, and the framerate dips quite a bit, but it isn't too bad.
I think most people's problem with it is it's departure from Postal 2. If you're looking for a Postal 2-like experience, don't get this, get Postal 2 Paradise Lost. It's cheaper and honestly a much better product.
This game isn't like Postal 2, it's a third person action shooter with a Postal 2 theme to it.
So, pros and cons:

Pros:
- Lots of new weapons and items - such as beehives to throw at enemys
- Lost of references to Postal 2 - Lots of items/weapons return, recap of what happened in the last game, and quite a few returning characters
- Champ... Champ is awesome
- The game looks very nice. Seriously, the graphics are amazing
- You can dash - a feature that I wish was in Postal 2
- It's amazingly fun to completely trample people by dashing at them
- Branching story with different missions for each branch
- The art is quite nice

Cons:
- The controls are fucking wonky at times. Sometimes your accuracy is really off, and everything is either above or below the crosshair. Also, you can't jump anymore. You can only vault over certain objects while you're taking cover behind them
- The framerate dips a lot
- The game crashes occasionally
- Quite a few odd glitches
- The saving system is pretty garbage. Unlike Postal 2 where it was clean and organized, this saving system has your save data all over the place
- No difficulty settings. Postal 2 had so many difficulty settings to choose from, so why can't this?
- Rick Hunter (The Postal Dude's voice actor) isn't here for this game. Instead, they have Cory Cruise substituting for him. Cory does an alright job, but it isn't as good as Rick, in my opinion
- The inventory is a cluttered mess. In Postal 2, everything was organized into catagories

Pros or Cons? - These I'll leave up to you to decide:
- The game is in third person now
- The game is much more linear. Postal 2 put you in an open world with some objectives to complete around the map, while Postal III is linear and mission based.
- The soundtrack is pretty good, but often times very oddly unfitting
- The distastful humor from Postal 2 is back, and ramped up to be worse than before

I haven't played the game too much yet, but honestly I feel like I've gotten the full experience from just my first 2 hours of gameplay.
So far I've enjoyed the game, but I'll let you weight the pros and cons and make a decisions for yourself.
Also, rather than paying for it and giving Akella more money that they don't deserve, just email Mike J of RWS asking for a key. He's often pretty generous with them.

column9:
Average graphics, good keyboard and mouse gameplay, lots of fun, and an interesting story. In this game, the story changes depending on your actions. I chose the positive side and really liked the ending.

The negatives were the bugs, slow loading times, mediocre optimization, and the third-person gameplay!

Even though the game is getting negative reviews, it maintains the quality of Postal 2 and, even better, it maintains the fun, which is the most important thing for me!

I highly recommend it!

This game is awesome! Yeah, I know the achievements are a little laggy, but that doesn't stop it from being awesome... Even though it was made by TrashMasters, it's definitely a B+! It's a B+ because it crashes sometimes, and I'm not sure about the achievements... Maybe they're not laggy and can be achieved... Overall, thanks to the developers and everyone involved in this project for a smooth game. THANK YOU SO MUCH!

column8: I don't get it why this game has so bad reviews. Yea, it's bugged and annoying sometimes, but Postal 2 was kinda the same and everyone loves it. Freeroam mode is avaiable, at least after finishing the game, so if anyone misses some slaughter - you can have it too! Anyway game plot is funny, I like 2 pathes avaiable, new Dude model and voice is great, music is just awesome and even melee weapons ain't that bad to use if you learn to. Of course it's not worth anything above 5 euro on sale, but I don't regret buying it, I had lots of fun doing crazy missions and replaying whole game to explore other path.

Many who played Postal 3 give the game mostly negative reviews, and they're understandable. After all, the game itself is incredibly buggy and completely unoptimized. But it's trash, and trash is trash, no matter where you are. Especially since after completing the story, the player is given a free mode where they can do whatever their wildest imagination desires, in the best Postal traditions.
7 helmet-sucking games out of 10

I'm not sure what to say, but I liked Postal 3. Sure, it has some minor flaws, but it still has the action, the thrill, and the grind that's left over from the previous games. Overall, I liked Postal III.

column9:
It's changed from an FPS (Postal 2) to a TPS (Postal 3), and the screen shakes violently. It's extremely difficult to see.
The controls have also changed completely, and there's no jumping.
Stages are mission-specific, so you can't walk around freely.

At the time of purchase, it had received mixed reviews, but this seems to be overwhelmingly negative.
If you like Postal 2, I recommend not buying this. It's a different game.

column8: Really disappointing. Coming from a fan of Postal 2 and all it's episodes, you'd really expect Postal 3 would be the sh*t, right? No! They went reverse on a big stick. If it wasn't for the graphics (which is something I don't care much about in a game) you could say it's the worst of them all (if you judge each one by it's place in time, it is). It's bad to a point I will take reviews on Steam seriously from now on, in order to try saving myself from wasting money. I can't say there is much of a plot in the game. You just start on some radom shootout with minimal context and try to survive and complete the objectives. You have less weapons, the structure and elements rely too much on Postal 2, the Dude's voice is not the same, no flying scissors,   snipers, kicks to the face, and yeah... no more crack smoking! If it's on sale and you want to try it yourself and regret it later, go ahead. But if it's full price, definatelly not worth it

column8: This is the buggiest piece of crap I have ever played. Steam REFUSES to give me a refund, even though I bought this game back in April of 2012 for $40. The only reason I have more than 2 hours playtime is because it was stuck in the loader downloading the game on a 384kb line back in 2012 (I live in South Africa) and steam decided that me downloading the game was actually me playing it. I hardly played this game, it completly bugged out on the segway mission, with AI driving into walls and getting stuck. Worst purchase I have ever made, I urge anyone else considering to buy this NOT TO. Don't pay a single cent for this garbage.

column9:
I'm a die-hard fan of the second generation. The settings are okay, but the combat is terrible. The first time I attacked a passerby with my bare hands, I felt like I'd never be able to kill him.

While slightly better marksmanship can make you unstoppable with your pistol and M16, the screen flickering when enemy firepower is strong is frustrating, and there's also the mysterious range of the enemies.

Being burned is almost certain death, but you can still crouch for a while to recover, huh? Running is a death sentence. NPCs can only be burned, and exploding the fire extinguisher on the wall won't put out the fire.

Why do I have to replay two levels if I rejoin the cops midway? What the hell?

Why did they remove the swearing and threats?

There are so few weapon options.

The sandbox doesn't feel like a sandbox, and the linearity doesn't feel like a linearity...

We have to mention the various lags and crashes. Initially, some users on 8.1 couldn't enter the game, and throwing items would cause the game to crash, whether it was because they were unplugged or offline. Of course, it would crash for no apparent reason. (Here's a patch, I downloaded it via a VPN: http://pan.baidu.com/s/1qYPKmr6 Password: 36kx)
Of course, the biggest complaint is that it uses the Source engine for third-person perspective, and it's so poorly done. I imagine a GMO player could easily surpass this game by making their own Postal 3.

Even with its countless flaws, I'm still looking forward to the next installment.

column8:
Overall, the game just feels... deceitful. Fake. Disingenuous. It's the video game equivalent of watching a child getting hit by a car.

Pros:
*The Soundtrack - surprisingly good. Clearly much more effort went into it than everything else.

Aaaand that's about it.

Netural:
*Third person perspective - I personally don't mind it, but it would've been nice to have had the option of having a first person perspective, too.
*Corey Cruise as Postal Dude - disappointing to not have Rick Hunter's amazing voice soothing my ears, but Cruise still does a commendable job.

Cons:

Hoo boy. Here we go.

*The Humor - Guys, making The Postal Dude say "I blame (irrelevant subject here)!" nearly every time he kills something is NOT funny. Rehashing lines from Postal 2 isn't cute.

*No map, arrows, or anything that indicated where to go next.
*Annoyingly long loading times.
*Poor optimization.
*Crashes frequently.
*Stutters every time a new mission starts.
*A.I. can be incredibly stupid, especially when you're supposed to protect someone.
*LOUD, imbalanced sound.
*No Open-world exploration between missions - Seriously? This is what made Postal 2 so much fun.

*Good/Evil karma system, Multiple Endings - interesting idea. good for replayability. Too bad I achieved one of the endings in about 5 hours, most of which were spent wondering where the hell I was supposed to go.

Did I enjoy myself during this game? A little. Did I laugh? Yes.
Are Postal 2, and Postal 2: Paradise Lost, and Postal 4 superior to this game in every conceivable way?

Yes. Yes they are.

Le Postal maudit renier par l‚Äô√©diteur lui m√™me... J'ai voulue me faire ma propre id√©e.

Ben effectivement, c'est une sacr√©e daube, on revient sur le principe du premier Postal avec du nettoyage d‚ÄôAr√®ne(19 presque toute en couloir) mais cette fois, avec une vu √† la troisi√®me personne. Dans le premier Postal, √ßa fonctionne parce qu'on a une vu d'ensemble(du dessus).

Ce jeu tourne avec le moteur Source(half life 2) et √ßa ressemble vraiment a un mod amateur. Je me suis √©clater sur Postal, Postal redux, Postal 2(un incontournable) et son DLC. Ce troisi√®me opus, j'ai vraiment essayer de l'aimer... Mais j'y arrive pas.

column9:
The cursed Postal, disowned by the publisher itself... I wanted to make up my own mind.

Well, indeed, it's a real mess. It's a return to the principle of the first Postal, with Arena clearing (19 almost entirely in corridors), but this time, with a third-person view. In the first Postal, it works because we have a bird's eye view (from above).

This game runs on the Source engine (Half-Life 2) and it really feels like an amateur mod. I had a blast with Postal, Postal Redux, Postal 2 (a must-have), and its DLC. I really tried to like this third installment... But I can't.

The most annoying thing, I think, is the bugs. The game lags in certain Arenas, even on a gaming PC. Achievements don't work or unlock themselves for no reason. And if the game crashes, well, you just have to reboot your PC.

Anyway, try it only for your passion for failed games ;)

Jugu√© al Postal 2 y me encant√≥. Al enterarme de que iba a salir el 3 e imagin√°ndome las mil maneras que iba a tener a mi disposici√≥n para acabar con terroristas e inocentes por igual me emocion√©. Qu√© equivocado estaba.

La tercera entrega liquida a la saga mediante el sistema m√°s lineal que he visto nunca. Ahora es cuando alguien dice: "Pero te deja jugar sin matar, matando a todos o a algunos y eso te lleva a distintas situaciones". Aclaro. Postal 2 era un gran juego en el cual no matabas porque el juego as√≠ lo quer√≠a, Portal 2 te tentaba a cometer verdaderas atrocidades porque el jugador lo quer√≠a o porque as√≠ era m√°s f√°cil el juego.
No voy a soltar mierdas de "dilemas sociales" o "la verdadera naturaleza del ser humano", pero as√≠ es.
Este Postal 3 te lleva de la mano TODO el rato, si hasta tiene tutorial. La historia es un intento MUY fallido de resultar gracioso, mientras que anteriores entregas lo eran sin intentarlo tanto. La jugabilidad tambi√©n es mal√≠sima, siendo el primer juego en vista isom√©trica, el segundo en primera persona y este en tercera con "c√°mara sobre el hombro". Es confuso, no matar a nadie es casi imposible y mantenerte de un bando en una misi√≥n donde se enfrentan dos grupos requiere de una precisi√≥n divina, debido a lo f√°cil que es que un componente de tu bando sea herido por tus intentos de acertar a algo.
No lo recomiendo para nada.
Compra el Postal 2 y d√©jate de terceras partes
column9:
I know this is what everyone says, but here I go.
I played Postal 2 and loved it. When I found out the 3rd was coming out, imagining the thousand ways I'd have at my disposal to take out terrorists and innocents alike, I was thrilled. How wrong I was.

The third installment ends the series with the most linear system I've ever seen. Now is when someone says, "But it lets you play without killing, killing everyone or some, and that leads to different situations." Let me clarify. Postal 2 was a great game in which you didn't kill because the game wanted it that way; Portal 2 tempted you to commit true atrocities because the player wanted it or because it made the game easier.
I'm not going to spout bullshit about "social dilemmas" or "the true nature of human beings," but that's how it is.
This Postal 3 holds your hand the ENTIRELY, and it even has a tutorial. The story is a VERY failed attempt at being funny, while previous installments were funny without really trying. The gameplay is also terrible, with the first game in isometric view, the second in first-person, and this one in third-person with an "over-the-shoulder camera." It's confusing, not killing anyone is nearly impossible, and staying on one side in a mission where two groups are facing off requires divine precision, due to how easy it is for a member of your side to be injured by your attempts to hit something.
I don't recommend it at all.
Buy Postal 2 and forget about third-party games.

Ta gra nigdy nie powinna sie ukazac... Ludzilem sie ze bedzie podobna choc troszeczke do drugie czesci. Optymalizacja graficzna i dzwiekowa to dno. Przy wiekszych burdach dzwiek zaczyna sie psuc a gra zaczyna klatkowac. Brak otwartego swita, lokacje narzucone przez dane zadania, misje nudne, liniowe, ochraniaj, uzyj odkurzacza i przy okazji zabij lub oglusz grupe wscieklych ludzi. Wymuszoy dowcip ktory ewidentnie probuje nawiazac do 2 ale jest tak stuczny ze az nie smieszny. Sztuczna inteligencja przeciwnikow w Postal 3 powinna nosic nazwe Sztucznej glupoty. Przeciwnicy zacinaja sie na niewidzialnych scianach, latarniach , na drzwiach etc. Jesli bedzie Ci sie chcialo przeczytac moje chujowe wypociny to pod zadnym pozorem [b] NIE KUPUJ POSTAL 3 [/b] juz lepsza inwestycja bedzie zakup GENITAL JOUSTING.
 
[h1] PLUSY: [/h1]
 + na szczescie czesto wywala gre, odechciewa sie grac
 + glos glownego bohatera

[h1] MINUSY [/h1]
 - wszystko ?
column9:
This game should never have been released... I was hoping it would be even a little like the second installment. The graphical and audio optimization are abysmal. During major fights, the sound starts to break and the game starts to freeze. There's no open world, the locations are dictated by the objectives, the missions are boring and linear: protect, use a vacuum cleaner, and in the process kill or stun a group of angry people. A forced joke that clearly tries to reference Postal 2, but it's so contrived it's not funny. The enemy AI in Postal 3 should be called "Artificial Stupidity." Enemies get stuck on invisible walls, lampposts, doors, etc. If you bother reading my shitty ramblings, then under no circumstances [b] DO NOT BUY POSTAL 3 [/b] A better investment would be GENITAL JOUSTING.

[h1] PROS: [/h1]
+ Fortunately, the game crashes frequently, making you lose interest in playing
+ The main character's voice

[h1] CONS [/h1]
- Everything?
This game is just stupid crap! The sound is so bad and there's no plot. I haven't played the previous games.

column8:
If you're expecting anything in this game that is either on par with or improved upon from Postal 2, you will be severely disappointed. If you're expecting a competent shooter with good humor, you will be severely disappointed. If you're expecting anything more than complete garbage, you will be severely disappointed.

Seriously, this game just about broke my heart when I played it. At first, I couldn't accept the fact that what I was playing was terrible, because I pre-ordered it for the full $60 and I didn't WANT to believe that it was bad. Regardless, my senses eventually kicked in. This game is the reason why I have a category in my Steam Library labeled "Horrible Mistakes".

column8:
Best said by the owners of the dogturd themselves:

Disclaimer of Shame
Postal III is a third-person shooter in which you‚Ä¶ ehh‚Ä¶ uhm‚Ä¶

Alright I‚Äôm going to level with you ‚Äì don‚Äôt buy Postal III. Seriously, you‚Äôd regret it. Hell, you‚Äôd regret playing it for free. It‚Äôs a borderline-broken, boring, frustrating, unfinished mess, and there was nothing we could do stop it.

What happened is that we agreed to let a big Russian publisher develop and publish a third Postal game, which we would handle the design for. It was actually going well for the initial development time, but then the economy crashed especially hard in Russia and the project was handed to a smaller, less experienced team that didn‚Äôt have the skill or resources to make the game we designed, and they were forced to rush development to meet unreasonable deadlines. Corners were cut severely, dramatic changes to our design were made, and the game was put out in an unfinished barely-Alpha state. The game is simply unfinished and broken. And when it does work, the game is just boring and frustrating to play. The sad part is that the publisher made little-to-no effot to fix it themselves, nor did they ever give us access so that we could try patching it up for them. We are stuck with Postal III as it is.

You‚Äôre a responsible adult (we hope), so I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre capable of making your own purchasing decisions. I just want you to consider all of the above, before you make the leap of regret into paying real hard-earned money for this title. We don‚Äôt own the game, we can‚Äôt support it and we don‚Äôt get anything from its sales, so if you decide to risk the purchase ‚Äì you‚Äôre on your own.

http://runningwithscissors.com/?page_id=853

column8:
I'm going to recommend this for one reason and one reason only:

This game is a meme at this point.

Running With Scissors have made numerous jokes and criticisms of this game in the media and in their games. The true way to understand how reviled this game is, is to try it yourself.

This being a meme however does NOT make it a good game. In fact, this is a very lackluster game. I'll list some of the reasons why.

-The melee hit detection is plain horrible
-Its stuttery as hell
-The numerous loading screens are unbearable
-The missions are repetitive and they aren't fun

Those aren't all the things wrong with it, there are many more.

Normally I wouldn't recommend something like this, but it is a POSTAL game after all and, believe it or not, I would recommend you get it to complete your POSTAL collection. It helps you to appreciate Running With Scissors' current agenda and to me it makes all the Postal 3 jokes a lot more funny.

Oh yeah, there is a mod that makes it not terrible coming out soon too, so that is another reason to get it.

O jogo tem uma hist√≥ria decente. I.A e bugs s√£o insuport√°veis. Compre apenas em promo√ß√£o, se gostar.
ps: o final neutro √© quase imposs√≠vel de conseguir.

Eu nunca pensei que me daria ao esfor√ßo de analisar esse jogo de forma seria pois jogar esse jogo do come√ßo ao fim era um teste de paci√™ncia que n√£o compensava, mesmo pros f√£s de carteirinha da franquia.

Chego em casa e vejo que o jogo tem uma atualiza√ß√£o e depois de alguns segundos processando eu fico abismado com a informa√ß√£o. Eu pensei que o jogo tinha sido removido da Steam (e tinha) e t√£o grande a minha surpresa ao ver que simplesmente remover o DRM desse jogo resolveria 90% dos problemas t√©cnicos nele apresentados. Porra, eu joguei 1 hora inteirinha sem crashar, at√© ontem esse jogo s√≥ era comparativo para eu diminuir outros jogos igualmente ruins aqui na plataforma, quanto a isso tenho que parabenizar a RWS.

Mas...vamos l√°. O jogo n√£o crashar faz com que esse jogo deixe de ser um teste de paci√™ncia e s√≥ se torne um son√≠fero na mais pura defini√ß√£o da palavra. Pra quem nunca jogou esse jogo ele tem um sistema muito idiotinha de karma e com base nas decis√µes do player ele pode se manter num pathing bom (que leva a um final bom) ou cair no pathing ruim e ter o final ruim...√©, bem preto e branco. Com essa experiencia nova eu pensei em ir pro pathing bom j√° que a √∫ltima vez que me coloquei nessa tortura anos atr√°s fui atr√°s de s√≥ atirar em tudo que se movia por que sei l√°...√© Postal?

Jogar esse jogo com o intuito de pegar o final verdadeiro √© a verdadeira tortura, os objetivos s√£o MUITO chatos e quando eu vi o Dude uniformizado como policial eu me perguntei como isso se quer seria poss√≠vel, trechos de tiro intenso ainda existem mas existem momentos onde voc√™ vai se limitar a usar um Tazer ou alguma forma n√£o letal de lidar com a situa√ß√£o e isso poderia at√© funcionar em games como Postal 2 mas aqui √© s√≥ muito repetitivo.

Algo legal dessa din√¢mica √© que os dois pathings s√£o bem diferentes at√© mesmo mudando fases por completo, √© poss√≠vel zerar esse jogo sem saber que o Uwe Boll estava nele (o diretor do filme de Postal) ou sem saber que o Dude j√° foi presidente mesmo que por 20 segundos, mas honestamente, o quanto voc√™ realmente se esfor√ßaria por um game desses? A hist√≥ria j√° n√£o √© canon ent√£o nem por entendimento da franquia isso aqui importa.

Quanto a gameplay, √© asquerosa. A movimenta√ß√£o do Dude √© BIZARRA ele corre t√£o r√°pido que derruba praticamente qualquer coisa que atropelar e tem uma stamina invisivel que pode te deixar na m√£o na hora errada. A mira √© imprecisa e com algumas armas (especialmente o aspirador que voc√™ vai usar em uma √∫nica miss√£o mas vai carregar durante o jogo todo por motivo de desenvolvedor russo) faz com que voc√™ s√≥ mire no peito pra acertar a cabe√ßa, √© estranho. O free roam pelas fases √© bloqueado at√© voc√™ zerar o jogo mas quantas pessoas realmente fizeram isso? e honestamente...sei l√°.

Para aqueles buscando platina a melhor noticia √© que as conquistas que eram imposs√≠veis (sim, isso aconteceu, existiam conquistas que poderiam ser exploitadas mas algumas eram imposs√≠veis sem uso de meios externos) foram removidas. Mas a gameplay √© t√£o tediosa que s√≥ consigo desejar boa sorte para aqueles que quiserem pegar todas as pngs de matar x inimigos com arma y nessa bomba de jogo.

Vale uma ressalva pra dublagem do Dude e pra trilha do jogo que s√£o as √∫nicas coisas boa nesse jogo, o Corey Cruise manda muito bem e eu fiquei muito feliz que ele voltou no quarto jogo por que eu gosto tanto da interpreta√ß√£o dele do personagem quanto gosto da do Rick Hunter. Quanto a trilha, at√© hoje algumas m√∫sicas do A Fall To Break est√£o na minha playlist pra me cortar no banho, men√ß√£o honrosa pra Lost, Left, All Alone que comp√µem os cr√©ditos do jogo e de vez em tempos eu volto a ouvir. 
 
Por fim, gostaria de mencionar a conquista de matar 300 terroristas que at√© ent√£o era bugada e a forma de conseguir seria matar o boss rinoceronte 300x e isso fez muito marmanjo criar um save antes do boss morrer e perder 1 horinha em loading brincando. Eu n√£o sei se isso foi concertado mas espero que n√£o por que mais Postal que isso √© imposs√≠vel. 

Em resumo, Postal¬≥ n√£o √© mais o pior jogo que ja joguei, mas eu provavelmente cairia no sono se me for√ßasse a jogar nem que fosse mais um pouco. De forma alguma isso aqui vale 2 reais que seja quem dir√° 20 mas se voc√™ por algum motivo j√° tem o jogo e dropou depois de ter que recome√ßar uma fase por que ousou jogar uma granada e o jogo crashou talvez vale uma risada ou sei l√° o que levaria algu√©m a baixar isso de novo, eu s√≥ abri por que por acaso eu esqueci de desinstalar ele quando estava ca√ßando as conquistas dos demais jogos da franquia.  Caso contrario, passar longe, n√£o espere nada mais vindo desse titulo at√© por que acho que a RWS s√≥ tem controle parcial sobre esse jogo (j√° que foi desenvolvido pela AKELLA), e al√©m de que eles j√° deserdaram esse filho de qualquer forma e a hist√≥ria segue sem ele nos pr√≥ximos t√≠tulos. Tem alguns mods muito legais que voc√™ encontra f√°cil na comunidade STEAM que talvez tamb√©m vale dar uma olhada, mas quanto ao jogo base em uma instala√ß√£o limpa isso aqui ainda fede e muito.
column9:
I never thought I'd bother seriously reviewing this game, because playing it from start to finish was a test of patience that wasn't worth it, even for die-hard fans of the franchise.

I get home and see that the game has an update, and after a few seconds of processing it, I'm stunned by the information. I thought the game had been removed from Steam (which it had), and I was so surprised to see that simply removing the DRM from this game would solve 90% of its technical issues. Hell, I played for a whole hour without a crash. Until yesterday, this game was only used as a comparison to dismiss other equally bad games on the platform. I have to congratulate RWS on that.

But...let's go. The game not crashing makes this game less of a test of patience and more of a soporific in the purest sense of the word. For those who've never played this game, it has a pretty silly karma system. Based on the player's decisions, they can either stay on a good path (which leads to a good ending) or fall into a bad path and get the bad ending... yeah, pretty black and white. With this new experience, I thought about going for the good path, since the last time I put myself through this torture years ago, I was just trying to shoot everything that moved because, I don't know... is it Postal?

Playing this game with the goal of getting the true ending is pure torture. The objectives are SO boring, and when I saw the Dude in a police uniform, I wondered how that was even possible. There are still intense shooting sections, but there are moments where you'll be limited to using a Tazer or some other non-lethal way to deal with the situation. This could even work in games like Postal 2, but here it's just very repetitive.

One cool thing about this dynamic is that the two paths are quite different, even when completely changing stages. It's possible to beat this game without knowing Uwe Boll was in it (the director of the Postal movie) or that the Dude was once president, even for 20 seconds. But honestly, how much effort would you really put into a game like this? The story isn't canon, so it doesn't even matter from a franchise perspective.

As for the gameplay, it's disgusting. The Dude's movement is BIZARRE; he runs so fast that he knocks over practically anything he runs over, and he has invisible stamina that can let you down at the wrong time. The aim is imprecise, and with some weapons (especially the vacuum cleaner, which you'll use in a single mission but will carry throughout the game due to the Russian developer) you only aim for the chest to hit the head. It's weird. Free roam through the stages is blocked until you beat the game, but how many people actually did that? And honestly... I don't know.

For those aiming for platinum, the best news is that the achievements that were impossible (yes, that happened; there were exploitable achievements, but some were impossible without external means) have been removed. But the gameplay is so tedious that I can only wish good luck to those who want to get all the PNGs for killing x enemies with y weapon in this bomb of a game.

It's worth mentioning the Dude's voice acting and the soundtrack, which are the only good things about this game. Corey Cruise is great, and I was very happy he returned in the fourth game because I like his interpretation of the character as much as I like Rick Hunter's. As for the soundtrack, to this day, some songs from A Fall To Break are on my playlist to keep me busy in the shower. Honorable mention goes to Lost, Left, and All Alone, which make up the game's credits and I listen to them every now and then.

Finally, I'd like to mention the achievement for killing 300 terrorists, which until then was bugged. The way to get it was to kill the rhino boss 300 times. This caused many adults to create a save before the boss died and waste an hour loading time playing around. I don't know if this has been fixed, but I hope not, because Postal¬≥ is impossible to beat.

In short, Postal¬≥ isn't the worst game I've ever played, but I'd probably fall asleep if I forced myself to play even a little longer. This isn't worth 2 reais, let alone 20 reais, but if you already have the game and dropped it after having to restart a level because you dared to throw a grenade and the game crashed, it might be worth a laugh or whatever would make someone download it again. I only opened it because I accidentally forgot to uninstall it when I was hunting for achievements for the other games in the franchise. Otherwise, stay away, don't expect anything more from this title, especially since I think RWS only has partial control over this game (since it was developed by AKELLA), and besides, they've already disowned this son anyway and the story continues without him in the next titles. There are some really cool mods that you can easily find in the STEAM community that might also be worth checking out, but as for the base game on a clean install, this still really stinks.

column9:
Although it's billed as a sequel to the inappropriate (?) errand game "Postal 2," for some reason it was developed by a different developer than RWS.

This TPS game sees the protagonist, "Postal Dude," complete outlandish (?) errands, with a total of 16 branching missions (assuming you're on the good route).

I initially completed the good route, and personally found the storyline surrounding the oddly hilarious characters entertaining.

However, there were many more negative aspects...

1. The game freezes and crashes frequently, making it extremely stressful.

2. Compared to "2," which allowed for a certain degree of freedom of movement but also a fairly large map, there's very little freedom in the errand missions, and the maps available for each mission aren't very large.
(The Good Route does have two random errand missions called "patrol jobs," similar to "2." However, the map is a bit small, and simply going to a designated location automatically triggers an event and then the mission begins, so it doesn't feel like there's much freedom.)

3. The effects for explosions and other things are a bit inferior to the previous game, and some of the sound effects, like machine guns, are quite loud.

(The character modeling is good, though...)

Crashes and freezes are particularly common during scenes where a large number of enemies and allies are fighting, and to be honest, it's so bad that it makes you wonder if they really did debug it.
(On the good route, this happened frequently (in my playthrough), especially on levels 9, 12, 15, and 16. I managed to get through these crapshoots by saving frequently, though...)

Especially when the game crashed the moment I defeated the final boss for the first time, I honestly wanted to say, "Huh?"

Also, even though there are branching paths, it felt less substantial than "2," and honestly, I had a strong feeling of, "Is this the end?"

By the way, this is still 13.5GB (just over 11GB when downloaded), far more than "2" (the new version is about 7GB, including DLC). I wonder where that space is going...)

Frankly, with this content, it's a disappointing work that feels more like a "secondary work made by Postal fans" than an official sequel.

To be honest, even if you enjoyed "2," I wouldn't recommend picking it up casually unless you have a special reason, like a story topic, unless you have a specific reason.
(Well, if you can endure the constant crashes, I wouldn't stop you...)

column8:
Honestly, do the world a favor and buy postal 2, not this. However, if you like the idea of modding, postal 3 is quite easy to alter, that's literally the only upside. As quite frankly the missions are awkward as sin, awkward aiming with weaponry and incredibly clunky melee combat. But then again the clunky melee combat is a GIVEN, it's source engine afterall folks.

Honesty time: Only purchased this to mod it to recreate / attempt to remake postal 1 or 2 features in it.

column8: As a huge fan of committing attrocities in Postal 2, I'm sorry to say I had to give up on this weak ass game. Gone is the open world, free form fun. No, now we need to follow some half-baked linear story as if that was ever anyone's interest in this franchise. How is grabbing cats and decking soccer mums anything compared to filling a bank with grenades, pouring in gasoline and making it rain like a stripclub of flaming meat-paste. This is the diet coke of evil.

Thank you RWS for making great games, and sorry you had a big bump in the road of success.

I've been playing this series since childhood! Starting with Postal 2, when I was still in fourth grade. Back then, the hardware was very weak, and it was impossible to buy and play Postal 3. Then 2016 arrived, and I decided to buy this game, despite the negative reviews. I launched it and was surprised to find that it was powered by the Source engine. Okay, I started playing and I'm really disappointed :( The game isn't the same as it used to be, like the previous game.
1. Terrible Russian translation, plus worthless cutscenes.
2. Inconvenient controls, only third-person view.
3. Terrible missions right at the beginning of the game that will bore a new player.
Want to buy this game? Better buy the previous games and enjoy them.
Is it worth your money? NO!
And I think I'll stop here, as I don't see the point in writing any more about this game. I hope they fix everything in the fourth game!

column8:
Postal III is a good game. Is it the best game? No. But it is a good game.

Here are the things thats in the game so you'll know. I'm not gonna say to buy it or not but you have the choice whether you choose to or not. So here the following things this game has compare to Postal 2.

Different voice actor for Dude.

The map is rather a bit smaller in oppose to Postal 2 big maps, where its practically open world while it isnt in Postal III where you can actually explore places in Postal 2 and go through pretty much any houses you see. Postal III doesnt have that and certain areas are only opened.

Third person view, replace first person view.

No difficulty in this game, which is pretty crucial to those that enjoys a challenge, in oppose to Postal 2's, especially the highest difficulty where pretty much everywhere is a warzone.

Alternate endings: Good, neutral, bad (only way to get neutral is to literally not do anything good or bad, just mind your business).

The story is fairly good, and depending on your paths the good ending has some epic battles. But overall, the game is rather average.

Did I also forget to mention theres no workshop as well? Postal 2 has that.

I recommend those that enjoys a good run on the story like me. I DO NOT RECOMMEND THOSE THAT WANTS TO ENJOY THE GAME IN GENERAL! Get Postal 2 if you are into that.

column9: In a nutshell, something similar to Postal 2.

column8:
Absolute dogturd of a game, it somehow has more bugs and more crashes than Postal 2, which was made 8 years before it.

The plot is paper thin and incoherent, it is mostly a shooter on rails with no real open world sandboxyness to it. The weapons are atrocious, the camera being a janky mess that makes it almost impossible to hit anything, as you will shoot right or left of your reticle. Melee is borderline useless, as it will often not hit any critical parts, without a lot of practice and not hitting critical parts, causes close to no damage.

The only reason I have 18 hours in this mess, is cos that is only how long it took to 100% it for kicks and there is no replay value, so it can now RIP uninstalled forever.

column8:
DISCLAIMER: Most of the hundreds of hours I have on this game are actually from a Total Conversion mod for it called Catharsis Reborn, I've only done about 4 playthroughs of vanilla Postal 3 over the years, so I've really only played it for around 8-10 hours.

The Good
- Short length. Normally I'd have a problem with a game being incredibly short, but not this one. The gameplay is pretty much boring garbage all the way through, so the fact that it's over quickly is a nice unintended blessing.
- Cool voice acting. Most of the dialogue is just shitty attempts at jokes which aren't funny at all, but the voice actors do a good job with that they're given. The Dudes voice actor also does a great job at making things at least slightly tolerable.
- Nice (but worthless) weapon variety. There are a lot of weapons on offer here and they have some decent looking models and sounds for the most part, it's just that most of them range from bad to useless, and don't really get any better from there (see below for more).

The Bad
- Broken weapon balancing. Lots of firearms like the Pistol and Shotgun are incredibly weak, and melee is very low damage as well. Through pretty much the entire game only one gun is worth using, the M16. The M16 is an automatic weapon with high damage, low recoil and fast reloads, and so many enemies use it that it's almost impossible to run out of ammo for, making it the default weapon for pretty much the entire game.
- Map design is terrible. The maps in Postal III have very little in them and hidden items are almost non existant. Exploration is also totally gone, because the game is completely linear, instead of being able to go from map to map as you please, you're locked to single maps at a time and constantly forced into new missions.
- Unfunny humour. Like I said with my POSTAL 2 review, humour is subjective, so whether or not I find something funny won't really change whether others find it funny or not, but it seems that most people who've played it think that the attempts at jokes in Postal III were garbage, and I completely agree.
- No exploration. As I mentioned above, the game has no exploration besides the little exploring you can do in the maps you're locked inside, which generally don't include anything to find other than the occasional ammo pickup here and there. There is an unlockable free roam mode available after you finish the campaign, but there's nothing to do inside the free roam world other than pick up weapons and kill civilians, which doesn't feel fun or satisfying at all.
- No health items. Yes, that's right, Postal III completely removes health items and replaces them with a regenerating health mechanic which makes the only way to get health back sitting behind a wall and waiting.
- No difficulty options. Yeah, they removed those as well. POSTAL 2 had dozens of different difficulty options, Postal III has just one. This means that the game is always locked to one mode, easy as shit. The game has no real challenging moments at all, and I managed to complete the game without dying once with very little effort.
- Karma system. While POSTAL 2 let you play your way, it never punished you for choosing a certain style, Postal III does this a lot. The Karma system splits the game into 2 different paths, the Good Path and the Insane Path. On the Good Path you have to keep your Karma meter from dropping to bad, otherwise you get forced onto the Insane Path. On the Insane Path if you manage to fill your Karma meter up to good, you get the option to move on to the Good Path. The Karma bar is affected by how you deal with NPCs, if you kill unarmed people (and sometimes even armed attackers if the game just feels like being an unreasonable dick, which it does on certain missions) your karma will go down, leaving innocents alone and using non lethal weapons on enemies will bring the bar up again. This means that you are punished for being violent in Postal, a series which has always been about violence, this just ruins any potential fun the combat could've had, especially because the Insane Path is worse than the Good Path just by being more frustrating and tedious.

Overall, Postal III is a clearly unfinished and poorly thought out mess, clips of the game from 2007 up to its release in 2011 show that it changed a lot throughout development and its clear that the teams that worked on it just ran out of money and got desperate, hoping that booting the game out the door before it was properly finished would save them by making some small profits on release to recover the dev costs. It didn't, and Akella and Trashmasters are now dead as a result, Postal III clearly explains why, it's a broken, buggy and tedious mess that nobody should bother trying, even for a joke, it's just not worth wasting time on, it isn't even canon in the POSTAL universe anymore thanks to POSTAL 2 Paradise Lost retconning it, so you have no reason to bother with it, save your money and your time.

column9:
Don't buy this game. Never.
Take Postal2, it's better.

Pros:

+Improved graphics
+More ways to humiliate the commoners
And that's it
Cons:
-The third-person view ruins the atmosphere of Postal
-The levels (I mean levels, because I didn't see any locations like in Part 2) are small. In Part 2, the map was quite large and allowed for freedom of movement
-Uneasy (?) controls
That's it. Whether you buy the game or not is entirely up to you, but I don't recommend it. 2/5, nothing higher.

column8:
Let's be honest here. Postal 3 is [b][i]not[/i][/b] a good game. Running With Scissors disowned it, and made it canon discontinuity in Paradise Lost. Paradise Lost is the true sequel to Postal 2, not Postal 3.

[b][i]However,[/i][/b] that being said, you [i]can[/i] have some fun with it. You may have to turn cheat codes on for that, but regardless, there is SOME fun to be had.

And, if I was forced to play either this or Mighty Number 9, I'd pick this. Every time. Broken yet cathartic and mildly entertaining beats mediocre-boring-lazy-overextended-weaksauce-banked-too-much-on-nostalgia-not-fun yet playable any day.

Seriously, pick it up if it goes on sale. Otherwise, just stick to Postal, Postal 2, Paradise Lost, and Postal Redux.

I loved Postal 2 and heck I even enjoyed the Uwe Boll film. But this game kind of sucks to be honest. It has some enjoyable moments here and there but most of the time it just pissed me off. The AI can be very annoying most of the time. For example. the mission where you have to escort the slave to City Hall. Every time I shot a paparazzi he would run back and I would have to hit him just so he can follow me. There are also a crap ton of glitches. In the same mission the slave would always get stuck trying to pass through a doorway. I would have to shoot him and keep saving so I can restart. The voice acting was sub par at best. It feels like no one really wanted to be there. I might continue playing the game but that's only because I payed for this and because I loved the second one. I wouldn't be surprised if I just stopped playing because I have better games.

Quando anunciado eu esperava muito desse jogo, infelizmente foi decepcionante. Mesmo em promo√ß√£o ainda prefiro n√£o recomend√°-lo, com certeza Postal 2 e Paradise Lost valem muito mais a pena.

Tecnicamente o jogo est√° muito ruim... A movimenta√ß√£o do personagem e dos demais NPCs √© bastante ruim e a IA √© p√©ssima, at√© mesmo o modo "Kill-Kill" parece n√£o funcionar muito bem. O jogo possu√≠ pouca variedade de armas e algumas n√£o funcionam bem, a mir√° tamb√©m n√£o √© muito bem ajustada e as armas Brancas simplesmente as vezes n√£o acertam o alvo como deveriam. O mapa tamb√©m est√° bem menor do que o Postal 3, n√£o havia necessidade de um mapa gigantesco, por√©m a sensa√ß√£o de liberdade no jogo √© bastante limitada por conta disso.

Vizualmente o jogo √© agrad√°vel. Poder fazer algumas escolhas foi um elemento bem legal implantado no jogo, se bem estudado e trabalhado pelos desenvolvedores, num futuro jogo poder√° nos dar escolhas bastante divertidas. Jogar como policial tamb√©m foi bem divertido.
column9:
When it was announced, I had high expectations for this game, but unfortunately, it was disappointing. Even on sale, I still prefer not to recommend it. Postal 2 and Paradise Lost are definitely worth a look.

Technically, the game is very poor... The movement of the character and other NPCs is quite poor, and the AI ‚Äã‚Äãis terrible. Even the "Kill-Kill" mode doesn't seem to work very well. The game has little weapon variety, and some don't work well. The aiming isn't very well adjusted, and melee weapons simply don't hit their target as intended. The map is also much smaller than Postal 3; there was no need for a gigantic map, but the sense of freedom in the game is quite limited because of this.

Visually, the game is pleasant. Being able to make certain choices was a really cool element implemented in the game. If well thought out and developed by the developers, a future game could offer some very entertaining choices. Playing as a police officer was also quite fun.

The story and the setting seem also good.

Without the mods, It's a negative review.
