As a Postal fan, I was surprised to see this wasn't actually good. I got to the second mission, where you have to use cat nip spray to get a bunch of HIV cats, however, there was a few problems.

1: When a cat gets latched onto you, you have to spam left and right mouse to get it off. This wouldn't be a problem, but if you have the cat nip out, you can easily press right mouse, which consumes a ton of cat nip that's needed for the mission. Yes, it's limited. No, there are no refills (not as far as I could see)

2: The Chinese gang never stopped attacking me. And this is the second level, where my only weapons are cats, cat nip spray, and a vacuum. They had pistols, machetes, and M16s. Little unfair. Also, they never stopped respawning, leaving little time for me to grab the cats. I ended up having to throw a cat at one of the guys to grab a machete, which took some time. Which brings me to point 3.

3: Some weapons are broken. My favorite weapon from Postal 2, the machete, is reduced to a useless toy. The main attack took many attacks, and throwing it like a boomerang was hard. The machete wasn't thrown at the crosshair, rather below it, and even then it would miss a ton of targets. Also, it got stuck often, even when thrown in an open space.

After dying 3 times, the game crashed. I was dissapointed in this game. The gore is better than Postal 2 in my opinion, but there's so many glitches and the game is unfair on the earliest levels. Although, I'm probably one of the few who's okay with the new voice actor (mainly because Akella actually offered to have Rick Hunter voice the game, though he refused) and while some lines were pretty funny to me ("I blame pacman.") some lines pretty much made me cringe. ("Bacon bacon bacon!" and other fire related lines) I also think I heard him say a really old meme (the cheeseburger one) but since this game was made in 2011 I can excuse that.

If you do plan on getting this game, turn off motion blur at the start. It'll save you a lot of headaches.
column9:
As a Postal fan, I was surprised to see this wasn't actually good. I got to the second mission, where you have to use cat nip spray to get a bunch of HIV cats, however, there was a few problems.

1: When a cat gets latched onto you, you have to spam left and right mouse to get it off. This wouldn't be a problem, but if you have the cat nip out, you can easily press right mouse, which consumes a ton of cat nip that's needed for the mission. Yes, it's limited. No, there are no refills (not as far as I could see)

2: The Chinese gang never stopped attacking me. And this is the second level, where my only weapons are cats, cat nip spray, and a vacuum. They had pistols, machetes, and M16s. Little unfair. Also, they never stopped respawning, leaving little time for me to grab the cats. I ended up having to throw a cat at one of the guys to grab a machete, which took some time. Which brings me to point 3.

3: Some weapons are broken. My favorite weapon from Postal 2, the machete, is reduced to a useless toy. The main attack took many attacks, and throwing it like a boomerang was hard. The machete wasn't thrown at the crosshair, rather below it, and even then it would miss a ton of targets. Also, it got stuck often, even when thrown in an open space.

After dying 3 times, the game crashed. I was dissapointed in this game. The gore is better than Postal 2 in my opinion, but there's so many glitches and the game is unfair on the earliest levels. Although, I'm probably one of the few who's okay with the new voice actor (mainly because Akella actually offered to have Rick Hunter voice the game, though he refused) and while some lines were pretty funny to me ("I blame pacman.") some lines pretty much made me cringe. ("Bacon bacon bacon!" and other fire related lines) I also think I heard him say a really old meme (the cheeseburger one) but since this game was made in 2011 I can excuse that.

If you do plan on getting this game, turn off motion blur at the start. It'll save you a lot of headaches.

I'm sooooo fucking nuts. How could they screw this up so badly, developers? This isn't a post, this is some kind of GTA miscarriage. They've literally screwed up almost everything. Here's a list of what I liked:
-Soundtrack. Really nice.
-The shovel has become quite useful.
-Decent graphics.
And here's a list of the cons:
-Almost all weapons. Only firearms are usable properly. The sledgehammer doesn't do any damage at all. And a bunch of weapons have become completely useless.
-Enjoyment from the game - 0. I haven't been this bored playing a game in a long time.
-No open world. Not that it's particularly needed, but maybe it would have helped the game somehow.
-They give you a task to deliver something. Where do you deliver it? Guess what!
-Repetition. The vacuum cleaner missions actually make you sick at some point. - Bugs, lags, freezes, crashes. Thousands of them!
- Items and weapons thrown together. It's so fucking inconvenient!!!
- Poor animation.
Bottom line: one of the shittiest games I've ever played, and the worst yet.
Rating: 3 out of 10.
THE CRAP

10 lag out of 10
10 terrible soundtracks out of 10
10 GIVE ME MY MONEY BACK out of 10
ps. Buy Postal 2 instead

column8:
Der Postal Dude ist zur√ºck. Nach einem ersten Teil, der eher ein Hatred Light war und einem abgedreht komischem genialem zweitem Teil, der vor abgedrehten Ideen triefte, ist es schwer das noch zu toppen.

An Ideen f√ºr Teil 3 mangelt es den Entwicklern nicht. Wir sind nicht nur in der Ego Shooter Ansicht unterwegs und ballern uns durch die Gegend. Es gibt auch einen Haufen lustiger Mini Games, die den Story Verlauf antreiben. Wir haben HIV infizierte Katzen, besch√ºtzen Pornolegende Ron Jeremy vor emanzipierten Hausfrauen. Natr√ºrlich darf auch Crotchy und sogar Uwe Boll nicht fehlen.

Trotz dem Haufen an Ideen ist Postal 2 nicht zu toppen. Aber Postal 3 ist im Groben und Ganzen kein schlechtes Spiel. Man kann als Postal 2 Fan gerne zugreifen, wenn man dies bedenkt. Und Postal 1 Fans schauen besser in Hatred rein...
column9:
The Postal Dude is back. After a first installment that was more like a Hatred Light and a crazy, funny, and brilliant second installment dripping with crazy ideas, it's hard to top this.

The developers aren't lacking in ideas for part 3. We're not just in first-person shooter mode, blasting our way around. There are also a bunch of fun mini-games that drive the story. We have HIV-infected cats, and we protect porn legend Ron Jeremy from emancipated housewives. Of course, Crotchy and even Uwe Boll aren't missing either.

Despite the plethora of ideas, Postal 2 can't be topped. But Postal 3 isn't a bad game overall. Postal 2 fans are welcome to pick it up, considering that. And Postal 1 fans should definitely check out Hatred...

column8:
Rather than repeating every other review on here (either saying it's a laggy, buggy pile of shit, or sticking up for it without any support), I'm just gonna point put the pros and cons of POSTAL III. I personally enjoy this game, but I can see why others don't. Many people ask if it's really *that* bad, and if they should pass on it or not... I think you should TRY it, especially if you're a fan of the previous games. But don't fart around, try rushing through as much as you can - that way you can still qualify for a refund, which you may want.

Pros:
+A good amount of weapons. Not as many as Postal 2, but more than most games.
+Though generally very cheesy, it has plenty of comedic moments.
+Goofy brand name refrences. A video game store with a game called Left 4 Bread, a coffee shop called Lotsofbucks or some shit, etc.
+Sticks to the usual Postal story. The Dude is broke, has troubles holding a job, and doesn't get his hard earned cash.
+Ability to choose whether you're good or bad (or neutral). This changes both gameplay and story, and gives you different missions.
+Pee simulator - part two?
+Neat soundtrack. And it suites the game.
+Boss fights are pretty solid, and can provide a challenge.
+Tons of fucking blood and gibs, as well as vulgarity and some dark humor.
+Tons of replayabiliy, as usual.
+Fun gameplay, though for some people it may get boring.

Neutral points (some might see as pros, while others see as cons):
N) Not in first-person as POSTAL 2 was
 But then again, let's not forget POSTAL 1 was a top-down shooter.
N) Bizarre weapons, such as AIDS infested cats, a badger that acts as a chainsaw, and a vacuum that sucks up small items and shoots them out (non-leathal, and barely ethical to use).
N) You have to unlock Free-roam by completing the game.


Cons:
-Not made by RWS. Hell, they don't even make money from this game!
-Bugs. Big bugs! We're talking tarantulas and genetically-altered cockroaches! You and other people will get stuck in certain spots, game crashes (I've rarely had this, though other people seem to have major issues with that), freezes from time to time, and many more. Some are smaller, and some... not so small.
-Lag can be a bitch at times, and the frame-rate can drop to -10 FPS.
-Repetitive story. You start your job, you and/or your employer get attacked, you defend the area, the boss doesn't like that, you don't get paid, and on to the next one.
-No trading cards.
-Since it's developed by a Russian company, the English isn't very good. Poor grammar and what not.
-No Rick Hunter, but the new Dude repeats gameplay phrases used in P2.
-Physics are all over the place. Sometimes when you shot someone in the head with a pistol, their head will pop off. Other times you'll use a fucking machine gun, and they'll just drop dead with no gibs. If you tase somebody then pour gasoline on them, they occasionally set on fire. See what I mean? The physics aren't consistent. 
-Achievements are glitched. Which ones, you ask? Depends on how unlucky you are. I've heard some people have issues with certain achievements I don't have issues with, and vice versa. Sometimes an achievement is apparently locked, sometimes doing the necessary tasks won't add up. I've spent half hour lighting people on fire, killing dozens of people, but my achievement progress was only 4/50. No, I don't mean 4 out of the 50 remaining.

column8: If you really love the Postal franchise you'll love the humor and enjoy the characters and you WILL have fun.  It's dysfunctional and wrong, nothing is sacred and that's all that matters. A couple new weapons are a real winner (badgersaw, beehive) and the missing anthrax infected cow heads and missing taliban WMD rocket launcher is a real bummer. Half the fun I have with Postal 2 is the AFFECT of a biological agent trap or the automatic spreading of sick on a populace as postal dude stands by, innocent. I missed people running up to stop near me and say "I..." only to begin vomiting blood and die - because of some devious mischief I had nothing at all to do with, I promise. Postal III lacks this depth of game play. It is somewhat linear.  Not completely on rails, but not free. But when you've got Ron Jeremy, Sarah Palin, Gary Coleman's face, Osamma Bin Laden, homo cowboy thegway biker gangs, Krotchy and all the racism and political jokes you could ever want just waiting for you...you would be cheating yourself to not at least give this game a try. I got the game and played it through and I regret nothing.

column8:
[b] It's very hard to say how I feel about Postal 3. [/b]

I'd star off by saying it's a broken piece of shit game. It really is. It's broken all the way down to the achievements. It's extremely linear and the "free roam" maps are small as hell. when you initially play, your like wtf did I just play, but then, you play the good side of the story. -- I even hate to say this but the good story version of the game seemed to be more of  a overall game, even the boss fights were actually boss fights to an extent...
[spoiler] (the ending was actually pretty epic with the tank battle) [/spoiler]

The fact that this alone allows you to draw out the gameplay factor a bit does kind of give it a replay value... Kind Of.... This is when 17 levels actually becomes 27 levels and you actually kinda feel bad for the game, because you start to see it's potential.....  This is when you really want to give it [b] At Least a 7/10 [/b] but ... you know it's [u] really a 5/10 [/u] and you can't recommend it to anyone because it's very incomplete.... 
____
[b] 5/10 [/b]
____

Maybe someday a team will come along and fix it.

column9: They remove DRM and less crashes than before.

After 5 years, I finally beat this crap.
Crashes - over 40 (on 5-6, I deleted all the intro videos, cutscenes, and other crap so I wouldn't have to watch it every time I started).
I constantly had to update the sound cache to prevent the sound from glitching.
I had to manually edit the configs and other settings to get rid of lag, freezes, and frequent crashes out of nowhere. o_O
At least 5 achievements didn't count, and even after replaying/restarting, they wouldn't open.
-------------
Before this, I installed it from a disc I bought, but I realized there was no point in playing it without earning achievements, so I dropped it. Well, I managed to get it for 124 rubles during the New Year's sale. And finally get to play this masterpiece of the domestic gaming industry...

Game rating: 2.5/10

column9: They didn't even bother to make a game out of this ... I had high hopes for this but it ended up being very disapointing. What little gameplay there was ... was very simple and boring. Refund! >:(

[h1]The internet is to blame for everything[/h1]

Postal 3 is a very long-suffering game. It was announced almost immediately after the release of the add-on for the second game. However, RWS decided not to develop it themselves but to outsource it. Where? To Akella. They had a good relationship with them, and Postal 2 became a mega-cult in our area. And they liked their "Corkscrew Burns" mod. This decision was fatal. Unaware of the specifics of how Russian gaming companies worked at the time, RWS essentially put the series in a very difficult situation. Development hell continued for eight years. They promised mountains of gold and our answer to GTA.

And so, in 2011, the game finally came out. Critics and players alike slammed it. And although it sold well, the vibe around it was simply awful. Broken promises, terrible optimization, tons of cut content, and overall trashiness. Akella, who refused to admit mistakes, initially released it only on discs with StarForce protection. The release on Gaben's store only happened a year later, and even there they managed to slip in DRM protection, which stopped working in 2022 and the game was removed from sale. But a year later, it was brought back, along with two major patches.

The plot: The Dude ends up in the town of Catharsis, also in Arizona, and tries to find money for gas. You can play the game the law way, or the maniac way. This affects not only the ending but also the missions themselves.

Graphics - The game used the then-new Source engine, and its visuals are reminiscent of Valve games. It's not that bad, really.

Sound - My favorite soundtrack in the series. The Dude is played by Cory Cruz, who replaced Rick Hunter for some reason. And he'll play our hero again in the future. In the CIS, the voice acting was done by Kurazh Bombay. Many people didn't like it, but damn, it's better than Gruzdev, who didn't care who he was voicing.

Gameplay: Unlike the second game, which was more or less open-world, this one is linear and divided into locations. Is this a consequence of the engine? Source isn't very good at open-world gameplay. The game is also now third-person, and I actually like it better that way. The weapon arsenal is still rich with various weapons, although the napalm gun, for example, is gone. For peaceful play, the Shocker, Pepper Spray, and Gamamet are available. They were given to everyone with the patch and were given to everyone with the pre-order.

Cons: 1) Despite all the efforts and two major updates, the game remains a hotbed of glitches. Although it's much better than it was at launch. When the game lagged on high-end hardware, it crashed constantly and dropped frame rates. This was odd, considering we're talking about the Source engine, which is renowned for its optimization. There are also mechanics that don't work, like kicking, you won't use them at all. Melee combat is basically nonsensical. The only weapons you need are standard firearms; all the exotic ones just get in the way.
2) The story is essentially filler and overflowing with terrible Russian humor. There are also unnecessary cameos (in the second game, only Gary Coleman was featured). Moreover, the game is very short. It takes about three hours to complete the peaceful route. And then there's the evil route.

Bottom Line: Of course, Postal 3 is not a masterpiece. But were the previous games masterpieces? No. And surprisingly, after RWS started trashing the 3D series, its popularity in the community only grew. Why? Well, the fourth game came out, and it basically didn't work properly. And it didn't offer anything new.

The Postal series has a fanbase the size of a village, and RWS knows who they're making games for. But the 3D series certainly didn't deserve all that hate. And let's be honest, Akella really lost out when they didn't realize the market had changed by 2011, and Arkhipov still refuses to admit his mistakes. But what did RWS give in return? Jokes about shit and missions to clean it up. In that case, it's better to throw shit-stained napkins in the faces of feminists.

A nameless idiot known as the Dude, after detonating an atomic bomb in the Arizona town of Paradise, moves permanently to a similar hole with the intriguing name of Catharsis. Grotekstic villains, mind-blowing missions, gripping gameplay, and, as usual, a cleverly twisted social satire plot await the Dude, and you too.

Having acquired the rights to the game, a studio called Trash Masters developed it. As the saying goes, "As you name the boat, so it will float."
The studio's name speaks for itself. Oh yeah, the game is powered by the Source engine.
Some things in the game have completely changed, while others remain. The signature dark humor, the charismatic protagonist, the rich arsenal. But the game itself is complete trash. Let's start with the first mission, which "introduces" the player to the game. No, they didn't show the game's world or start any interesting narrative. Instead, you're forced to collect soiled napkins in some club...which you have to vacuum up.

Then you'll have to collect cats while running from Chinese with clubs and machetes.
There's also one very "interesting mission" in the game where a bull, painted like a cow and high on amphetamines, with a gay cowboy on his back, fights a S.W.A.T. fighter. I wonder how they even came up with something like that.
Also, throughout your playthrough, the game will constantly lag, crash, and freeze. If, after all this, you still decide to play this complete piece of crap that you can't even call a game, then good riddance. If you want to play it properly, you'll have to do a few more things: find the game in your Steam library, select "Set Launch Options" in the properties, and then add this: + host_thread_mode 2 + mat_queue_mode2
In short, it's terrible. Don't buy it, don't download it, don't play it.

I didn't really like the third game. But the shootouts are still fun and the soundtrack is spot on. Otherwise... well, so-so. I wouldn't say it's crap, but I wouldn't call it anything special either. Basically, Postal 3 is like Postal 1 with similar themes from Postal 2. They've adopted the linearity of Postal 1, but unlike the first game, where the Dude killed everyone for no reason, there's a plot here, just like in Postal 2. It's a rather unfortunate hybrid of the first and second games.

column8:
One Word...
HORRIBLE.

The fact that this game wears the name Postal is a disgrace.
Everything you loved about the Postal franchise gets raped by a bad Russian publisher who took in fact many years to create this broken crap product. It was also released way too early. I hope Akella is dead. RWS got pretty much ignored when this product was created. Also Akella and the last dev team left the product to die. Not even a proper source code has been released. This makes it nearly impossible to fix or mod the game. The game is so bad that many game functionalities are simply not working like melee weapon hit detection. To this comes bad performance and crashes. Story and gameplay wisely this product is a joke anyway. I wouldn't waste my time with this product and you shouldn't neither. Buy Paradise Lost instead. Or wait for Postal 3 Unreal. A Postal 3 remake in the unreal engine. Remade from scratch! Also there is Catharsis Reborn. Some sort of remake/sequel/alternative game in the Postal 3 Source engine. They might be able to create something good with it. I waited so long for it, but it was just crap in the end. Sad story...

My Rating? None, I simply dont want to rate a broken alpha product. Not worth it.
If you really need to try this game, get it somewhere "free" or get a very very cheap key.
Sometimes RWS also gives some out for free, as demonstration how bad the game is.
Im honest, I didnt finish the game. I guess some years ago I made it to the half with tons of crashes. Recently I got the Steam version for a cheap price. Its nearly as bad as it was when it was released. I simply cant bring myself to play this shit to end. Seriously. This game rapes me, I demand injury compensation!

Positive:
- Partly nice art design
- Soundtrack
- I like the "evil" twin Postal Dude's design and new voice, cool that it was reused in Paradise Lost

Negative:
- Bugs and crashes
- Performance problems
- Sound mixing problems, too loud, too quiet, missing sounds, unfitting sounds
- Melee weapons have a hit detection thats probably the worst ever
- No free roam
- Boring repetitive missions
- Bad English grammar and text
- Akella sucks

It may could have been a good game if they let RWS help with the development. But instead there was silence between both devs and Akella just made it worse with releasing it fast. This was the death for the game. RWS regrets this game a lot and I doubt that there will ever be something like this happening again.

UPDATE 2022:
Well, nothing changed, surprise. I actually gave this game another go and its as bad as ever. I actually tried to force myself through to the end but I almost gave up at the endboss since the game just crashed all few mins to the point that the game was almost not finishable. Molotovs and the rocket launcher also instantly crash the game or kill you. It is just a sad shame and the fact that no one can fix it due to missing source code is a shame. Akella deserves the worst. Also most of the achievements are completely broken or only unlock in very specific ways. I was thinking about getting them all just because I am a Postal fan but so much for that I guess. I still recommend to avoid the game, there just isn't any meaningful (or working) content here.

Luckily the mods Postal 3 Unreal and Catharsis Reborn actually have come far in the past 6 years since my review. Check the products out on YouTube. The latest gameplay trailers look so promising and they are definitely far into development.
column9:
One Word...
HORRIBLE.

The fact that this game wears the name Postal is a disgrace.
Everything you loved about the Postal franchise gets raped by a bad Russian publisher who took in fact many years to create this broken crap product. It was also released way too early. I hope Akella is dead. RWS got pretty much ignored when this product was created. Also Akella and the last dev team left the product to die. Not even a proper source code has been released. This makes it nearly impossible to fix or mod the game. The game is so bad that many game functionalities are simply not working like melee weapon hit detection. To this comes bad performance and crashes. Story and gameplay wisely this product is a joke anyway. I wouldn't waste my time with this product and you shouldn't neither. Buy Paradise Lost instead. Or wait for Postal 3 Unreal. A Postal 3 remake in the unreal engine. Remade from scratch! Also there is Catharsis Reborn. Some sort of remake/sequel/alternative game in the Postal 3 Source engine. They might be able to create something good with it. I waited so long for it, but it was just crap in the end. Sad story...

My Rating? None, I simply dont want to rate a broken alpha product. Not worth it.
If you really need to try this game, get it somewhere "free" or get a very very cheap key.
Sometimes RWS also gives some out for free, as demonstration how bad the game is.
Im honest, I didnt finish the game. I guess some years ago I made it to the half with tons of crashes. Recently I got the Steam version for a cheap price. Its nearly as bad as it was when it was released. I simply cant bring myself to play this shit to end. Seriously. This game rapes me, I demand injury compensation!

Positive:
- Partly nice art design
- Soundtrack
- I like the "evil" twin Postal Dude's design and new voice, cool that it was reused in Paradise Lost

Negative:
- Bugs and crashes
- Performance problems
- Sound mixing problems, too loud, too quiet, missing sounds, unfitting sounds
- Melee weapons have a hit detection thats probably the worst ever
- No free roam
- Boring repetitive missions
- Bad English grammar and text
- Akella sucks

It may could have been a good game if they let RWS help with the development. But instead there was silence between both devs and Akella just made it worse with releasing it fast. This was the death for the game. RWS regrets this game a lot and I doubt that there will ever be something like this happening again.

UPDATE 2022:
Well, nothing changed, surprise. I actually gave this game another go and its as bad as ever. I actually tried to force myself through to the end but I almost gave up at the endboss since the game just crashed all few mins to the point that the game was almost not finishable. Molotovs and the rocket launcher also instantly crash the game or kill you. It is just a sad shame and the fact that no one can fix it due to missing source code is a shame. Akella deserves the worst. Also most of the achievements are completely broken or only unlock in very specific ways. I was thinking about getting them all just because I am a Postal fan but so much for that I guess. I still recommend to avoid the game, there just isn't any meaningful (or working) content here.

Luckily the mods Postal 3 Unreal and Catharsis Reborn actually have come far in the past 6 years since my review. Check the products out on YouTube. The latest gameplay trailers look so promising and they are definitely far into development.

column9: In a mission where you have to calm everyone down, so to speak, who are joined with the police... it happens that I do the missions and suddenly when I overcome a part where a helicopter arrives, the game closes on me. Well, that in itself is great, the game is just the problem.

I don't even know where to begin. I must be a mentally ill sadomasochist writing a positive review and playing this game. The first thing you'll encounter, if you dare play "this," isn't even the bugs and crashes. It's the impossibility of playing because the sound lags and hurts your ears. Okay, so we've tinkered with the game, adjusted the sound, but the next problem is that the game is "unfinished": Everything looks like a pre-alpha version of the game, melee weapons don't reach enemies, some character animations are insanely terrible, there's an imbalance, periodic crashes, bugs during missions, and pathetic shooting. There are so many downsides to the game. I don't see the point in listing them. So where are the pros, and why do I play it? You ask. It's all about the dark humor, and there's plenty of it: bullying various people, dirty jokes, funny dialogue, and an excellent living weapon, Badger (Badger. Badger. Mushrooms. Mushrooms). A controllable crazy monkey. There are plenty of weapons, but they're buggy. The missions are crazy, sometimes successful and funny. But for the most part, they're not particularly interesting. A good soundtrack sometimes saves the day. Interesting characters (Ron Jeremy, for example). What can I say, there's even Mavrodi. Sitting after work with a bottle of beer, shooting, and running around to relax‚Äîthat's just what I'm for. I absolutely don't recommend it to anyone and would give it a neutral review. This game is clearly for an amateur or a pervert. This game is a shining example of domestic trash game development. Akella was the one who created this "miracle." It took a lot of effort to screw up the Source engine and spend so much money on development like that. Fortunately, they won't be trusted to develop RWS games anymore. I hope most fans of the series will forget this as a bad dream.

[h1]General[/h1]
After reading the many unflattering reviews of the last decent installment in a beloved series for half a decade, you can't help but wonder, "What could they have done to the game that everyone is criticizing it?" And, not trusting blind criticism, we start playing and evaluating.

...

And after finishing the game, everything becomes clear. In this review, I will sincerely try to highlight the positive aspects of each aspect of the game, and then I will finish it off with the terrible flaws.

A leisurely playthrough took: 6 hours.

[h1] Plot and Lore[/h1]
The Good:
The developers were able to exploit the idea that it is theoretically possible to play a game like Postal humanely, without killing. And this karma system influences the plot. The game has multiple endings, depending on your playstyle.

The comics during the game. They were well done. The beginning tells the entire story of the series in comics, and the endings are drawn in comics (sort of like an afterword). It's high-quality and funny.

The groups of disgruntled people you have to fight are more stylized than just a random T-shirt; they now have merchandise.

The characters are quite memorable, perhaps because there are only three of them?

And not so much:
Horror and sodomy instead of a plot. The developer made a fatal mistake in their calculations. They were counting on the game's fans being downright idiots who find it funny that someone can pee on someone, or that shit is lying on the street, or that someone is masturbating. But that's not the case. The game overdoes the absurdity in the plot so much that you stop believing it. You lose that connection with the game, that interactivity. You're just running around and pressing the buttons that tell you to. It's off-putting. The whole game is a series of similar missions: kill (neutralize) so many people. That's it!
Paid MMM advertising. It's just killing me. Only the Russians could pull off such crap. Remember, it was 2011, the game was just coming out, and Mavrodi was just getting his sect back together again... ah, Mavrodi appears in the game, even giving details of what he has and where he is in the sect for free. And he only appears for a few seconds, really. Like an advertising blog. Even though he's announced in all the credits. Suspicious, right?

[h1] Graphics[/h1]
Good:
The idea of ‚Äã‚Äãgrotesque (comical) depictions of people might have been a good one.

And not so good:
The graphics were outdated even at the time of release.

[h1] Technical [/h1]
The good:
The new DivJock allowed for more realistic movement, but let's be honest, that's thanks to the engine. You still need to learn how to use it, right?

The bad:
The game is clearly unoptimized and buggy. Only on an i7-6700K was it possible to get it to run at a decent frame rate in battles.

[h1] Sound and Music [/h1]
The good:
The music itself is good. Sometimes it even fits the madness playing on screen.

The voiceover by Courage Bombay might have been good.

The bad:
The sounds just don't work sometimes, and some sounds aren't implemented. Some glitchy, creak, and crackle at maximum volume.

The volume balance between music and sounds is off anywhere. It's disgusting to hear all of this.

[h1] Gameplay[/h1]
The good:
People explode into pieces more interestingly. These pieces splatter everything with a bit more blood than in previous games in the series.

The bad:
The game simply HAS NOT BEEN TESTED. Missions require real effort to complete, constantly monitoring whether your companion gets stuck in textures, because you'll lose or even lose them and be unable to complete the mission.

The world isn't open‚Äîthe game is essentially linear, down to the way missions are rearranged.

The animation is terrible.
The controls are terrible. It's almost impossible to play.
The vomiting isn't realistic, much worse than in previous games.

[h1] Overall Results[/h1]

column9: The game has a weak plot, so I do not recommend it.

Compared to Part 2, it's a disaster. The game is incredibly broken. It's not optimized. Sometimes it freezes in completely incomprehensible places (I'm running GTA V on very high settings). The missions are repetitive. The artificial intelligence is just crap. The graphics, for 2011, don't look any better than Part 2.

Get it at a very deep discount. You might have some fun, but it won't last long. It's a shame this happened to one of my favorite series...

It's fun. The graphics are better, and the blood looks more realistic.
But the downside is that there are a lot of bugs. In some quests, characters tend to stick to air walls, and the AI, despite being enemies, just walk past each other without shooting at each other. It's like they're friends.
I recommend buying it when it's 75% off or later.

column9:
I was introduced to Postal in 2009, after playing the first game at school and watching the Uwe Boll film. I can talk about the first Postal for ages; it's still my favorite game in the series (180 hours in the original game and 170 in the redux), and I can say that Uwe's Postal is the best film adaptation of the game. When I registered on Steam, I immediately got the first and second Postal for cheap, and in 2015 I got Postal 3 (it cost about 120 rubles, I think, or 140, it doesn't matter). Naturally, I was hesitant, especially knowing the criticism the game received, what kind of reviews it got, and how, for 140 rubles at the time, you could have gotten something cooler than some trash from our guys. And it's not surprising - Postal 3 was in really bad shape at the time, it kept crashing for me, the melee combat was annoying, and then there was that karma... Anyway, I forced myself to get the good ending the first time, then the bad ending again. It was unpleasant to play, but something kept me hooked. It was probably because it was built on the Source engine, and it had crappy humor that only a domestic gamer-turned-degenerate like me, who was giggling at terebonek or whatever was popular back then, would understand. And of course, the music in the game is truly top-notch, I'll give it a thumbs up in advance.

It's 2023 now, and from 2015 to 2022 I returned to this game occasionally, running through it in three hours for fun (since Postal 3 is very short), and I didn't forget the previous games. And every time, the Troika community found something new, like the third ending, the 2008-2009 builds. Mods appeared that almost brought the game to a stable state. I even remember there was a mod for the second, where Postal 3 was transferred to Postal 2. The million-dollar question is: if this game was so heavily criticized and even RWS themselves ignored it, there were fans who finally finished it, and now the game suddenly has mixed reviews instead of very negative ones? It's an open question.

Of course, compared to Postal 2, Postal 3 looks very funny and stupid. It's third-person, and again, the karma counter, terrible AI. The game is simply full of problems. But now I've completed Postal 3 for the first time with the mods that are in the Steam guides. And the game never crashed for me, I was comfortable using all the perks the developers came up with, and I had a blast with this political incorrectness that doesn't exist these days. I can now say that Postal 3 will be better than Postal 4 and Paradise Lost, because I don't even want to take those two games from the original developers seriously. It's funny that the Brain Damaged add-on is head and shoulders above those two knockoffs, yeah.

In short, Postal 3 is a very specific product, difficult to play due to the local peculiarities I mentioned above. But if you can overcome everything, don't be lazy and install mods that will make the game more comfortable, enter one console command to eliminate sound issues, or even better, install the original voice acting, although Bambey voiced the game very authentically (again, everything is at the top of the guides, see for yourself, it's all done in a minute), you'll get an extremely funny thing that can be completed in one sitting with a beer and will keep you coming back. Nowadays, these physics bugs, artificial intelligence (by the way, everything has become even better now, because when I played, the NPCs I needed to rescue were stupidly standing in place, and now they can at least walk normally) and terrible combat look very funny. But damn, this trashy plot with its grindhouse presentation, numerous allusions to black humor, the music, and the general anarchy of the game are now a joy. And it's even on sale for 40 rubles, lol, you guys are so lucky!

Just don't expect anything and you'll have a blast. It's by no means on the level of the masterpiece first game or the more or less decent second, but it's still a decent product that became a phenomenon thanks to modders and the recent update that brought the game back to Steam. So give it a try, especially since the game is very short; it'll take you a maximum of 5 hours to complete both the good and bad endings.

6/10

column9: The advantage is that there is no advantage at all

Postal III is a third-person shooter like its predecessors. It's developed using Valve's Source engine, which was first used in Half-Life 2.

A little about the game's plot and features:

The game's protagonist, the Dude, moves from Paradise City (because it was blown up) to the neighboring town of Catharsis. To make ends meet, the Dude trades jobs. Nothing has ever come easy for the Dude, and this time, he faces challenges from the police, eco-fanatics, and gay bikers. But there's always a choice: you can side with the law and clear the streets of bandits or fill them with blood again! The game also features a variety of unique bosses. Weapons abound, including badgers, sickles, pistols, and a variety of rifles. According to gamers and critics, the game was a failure. The city wasn't as big as it seemed, the plot was uninteresting, and the controls were awkward.
So, I don't recommend buying this game. :--)

column8:
[h1]Short Review[/h1]
Postal 3 is not a masterpiece and isn‚Äôt as good as the second one, but still enjoyable if you like the Postal series and don‚Äôt mind buggy gameplay and an occasional crash, consider buying the game on sale.
[b]Overall Score:[/b] 62/100

[h1]Extensive Review[/h1]
Right off the bat, I love the Postal games for being violent, funny and because the Postal Dude is an epic protagonist. If you loved Postal 2 and want more, Postal 3 is probably right for you. It is by far not as good or as bug-free, but entertaining none the less. Get it when it is on sale, because it sadly isn‚Äôt worth the 20$ they want. I got it on sale and regret nothing.

[b]Campaign & Story[/b]
It is a lot shorter than Postal 2 but instead offers different branches based on your actions during missions. This means you can replay the game a good 3 times and will have new content or at least a different story. The narrator and characters are funny, and the dialogue fits the Postal series nicely. The cutscenes have an annoying film grain, but are still funny. The story is not meant to be taken seriously and progresses nicely. But let‚Äôs face it, we play Postal to kill people and not to evaluate the Dude‚Äôs life choices.

[b]Graphics & Performance[/b]
Here is where the game is weak. Many others report crashes, poor frame rates and bugs. I experienced that as well, but if you are patient (not mashing your mouse when the game freezes for a sec) and change the settings to suit your system you should be fine. I did not run the game at ultra settings because programming wise it is not optimized and sometimes the animations are poorly integrated. Movement controls and aiming are not ideal, and some maps or many enemies might lag at times. Loading screens are long, but that might just be my rig. All these performance issues [i]DO NOT[/i] take away from the game being fun and enjoyable. If you are willing to live with some issues you can still have a blast with Postal 3. It ran fairly well and smooth for me for the most part.

[b]Gameplay and Experience[/b]
The gameplay is okay and you get used to it not being great quickly. Movement and looking work fine, and the NPCs are responsive (not as good as Postal 2, but still fun to kill). They used some similar voice actors or audio files and many references are made to the previous game. There are plenty of weapons to choose from, including a freaking badger and angry bees. You can urinate, incinerate people, and ride a segway. Overall it is fun and the gore is nice as well. It is different from Postal 2, and if you keep in mind that essentially a team of fans made this with the source engine, any ‚Äúdisappointments‚Äù won‚Äôt bother you. The achievements are bugged, but you can get a good 70%.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
If you love the Postal series and this game is on sale, go get it. It is fun, silly and amusing for a piece of garbage. If you can look past some performance issues, this game is great! Seriously, I enjoyed every minute of it but get it on sale. If you don‚Äôt like it then it‚Äôs 5$ gone and not 20$. I highly recommend it to Postal fans. I regret nothing!

column9: The worst game in the thrilogy of POSTAL ! It is full of bugs and wrong optimized , please DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY !

It lags in some places, but the game cost me 109 rubles :3.
I really liked the voice acting, music, and characters.
People are dumb and don't know what will happen if you beat the game‚Äîof course, everyone will discover an interesting OPEN WORLD!
Complaining about lag? Solution: Set Anti-Aliasing to 2 or 4 (not recommended on computers since those days), disable it using the PsyhX fix. In the autoexec files, set shadows to 0, and ragdolls to 0 or 1. 60FPS was still limited for me.
- Cons: During the boss fight (Uwe Chavez), the game crashes when climbing up. NPCs are slow.
Okay, I'll give it a 6.9/10. Oddly enough, they love the game in America. I've never seen a video about Postal III from Americans, but it got a lot of likes and good reviews. Maybe it's all because of the Russian version. For some reason, Americans haven't had crashes or glitches with sound or NPCs while playing.
Maybe they shoved some crap into the Russian version, which is causing the lag, the NPCs are slow, the voice acting is terrible. Type snd_rebuildsoundcache in the console, and the game will crash, and you have to go back and that's it! Profit.
Disable HDR, enable motion sharpness, and type r_3dsky 0 in the console. That's all I can add.

column8: I had a bit of fun with Postal 2 back in the day so when Portal 3 promised me a honey badger as a weapon and a better camera for the game I threw my money at this once it was on sale. As I purchased and installed this game I found the free roaming atmosphere that left the world open in the previous game where choice was key to story progression had been replaced with a small linear map that pushed obnoxious cutscenes in our face with a voiceover that screams "I'm trying to sound like Duke Nukem." The worst part is that this game actually gave me herpes. As I played this game I found that my fingers started breaking out in blemishes which then spread to my arms. Before anything could spread further the honey badger jumped out of the screen and ripped out my jugular. With my last breath I write this review. Please tell my family I'm sorry I bought this game.

HA HA HA OHHH HOW FUNNY! OH MAN! I TOTALLY LIKE THAT GAME!
60% OF POSTAL 2 DEFINITELY WASN'T STOLEN AND MASHED INTO A DISGUSTING MESS! NO, NO! EVERYTHING IS FLAWLESS!!!!111

Thanks Uwe....
Postal 3 couldn't exist without Postal 2. It starts with the annoying intro, which spends 5 minutes explaining what happened in Postal 2. Then 2 seconds of gameplay, then a cutscene, then 2 seconds of gameplay, then a cutscene. The use of poorly sourced and selected music is also great. Postal 2 probably had a homemade soundtrack that emphasized the atmosphere. Morbid, dark, but also fucking funny. The songs don't even loop properly. If Postal 2 has bloody sputum with pus, then that's Postal 3. I see this part as something independent and don't want this game to be associated with Postal 2. In my opinion, it would have been a good greenlight/pre-alpha title with a season pass. So you're surprised that pirated copies are taking over...?

Somehow, it's not what it used to be...
The nice Postal 2 feeling just doesn't come back after 2 hours.

Sure, being evil is cool, and killing is fun, but that's about it.

- A bit too many cutscenes
- Story is so-so
- Performance issues

+ New weapons
+ New enemies
+ Soundtrack
+ Controls
+ Making decisions
+ Achievements
+ Characters
+ Well-known characters like "Cesar Millan / The Dog Whisperer" appear, etc.

Sure, there are some positive aspects, but it's just no longer fun to progress in the game, despite some original ideas. It's all about completing jobs and making money.

The game is only interesting up to ‚Ç¨5 if you just want to slaughter.

column8:
I previously had a positive review, because I somehow played through the first time with no crashes until the final boss. Now I can't even finish the first level without crashes in the gasoline tutorial

Just play Postal 2.

[h1]Pros[/h1]


[*] Looks pretty

[*] Shooting is very precise

[*] Blood and gore

[*] Corey Cruise's new performance as The Dude steals the show. He does it way to well

[*] Consistent with the previous game.

[*] Level editor that almost no one uses



[h1]

Cons

[/h1]

[*] Crashes in many areas

[*] Sourse engine limitations. Very small areas, and areas with a lot of NPCs lag like hell

[*] By default, set to run on "-2" CPU cores due to a misprint (Source seems to autocorrect it to 1). Due to this, everything runs on a single core, and it runs like shit

[*] Jenn Walcott's performance is horrible, and was obviously recorded in the early 2000s due to poor audio quality. Her model also looks nothing like her, oddly enough.

[*] Melee weapons don't work right

[*] Fire doesn't work right most of the time

[*] No jumping or crouching

[*] No lip sync for The Postal Dude.

[*] Broken achievements. This game will never be 100% finished for achievement hunters.

column8:
I loved Postal 2. I read plenty of reviews of Postal III and saw enough coverage of the development hell involved in producing it. For some reason I figured that I might somehow be able to get something out of this game. But there are so many critical and fundamental issues with Postal III that I cannot even find solace in the arcs of urine and vomit. 

More video intro (which is just in-game footage with a filter) than gameplay in the first 30 minutes or so. Fundamental sound issues. AWFUL dialogue, and not in the cheeky Postal 2 way - lots of it is just directly copied from 2. Giant walls of text explaining the mundane tasks you need to accomplish. Melee weapons are largely useless as characters seems to slide past each other like they're greased. The animations and models seem like they simply put higher res textures on the models from Postal 2. Social commentary that would make a Che Guevara t-shirt seem well considered. In an era where open world modes are needlessly crammed into every game going, Postal III somehow manages to remove the open world of the second game. 

Not even if it's on sale.

Niestety mimo ≈õwietnych pomys≈Ç√≥w bronie te czƒôsto siƒô nie sprawdzajƒÖ, w zasadzie to najlepiej jest przej≈õƒá grƒô u≈ºywajƒÖc tylko pistoletu czy M16. Ale nie kupujcie tr√≥jki. Szkoda ≈ºe tak wysz≈Ço, przeczesa≈Çem troche internetu ≈ºeby popatrzeƒá jak siƒô prezentowa≈Ça ta gra przed premierƒÖ kiedy nale≈ºa≈Ça jeszcze do RWS i c√≥≈º.. Wszystkie te zabawne bronie oni wymy≈õlili, mapa mia≈Ça byƒá wiƒôsza ni≈º w dw√≥jce i mia≈Ç byƒá w pe≈Çni otwarty ≈õwiat, mia≈Ç byƒá zrobiony multiplayer a sama gra mia≈Ça wyj≈õƒá tak≈ºe na Xbox 360 i PS3. Gdyby nie ci ruscy :(. Postal 3 zas≈Çuguje na 4/10
column9: One word... "Why?" Postal III had so much potential. If this game had been developed throughout its entire development by the studio Running With Scissors, and not some Russian company called TrashMasters, it would probably have been really good. It could have been better than the second one! Especially since it runs on a much better engine than its predecessor (the Source engine known from Half-Life 2). But that's not the case. Postal III is inferior to Postal 2 in basically every way... yes, every way! The second one was better: the story and the game world, the gameplay was better, the weapons were better, and even the optimization (WHICH IS STRANGE, BECAUSE THE 3RD RUNS ON A BETTER ENGINE). And I even have the impression that the graphics in the second one were better... But let's start from the beginning: In the game, we once again play as the Dude, and the game takes place after the events of the second expansion pack, "Apocalypse Weekend." As we know at the end of that expansion, a nuclear bomb explodes in Paradise, and the guy and his dog, Champ, flee this beautiful town. The guy ends up in the neighboring city of Catharsis, and our task is simply to find a job. What's wrong with the plot? Well, first of all, the guy himself. He's changed beyond recognition, even though the game takes place immediately after the events of the expansion! But not only has his appearance changed, the voice actor has changed as well, and I don't know about you, but I liked the voice actor much better. Even the guy's personality has changed! Now he's not a sociopath who's irritated by the stupidity of the world around him; he's a prankster sociopath. The plot itself is completely pointless at many points (warning: parenthetical spoiler, but so what: At one point in the game we find our dog Champ back, who happily attacked a homeless man and started biting his, uh, Krotchy (If you know what I mean), at the same time a policewoman comes to us and says it's wrong, we end up in court and they take our dog away... couldn't the guy just kill her or run away? He didn't have to politely go to court with that policewoman...) and there are quite a few such situations... But a good plot has never been the most important thing in Postal. How is the gameplay? In a word, it's poor: Melee combat very often doesn't work, it's just very hard to hit anything with anything! Firearms would be okay if it weren't for that damn bouncing crosshair! Throwing weapons work well, surprisingly, there's a quite pleasant and simple aiming system for grenades and the like. It's a shame the combat has been ruined, because the arsenal itself looks fantastic: Besides returning classics like the Shovel, M16, Machete, Molotov Cocktail, and Gas Can, we also have many new, brilliantly designed weapons that fit the Postal setting, such as the Badger, which we can use to set passersby off, the Bee Hive, which works a bit like a grenade, a modified vacuum cleaner that we can use to suck up objects and then shoot them, the Interactive Monkey, and the Krotchy bomb. Unfortunately, despite their brilliant ideas, these weapons often fail to deliver. In fact, it's best to play through the game using only a pistol or M16. And the enemies are complete idiots: sometimes they don't even notice us, often starting shooting after about four seconds of looking. Remember how in Postal 2, despite the tasks we were given at the beginning of the day, we could explore this beautiful town, peeking into houses, murdering passersby, and searching for better equipment? Well, this is completely different. The main storyline automatically carries us from mission to mission... But hey! After all, after the game, we have Free Roam! So what? Where's the fun in this game when the map is tiny, we can only enter two or three houses, and we can forget about fun exploration because we're given all the weapons at the beginning, the pedestrians are idiots, like the police who don't even look for us if we do something wrong, and there's no map to see where we are... The graphics are pretty average. I quite like the street and building designs, but the character models and special effects... yuck. The new voice acting, while worse than the previous one, works quite well... better than all the other character voice acting, which is rather poorly chosen. The sound effects themselves are okay. The music is pretty good, especially the main theme, which I liked. The soundtrack is probably the only thing that's done completely well here. Despite being a bad game, it can be a bit entertaining at times, but only at times. If you're planning to buy Postal 2, BUY it. It's the best part. If you want more, buy the expansion for Postal 2. If you want even more, buy Postal 1 because it's not just bad, it's old. But don't buy Postal 3. It's a shame it turned out this way. I scoured the internet to see what the game looked like before its release, when it was still part of the RWS franchise, and well... they invented all those funny weapons, the map was supposed to be bigger than in Postal 2, it was supposed to be fully open world, there was supposed to be multiplayer, and the game itself was supposed to be released on Xbox 360 and PS3. If it weren't for those Russians :(. Postal 3 deserves a 4/10.

column8: I have played postal 1 and postal 2 with the 1337 patch a long long time ago (to make it work properly on really old systems) and i have postal 2 on steam now, so essentially i have paid to that game twice now, actually 3 times as i bought it off rws website quite a few years ago as a digital download (non steam related). To be honest i dont mind as its a great game to play and still makes me laugh (good on ya running with scissors). However, i am a PC owner and a FPS player and i am a very dissapointed that this latest incarnation has turned into a TPS and appears to be a port from a console game. Not a happy bunny RWS, i should have taken on board what some of the others had said.

column8:
Holy Fuck this is bad.

I mean I heard it was bad. And the last two games were bad games in their own ways as well. [NOTE: I am not talking about offensive content I am really talking about the quality of the games]. Postal 1 was an absolute mess, and a violent, attention whoring relic of early PC gaming, and Postal 2 was a short, glitchy, grotesque, and insanly racist piece of FPS history...

But this is more glitchy than it's predecessor, it lacks the "charm" the previous game had, and it's not a sandbox! It's a poorly made 3rd person coverbased shooter that goes from bad cutscenes to bad gameplay back to bad cutscenes. THERE IS A FORCED TUTORIAL MISSION AT THE BEGINING CALLED "CROSS THE BRIDGE" OR SOME SHIT AND YOU MOSTLY CROSS THE BRIDGE IN FUCKING CUTSCENES!!!

Bottom line the Postal series is a game set in a shared universe that is full of crude, immature shock comedy... and that isn't a bad thing. Frankly, I'm nostalgiaic over the first one. I played it a lot as a kid and at the time I took the whole thing as a big joke meant to offend people (which a great portion of it reall is just that), and my cousin played it, I shared it with all my friends back when I had the physical copy... It's the worlds wierdest "kids" game lol. BUT Postal 3 has horrible UI, hit detection, level design, has the worst graphics of a Source powered game that I've ever scene... Get Postal 2: Paradise Lost and the Workshop MODs. FUCK Postal III!

[h1]I fucked a cat, then got shot for no apparent reason, and then the whole city was slaughtered.[/h1]
Postal 2 called it a classic, and I've been looking forward to Postal 3 ever since.
In 2011, I downloaded the first version with the "Three Aunts" voiceover and finished both the good and evil routes in two days.
It cured my depression.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Last night, I got sick and downloaded this garbage.
I didn't expect the legitimate version to have more problems than the pirated version.
First, you can't switch screens in full screen, otherwise it becomes unresponsive.
You can't use Impulse 101 on the console because it freezes.
It freezes for no reason during missions.
After playing the Steam version for two hours, my summary is:
[b]Crash, crash, crash, crash.[/b]
-----------------------------------------------------------
Putting the crashes aside, the graphics quality is pretty good right now. After all, the 2007 Origin engine, which is always considered a highly optimized engine,... It's just optimization.
You get stuck when enemies shoot, when you run, and when you kill someone. It's a constant 10 FPS when there are too many corpses.
That's called optimization.
----------------------------------------------------------
The frame rate of this slideshow isn't a big deal; you'll get used to it.
But the facial expressions of the NPCs in the cutscenes are like they just lost their mother. They're frozen, and then there's a few lines of text.
The cutscenes aren't even as good as the game itself.
----------------------------------------------------------
With cutscenes like this, you can imagine what the in-game AI will be like. Yeah. It's all just idiotic. There's no AI at all. For example, sometimes enemies look at you like you're a rare species. It's basically just mindlessly guiding you to kill.
----------------------------------------------------------
If the AI ‚Äã‚Äãis completely retarded, can you just mindlessly kill? You forgot the slideshow-like framerate.
So if you want to vent a little, you have to use the console. "God giveall giveallammo" (likely a game or game title). Otherwise, you deserve to be killed.
-----------------------------------------------------------
The game is so bad, so what about the soundtrack? I personally think the main menu music is the most engaging. I won't comment on anything else.
The sound effects are mostly from Heroes II. So lazy.
-----------------------------------------------------------
The loading system is also inherited, loading each scene once. There's nothing much to criticize about that.
What else can I criticize? It's [b]Akella[/b]
No matter how bad RWS games are, they can't be this idiotic. There were eight years between the second and third games. Only Akella could achieve this. So, Akella was outsourced.

Now I can only look forward to RWS's postal: redux.
-----------------
This is my 100th review, and it's worth choosing such a crappy game that I played through thoroughly.
But my depression still hasn't been cured...

I, like most, was a big fan of Postal 2 and with great excitment fired up Postal 3 only to be let down. It is much more linear with two distinct paths that clearly are meant to be played in order; I clearly choose the "wrong" way first leading to a confusing ending that was cleared up after playing through differently the second time. Poor combat, a phoney open world, a horrendous amount of bugs and a sound track that gets annoying in a hurry leads me back to playing Postal 2 and wishing I never made this purchase.

-Hist√≥ria podre, oque era Postal 1 e 2 agora ficou "politicamente correto", mas tu escolhe tentar ser dos 2 lados (bem e mal)
-Mesmo com a Engine Source tem v√°rios bugs 
-Liberdade?Ta no seu cu, o mapa da cidade √© desbloqueado por completo quando tu zera o jogo, e tu entra em quase qualquer lugar do jogo, mas s√≥ depois de tu zerar que √© a√≠ que tu ta de saco cheio do jogo

-Essa hist√≥ria faz sentido?Eu preferia quando o Postal Dude saia na rua matando todo mundo, ou ele tentando viver a vida normal dele e acontecendo um monte de putaria e ele tinha que matar todo mundo, nem sei que tipo de maconha estragada esses caras fumaram pra fazer a hist√≥ria. -No Postal 2 era perfeito (ta nem tanto), tu era preso e tu podia fazer um esquema pra escapar da pris√£o, tu podia se disfar√ßar como policial, tinha aquela roupa que mostrava a sua bunda e tu parecia um... sei la que porra era aquela s√≥ vestia aquilo por causa das luvas, tinha cenar√≠os pra explorar e MODS, aqui n√£o, tu s√≥ tem que prosseguir com a hist√≥ria chata e pegar armas conforme tu vai prosseguindo o jogo, e tu n√£o pode vestir porra de roupa nenhuma

column9:
+More violence
+"Better" graphics than the previous one
+More weapons
+Source Engine, the same engine as HL2 or Portal 2
+Postal Dude with racier jokes than ever
-----------------------------
-Rotten story, what was Postal 1 and 2 is now "politically correct", but you choose to try to be on both sides (good and evil)
-Even with the Source Engine, there are several bugs
-Freedom? It's up your ass, the city map is fully unlocked when you beat the game, and you can enter almost anywhere in the game, but only after you beat it is when you get fed up with the game
-Why the fuck do fat people fall to the ground like paper? -Does this story make sense? I preferred it when Postal Dude went out on the street killing everyone, or when he was trying to live his normal life and a lot of shit happened and he had to kill everyone, I don't even know what kind of bad weed these guys smoked to make the story. And damn, what a hell having to side with good. You have to use that shitty, annoying stun gun that's not even thrilling to use. I'd rather side with the bad guys anyway.
- In Postal 2, it was perfect (not so much). You were arrested and could make a scheme to escape prison. You could disguise yourself as a cop. There was that outfit that showed your ass and you looked like... I don't know what the fuck that was. You only wore that because of the gloves. There were scenarios to explore and MODS, but not here. You just have to continue with the boring story and pick up weapons as you go along, and you can't wear any fucking clothes.
- There were several scenarios to explore (again, saying that) in Postal 2, and the map expanded as you progressed. My favorite stage was that circus or whatever, where your mother... I mean, an elephant was chasing you.
- Seriously, this game was developed by the same company that created Postal 2? Like Seriously, man?

Buy this game if you're a REAL fan of the Postal series, but I'll warn you right now that this game is really bad, it doesn't even have multiplayer, it deserves a really good 2/10.

Weil Postal 2 bis heute zu meinen Lieblingsspielen geh√∂rt und es meine Pflicht als Fan war.

column9:
The game is a complete waste of time. I finished it in 8 hours, and somehow you feel like you didn't get anything out of it.
Why did I play it until the end of the story?
Because Postal 2 is still one of my favorite games, and it was my duty as a fan.
So please think twice about getting it.
And if you still don't know what to do, watch some YouTube videos about the game.

Don't know what to say about POSTAL 3.The story is ok...A pretty good soundtrack but the gameplay sux and is very repetitive:
Pros:
-Good story
-Has some funny moments
-You get to play as a cop XDDD
Cons:
-Full of bugs
-Few weapons
-Melee weapons are horrible in this game
-Very repetitive
-Some achievements won't unlock
-Poor AI;
I would only recommend this game if you are a hardcore fan of the postal series.On the other hand this game wasn't taken seriously by the game devs. they just thrown some shit togheter and called it Postal 3.But in the end it's not that bad if you manage to spent some time in it,don't forget it was made with Source Engine and has his good parts.In my opinion I'll give a 5.5/10.

column8:
First impressions so far.

I downloaded the game. (wish I hadn't).
Clicked Play. I saw a picture of Uve Boll sticking his finger up at me, The game then crashed. Yep, that's basically my expectations for the rest of the game. I then started the tutuorial and was told to ingite some zombies. INGITE. (That's not my spelling mistake, that's exactly how it was spelt and what the game told me to do.

They've also slaughtered the Source engine, it's no wonder we don't have Half-Life 3. Valve had to make another engine after this game was released.

Also, for those of you that like your Source console commands and your Postal experience in 1st person mode. You get to eat dick because typing firstperson into the console tells you that the game is already in first person. (even though the whole game takes place in 3rd person). Entering thirdperson makes the camera aim straight at the floor. So instead of using the default 3rd person mode that Source uses they've decided to use the first person mode and pull the camera back, for some reason. 

I was also told not to press a button, so I'm not whilst I currently wait for the game to progress. After I spent waiting the game started to insult me for doing exactly what it told me to do. 

The people that made this game should kill themselves. I'm not joking. They've made a mess of the Source engine and a mess of the Postal series.

column9: It could have been better

A product from a domestic manufacturer.
‚Äî What is Russian business? ‚Äî Steal a case of vodka, sell the vodka, and drink the money away.

Quotes from Wikipedia and Lurk:

-Many of the developers' promises were never fulfilled.
-The game was a flop and received negative reviews from both domestic and international sites. The failure was so severe that RWS even canceled the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, and Mac versions of the game, and even called the game a spin-off and non-canon.
-The Steam version of Postal 2 contains an Easter egg: you can find a copy of Postal III in the bushes at the junkyard and urinate on it, which awards an achievement.
- The theme of Postal III is touched upon in the canonical Postal III replacement, the Postal 2 expansion Paradise Lost, in which the Dude, at the very beginning, gets into a car accident, which causes him to fall into a coma for 11 years and sees a "dark future" in the form of Postal III.
- The feeling that the game was made by a group of schoolchildren with a passion for programming lingers until the very end.

- The Arizonans from RWS, noticing player reactions and receiving thousands of angry emails, fearing for their reputation, decide to try out the final product and are speechless. Seeing the brainchild of domestic developers under their own brand, they demand that Akella hand over the rights to Postal 3 so they can remake it and continue releasing patches, as the fans' attention is more important to them than to Akella. But Akella's bosses not only don't want to hand over the rights to the third game, they're also claiming all the rights to the series for themselves, churning out "Postal vs. Mukhtar," "Shtopor ZHZhot 2," and Postal 4, and making a tidy profit from them. They couldn't care less that the series itself would deteriorate into crap, after all, Russian business is Russian, and money can be made from mega-crap games based on mega-crap movies (like "Shadowboxing," for example). RWS, stunned by this scenario, gave Akella the cold shoulder, saying this in a statement:

Let Akella suck our dick if she wants the rights to Postal so badly; let her head straight to court!!!

At this point, TrashMasters has been shut down, and further development of patches and other games has been permanently suspended. The game's website has also been shut down, and the Russian fan community has migrated to Western forums. The war between RWS and Akella is over ‚Äì Postal 3 has been declared non-canon, and all ties with Akella have been severed.

Draw your conclusions.

Let's break it down into pros and cons.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Dude looks cooler üòé
[*]The graphics are better thanks to the Source engine ‚ú®
[*]Still have the usual naughty jokes, like [spoiler]C·µâ‚ÅøÀ¢·µí ≥·µâD[/spoiler] üîû
[*]There are new weapons, like an electric taser, a light machine gun, a fart gun, a laser pointer, pepper spray, and catnip spray. Vacuum cleaner, beehive, monkey assistant, badger saw üî´
[*]Choose whether to be good or evil üòáüòà
[*]Regenerates health ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

column9:
Postal 3 is a third-person shooter released in 2011. Because the third installment wasn't developed by the original team, Running With Scissors, but rather licensed to the little-known Russian studio Trashmasters, the game's quality was shoddy, making it a dark spot in the Postal series' history. When discussing Postal, one must mention its success. Touted as even more violent and gory than Grand Thief Auto, the game was banned in over 20 countries worldwide (including Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau, China, and Japan). As the saying goes, "where there's a demand, there's a market," and while brutal violence is a common selling point, Postal 3 unfortunately fails to deliver the pure thrill of carnage. Numerous bugs, awkward body movements, unfunny jokes, and a focus on story-driven gameplay rather than free exploration all contributed to its failure.

Despite using Valve's Source engine (the same engine used to power such renowned titles as Half-Life 2, DOTA 2, and Counter-Strike: Global Offensive), Postal 3's optimization remains exceptionally poor. The frame rate drops significantly when three or more non-player characters are present, and the splattering of corpses upon death often causes screen freezes. Computers scream in agony, as if attacked by mainland Chinese spyware. I can't help but wonder if the development team didn't test the game beforehand, or perhaps even skipped the optimization steps. Players who end up burning out their hardware deserve the consequences. I've heard that even the best computers can't run this dreadful game smoothly, even at the lowest graphics settings.

The gameplay is abysmal. I generally don't take parody-oriented titles seriously, but this one simply treats players like idiots. Not only does it abandon the free exploration that made the previous game so popular, but it also shifts the levels to a linear, one-track path with absolutely no freedom. The missions offered are also largely the same, usually just killing a group of people or escorting a target. This lack of variety makes it easy to get bored. Even more frightening is the omnipresence of game bugs: quest items disappear, targets get stuck, doors can't be opened to trigger plots, the program crashes, the screen is broken, and save files are lost. It's no surprise that Metacritic gave this game a 24.

In short, "Postal 3" is a hopelessly poor game. Not only does the game itself lack content, but even basic optimization and bug fixes are missing. Without the free exploration feature, it becomes a shoddy game with no real highlights. Its overall quality not only fails to compare to other games of the same genre, but even most independent games on the market easily outperform it. While its graphics far surpass those of the original Postal 2, released twelve years ago, the gameplay is a world apart; Postal 3 can't even begin to compare to the original. I can't recommend this game to any fans of the "Postal" series. Unless you're looking for a painful, butt-wrenching experience, don't buy it.

Pros:
+ I can't find any positives. Too much pain for too little gain. Avoid this game if you're lucky.

Cons:
- Poor optimization. The frame rate drops when too many people are on screen.
- Excessively buggy. It's irresponsible to release this game without debugging. -Yoneta Ko, who trashed the Source engine, inevitably drew the wrath of Gabe Newell.

Conclusion: I suggest you save a day's living expenses, buy a beer and some chicken skewers, and enjoy life!

Easy-to-read blog post with pictures and text:

[h1]Postal 3[/h1] A wonderful example of what happens when you entrust a game to the idiots at Akella. I can't understand why RWS didn't make the game themselves, but essentially handed it over to be slaughtered.
[h1]Cons[/h1] 
[list]
[*][b]Third-person view[/b] - I think Postal 3 would have looked much better in first person, but no, Akella decided to go their own way. You simply won't be able to hit it in the face with your fist.
[*][b]Voice acting[/b] - not only is it monotonous, but during conversations a cacophony of sounds begins: hissing, creaking, distorted sound, white noise‚Äîin short, it's really annoying. [*][b]Mavrodi[/b] - Yeah, they added this clown to the game to promote his new scam, "MMM-2012." Maybe I'm exaggerating, but I don't see any other reason. Remember the 90s, when Mavrodi screwed half of Russia? It could happen again, after all, a sucker isn't a mammoth.
[*][b]Crap weapon[/b] - Don't even think about using anything other than a firearm. While you're aiming a pointer, hoping Champ will bite off your enemy's balls, you'll already be sliced ‚Äã‚Äãup.
[*][b]Stupid AI[/b] - An enemy is running up to you, do you think he'll shoot at you? No, he'll just stand there and stare at the walls in this game...
[/list]
[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Music[/b] - The music is surprisingly good (except for that lullaby on the bridge at the beginning of the game).
[/list]

Overall, I STRONGLY don't recommend playing this; the game is simply ruined. By the way, Akella wanted to take the rights to the series from RWS. Cool, right?
[h1]1 Mavrodi out of 10[/h1]

column9: The second level crashes

Postal III

A sequel to the legendary, brilliant, and best game, Postal 2. The second game caused a stir in its day, featuring vulgarity, blood, violence, cruelty, mockery of various cultures, dark humor, the Dude's raunchy remarks, dismemberment in all its glory, and endless ways to kill. Postal 2 was considered the benchmark among open-world, first-person games.

It's back in 2003. Postal 2 was released, where we, in the shoes of a certain Dude, complete various tasks, living out another day in a godforsaken place, the city of Paradise (ironically, Paradise). We have an open world, a multitude of weapons, useful items, and complete freedom of action. No one forces you to stand in line for milk, steal and run, or stand and endure the slow and stupid shoppers in front of you. The varied missions were always a joy (signing for permission to play violent games, urinating on your father's grave, confessing, buying meat, paying fines and receiving packages, etc.). You were free to roam and kill, run from the cops, or even escape from prison, BUT this review is for the third game, not the second.

POSTAL has changed!!! New city, new look, new voice. The humor is still top-notch, and the Dude's quotes are quoted by players. In the eyes of underage gamers, withdrawn misanthropes, sociopaths, and people with mental disorders, he's a hero, an idol, a role model (and I was one of them, take your pick). The core of the game hasn't changed 10 years later (it was released in 2013). You're the reckless Dude, capable of carrying a ton of weapons, killing anything that moves, and getting away with it. Follow the path of good or evil, or be a complete asshole, slaughtering everyone left and right, even those who are temporarily your allies.

Pros:
- Third-person view, now you can see the guy, what he's wearing, how he acts, the blood on his face when he's being hit with a machine gun.
- Weapon selection has become much more convenient, each weapon now has its own key. Say "stupid," and you're right. Of course, a weapon selection system, like in Assassin's Creed Brotherhood or Saints Row III, would be more convenient, but it's still cool.
- Lots of new weapons: Champa's Laser Pointer, Mad Badger, Horny Monkey, Bee Grenade, M-60 Machine Gun, Fire Axe, Taser, and those are just the ones I remembered.
- There are branching plot points, which is cool. You can be good or evil; choose one path, and by playing to the end, you'll see a completely different outcome, missions, and paths. The game has three endings, but I personally experienced two. Oh yeah, choosing your behavior doesn't mean it's forever. Change as you go. Tired of being good? Kill everyone, embrace madness, and vice versa.
- The story is average, but the game is enjoyable, watching the cutscenes voiced by Courage; those who know will understand.
- Convenient shooting: use cover, aim for heads by zooming in on them, throwing grenades has become better (aim, choose a trajectory, throw, or lay them like a mine).
- Some kind of transport, a Segway, but you'll have the opportunity to ride around the city on two wheels instead of two legs.
- Run! You can dash, knocking enemies, rivals, and passersby to their knees, and shoot them when the opportunity arises.
- Humor! Lots of references, Osama, Sergey Panteleevich (We Can Do Much), Postal Babes, and others.

So far, that's all I can remember while playing.

Cons (of course, they're a must-have):
- Poor controls when using melee weapons (Badger doesn't care)
- Dude forgot how to jump and crouch, and this game really needs it, in maneuvers and fights.
- Bad kick animation; they'd be better off with a knockback, which is present when an enemy is too close.
- The machete-boomerang has become a terrible weapon, not like before: you crouch, chop off their legs, and watch them suffer and crawl away.
- There were crashes, for no apparent reason, and the game sometimes lags at the beginning after a cutscene.
- Health now regenerates, which always annoyed me. - Useful items (locator, food, money, health bar, armor, and other items from the second part) were removed.

So far, that's all I can remember and see.

But the game will still find its players, fans, and haters alike. But when did Postal ever give a shit about all that?

Be mad and enraged, kill and enjoy, because where else but Postal can you do that? (Purely rhetorical question.)

10 Dudes with Champs out of 10
